summary: Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) and Mia (Emma Stone) are drawn together by their common desire to do what they love. But as success mounts they are faced with decisions that begin to fray the fragile fabric of their love affair, and the dreams they worked so hard to maintain in each other threaten to rip them apart.

"La La Land" is a romantic musical drama released in 2016, written and directed by Damien Chazelle. The movie stars Ryan Gosling as Sebastian, a jazz pianist, and Emma Stone as Mia, an aspiring actress. The film follows their love story and their struggle to pursue their dreams in Hollywood.

One of the strongest aspects of "La La Land" is the stunning cinematography and the mesmerizing musical numbers. The film's use of bright colors, dynamic camera movements, and creative lighting create a dreamy and immersive atmosphere that transports the audience into the world of the film. The musical numbers are beautifully choreographed and performed, and the songs are catchy and memorable.

The acting is also a highlight of the movie, with Gosling and Stone delivering strong performances that showcase their chemistry and emotional range. Both actors bring depth and nuance to their characters, and their portrayal of the ups and downs of a romantic relationship is both believable and moving.

The direction by Damien Chazelle is also noteworthy. He masterfully weaves together the different elements of the film, from the musical numbers to the character development, creating a cohesive and engaging narrative. The pacing of the film is excellent, with each scene flowing seamlessly into the next.

However, one of the criticisms of "La La Land" is its portrayal of jazz and its historical context. Some critics have argued that the film oversimplifies the genre and fails to recognize the contributions of African American musicians to its development. Additionally, some viewers may find the ending of the film bittersweet and disappointing.

Overall, "La La Land" is a visually stunning and emotionally powerful musical romance that showcases the talents of its cast and crew. While it may not be without its flaws, the film is a triumph of modern filmmaking that is sure to captivate audiences with its beautiful music, impressive visuals, and heartfelt story.

It took me awhile to understand the premise, and once I started to get it, it took a turn I was not ready for. The acting is good and the songs are catchy, but the structure and storytelling were all over the place.

Damien Chazelle's Oscar-winning musical 'La La Land' is a colourful story that follows aspiring performers as they embark on a whirlwind journey navigating their careers in bustling Los Angeles. The film brings together both classic Hollywood and modern surroundings in an appealing blend of visual styles.

Emma Stone stars as Mia Dolan, a struggling actress who spends her time working in a coffee shop and booking unsuccessful auditions. When Mia meets jazz enthusiast and aspiring club owner Sebastian Wilder (Ryan Gosling), the two quickly begin a passionate romance. But when the pursuit of their dreams begins to tug at their relationship, they must choose between their once-in-a-lifetime romance or their dream careers.

Coming off the success of his 2014 drama 'Whiplash', Damien Chazelle takes a more colourful spin in the director's chair as he gives viewers a magical story fuelled by aspiration and sacrifice. Set against a modern-day Los Angeles backdrop, Chazelle brings these two characters to life in a bold, passionate experience that is a visual feast. The 128-minute runtime allows Stone and Gosling to take viewers on a touching journey that features vivid cinematography and extravagant musical numbers. Chazelle's unique directing style is evident throughout, with smooth, uninterrupted takes being scattered across the film.

When the 2017 Academy Awards rolled around, it was no surprise that 'La La Land' would be the most colourful nomination out of the nominees. The lighting and costume design give the film a polychromatic look that appeals to viewers of all ages. As well as incorporating older filmmaking techniques, Chazelle draws inspiration from classic films like 'The Young Girls of Rochefort' and 'Singin' in the Rain' - all of which feature outdoor dances. Despite being taken along on the loved up journey between Sebastian and Mia, viewers can't help but feel distanced from the characters. The lack of backstory prevents viewers from being able to form a close attachment to these characters.

Themes like following your dreams and dreams vs reality seem to be at the forefront of 'La La Land'. Repetitive shots and circular narratives show Sebastian and Mia's journey across the film, even the film's locations plays into the film's morals. Although Los Angeles may be the 'city of dreams', to achieve your aspirations you may still have to make sacrifices. The film leaves its ending up to interpretation, whilst on one hand, you can see the true ending, a homage to the perfect Hollywood ending, or you can see it as a look into what could've been in store for Sebastian and Mia.

Despite Gosling and Stone giving sensational performances, believe it or not, neither were the original choices for their respective roles. Gosling's role was supposed to be played by Miles Teller, who previously worked with Chazelle in 'Whiplash'. Stone's role was originally filled by Emma Watson, who, due to scheduling conflicts, had to drop out. Fans of both Gosling and Stone can watch the pair in the 2011 rom-com 'Crazy, Stupid, Love', and the 2013 thriller 'Gangster Squad'.

In conclusion, 'La La Land' is an extravagant, bittersweet combination of classic cinema and modern filmmaking. The film makes use of its talented cast in more ways than one, as the leads take on musical roles alongside performative ones and manage to provide a pleasant viewing experience.

I would give a five out of five for this movie for its excellent music, the theme it presents, and its romantic element. First, La La Land's music created an impression beyond words that stays fresh even after years. There are 15 songs in the movie. I love the song at the very beginning of the movie called" Another Day of Sun" which carry the message of never giving up your dream's up. On contrary, if you are not a big musical movie lover, watching La La Land could be big torture for you.Second, I like how the movie poses an unconventional ending as a romantic movie. Compared to most romantic movies which tend to have an idealistic ending- the prince and princess live happily ever after. Third, unlike most romantic movies, La La Land has no R-rated scene. Yet, the romantic comedy element captured the romance well. The director plotted the process in which Mia and Seb fell in love in witty and charming ways. 
Lastly, as an international student who came to a different country to accomplish my goals and dreams, watching this film has given me a more personal connection. For romantic relationships, I can resonate well with the dilemma of dream and love. After watching this movie, I rethink my priority of putting family and love in front of career goals. This movie also provides great strength for me to realize my goal as I listen to the movie songs over and over.

(1) I found it easy to stop this film and go to sleep.  I became bored during the long opening sequence on the freeway.  Shortening the rest of this film would help also. 
Cutting the Christmas carols to avoid using tired music and showing a dysfunctional interaction between the pianist and the manager, dropping the rude freeway interactions between the two leads, and editing out some of the inept auditions and the one-woman play, would all help.  I found it hard to sympathize with Emma Stone's character's acting career objective with all these false notes.  (2) The only dialogue I liked was John Legend's character's criticism of Ryan Gosling's character's view of jazz and opening a jazz club. Since I share this doubt about the sense of opening a jazz club, I could not sympathize with the lead male's objective in the film.  (3) I focused on the film's use of color and jazz music to stay engaged with this film.  (4) Apparently, Emma Stone's character told her husband very little about her previous relationship with Ryan Gosling's character.  Seeing this omission provided an off key end to the film.

I just didn't connect with this film. I love musicals, and this one seemed to be imitating a sort of older style (like singing in the rain era), but it didn't have the movement those films did. Sure the old musicals could be sad and sweet, but they also banged out rousing tap dance numbers or included comedy to get you laughing at what the protagonists have to overcome.

La la land always felt like it was filmed on a stage with actors to me. Stand here, line there. Okay sing now--but not too well because you're not a broadway singer, and don't sing an interesting song either (I couldn't hum a single tune from the show except the opening of that very slow piano song they played three separate times). It just felt lacking. Like they should have hired performers instead of actors, or re-worked the songs/cinematography a bit to be more interesting. I mean come on--in the big climax of the film she stands there and sing/tells a story. I don't think she changed expression or moved once and that's supposed to be the audition that finally lands her a role?? It was unbelievable. But even if it had been believable it was unlikeable. Just there. Existing. Like I guess I saw it but I got nothing out of it.

I loved this movie. As I am watching this movie for the first time now in 2022 I came in with high expectations knowing the awards it won, were nominated for, and debatably should have won. For a story this checks all the boxes and adds more with the amazing ending; which at first made me mad but now slowly realize how it contributes to the story. The acting was amazing from Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling and all the dance and singing scenes kept you interested in the movie to the very end. Great movie, one of the best in the decade and probably the century.

This is, hands down, the greatest romance I've ever seen. I'm not huge on the genre of romance, nor am I a fan of musicals, but La La Land sold it to me. It just tears your heart out! It's charming, lovely, smart, and heart-warming. Emma Stone shined like a diamond in this film, combining the best of her acting, gorgeous looks, and charming character. I could not have picked a better couple for this film than Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling. Their performance together took my heart to far-away galaxies a hundred times over, and still left me hungry for more! The sheer power of a Steinway and Sons Piano and the soothing, nostalgic sounds it makes, takes this film's power of emotion to a whole other level. The filming was excellent combined with the dancing, music, and setting of each scene. All of it combined made for a mind-blowing romance which deserves all the praise it has received from the hungry critics. Two thumbs way up.

The direction of Damien Chazelle (as well as his writing) is beyond excellent, shown by the amazing performances of Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, the music by John Hurwitz and songs, the cinematography, the story, the atmosphere. This film makes you joyful and melancholic.

As the musical genre of film has rapidly lost its way, Damien Chazelle's "La La Land" is a visually stunning and perfectly choreographed callback to the greats using a deep plot on the journey to success, and the sacrifices of that ambition. Similar to Chazeeles another musically focused masterpiece "Whiplash" he focuses on self-sacrifice. In Whiplash Neiman gave up his character to become a drumming great, In La La Land Mia and Sebastian give up their love to pursue different dreams. In Whiplash, there's a little glimpse of this theme with Neiman breaking ties with his girlfriend to focus on drumming but Mia and Sebastian's love is the key focus here. It ends on a bittersweet note that's shown incredibly. Both achieve their goals but due to the time and focus it takes to do that they split away. Unlike most relationships ending Mia and Sebastian have no lost love, There is still a deep love and care for each other in the end. There is a stunning showcase of what could've been between these two if the world really was a so-called "La La Land" where love and happiness prosper over all, but it grounds the viewer in a painful truth. The genre its plot is set it baits and almost traps the viewer in a false security that all will work out in the end. The bursting colors, happy songs, and romantic dances all by you into the "La La Land" All the factors that work towards this is nothing short of filmmaking genius, impeccable directing. The performances from Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling were great, with strong chemistry between both. The performances, music, dances and perfectly executed plot makes La La Land one of the finest Musicals to come out in recent history, if not the best.

Every single cliché you have ever seen rolled up into a movie that starts as a musical but then kind of forgets about that halfway through. A painfully clichéd romance story with very little substance, populated by cardboard cutout characters, and unfortunately also missing a sorely needed show-stopping musical number.

My favorite musical I've ever watched and fallen in love with. I'm still rooting for this to win Best Picture, but Moonlight deserves it. The cinematography, lighting, and score were terrific! I'm flabbergasted!

One of the most artistic and emotional movies I've ever seen. A refreshing take on the modern romance that is surprisingly down to earth. The contrast between the fantastical dance scenes and the relatable problems the characters experience is simply delightful. I caught myself forgetting that this was simply a movie. If the pop color doesn't entertain you the soundtrack is absolutely astounding. Most of the bad reviews I hear about this movie are from people who can't admit to themselves that enjoying a musical is okay.

I'm not one for musicals or this general style of by-gone movie types but I really enjoyed this movie for what it is.  It's gorgeous to watch.  It's not the best dancing and best singing (and quite frankly, I'm glad it wasn't... that's where the character's charms lay), but it comes together so well and the acting is great.  It got my emotions stirring but that's no surprise for me.  I hesitated to watch this for a long time, but I'm happy I finally did.

I heard the makers wanted to give an "golden age of Hollywood musical" feeling.  Which they do, the look.  But failed on three major fronts.  That would be story, character and pacing.  The two leads are as appealing as cardboard, no fault of the actors.  That's how they were written and directed.  The story is basic as you get and the pacing is non-existed.  Instead of "Singin' In The Rain", we get "An American In Paris".  No wonder this was an Oscar darling, whenever these characters have feelings, it's forced melodrama with no comedy or entertainment.  But I'll give credit where credit is due, the songs and dances are very good.  Just everything is else is lousy.
Wonderful movie and I love the colours/cinematography. Ryan and Emma do a fantastic job and the soundtrack is very catchy.

Having just gotten back from seeing 'La La Land', with a rare day off music college, it came to me that it was one of the best new release/first viewings for me in a while.

Very few films in recent memory has left me leave the cinema with my heart properly warmed, a beaming smile on my face, tears in my eyes, feeling uplifted and properly moved. 'La La Land' however has managed that feat. Would also go further to say that it is one of the best modern film musicals after Disney's Renaissance period in the 90s, and very much a modern classic. Am not surprised at all its award wins and nominations (including being a record breaker at the Golden Globes), and if it does well at the Oscars as well there will be no complaints from me.

'La La Land' clicked with me most likely because of my love for golden age Hollywood, musicals (a somewhat maligned genre these days, but while there are a fair share of not particularly good ones there are a bigger number of great ones and even masterpieces), and how it fondly reminded me of what makes me love them so much. Also because of being able to relate to its themes and conflicts, due to being there myself. The talent was also appetising, starring Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, directed by 'Whiplash's' Damien Chazelle and featuring cameo support from JK Simmons (who coincidentally won a Best Supporting Actor Oscar for 'Whiplash), John Legend and Rosemarie DeWitt.

It was just sheer joy to see a film with so much potential deliver on that potential and even more so, having seen a lot of stuff recently film and TV that wasted their potential it was refreshing to see a film actually delivering on it.

Visually, 'La La Land' is a gorgeous-looking film, with lots of vibrant colour that leap out at you from the screen while not having too much of a dizzying effect and cinematography that's not just a dream to behold but inventively done without falling into self-indulgent territory. The music and songs may induce, and has induced, mixed reactions, count me in as somebody who found the songs infectious, emotion-filled and with enough to make one top-tap and hum along.

The musical numbers are winningly choreographed too with non-stop exuberance. The opening number is especially true to this. The script is warm, funny, affectionate and poignant, and also with an honesty. It's not a complex script, nor did it need to be, and neither does it make the mistake of being too simple. The story is admittedly slight in places, then again so were the stories of even the best golden age musicals and they still managed to be classics because of how everything else was executed and because of the atmosphere.

Something that is true with 'La La Land', a film where anybody can relate to its themes. Even more special though is that not only does it pay tribute to musicals and films of the golden age (especially those with MGM), with their bold colour, exuberant marriage of music and dance, it also has a winsomeness and melancholic nature seen in films like 'The Umbrellas of Cherbourg' yet does it in a way that will appeal hugely to modern audiences. Loved that the two leads' relationship and chemistry was much more complex than the love-at-first-sight sort (far from it, more antagonists turned lovers) with a meet cute first encounter (again also not a case).

Chazelle's direction shows someone with a sheer love for film and film-making, more than evident in execution that is affectionate and full-of-life rather than self-indulgent. The chemistry between the two leads and their performances would need to be good to make the film work. No worries there. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone look so natural and at ease together, nothing looks false and it is easy to root for them and their conflicts.

Both of them give terrific performances, performances so good that less than great singing was immediately forgotten about. Especially Stone who has never been better in a performance of great expressivity and nuance, so many emotions such as vulnerability, strength, cheekiness, charm and buoyancy with never a hint of a heavy-handed touch. Gosling matches her, if not quite as good, showing a very charismatic presence and an effortless twinkling charm. All the support, although basically cameos, registers memorably.

All in all, a dream come true and totally banishes any blues and daily troubles away. 10/10 Bethany Cox

I'm writing this review after I have lost count of just how many times I've seen this film in it's entirety, much less in the snippets of is musical sequences or even dramatic ones at that. La La Land is a film that never loses its touch. No matter how many times I view it, I always ponder on what could've been, just how Mia and Sebastian do in the final scene.

To begin, the cast is essentially just Mia (Emma Stone) and Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) who's romance simply never fails to captivate. They simply seem so perfect and made for one another, but yet they're not meant to be together. At a certain point in the film, Sebastian takes Mia to a Jazz club in hopes that she learns the beauty of Jazz music. As they listen to Jazz live, Sebastian states, "It's conflict, and it's compromise, and it's just... it's NEW every time. It's brand-new every night. It's very, very exciting. And it's dying. It's dying, Mia. It's dying on the vine." After countless rewatching, that quote almost represents Mia and Sebastian's relationship throughout the film. From the clashing of Mia not liking jazz, and Sebastian not wanting to name his club "Seb's" to the compromising of Mia learning about Jazz through Sebastian and Sebastian naming his club "Deb's" due to Mia. Every time we see the pair on screen it's a new thing for them, something new to do or something new that's happening to them and it's very exciting to see... until slowly but surely it dies. On the vine.

Damien Chazelle (Director) makes La La Land feel dreamy and at times, quite literally out-of-this world with the phenomenal musical acts and choreography being placed in magical settings. The feeling of each sequence and film feeling quite literally like the state of their relationship. On top of that, Score composer Justin Hurwitz made some beautiful beautiful pieces of music that fit so elegantly every step of the way. In order to achieve such beautiful images, there is Cinematographer Linus Sandgren to thank for that. All in all, one of the most delightfully pleasing films of all time with an ending that makes you feel as though love can't exist at all.

In the end, La La Land proves itself as it continues to stand strong within the realm of musicals, romance, and drama without ever becoming cheesy or repetitive. An absolutely phenomenal and gorgeous film that belongs to a city of stars.
Most realistic romance movie I've ever seen. The soundtrack was also fire. This movie will be considered a classic in fifty years, mark my words.
A movie that constantly begs the question, "Ya like Jazz?" before immediately following up with, "Well you better!"

Captures the feeling and joy of falling in love. I went in with low expectations, as I'm not a fan of musicals, to then be left in tears by the end. Inspiring performances from its leads and an amazing score puts this movie on my list of all time favorites. If this movie doesn't pull your heart strings you might not be human.
My Favourite movie of all time

Todo un clásico, la la land es un homenaje al cine, al teatro, a los sueños, al amor y al romance. Es un relato evocador, acompañado de una soberbia estética y una producción sobresaliente. Si bien el romance que muestra en pantalla es algo que ya hemos visto previamente, la forma como este es ejecutado, es en verdad impresionante, y aunque aparentemente es algo simple, en verdad se ayuda de todos sus detalles de producción para hacerte sentir enamorado; se vale de las escenas musicales para representar de una forma fantástica los sentimientos o emociones de los protagonistas, como lo pueden ser el enamoramiento, la frustración o sus motivaciones,...ES BRILLANTE!. La banda sonora y las canciones son pegajosas y alegres, las coreografías están magistralmente dirigidas, actuadas y filmadas con largos planos secuencia y movimientos de cámara sumamente ambiciosos. La la land, es realismo mágico al 100%, cine puro y aunque no suelo decir esto, la la land es toda una obra maestra . 8,6/10

I found this movie very entertaining, but it's not a movie that should be an Oscar winner or Golden Globe winner. It does have a good story, but it's not strong enough for the Oscars or Golden Globe awards, at least in my opinion. Whenever you see a movie like this that's a musical, never pay attention too the paid movie critics reviews, pay attention too the audience reviews instead. Any paid movie critic who is from an online newspaper should get no attention. We have the internet now, social media and movie reviewing/tv show reviewing websites like here on Rotten Tomatoes and IMDB. We don't need too listen too the paid movie critics' nonsense. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling do a good job with their performances and the cinematography and directing is on cue. The screenplay told the story well. The style of the movie is also good. But again, this kind of a movie is for people who like musicals. I highly recommend this movie for movie fans who like/love musicals, but if you're not into musicals, that's okay, you can skip this one and find another movie that Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling have done that isn't a musical. All in all, a good and very entertaining picture.

The story of the movie La La Land is one of romance and ambition. The movie looks into both the struggles and joys that come with being in a relationship. This epic love story musical gives the audience a story to fall in love with and music that sticks with them long after watching. Through the use of stunning visuals and catchy musical numbers,  a gripping story is formed that has the potential to make all romantically involved or once-involved audience members connect with the story on a personal level. These aspects allow the story of Mia and Sebastian's love to stay strong and engaging for audiences. This movie has set the tone for what a romantic musical should be and will bring audiences enjoyment for far in the future.

Bright, vivid, and lavishly produced modern day musical about a struggling LA musican (Ryan Gosling) and actress (Emma Stone) is a charming throwback musical love story. Camera, costumes, and photography do most of the heavy lifting when it comes to the musical dance sequence elements, making up for the stars limited abilities, but Gosling and Stone give the film a whole lot of heart and soul. They present fully fleshed out characters as compared to most movie musicals where characters are less developed and are more or less simply character archetypes. The old fashioned Gershwin-like score and songs are terrific and Emma Stone has a surprisingly good breathy singing voice. Even if Gosling is less talented in the singing department, he makes up for it with a fine performance. Although"La La Land" does bring some welcome realism to it's story not typically seen in musicals, it does not go nearly as dark or subversive as Jacques Demy's "The Umbrellas of Cherbourg" or Martin Scorsese's "New York, New York" which were more a deconstruction of the musical as a genre. Overall, "La La Land" is a charming throwback for fans of old fashioned movie musicals, even if it's more of a novelty than a true classic. Still, I have to admit I prefer Peyton Reed's homage to Rock Hudson and Doris Day films with his "Down with Love" which although wasn't really a musical outside of the one closing number, but it's throwback feel was far more nostalgic for me.

음악의 힘은 역시 로맨스 장르에서 가장 잘 발현되는 것 같다. 만남-사랑-행복-위기-극복 의 클리셰를 충실히 따르는 듯 하면서도 몇 차례 비틀어 놓은 점이 매력적이다. 서로를 사랑하지만 숨기고 싶은 내면의 약점과 열등감이 그들의 진심을 가로막는다. 어려울 때의 그들은 서로가 서로에게 위로가 되었다. 마냥 낭만적일 것 같던 둘의 관계는 역설적이게도 서로의 꿈을 너무 잘 알기에 틀어지고 말았다. 두 사람이 꼭 원수가 되어 헤어지는 것만 이별이 아니다. 그런 의미에서 마지막에 두 사람은 서로의 꿈을 이해하고 그 성취를 확인했기에 비록 이어지지 못했지만 미소지을 수 있었다. 사랑과 이별의 아픔에서 아직 헤어나오지 못한 나에게 다소간 위안이 되는 작품이었다.

This movie is a true masterclass in filmmaking. The movie opens in one long shot and immediately you are into the movie, without knowing anything about the characters. La La Land: a visually dazzling masterpiece.
It will only takes you a few seconds to notice that this movie is something different. Yes, the opening scene itself already shows that Damien Chazelle did one of the greatest movies of all time. Period.
Long single shots, outstanding sceneries, a stunning cinematography... La La Land will make every cinema fan feel delighted with so much colors painting Los Angeles as the city of dreams, or, to make a reference to one of the amazing songs of the movie, the City of Stars.

An absolute tour de force! One of the most endearing musicals known to man-kind and almost flawless in every way. La La Land follows an aspiring actress and musician who cross paths and bond over their shared passion to achieve their dreams. This is without a doubt the heart and soul of the movie, the acting performances delivered by Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling are outstanding and the chemistry they shared was a delight to watch! It's incredibly moving to see them open up to each other and express their emotions to one another. The musical segments involving them are an absolute joy as well as you just can't help but smile from ear to ear when they start dancing! Speaking of musical segments, they're all wonderfully done, from the music to the dance choreography to the range of emotions shown off, it's all phenomenal and makes you wanna get up and start dancing yourself! The cinematography, costume design and setting were all executed with such finesse! The lighting and angles used in certain shots is just mind-boggling, from the auditorium scene to the jazz club sequence, you can't help but be amazed! The different time jumps and how they showcase it through the outfits worn by the cast is just as remarkable and improves the immersion drastically and didn't hamper the experience in the slightest. Another thing this movie does fantastically is its interpretation of how we as humans strive to achieve our dreams, it almost brings a tear to your eyes. How they showcase both Mia and Sebastian's drive to achieve those dreams is surprisingly realistic and goes to show that we as humans can achieve anything if we set our mind to it. The pacing was also brisk and upbeat, while it isn't fast-paced, it still isn't boring, every scene feels important to the overarching plot and it never feels like they're panning out the run time. You never get bored whilst watching and you're always interested to see where the story goes next. Finally, the ending was mature, slightly melancholic but still absolutely satisfying! We see how Sebastian and Mia grew apart. However, in the final moments, they see each other one final time, but it isn't a sorrowful moment, it's instead reassuring as they give each other one final glance to signal that they're happy for each other that they both ended up achieving what they set out to do. La La Land is one of those rare movies that remind us why we love cinema to begin with. Such a beautiful, mature and deeply moving film could've never been made if the crew behind it didn't pour their heart and soul into the project! Everyone truly gave it their all and it's a miracle such a movie exists to begin with. Taking all these facts into account, it isn't a shocker it won twelve Oscars! Truly one of the greatest movies of all time!

Blah La Land

I usually only review things that like ("if you can't say anything nice…" sort of thing) or more often, to defend it from its detractors. So it is in that spirit that I invite anyone to enlighten me on the seemingly universal love for  "La La Land." 
Simply put: I just don't get it.  
The fantasy elements, the dance numbers the jazz score and the chemistry of the two leads are all terrific.  The final montage is beautifully done. Even the song lyrics, when not being over-powered by the score, are very nice.  But the story is such a slog and neither Gosling nor Stone have a strong enough voice to carry the show.  
Both City of Stars and A Beautiful Night maybe lovely and even "catchy" tunes, but they are delivered without any conviction. Gosling sings everything under his breath and Emma's timid little voice only gets going at the end of her last number and by then - it was too late for me. 
I grew up on movie musicals: Westside Story, The Music Man, Bye Bye Birdie. I love the more recent ones like Little Shop of Horrors, Chicago, Les Miserables and even Into the Woods.  Just listen to Ellen Green sing "Suddenly Seymour" and "Somewhere That's Green" or Rene' Zellwigger's "Roxie," or Hathaway's "I Dreamed a Dream." There are no showstoppers or defining moments like those in La La Land, much to my supreme disappointment.   It's not a bad movie but neither is it a great musical, no matter how much Hollywood fawns all over it.
Not all the tunes hit the mark and the coda runs long, but you can't help but enjoy the twists and turns of the lead characters relationship
The non-official Oscar winner.

This movie is and will forever be a masterpiece, not only because of the music but also the photography, the acting, the whole story of Mia and Sebastian. Their grownth as individuals while persuing their dreams  is palpable. So real. So true. We won't do the best for us and at the same time for our partner every single time. Turns out what we thought was the best for both, may be not for neither. Some times we comit mistakes. Other times we comit the worst of our entire lifes. And we can't always help it. It's so sad when you feel there's no space for you, your dreams and the dreams of your partner in a relationship (I cried a lot because of it). Life is not always kind to us. Destiny can be a luck, but also a bad luck. But i think, at the end, they found a way to support each other, what was very difficult back then when they were together. They made it in the final scene (Sebastian by chance. Mia without even notice. Both without the primary intention to do it). Maybe the timing wasn't right. Maybe they don't belong together. Maybe they did. Who knows? Even apart, they were a crucial part of each others dreams. Love is L.U.V.: Listening, Understanding and Validating. And I think that was exactly what they did. She fought with him because she knew he wasn't following his dreams. She understood his passion, she validated it because she listened how much it meant to him since the beginning. He got mad because he was willing to sacrifice his dreams for hers and thought he was doing what would make her happy. He validated her dreams too, but listened more to his fears than to her, what she wanted from him: to be there with her when she needed him. The true is that they could only be truly happy if both could see both dreams coming true. They unsdertood that and validated that. But it's not that easy to have everything. Real life it's not flowers and glitter all the time. We need to make our choices and to live with the consequences of it. They couldn't say "My dream is more worth the try than yours, you need to sacrifice yours so I can live mine."  or "I don't need my dream coming true to be happy, we can live just yours." I mean, they could, but the would never do it to each other. And they shouldn't, cause both still needed that. They needed their dreams. So, their happiness for the other one at the end is pure and genuine. They made their choices: they let each other go to live their lifes, to achieve their goals. And they did! And so well done. They were proud of each other. At that moment, they saw with their own eyes that their paths were crossed years ago with a purpose: to not let each other give up on their dream. And, surprisily, life was kind at the end (after being really tough earlier). Life let Mia see Sebs living his dream and Sebs see Mia living hers too. I know that moment hurted like HELL to watch, but they needed that. After all, they sacrificed their love to their dreams to come true, didn't they? They deserved to see each other happiness. "La la land" is about the cost of our dreams, the understading that everything happens for a reason even if it's not in the way we wanted, the consequences of our choices and what we are able to do to see the people we love happy. What is true love? Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling were impeccable. Emma is always astonishing, Ryan was amazing and improvised so damn well. "People love what other people are passionate about." That's why they fell in love with each other. And that's why I am in love with this movie since 2016.

Sin duda la belleza de esta película no está en el guion ni en los personajes, si no en el entorno que los rodea. para mi en lo que acierta esta película es en hacer un entorno tan agradable e interesante que los mismos están contando la historia a la vez que los protagonistas. Otra cosa que me encantó de la película fue su increíble cámara, que en todo momento siempre parece una misma con los personajes. Aunque el guion para mi no es el fuerte de esta película tiene momentos tan hermosos y tan memorables que son clásicos instantáneos, también los musicales que se introducen en la película están muy bien medidos y ninguno se siente forzado. Para mi lo que los hace diferentes a otros es que en las canciones se profundiza a los personajes y al entorno que los rodea, haciéndolo de manera muy original y linda a la vista y al oído. La la land es una película que tienes que ver por lo diferente y única que es a su manera. Simplemente hermosa.

The best word to describe this Ryan Gosling/Emma Stone musical movie is DAZZLING! From the direction, to performances, to a darn amazing soundtrack, "La La Land" checks all the marks to becoming a critic darling at awards season.

Sadly, of course, we all remember what happened the night of the Oscars. But I genuinely believe that this movie will live on, not because of that plunder, but because of the content itself. It's a modern movie musical. Many movies such as "Hairspray" and "Moulin Rouge" have tried to revive that classic romantic genre, but in my opinion, only "La La Land" truly succeeded at this. At times, I forgot that this movie is set in modern times as I found myself reminiscent of the classics, most notably "Singing In The Rain".

One thing I absolutely adore about it is the ending. While tragic, it also just seems authentic. Things don't always work out in real life. Lovers don't always have their happily ever afters like in the fairy tales. We see a tragic montage of what could've been and the tears begin to fall down the audience's faces.

Overall, this movie has a perfect blend of comedy, romance, drama, incredible choreography, beautiful melodies, and phenomenal performances by the leads.
This movie is a breath of fresh air in a time when movies now days are mind numbingly repetitive and largely forgettable. Definitely one of the best movies of this decade.

This really was a fantastic movie and worthy of the awards recognition it got. The love story was great, the song & dance numbers were excellent, the vivid & saturated color palette was perfect and the comedic elements were well-done. I would've preferred they find a bigger role for J.K. Simmons as he's one of my favorite actors but I can see how it was necessary to minimize him when he was so important to Chazelle's last movie. I imagine this will end up being Chazelle & Hurwitz's magnum opus as they seem born to make this movie, and now they have. Emma's performance grew on me as the movie went on as she really showed a ton of range here, with the whole movie riding on her nailing her performance the way she did. I was less enamored with Gosling, who I've always thought was rather overrated and whose character was given dissatisfyingly rude traits like holding the horn down for no reason whatsoever; his creative differences with Legend came off as awkward and his facial expressions remained subdued the entire movie. The middle of the movie did lag a bit as they stopped doing as many songs and tried to turn my anti-frown upside down, but overall I loved watching this!
Es absolutamente colorida y fresca, sin duda la banda sonora y dirección son increíbles, la fotografía es fenomenal.

In un'era in cui i musical sono sempre meno in voga, La La Land sfrutta questa occasione per utilizzare la parte cantata come contorno ad una storia che sarebbe in grado di funzionare anche senza di essa.
Ciò che colpisce maggiormente, oltre ai colori da favola e alla fotografia, è l'incredibile performance di Emma Stone, semplicemente stupenda, e l'alchimia che si crea con Ryan Gosling, nettamente meno performante nelle parti cantate.
Il finale è allo stesso tempo delicato e potente; sintomo di grande qualità.

Chazelle gripped me with Whiplash, so I decided to revisit La La Land after a few years to see what I could extract from having seen two of the man's films. Emma Stone can be a bit hit/miss, combining an occasional relatability with repetitive over-acting. Ryan Gosling has always been a favorite of mine, for his versatility in playing either quiet loners or aggressive hardcases. He is more of a French shower in this one. The screenplay allows the two stars plenty to get their acts on in natural, fast exchanges. The two have history, and their chemistry brings the film up. I'd honestly forgotten about Simmons being in this, Oscar winner for Whiplash. He is always welcome, even if squandered here. John Legend also shows up. Yeah.

Let's get this out of the way: the musical numbers here are nothing remotely special. I don't mean to slag Hurwitz off in any way, but every time the music begins I had the urge to skip. Gosling has dabbled in music, but he cannot support Stone's clear lack of "the voice" and fails to convince himself. The set designs and choreography occasionally make up for this shortcoming, but most of the time it is putting lipstick on a pig. The songs do not revolt, but do not entice in the way clearly intentioned by including them in the first place. I must note that most of the jazzy solo instrumentals are decent and the Love Theme is beautiful.

The story almost transcends the poor musical sequences. The simplicity of two well-matched leads falling in love and then drifting apart against the backdrop of LA. We have a sense of realism against a juxtaposition of magic, comedy, genuinely touching romance, and escapism. For that, the film is unique and cannot be ignored, as it wasn't in the awards.

Review – MOVIE CLUB #1-  LA LA LAND 
A movie directed and writed by Damien Chazelle, La La Land is a musical movie and also a love story, that a girl name Mia dreams about to been a sucesseful actress and one boy name Sebastian dreams of been a jazz pianist and they meet then help each other to chase your dreams, and than they fall in love.
It's a great movie, the songs, the scenery, the collors are beautiful it's pleasant and the story is engaging. 
The cast is full of talented people: Ryan Gosling (Sebastian), Emma Stone (Mia), Jonh Legend (Keith), Rosemarie DeWitt (Laura), J.K Simmons (Boss) and Finn Wittrock (Greg).

La la land is a non-cliché musical movie. Although musical isn't my favorite movie genre, the history of the two young artists fascinated me, Mia with her dream of becoming an actress and Sebastian a pianist in love with Jazz with the mission of not let the Jazz die. The movie shows an overproduction and scenarios with many colors. The songs travel through places and memories, of what was and what could it be.
I especially liked the end of the film, although not expected, it was nice to see that both got to make their dreams come true and are grateful for each other for that. I recommend it to everyone who appreciates a good movie, regardless of the genre.
Boring and shallow. The story wasn't convincing and the plot just wasn't there.

Absolutely beautiful. I personally am not usually a fan of musicals, but this film was so well done and the music was so catchy that I couldn't resist. Emma Stone puts out a fantastic performance, and the chemistry between her and gosling is amazing. A must watch, even if you typically dislike musicals!

A visually stunning and symbolic film with purposeful sparkles of grandiose banal Hollywood.  Each successive watch of this film further deepens my appreciation for the script and the input the actors had on the final product.

Who knew either of them could sing - and that wasn't the worst part - but the story line was weak and so were the characters. I won't likely ever watch it again! And if I could have walked out, I would have.

Just WOW!

La La Land is not just another musical film; it is a one-of-a-kind film that transports me to a variety of heavenly emotional states. The perfect cast, music, dancing, cinematography, and a slew of other elements were all flawless.

Although I can't get past the ending, I still admired it because it's realistic and you can tell it's the best decision they've ever made.

All in all, the most important lesson I've learned is to "always follow your dream."
the film transports you to several scenes in others instead it leaves the emotions a bit in the background for the rest the technical composition is excellent

Not my type of mvoie.

I don't even know where to start. The acting is incredible. I don't remember the last time I've ever wanted two characters to end up together more than this. The story is intricate to a point where no scene is wasted and everything progresses the film forwards. If you know anything about LA, there will be a number of inside jokes and imagery which stand out, but even if you don't, LA feels like a dream-like land that we have all probably imagined at some point. The music, tone, nostalgia, backdrops, lighting, cinematography, dialogue, metaphors, imagery, everything is fantastically balanced and amplified when needed. How you feel about the characters, and how they feel about each other is so real, and to me, is a realistic portrayal of what love can feel like in an ever-changing world. La La Land is a poetic, thoughtful, beautiful rollercoaster, full of emotion and a love letter to LA, life, and love.
When I saw this movie I fell in love with the musicals, the songs are incredible and the plot is very good, maybe a tear will come out or you cry a lot (as in my case) when you finish watching it.
a musical masterpiece, everything is perfect in it

Definitely not what I was expecting! I love Emma and Ryan together but the storylines were a bit drawn out and disappointingly difficult to follow. Some of the musical numbers/dream sequences felt out of place and over the top, sending the audience out of La La Land. I did really like the jazz coming into a new generation and John Legend's music! This movie was really good but not not great.
La La Land was nominated to a remarkable quantity of awards, and whilst I agree on them, its magic relies in the film's heart.
Beautiful, great, emotional movie.

Visually dazzling, enchanting and all around upbeat, La La Land might not have won Best Picture back in the day, but it's still a stunning film nonetheless. Topped with spectacular performances from Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, this is a great modern revival and love letter to old school musicals.

There's a lot this movie gets wrong and a lot that it gets right.  The best elements are the chemistry between the leads, the art direction, the cinematography, and the direction.  There is a fantastic surrealist blend of movie and stage elements, along with a great use of color for a truly innovative visual production.  For a musical about a musician however, the music leaves much to be desired.  While perfectly well written in a vacuum, there is sloppy integration between narrative and song, with a disturbing lack "pure jazz" that Gosling's character professes to care so much about.  With the writers' seeming failure to have any interactions with a real musician as research, the film's story is doomed to be a narrow minded caricature of an LA beatnik and the "dying art" of jazz.

Watched the movie after it was warmly recommended to me by my fiancée (a friend at the time though).. and I am glad that I listened to her. As a guy who typically gravitates towards war-, action-, and space movies, this movie took me by surprise and was way better than I had expected.

Starting from the very first scene, I watched with a grin and the joy lasted towards the end. Though joyous, the movie was also very bittersweet - which hit me particularly hard due to the tangent the narrative had with my own life at that point in time.

My fiancée, who was my friend back then, was someone that I feared would only be in my life for a glimpse moment because I couldn't imagine that she liked me - yet I had incredibly strong emotions for her that I had never felt in my life prior. Eventually, she also started dating another guy during our friendship - which made my life a living hell. Given the context, I strongly related my struggles to the struggles of Ryan's character as he dealt with the same, especially towards the end wherein the love of his life ended up with another guy.

Luckily, I didn't end up with the same fate as Ryan's character.. Nonetheless, it's still a movie that I have a lot of emotions tied to. All in all, a great and memorable movie. More so for me due to how it reflected my own life at the point of watching it.

This easily goes down as my favorite romantic film in recent years. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling deliver a romantic portrayal of a fantasy living in Los Angeles. What I love about this movie more than anything is that the first half of the movie is the honeymoon stage of a relationship and the last half is the reality that surrounds every relationship at a certain point in time. This movie is also enhanced by many musical elements with stunning musical dance numbers and cinematography that is just like clouds in a dream. The soundtrack is just beyond great and deserves all the recognition that it earned. When this movie was being advertised I had no interest to see it, I went to go see it just randomly on a Friday night and I was blown away by what Damian Chazelle manage to create. For Someone that is not interested in Jazz, this gave me a new perspective on the genre and made me appreciate it. It’s a dazzling tale of love and life with all the glamour and downfall that living in Hollywood brings to so many.
The ending gets me every time.

I loved this movie! The history, cast, scenography, music, all under an excellent direction that knew how to join each of these aspects to make a work of art that transmits emotions that seem as contrary as happiness and sadness with a single scene.
First, the story plays along the line of cliché without falling into it and that is what makes it so special, it shows us the ease and simplicity which we can come across someone who will change our lives, but also shows how that person can last long enough to become a burden, how we should be left behind certain things, adding a touch of nostalgia, the famous "What would have happened if...?".
The cast is wonderful, the roles of Mia and Sebastian seem like they were made specifically for Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling. They do an impressive  job, Emma giving Mia joy, spontaneity and charisma, and Ryan giving Sebastian that serious, sarcastic and persevering personality. In addition there are good performances from John Legend, Jessica Rothe, JK Simmons, among others.
The scenography is a phenomenal job, it shows us amazing views of Hollywood with an excellent choice of colors that makes us feel exactly the emotion they want, and with all other aspects to take us right to that moment.
The music is divine, it's the best thing of the movie, Justin Hurwitz did an impeccable job combining the Jazz style with orchestra. Songs that transmit a thousand emotions by themselves, for example "The fools who dream" or "Someone in the crowd", added to the excellent visual work. The soundtrack and its title song "City of Stars" were decorated at the academy awards.
In conclusion, I highly recommend this film that envelops you and makes you feel identified with each of the characters. Art that we can appreciate and enjoy through the eyes and ears. Of course, backed by nothing more and nothing less than 6 academy awards and 7 Golden Globes, just to mention some of its 88 awards.
Music heals everything. LA looks so attractive.
The music is very fun and will get you to move your foot up and down at times but that is pretty much it. The story feels predictable and the acting is dry at times. Nothing really special about it.
"It is conflict and it is compromise and it is very, very exiting"

A fantastic and entertaining musical, combined with Chazelle's script and direction, the performances of the cast, Hurwitz's score, the songs he co-wrote with Pasek and Paul, Sandgren's cinematography, Cross's editing, Wasco's production design, Reynolds-Wasco's set decoration, Zophres's costume design, emotional weight and themes, La La Land ranks highly amongst the films to have been nominated for the Oscar for Best Picture!!!

6 bags, a few old jazz records, at least one soda filled with tears, and some well-choreographed dance moves! I didn't even care to see this movie, but I made myself do it in order to get to 531 movies in like 500 days, or whatever it is at this point. So Gosling and Stone are amazing here (again), and Gosling shows that he can really do anything as an actor. I can't wait to see him, Anthony Hopkins, and Michael Douglas in "Slayers," coming soon. I'm genuinely glad I watched this movie, 'cause it turned out to actually be deserving of all that Oscar gold. It also has a sad ending to some extent, but I think it really fit for the movie.

I'm not embarrassed to admit that I really enjoyed "La La Land". I'm actually not a fan of musicals (although I did enjoy watching the High School Musical movies with my kids). I prefer the Godfather, Bourne, and Lord of The Ring movies; and romantic comedies like Annie Hall, Roman Holiday and Princess Bride; and classics like Casablanca.

But "La La Land" lifted my spirits, made me smile and had me swaying in my seat. It was gorgeous, romantic, wonderful and heartbreaking to watch. The song and dance routines seemed to burst right out of the screen and it all evoked a lot of emotions in me, especially that amazing ending. And Emma Stone is just glorious and gifted (I also highly recommend seeing her in "Easy A"- still my favorite Emma Stone movie, although she was also amazing in "Birdman").

This movie shows us that we can find love wherever it is and that dreams come true if you fight for them and that if you give up there will always be someone to get up and continue even though the ending takes you out of the comfort zone that the movie has. actors Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling keep a good chemistry the music gives even more life to this movie but in many moments it enters seas of cliches these have their reason which is to prepare you for a great ending
Brilliant movie movie, great performances of Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, super nice script. The movie has a high potential to become a classic.

I got to start by saying that I really really hate musical movies, they are just so boring to me, but La La Land was different cause it's not a movie, it is a dream.

First of all, the opening scene of the movie was the worst opening scene in history I think, I felt like it was so long meanwhile it was just 5 min. It has nothing that grabs the attention or makes the audience want to watch the movie and continue it.

I loved how in the movie we are seeing what the characters are seeing or a better way to say it: what they are dreaming, that's why I said the movie is a dream, not a movie, while i was watching La La Land I felt like I was thrown in a dream.

The movie's cinematography & colors are another level, it was so pretty and reflecting what each character was feeling and seeing.

The customs were beautiful especially Mia's (Played by Emma Stone) dresses, their colors were beautiful and they really fit the character very well.

The music score was so strong and just pure, absolutely deserves an oscar and a golden globe win.

Ryan Gosling (Plays Sebastian) and Emma Stone (Plays Mia) gave us a performance that I personally will never forget, in some scenes, especially the one when they were having dinner after Sebastian came form that tour with the band, I felt like they were not acting at all and that is all real, the chemistry between these two was..., i don't know what to say.

The dancing moves, the music and all that were not easy to perform at all but with the right cast & crew, they made it look so easy and possible. 

La La Land is a movie that will live for years, really enjoyed the movie. Hats off to everyone who worked on it.

My rating is: 9.5/10

After a brilliant work at cinematography, La La Land proves that a perfect story not always includes a happy ending. This film contains an original score that captives the listener from the beginning. A perfect work of art made by Damien Chazelle with great fresh acting by Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling.

La La Land is a great musical/romance movie with a little bit of comedy throughout. 

Also, the cast who are in this movie do a really good job for what they're given, especially Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) and Mia (Emma Stone) they give the best performances throughout this great movie. 

Finally, it's got some beautiful cinematography which looks amazing and it's got some great musical scenes throughout. 

The only negatives which I had with this movie would be some of the dialogue an hour in or so with Sebastian and Mia, It honestly felt a bit forced to me and the ending wasn't what I was expecting which was a bit sad. 

Overall, I really enjoyed this movie more than I expected to, its honestly worth the watch.

Also, I forgot to mention that scene with J.K Simmons is honestly really good, I didn't even know he was in this movie at all but it's always good to see him having a role in these new movies.

La La Land is a musical-movie with a gentle, whimsical flow. It opens to an upbeat ensemble musical number that starts the movie off on an optimistic note. We meet the main characters, an aspiring actress and a jobless pianist with a passion for jazz. We follow them as they learn about themselves and their relationship, and revel with them as they discover the beauty of exploration, love and music. 
            The whole movie has a nostalgic, old-timey feel, with 1960's costumes and long, uncut shots. The music is well timed throughout the movie, and it has an easy-to-follow plot with deeply explored, unique characters. The whole movie is well filmed, full of nicely framed shots and emotion-inducing lighting and colors. Not only that, but it's quite a thought provoking movie. It transcends time by following subjects such as music, passion, love and following dreams. 
            La La Land is an inspiring, gorgeous movie. It is most definitely worth the time spent watching it.

La la land- craziness overloaded with music mesmerising us till end.THE DIRECTOR gave a love (story) letter via Ryan and Emma through their amazing and marvellous unforgettable memory of love with an ending that gave u a warm feel and woth a few drops shedding in that letterand he succeeded in wat he was going to say...An another milestone in Daniel chazelle career..after giving such a effective Whiplash..all of a sudden a new way of movie that too a musical romantic ..and sure the jazz worked too good for oscars..and no matter u can still wonder it got 6 oscars actually i wish extra 1 or 2 might be good.. Emma gave us too good performance and Ryan also killed it and wish he was too close to oscar..but as a whole its fine bcz ..Ryan is more than precious for award..
The way director narrated the story..each and every line and in scene..he killed it to extreme..amazingly the music..the main pillar of this musical romantic movie ..as we can cay its a new way of playing the love. ...From the 1st scene..how they met ..how they fall in love to the last the dreaming about jazz love and actually wat happend but what the audience as well the lovers thought were clearly described..The last 15 mins of the movie nearly made shed tears out the eye .with a worthy heart robbing experience..

A rather disappointing movie; there isn't really anything at stake for either of the two characters, who at times seem wildly in love but at other times, inexplicably not. The songs are just not memorable or even interesting; we ended up talking over most of the songs. The actors do a fine job acting but they're not great singers, and they really can't dance. They don't even really try to dance, which makes the extended duo dance 'routines', including a tap-dancing routine without any actual tap-dancing, feel weirdly forced and out of place and, again, boring.

It's quite pretty at times, overall the cinematography felt good, but not great. I found there were a few memorable emotional and musical moments, but they were the exceptions rather than the rule.

La La Land is one of the most gorgeous films I have ever seen. How the scenary of Los Angeles gets along with all the virbant colors ans the movie's soundtrack is amusing. I couldn't keep my mouth shut throughout the whole thing, whatever I was amazed about. My favorite scene would definitely be when the two - Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling - start dancing in the planetarium. Emma dancing along with the music with her stunning white dress left me in awe. But I would also pick the starting scene as one of the most iconic scenes ever. How they begin with the normal, dull traffic jam that is probably common in the city from what I heard, but ends up filming a whole musical themselves all of a sudden and I thought that was a great way to start off a movie, especially one like this one as much as it is a musical film. Though what I really liked about the whole storyline was how the main character ends up following her dream, rather than choosing love over what she really wants to accomplish. The two decide to follow what they have been dreaming of accomplishing thougb they share the same amount of love and affection towards each other. Captivating, magical, mesmerizing. 'La La Land' is a worthy ode to traditional Hollywood musicals of the past that acts as a visual poem, offering an escape from the reality of modern life. The dichotomy between love and dreams is explored consistently throughout, while the musical numbers and stunning camera shots of the whimsical Los Angeles promised land engulf us as viewers, sweeping us along for the ride. The chemistry between Stone and Gosling is palpable and lends itself to the sense of fantasy riddled with realism that the film conveys. I could talk about the ending forever, however for the purposes of this review I will just say that it is beautifully crafted and suitably reinforces the main message of the film. I love this film and couldn't recommend it enough.

Mia and Sebastian do not end up together due to their conflicting career interests that drift them apart from each other. Although Mia attends Sebastian's Jazz club with her husband and the reality sits in that they have each moved on, the film's ending depicts what ‘could have been' for the two characters if the circumstances under which they met were different. In this fantasy of what could have been, the events take place in a shocking, non-sensical way where Sebastian kisses Mia spontaneously when they first meet and is followed by a sequence of events that show how their lives took a better, more fairytale-like, route from there. This imitates the ‘happily ever after' endings of traditional Hollywood films which push forward the ideology that everything seems to fall into place in favor of the characters. In a way, the ‘what could have been' sequence serves as an inter-textual representation of Hollywood films in general which almost always have endings that juxtapose reality, or in this case the reality in the film that Mia and Sebastian did not get their happily ever after.

"La La Land" is simply overflowing with joy. Writer-director Damien Chazelle accomplishes this through the use of homage and pastiche, evoking prior sights and sounds from classic musicals like "Singin' in the Rain" and "West Side Story." In addition to invoking the exuberance of older styles, Chazelle adds a layer of realism to his film that its influences lacked. Chazelle is not a strict traditionalist holding onto the past, he is a revolutionary, as John Legend's character Keith similarly tells Sebastian. Yes, there is a riveting opening number, a dance sequence that defies gravity, and charming duets between Mia and Sebastian, but there are also scenes when characters get fired from their jobs and decide to give up on their dreams: "Maybe I'm not good enough!… Maybe I'm one of those people that has always wanted to do it, but it's like a pipe dream for me," Mia laments to Sebastian. In a similar fashion, the film's ending reminds us of the fleeting nature of love. Due to this perfect blend of realism and surrealism, "La La Land" has a magic of its own. ("It's conflict and it's compromise, and it's very, very exciting!") It is a passionate ode to cinema made for and by "The Fools Who Dream" that precisely captures their tortured plight. "La La Land" is pure cinematic bliss.

La La Land is a 2016 musical directed by Damien Chazelle who also directed the 2018 film First Man. The film stars Emma Stone as Mia and Ryan Gosling as the jazz pianist Sebastian Wilder.

The story follows a women named Mia who wants to become a professional actress, and a man named Sebastian who wants to open his own jazz bar. The story I found to be quite predictable, but still gripping, especially in the third act.

The acting was also really strong, especially Emma Stone as Mia, I found that she portrayed the character really well and gave a gripping performance.

The worst aspect of the film for me was the characters, mostly because I found them to be quite bland and sometimes even unlikable, but luckily I can say that they weren't the worst characters I've ever seen.

The cinematography was also really strong and stylistic, with some great shots of the characters and scenery. My personal favourite shot was one toward the end of the film involving Sebastian playing the piano in a spot light.

The sets in my opinion were also one of the best aspects of the film, especially in the final scenes toward the end.

The style of the film I personally found to be incredibly strong and stylistic, from the colour scheme and cinematography, to the direction and music.

Speaking of music, this film in my opinion has a really good and vibrant soundtrack. The music was both written and played really well, especially the one song City of Stars.

The film also had some very strong atmosphere, especially in the third act with Sebastian and Mia.

The choreography in the film was also really strong, especially the opening scene with the song Another Day of Sun.

The film I also very much enjoyed, and I hope to watch it again soon.

I really wanted to love this film since I have been a serious fan of Hollywood musicals since I was a small child. However, I came away feeling that the sole reason to see this film is to bask in the amazing shots - it is truly a beautiful film. Lighting, staging, color and photography are all top notch, and sometimes transcendent. There is a regularly displayed love of the dolly shot through the film (though in today's tech-wizard film,making, I kept wondering if the oft-used fast-pan was a digital way of cutting between takes, or if it was an actual pan). Disappointingly, everything else gets in the way of the beauty that this film displays. I was surprised that awards were given out for the acting, as it seemed as lacking in depth as the painfully hackneyed plot. I couldn't sympathize with either character as they were both insufferable with no redeeming traits other than their attractiveness (which, to be fair, is commonly the case with struggling LA actors and musicians - but this isn't supposed to be a gritty reality film). I actively wanted their relationship to fail and I usually like silly romantic films (my fave film in the romantic genre is Somewhere in Time). This is a musical, but musicals require BIG songs that you keep humming as you leave the theater and that you want to hear again (think The Music Man, Oliver, West Side Story, Mary Poppins). However, the music in this film was either un-hummable jazz (yes, I do like jazz) or insipid, forgettable songs that I wanted to be over as fast as possible. The vocalists were adequate singers in a bland current-pop sort of way, but that's not how its done in musicals. They're working in a medium that gave us Garland, Minelli, Streisand, Kelly, Preston...these poor La La actors just don't rate.  But, oh - those visuals. They are so good that I kept watching to see what was next. So go to school on the photography and if you get into films because the actors are good to look at, you'll be extra happy.Just don't expect substance or the genuine feel of a Hollywood musical.

This is the sort of film that makes you detest musicals with how simultaneously twee and self important it is and the fact that the two leads can barely dance and sing. Damien Chazelle directed the very good Whiplash (2014) which explores the pressures of being an artist with dramatic flair but the other two films that he has directed that I have seen have been huge disappointments. This film was frustrating with it's nods to old Hollywood that felt perfunctory instead of feeling like a genuine tribute and it had the sort of half baked qualities that a film like The Artist (2011) possesses. This is not something that anybody should be clamoring to see and it is offensive to the brilliant Moonlight (2016) that this would ever be considered worthy competition to it.

Aspiring actress Mia, Emma Stone, tentatively begins a relationship with classical jazz aficionado Sebastian, Ryan Gosling, after they bond at a friend's party. Mia decides to write and perform in a one woman play to jump start her acting career and Sebastian joins a modern jazz band led by Keith, John Legend, who he rebels against as their musical tastes are opposed to his own. Their relationship begins to break down as their ambitions are completely different and their relationship would require a lot of commitment in order to last. They each attain career success but do not end up together and reminisce about the life they could have had when they see each other again years later.

From the opening scene of the film in which people in brightly colored clothing jump out of their cars, stuck in a traffic jam, to perform the lackluster song "Another Day of Sun" to jerky choreography I knew I hated this film. From this point the film only gets worse as the songs blend together and Stone's monotonous delivery of her lines leaves us rudderless without a charismatic leading lady. I was hoping throughout for some redemptive moment, something that I could pick out and argue in favor of the film for but I was left with nothing. Going into the film I knew that I was particularly tough on musicals, I can only name a few that I actually like, and I detest Stone as an actress but if I can love One from the Heart (1982) and The Favorite (2018) I thought I could tolerate these two elements to find a great film lurking underneath.

The success of a musical to me rests on the quality of the song and dance numbers and this film lacks any memorable tunes and the choreography is limited as the two lead actors can't dance. Even An American in Paris (1951), which is mostly Leslie Caron being awful and dull conversation, partially rescues itself with a magnificent final scene but the closest this film got to competence was using a cover of A-ha's "Take on Me" over the party scene. Gosling simply can't sing as he drawls all of the lines in his big song, "City of Stars", and Stone is unconvincing as a dancer or a singer which ruins the film considering the fact that she is lumped with most of the workload. The scene of the two of them dancing on the ceiling of the Griffith Conservatory could have been something beautiful but it is ruined by the scenes before and after it and only really works when divorced from the dislikable characters.

Stone's win for Best Actress is blasphemous as she beat out the far superior Isabelle Huppert in Elle (2016) and will now shamefully be placed in the same category as Jessica Lange and Elizabeth Taylor as an actress undeserving of an Academy Award. Gosling doesn't fare much better although he can give great dramatic performances and Legend's role, essentially a cameo, suits him well.

Go watch Gigi (1958) or Kiss Me Kate (1953) if you want an classic MGM musical that actually works but we would all be doing ourselves a favor if this overblown hit was left in the dust. Stone and the poorly written and performed songs tank the film immediately and not one redeemable scene can be found in the film's 128 minute length.

Hollywood sure loves Hollywood and any movie that celebrates itself. There is no happy ending, no memorably songs, or outstanding performances. I wouldn't say it was bad it is just easily forgotten. Ryan Gosling can't sing and Emma Stone is passable. They really should have found actors that could sing. The movie had no business being nominated for best picture. If you want something to pass the time without making you mad or really bringing out any emotion this is it. Again not a bad movie, just nothing special.

La La Land

Chazelle is on a strike. With successive jaw dropping projects coming out, his passion grows more intense and the cinema much larger. Coloring the 70mm screen with rich mesmeric visuals, the director, Damien Chazelle is boasting his love with proper understanding of the Hollywood culture that he so blindingly adores. Not an inch goes by in the film that looks pretentious, working over a year on editing along with Tom Cross, Chazelle wishes you to understand the "if's" and "but's" of this show business in one note. And boy what a note it is. I am sorry but that hooked theme of Justin Hurwitz, whispered in every line of the film always sobers me up.

All hail the production team for carving out this desert as fresh as it looks, from clothes to designing and from locations to set pieces, the view gets better and better and so does the performance. And daunting as this task may sound, but Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling might be the new Woody Allen and Diane Keaton. But unlike them they aren't quirky but are goofy about the relationship and flirty about their first love. If Stone going over the montages of failed auditions is a threat, then Gosling on piano is her equal competitor.

I have always preferred them alone, one is happy being stubborn and intuitive- something that she later on adapts from him- and other being mature and hard on herself. Together, they would fall apart, they are meant to be, no matter how in sync are they while dancing and how pitch perfect are they while singing, their rhythm is too vacuumed by the outer world to float in one room, maybe they should have just stayed in that cinema hall, but despite of claiming it to be a La La Land, this is the reality, they had to get out.
