After months of anticipation, "La La Land" has proven itself to be everything that I had hoped!  About 2 minutes into the opening tracking shot, I was obsessed.  The stunning introduction perfectly sets the mood of the story and introduces us to the Los Angeles setting.  This scene is easily my second favorite tracking shot of all time (next to "Atonement").  The film pays tribute to classic musicals of the 40's with its lengthy single-take dance sequences like the six-minute tap scene as they search for Stone's Prius.  As the film progresses, each scene is more ambitious than the last and the execution is consistently perfect.  Dancing among the stars in the planetarium, moving in regular motion among bodies in slow motion, an entire scene fading to black as a spotlight illuminates one character in the center of it - you can't even measure the production value of this well-conceived tribute to the Hollywood musical.  Though a lot of stylized films miss the mark, this one hits the bullseye.  I often grow frustrated with modern movie musicals whose songs are forgotten before even walking out of the theater.  Days after seeing this film, I can clearly recall Justin Hurwitz's simple musical themes that stick with you far beyond the closing credits.   "La La Land" is a true musical triumph, and the genre of choice is jazz.  Much like in 2014's "Whiplash," director Damien Chazelle has found a way to make jazz accessible to modern audiences.  Ryan Gosling's monologue about jazz pinpoints the experience of hearing it live and reflects the passion of true jazz fans; meanwhile the jazz-infused musical theater songs keep the thematic genre at the center of the film.  In a weak Oscar class, "La La Land" soars beyond the competition and is a shoe-in for Best Picture (unless the culturally relevant statements of "Moonlight" manage to steal it away).  While many of the technical aspects make the film shine, its heart lies in its believable characters.  Emma Stone delivers her most impassioned performance since "Birdman" with her phone audition and I believe that she has the Oscar in the bag.  Her singing has a soft, light quality that properly suits her character and her chemistry with Gosling drives the film from musical number to musical number.  I also appreciate that Gosling did all of his own piano playing for this film, which adds to the realism of his character.  The casting of John Legend was really clever in that it incorporated a pop culture icon who sings with excellent vocal technique.  I believe that the screenplay will win an Oscar, though I would have enjoyed a little more humor.  I can also see it winning Oscars for Director, Cinematography, Film Editing, and Score.  My main complaint about the film is its ending, which reflects Hollywood ideals over what we would expect to happen.  I'm still worked up about it, though this emotional response is a testament to its effectiveness.  "La La Land" is the complete package.  It is destined to win several of the technical Oscar categories and is the only film that will leave me shocked if it does not win Best Picture.  If you haven't seen this one yet, you need to.  Now.
It deserves some awards, but it definitely is a lot of hype. Acting is average. Interesting story with good cinematography.

Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone co-star in Damien Chazelle's written and directed film, LA LA Land. Stone is Mia, a barista that is auditioning at every chance she can hoping to make it big as an actress. Gosling is Sebastian, a musician with dreams of grandeur who hopes to own his own Jazz club. If this does not sum up La and the millions that live there not much else will. The film does not have much plot beyond the blooming romance between the two leads, and their aspirations to make it big.

There is no question that musicals do not come along as frequently as they used to and amazing ones such as West Side Story and Sound of Music are even more uncommon. It is quite clear that Hollywood is still clamoring for this genre to remain afloat and do well as nearly any musical made anymore is Oscar nominated and this one is no exception.  If there was any doubt from the trailers that LA LA Land was a musical, the film does not waste a second and it instantly opens up with a musical interlude of people singing and dancing as they sit in rush hour traffic. The two leads are seen and interact rudely, but it is clear they do not know each other. We soon learn that Emma Stone is a barista that is going through auditions and she is one of the countless others that hopes to become an actress. After a few songs and moments there is a shift to Gosling's character. He is a struggling pianist that has strong love and interest in Jazz and only wants to associate with those who share this feeling. He dreams of opening his own club to prove that Jazz is not a dying art form. He stands in his own way and despite his talent he finds himself only doing gigs he believes are beneath him. After his introduction, the two randomly encounter again, without much progress. Apparently, LA is not so big after all since only during a third encounter 30 minutes into the film do we get a character name and a budding romance.

A great musical uses song to embellish the feelings of characters while simultaneously drives the plot forward in an artistic manor. This film fails to do this, as most of the songs seem as if they are placed to remind you that indeed this is a musical so let's insert a song here why not. None of the songs are particularly memorable and there is not much choreography aside from assuring that the two main characters move in unison. One of best scenes of the film is when a friend convinces Goslings character that that Jazz is dying. The reason for this is that those who love it are holding onto the traditional greats (Monk, Powell, Parker) and advancement of the great music must come from letting the music evolve and not cling to the traditional sound. His agreement to let himself go and become a successful sellout was an interesting comment. 

As the film goes on, it becomes more clear that what LA LA Land is trying to accomplish more so than anything else is be a microcosm of the modern LA. Text must be used to tell and remind the audience the time of year and its season because it is always Sunny in LA. The beginning of the film is like a new comer to LA, as there is the glitz, glamour, bright and vivid colors, song, dance, and plenty of history to go around. Once the charm wears off, behind it all there are simply just people with normal jobs struggling and hoping it to make it big. Through this struggle there is always doubt and moments of despair. Under this limelight, I began to enjoy the film significantly.  If, however this was indeed the film's intent, then more commentary on the people only talking with each other to better their chances for success would be warranted. Indication that even great talent or hope does not lead to success would have been more welcome than the happy go lucky traditional ending. LA LA land seduces you into believing it is a great musical and although I was entertained, it is clearly not to the extent that movie critics and Hollywood itself was.

After watching the movie, I was walking home and just turning over the movie in my mind. I felt as though there was something missing. But what was it? What brought the movie down? And all this thinking made me realise something. Damien Chazelle is an artist. No ordinary artist, he's categorised into the ever-lasting genius section. The movie kept me captivated all throughout, so there was no time to check my phone. To be honest, I didn't even realise that I needed to urgently pee until after the movie. The whole choreography of the movie had me utterly speechless. Chazelle's use of one-takes (long shots) are impeccable. You see, long shots are usually boring (for example, watch Birdman, the movie that's infamously known to have no jump cuts), but in every scene there was just something interesting happening, whether it be in the background, or just the facial expressions of the extremely talented Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling. I applaud both the stars on their dedication to learn such difficult parts and making the characters simply flow on screen. Gosling had to learn piano and the style of waltz while Stone's on screen appearance makes any movie worth the watch. The musical numbers were beautiful and unique, each too beautiful to forget. I'm humming the songs as I'm writing this! Hats off to Justin Hurwitz for the wondrous soundtrack. For me, however, what makes a movie is the way the story is told, and La La Land is like no other when it comes to this. If you strip the whole movie down, it's a simple boy-meets-girl love story. But once you add the lighting, music, dancing, special effects etc. you're caught up in this world of make-believe that you, oh so wish was real. It leaves you with a goofy feeling in your heart that maybe everything will be okay one day. You start singing like Mia (Emma Stone), and dancing like Sebastian (Ryan Gosling), which made me mad, of course, as I'm good at neither. And so, zooming in to me as I'm walking home, I realised that there was nothing missing from this movie. It left me mesmerised, yet mad. How can a movie be so great? It can be, and La La Land is.

As a whole La La Land was a captivating sensory adventure that was pleasing from start to finish.

La La Land is one of best reviewed, most lauded, and most loved movies of 2016. It has already won several awards and is very likely to win more. It received 14 Oscar nominations, tying the record set by All About Eve (1950), though All About Eve's 14 nominations was done with fewer categories, which seems slightly more impressive. La La Land is the front runner to take home the Best Picture Oscar. Let's get one thing straight: I like La La Land. I might even really like it, but I did not love it, at least not the way everyone else did. 

The plot is simple enough: Struggling jazz pianist Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) meets and falls for aspiring actress Mia (Emma Stone). Together they sing and dance through some of the loveliest scenes of Los Angeles on film. This is a side of L.A. not often seen movies. The center of American filmmaking is most often the setting of action and crime movies or it is meant to be a nonintrusive background. In La La Land, Los Angeles is stylized and romanticized. It is a city of purple sunsets, cool, blue nights, and hills and canyons and highways for song and dance numbers. I would not say that Los Angeles is a character because sets aren't characters, but it is at the forefront of La La Land. 

It's no surprise that Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone have good chemistry; this is their third movie together after all. Each does a fine job in their respective roles. They sing and dance well enough, though they sing and dance like nonprofessionals that have been taught specific, not too challenging choreography. Each has a signature song: Sebastian has the melancholy "City of Stars" and Mia's "Audition (The Fools Who Dream)" serves as the film's climax. Both songs have been nominated for the Original Song Oscar.


La La Land takes place in a daydream world and writer-director Damien Chazelle seeks to transport the audience to this wonderful musical world. He succeeds, to a point. La La Land is meant to be a loving, enthusiastic tribute to the musicals of the 1950's and 40's. The misstep it makes is this: instead of taking inspiration from the great musicals of the past to create a new, fresh take, it simply lifts from and imitates those films instead. Action and science fiction are the genres most often criticized for being derivative, but musicals can be derivative too. There are numerous visual references to other musicals (enough for a side by side video comparison). Some are indirect: the bold, bright color pallet of costumes and sets is reminiscent of the musicals of Jacques Demy. Others are more direct: Gosling jumps up on a lamppost just like Gene Kelly in Singin' in the Rain. Unfortunately, since I've already seen most of the movies La La Land references (Jacques Demy's Umbrellas of Cherourg, Young Girls of Rochefort; Fred Astaire musicals: Shall We Dance, The Band Wagon, Funny Face; and, most of all, Singin' in the Rain, An American in Paris, and every other Gene Kelly musical), subtly and not so subtly, it comes off less as a tribute and more as a hollow imitation.

There's a lot to like in La La Land. It's a nice story about aspiring performers falling in love and trying to achieve their dreams. From the pink and purple sunsets to Stone's bright, yellow dress, La La Land is filled with bold and vibrant solid colors that cannot help but catch the eye. The songs are pleasant and enjoyable, even if you don't like jazz (and I don't). Some of the musicals numbers are very visually appealing-I'm thinking of Sebastian and Mia's dance at the observatory specifically-but others never open up to be as grand as I was expecting. The opening number plays like generic tableau of what someone that hasn't seen a musical thinks a musical is like. I suppose I just can't help but be reminded of the classic musicals with undeniably better performers and songs and wonder why I'm not just watching one of those again. I didn't get the feeling of unabashed joy and love and wonder that I get whenever I watch Truffaut's Day For Night, Gene Kelly's Singin' in the Rain, or even Cameron Crowe's Almost Famous (all about performers in the entertainment business). But still, I enjoyed this movie.

The music was uninspiring and depressing. There are a few great visual spectacles, like the opening freeway dance number and the swimming pool swirl number. The dancing is forgettable and the lead actors singing is worse.

I'm giving 1.5 stars only because I was blown away by the opening number filmed on an actually freeway in Los Angeles. The music, the dancing, the direction, the photography, top notch! Moments like Emma Stone auditioning for roles I found to be quite funny (although my wife didn't get it at all) considering I'm in film and I have been in those rooms. But what made for a great opening sequence was quickly followed up with great direction around a very cliched filled script that was telegraphed the moment we saw the coffee shop scene in the first act. I didn't care about the main characters falling in love, I didn't care about the songs they sang, and I didn't care where they ended up at all. I didn't cry at the last montage sequence before the end and I just saw massive flaws of logic in character developments. This again is a film where Hollywood celebrates itself even tho no one actually cares about films these days (especially because of Netflix). This being a fantasy film about love really plays up the fantasy when they're "filming a big movie on the Warner Bros. lot." La La Land did so many things right, not just right but great, it makes the lacking story such a disappointment. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling were top notch and carried this movie through to the end. The music was so good I even created a playlist to revisit it again and again (I mean it's jazz, so good). I was in awe of the cinematography but this is much to be expected from Damien Chazelle as his previous works are all cinematography masterpieces. 

This leads us to the story I found it hard to put into words exactly why the story was so lacking and disjointed from how great everything else about the movie was. I have been reading both the highest praises and lowest blows given to this movie and none of them mention the story or more importantly the relationship between Emma Stone's Mia and Ryan Gosling's Sebastian. The setup is great, struggling actress meets struggling artist over and over and they seemingly fall in love. Only their career aspirations and dreams of the future pull them apart. Tragic right? Well, the tragic moments seem to be unending and this is where the story jumps the rails. While their love seemed real there is a fatal turning point where Emma basically squashing Ryan's dream and encourages him to go against his own desires (The only motivation for this moment appears to be to move the plot along, it felt so disingenuous to the characters). When Emma is presented with Ryan's feelings she flip-flops and blames Ryan All the while Ryan's love for Emma keeps him pushing Emma to achieve her dream to which she was all too willing to give up on. This all seems very anti-woman, it portrays them both as having weak character but it shades Emma's character as the weaker of the two. Even in the end, it hits her when she is already down. As if the audience didn't already think this movie was a tragedy it doubles down. Not only could they have the career aspirations they both sought so highly after, enough to disregard the love they had for each other, but if they just would have stuck it out it would have ended in beautiful bliss by giving them their hard earned cake and letting them eat it too. The tragedy already portrayed before the ending of the film was enough for this 'reveal' at the ending to not move me at all. I was happy to see the credits so I could go download the soundtrack and move on.

Clearly outclassing many films left and right, this was a lovely trip. A musical that doesn't rub the format in your face. So, imagine an alternate Big Bang Theory universe in which Penny, instead of moving across the hall from Sheldon and future nerd hubby Leonard, moves in with three other struggling actresses across town where she works as a barista instead of a waitress while unfruitfully pursuing her unsuccessful film career. And she sings and dances a lot more. And falls for a more jazzy, less nerdy, ivory-tickling version of Howard. Who sings and dances a lot more, too.

Got that in mind? Welcome to "La La Land" - the land where a superfluously Hollywood-driven, self-indulgent musical nostalgically meanders over 120+ minutes en route to its Best Picture nomination which, if it wins, I predict will be this generation's "The Greatest Show on Earth" or "Gigi."

La La Land is a heartfelt, upbeat romantic musical.

The plot revolves around a struggling actress (Emma Stone) and a struggling pianist (Ryan Gosling) who meet and fall in love. Both of these roles are played very well, and the stars have great chemistry.

This movie is essentially a tribute to a bygone era. It is in the style of the movie musicals of the thirties and forties, with similar music, choreography, and a similarly upbeat story. There is a clear love for the movies and music of old on display here. It is evident that the writer and director is passionate about these things, especially since his last film, Whiplash, is also about jazz.

The musical numbers are very well done, with well written dialogue and excellent choreography. There is also a very heartwarming love story to go along with these performances. The tone of the movie is very happy and colorful throughout.

I am not putting as much effort into this review as many of my others, since you've probably already heard a lot about it, considering it has swept the Oscar nominations. But I'm just going to write that it is a fun, uplifting film with heart. If you want to feel good at the movie, I recommend this one.

Amid its multiple nominations and awards, I was keen to make it to the cinema to see La La Land, although wasn't quite sure what to expect. Its an interesting film, with what in essence is a typical romantic story-line at its core. What sets it aside is the incredibly clever production that layers this basic storyline. The musical element is inspired, and does well not to overwhelm the movie, whilst the somewhat retro filter that seems to be across each shot works well. The soundtrack is great, as is the gradual conclusion of the movie. Inevitably going to divide opinions, although deservedly winning awards, and should be looked at for what it is - a romantic tale, and a very good one at that.

La La Land, with its 'feel good' aura and solemn twists has breathed new life into the musical genre, which has long needed fresh vitality.

Gosling and Stone are sensational from start to finish, with their charming performances and wonderful musical deliverance. This is a musical that packs a punch, both in terms of engrossing the viewer and creating an atmosphere and tone. 

The cinematography of La La Land is exceptional. The colourful vibe is consistent throughout and toned down where appropriate. Director Damien Chazelle has co-ordinated this sequence of song, dance and realism perfectly. 

The thought of a musical may deter many, but La La Land is the musical without the cliches and cheese. It may well have altered the genre forever.

La historia: dos perdedores que sueñan con hacerla en grande en Hollywood, Mia (Emma Stone) aspirante a actriz sin éxito y Sebastian (Ryan Goslin) un músico de jazz desempleado que se encuentran en una fiesta y se enamoran, pero ¿cuánto puede durar ese amor cuando lo que siempre han soñado se vuelve realidad?
Lo bueno: la manera tan acertada en que Damien Chazalle toma temas actuales como el desempleo, la frustración, la presión por ser alguien y ser exitoso y los transforma en un clásico musical americano, lleno de nostalgia y bailes de salón y tap (hace demasiado tiempo que no veía tap en una película), referencias a grandes películas del género como Dancing in the Rain o New York New York; creando una fantasía elegante y cruel a la ves. El guion sencillo pero efectivo nos lleva de la comedia romántica rosa hasta le melodrama, cerrando con un maravilloso epilogo musical espectacular.
Mención aparte es la fotografía y el diseño de producción, los dos perfectos y hermosamente cuidados. La fotografía limpia, saturada de color, recreando ese tecnicolor de los años 40's, con el uso seguido de grandes angulares para darle un aire de Cinamascope a toda la cinta (como te lo anuncian en el primer segundo de la película). Y el diseño de producción en donde los colores solidos son los importantes: amarillos, rojos y verdes para Mia reflejando energía de una joven aspirante a actriz , lo colores ocres, tierra, negros y dorados para Sebastian con la calma de la edad, de la espera y de la frustración..
Pero toda esta maravilla no podría lucir sin el par de actores protagonistas, que hacen un trabajo excelente. Emma Stone destilando energía y vulnerabilidad y Ryan Goslin tranquilo, calmado, lleno de pasión. Lo malo: no hay nada malo con esta gran cinta.
En conclusión esta película es una joya del cine contemporáneo, recordándonos el pasado pero siempre mirando al futuro, llena de romance, música y baile.

This movie was excellent and a throw back to the day of Rogers and Astair. Truly an escape from the rigors of life until the end. I left deeply disappointed in the ending, but I guess that's life. Then again I don't go to the movies for like. I dinged it 1/2 of a star for the ending.

The movie itself is beautifully shot and is able to equally ground us in reality all while pulling us into this nostalgic world of 50?s inspired film aspects. The contrast of brightly colored clothing against the everyday backdrop of Hollywood is beautifully done. The acting was fine but I found nothing overly exceptional about it. What really pulls you into this movie are the colors, music, dance and inspiration from similar films in the 50?s. How Chazelle uses these pulls from reality into this solitary world of just Mia and Sebastian to relate them and develop their love is stunning, everything was purposefully shot to mimic and older way films were shot. I was never bored or wondering how much of the film was left. By the end of the film when Mia and Sebastian see each other for the last time and the movie drives through an alternate world where the two end up together and both have their dreams all while still having each other, you also feel the heartache and conflict that the characters feel. You know they could have been but the world isn't perfect and not everything aligns that way.

4.5* Very charming, nice jazz numbers, a direction without effort, amazing cast, stunning cinematography. It's hard not to like this movie... There is so much magic in this film, beyond expectation.
La La Land pays homage to classic movie musicals. Not only does it visually allude to films such as Singin' in the Rain and The Band Wagon, but it also preserves the upbeat, wondrous tone of those classics. There is something wonderful about seeing this tone and style recreated for a modern film. Cynicism and pretentiousness are completely absent from this film, and nostalgia and joy take their place. Anyway, I guess that's what cinemas are made for... ;-)

La La Land is one of those films that Hollywood makes every year as a love letter to itself. However, shameless Oscar-bait aside, La La Land is charming, well-made and fun enough that it's hard enough to care; especially with one hell of an ending. A stage adaptation is most likely in the works.

Ah La la land! The darling of the Golden Globes! The soon to be darling of the Oscars! The return to a golden age of movie making and complete escapism for over two hours with strong performances, great visuals and a cracking script! Was all this true? Could a movie be a homage to this almost forgotten era of the musical yet still hold enough originality to be taken seriously on its own merit?
The answers to these questions is, on the whole, an emphatic yes!
This movie written and directed by Academy Award nominee Damien Chazelle, (of Whiplash fame), tells the story of Mia, an aspiring actress (played by Emma Stone) and Seb, a jazz musician (played by Ryan Gosling) and their struggles with their art, love and life in the City of Angels.
The movie is played out in "old school" musical style for the most part, resembling an old Gene Kelly movie, with infectious tunes and fantastic choreography added to the colourful backdrop that is L.A.
Stone and Gosling are excellent too in their respective roles with their on screen chemistry is electric and both well deserved their Oscar nominations for their roles in this film.
Overall, for the colour, music, dance and drama on show this is highly entertaining escapism at its finest which the Academy will surety reward significantly come Oscar night!

Truly charming and magical.  It's been awhile since we've had an original film that celebrates the joy of love and the arts.  It's not for everyone, but the spectacle, romance, and beautiful music in this film was made for someone like me.

A Trilha Sonora é boa, com destaque para "City of Stars".

Best film I've seen in 2017 so far! (I know the year just started but I didn't get a chance to see it in 2016!)  Here are the reasons why this movie is so fantastic.
CHARACTERS:  The characters in this movie are so amazing and well developed.  The two leads have such amazing chemistry, and that's what really carries the movie.
MUSIC:  There are so many great songs and music in here as well.  It has just the right amount of singing and dialogue.  My personal favorite is "Another Day of Sun".
COSTUMES:  We have a bright and beautiful display of color in this film, especially with the costumes.  That will be just as iconic as everything else in this movie!
THE ENDING:  That ending though, I was pleasantly surprised with it.  Even so, it's the most satisfied I've ever felt in a finale.  I honestly don't want another one because of how great that ending is.
     So, I would highly recommend this film to anyone who loves classic musical films!!!!

I have seen La La Land 5 times now in the theatres and every time I leave completely fulfilled yet a little empty. The ending is obviously not the optimal ending but it still fit the story beautifully. The whole theme of dreams and making them come true well told by both main character's story lines. I especially appreciated the cinematography with the primary colour pallet and the blurry spinning/montages make you feel like you were truly in a dream.  Although this is a "musical" many of the numbers seemed like you were watching a set with staged singing and dancing (similar to Glee) rather than spontaneous real life singing. Epilogue and Planetarium were so perfectly orchestrated that they seemed as if someone was dreaming them perfectly, compared to Another Day of Sun or City of Stars with the more classic spontaneous songs and choreographed dances. Every time I walked out of the theatre I felt like I had just gone to a museum and soaked up the art of hundreds of separate artists. God I love this movie.
This movie was absolutely breathtaking, it goes against the usual "Hollywood ending". And depicts how ones actual life is full of failures and disappointments, as well as magical moments.

La La Land is a great film in many ways. The story might be sub par, but the filmmaking/cinematography has got to be some of the best Hollywood has seen in this genre for a while. You notice every color on the screen at once; they are all so vibrant and go together so well, especially in the scene with Mia and her roommates getting ready for a huge party. Not only the colors, but the camera angles are superb. In many movies, you are left wishing you could see a close-up at one specific point or a different point of view during an emotional scene, but the filming and editing of La La Land captures all of the important emotion its audience needs. Overall, although lacking in its storyline, La La Land leaves its viewers in awe for reasons beyond the romance Stone and Gosling portray in the film.

One of the things that makes Singin' in the Rain such a great movie is that it exudes joy. You can't help but smile while you're watching. And this is about as close as you get to that in a modern movie. It's not really a musical in the traditional sense, and that's fine. And it's not always sunshine and rainbows - there are some real gut punches in the last 30 minutes. But it's as engrossing and emotionally moving as any movie I've seen in recent years. I was a little worried that the second half wouldn't be able to keep up the momentum after the main characters get together, but it works. Emma Stone is so good in this. It would be well deserved if she wins an Academy Award. Go see La La Land!

This is not a bad movie by any means - it's just not very good. Sure, it might captivate the audience of those who get sucked into hype and pretty colors and Ryan Gosling, but nobody seems to see past all of that into the true dictation of the film, and that's where all the mistakes lie. Sloppy dancing, poor continuity, heavily edited vocals, and let's not forget the stains on the plot. For starters, is everybody really going to gloss over the fact that Mia was fully prepared to cheat on her boyfriend, Greg? She'd been seeing this poor guy for a month, AND he'd invited her to dinner with his brother (a dinner that she "forgot" about), so he clearly was trying to get serious with her. Maybe it would've been easier to watch if the movie portrayed him as a jerk, but he was a really nice and understanding character for the ten seconds that we saw him. And what does Mia do? Bails on him the second that she hears that awful song playing over the speakers of the restaurant. Doesn't even give him an explanation, just says 'I'm sorry' and runs out smiling from ear to ear. Seriously Mia? Did you have to be a jerk about it? Don't you owe poor Greg enough to at least TELL him that you're going to go hang out with Ryan Gosling instead of him? Goodness gracious, what a dirtbag. 
Next we've got Keith. Who is he? Nobody knows until a little past the halfway mark in the film. We don't know who he is, but we sure do see him. Summer montage, as Mia and Ryan Gosling (can't even remember his character's name...it's like he wasn't even playing a character, he was just playing Ryan Gosling for 2 hours. He got a Golden Globe and an Oscar nomination for literally just being himself.) were frolicking around 'falling in love' and doing cliche things like kissing on trains and walking down the street together (where were they walking to? why were on they on a train? nobody knows, because there was cliche jazz music playing the whole time, like they've got to shove in our face every six minutes that HEY THIS IS A JAZZ MUSICAL IN CASE YOU DIDNT GET IT DID YOU GET IT IT'S JAZZ I'M SO ORIGINAL GAHHH. Anyway, so during this summer montage, they show a five second clip and Mia and Ryan meeting John Legend and his fiance as they show them their engagement rings, so I'm sitting there thinking 'how does Mia and Ryan randomly know John Legend?' and then BOOM! He comes back 10 minutes later as some guy named Keith who is complete strangers to Mia, even though she JUST SAW HIM AND HIS FIANCE. And then Mr. Keith / John Legend looks at Ryan and is like 'I haven't seen you in years' EVEN THOUGH THEY JUST SAW EACH OTHER THAT SUMMER. What...even...did this film not have editors...did nobody question this...what... 
And let's not forget about the total Birdman move Damien Chazelle tried to pull, doing the whole "take this scene in one take" thing. Here's the thing though: you can't just do that whenever you want. You can't pick out random scenes throughout the movie to do in one take, and then do normal film cuts for the rest of the movie. Birdman was taken in one complete take; that's why it was phenomenal. You have to have continuity in your film shots, but clearly Damien Chazelle threw that out the window.  He should'nt have switched back and forth for the shots, he should've just stuck with one and gone with it. If he had, I would have a lot more hair on my head. 
For some clarification, I don't hate Damien Chazelle (Whiplash is one of my favorite movies) I just don't like this movie. Maybe it's because there's so many mistakes with it that everybody's overlooking, maybe because it's overhyped, but this movie just makes me so angry. It had so much potential that got thrown in the garbage because of poor script editing, film cuts, music choices (most of their songs used the same cliche chord progressions and motifs of most amateur Broadway productions, not the good ones) and casting. If you're making a musical, you need actors who can sing and dance. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling are both talented actors, and Ryan Gosling is a talented musician (when he's singing out of his throat like in Blue Valentine, not when he's singing out of his nose), but this movie would've been 10x better if it had better casting choices. I mean come on, JK Simmons was in here and he had 3 minutes of screen time. Why would you waste JK Simmons in an insignificant role when you could've literally picked anybody off the streets of LA and gotten them to do it? JK Simmons is too talented to be given such an insignificant role. 
I know I've got a ton more to write, but I don't know if there's a word limit on these sort of things...

If they are playing for nostalgia, then great, but honestly there are better movies out there right now.

La La Land is a good, but far from a great movie. I understand its vast appeal, but to me it was so problematic in so many areas that it baffled me why not enough people realize that. The film is very charming and its first half is actually great, Ryan Gosling and especially Emma Stone gave remarkable performances, the ending is certainly something special, some scenes are quite romantic and I really liked some of its songs with Someone in the Crowd being my favorite, but City of Stars and Audition are overrated, dull and bland numbers that I really disliked, the cinematography is frequently quite poor and the film feels unnecessarily nostalgic in its various homages. But the biggest offender is the main character. The film managed to get around the fact that she is such a horrible human being and that is why most people just did not see that and she basically ruined his life when you thoroughly think about it. There are people like that in the world and they need to be portrayed on the big screen, but the film is problematic as it took her side and thus became a sexist movie that should leave men offended. That led to their relationship being more toxic than truly beautiful.

My critic quote: La La Land is all love and music wrapped into one artistic film.

What I loved: 1. The colors and lighting - Mia and her roommates' dresses red-blue-yellow-green combination sold me onto the movie from the start. Mia's blue dress against the red glow of the Lipton Bar when she meets Seb is such a wonderful shot. In fact, all of Mia's dresses are fantastic in their own way; I don't remember a scene without her wearing one! In the dream sequence towards the end, the white with the 2D drawings was a really unique choice to match the characters. A few moments later, the black/white contrast of Mia and Seb's outfits keeps the movie holding on to its "classical" roots. 
2. The piano - The music of the film is very memorable and emotional. "City of Stars" and the number that entrances Mia into the bar for the first time were my favorite pieces. Ryan Gosling did a really good job learning piano so quickly; the hard work really shows!
3. Emma Stone - Her conversations, her silly dancing, her smile and laugh, and her frustration with the auditions all included in this film made it wonderful. She has a natural charm!
4. The stars - All throughout the film, stars are everywhere--in the making, in the sky, in the observatory, on the set-- living up to the song "City of Stars".
5. The conflict - Mia and Seb struggle in achieving their dreams and keeping up a healthy relationship much like everyday people do. They faced lots of failure and frustration in the journey to their dreams. LIke Seb says about jazz, "It's about conflict and compromise": the road to the emerald city might not be without some obstacles. In their relationship argument, I felt like I had been there before: seeing the problems, responding to the issues in the same way. Both of these topics 
6. The ending - No spoilers!

What was iffy: 1. John Legend - Don't get me wrong, John Legend makes great music but seeing him in the film made me think it was some kind of commercial. I couldn't take it super seriously.
2. "Jazz revival" - After lots of thought, I've decided that if there were to be a movie about the heart and soul of jazz (similar to the attraction Seb feels for it), the main character would most likely be black, since African-Americans blended the genre into the music we love today. But, it's good that others are inspired by the music as well.
3. The camera swoops - The camera spinning slowly and quickly and the swooping back and forth on two different areas of the set really hurt my eyes. I had flashbacks to the Hunger Games when Katniss and Clove fight at the cornucopia-- just the camera rolling and shaking all over.
4. Seb's name - I only realized what Ryan Gosling's character's name was once Mia shows him the design for the club. This seems to be a common theme in new movies, since I found myself struggling with names while watching Rogue One, The Crown, and Fantastic Beasts.
5. Length - The 2h30min was a long time for me to sit comfortably in my chair. In my opinion, it could have been whittled down to 2 hours.

Director Damien Chazelle, brings us a story that is not a masterpiece nor original in any way. It is in fact, following the same old, but perfect Hollywood formula, almost to point of sucking up to it. But if this movie is so painfully repetitive, how does Damien Chazelle manages to take our senses and feelings into such a warm and joyful ride? La La Land may be one of the most cliched movies you will ever see, but that does not take away how magical, passionate, and immersive it manages to be.

There are doubts about La La Land's contribution as a story, but there is definitely nothing to doubt about the brilliant acting of Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling. There is a beautiful chemistry that happens between these two main characters. Emma Stone shows us a side of her we did not know, she shows us the great actress we have always known she could be. And in those few moments, where she is able to go all out as an actress, she leaves us speechless.

The music is not just good, it is beautiful. What more can you expect from Justin Hurwitz, the mind behind the score of Whiplash? Key moments in the film are unforgettable thanks to the music score. This, along the production and costume design, set the heartwarming and magical tone of the movie, all through its devastating yet hopeful ending.

Thinking back on the film, it is impossible to understand how anyone can be so engrossed by a story like this, including myself. Luckily, there is so much more to a film than the story. Acting, cinematography, costume and production design, and music are just some of the main areas where Damien Chazelle manages to bring out this musical to the surface, captivating everyone's attention, and making you forget about the fact that you've already seen this Hollywood story a thousand times.

Not necessarily the absolute best picture of the year, but it was a pretty good film with a very talented ensemble and original concept; however, it is a film that you need to be fully energized to see.

First of all, the movie was a spectacular experience in the theater; it's one of those films released these days that is best to experience with a captive audience. The music and choreography is also top-notch. Though it takes a while to get going, the flick's messages of fantasy versus reality and the significance of movies and music (in this case jazz) really ring true. Whereas Ryan Gosling's performance was fine and acceptable (though not too far outside his wheelhouse), I thought the real showstopper was Emma Stone, who really got to imbue her character with strength and poise through all of the ups and downs of her quest. While the pair plays off each other nicely with their sarcastic barbs volleyed to-and-fro, the romance seemed a little one-sided to me (where Mia was more in love with Sebastian than he was with her). For me, because the character she portrayed was more relatable than Gosling's, her character's story was a lot more engrossing to see than his. Unfortunately, the film's greatest weakness (and what holds it back from being an outstanding movie overall) is its failure to commit to, and in some cases contradicting, its themes. During much of the film, the idea of reaching your dreams by building something new instead of succumbing to the easy way out, but certain occurrences in the story feel like they are counteracting against this idea. In addition, the HUGE Sequence - I won't go any further into it to avoid spoiling it here - ends up undermining the the events [that wrap up the story with a bow] themselves AND their intent, in my opinion. In conclusion, this shortcoming keeps it from being one of the top movies of 2016 for me; still, I almost thoroughly enjoyed the film while I was watching it.

Having waited a year since its original release before I finally saw it meant that I could watch it without the typical Oscars hype that surrounded it. And frankly, I just don't get what the hype was all about.

The story is a somewhat muddled tale of a struggling actress and a jazz musician who fall in love, though they struggle to keep things together as they chase their dreams. Now, a plain story like this can usually be dressed up in a musical with flashy singing and dancing - neither of which are present here. The songs are repetitive, as it turns out that listening to the exact same chord progression repeated for two hours can become a bit tedious; and Stone and Gosling's "singing-in-the-shower" warbles certainly didn't dazzle this viewer. In fact, their restrained musical performances are an embarassment to the resplendant costumes and sets that surround them.

What's worst, however, is that its potential did shine through. There are two or three dramatic scenes between Stone and Gosling that are so well written and brilliantly acted, they genuinely show up the mediocrity of the rest. It's not a bad film, by any standards, just very painfully and shamefully average.

Finally, I watch enough Strictly Come Dancing to be irked by the poor shaping of Emma Stone's hands during her final musical number with Ryan Gosling. But that's being quite picky, isn't it?

LA LA LAND-2016(PG-13)-Feb. 4.
By:Clem The Movie Guy.

Los Angeles is legendary as a city where people come to make a name for themselves in film & music, a perception that sometimes is draped in the illusion that anyone with real talent finds instant success. La La Land is a modern day musical love story of two people pursuing their dreams in Hollywood. Emma Stone plays Mia Dolan, an aspiring actress attempting to fulfill her passion while working as a barista on a studio lot & making the grinding rounds of casting calls. Sebastian Wilder (Ryan Gosling), is a struggling jazz pianist  looking to fulfill his dream to open his own old-school jazz club, only to find himself playing popular music in clubs, at dinner parties & a variety of other paying gigs. When Mia & Sebastian fall for each other, the young couple's fairy tale romance is tested by the harsher aspects of the struggles to achieve their individual goals. La La Land is written & directed by Damien Chazelle, the acclaimed filmmaker behind Whiplash (my best film of 2014.)  Chazelle has made a magical, enchanting film story with stunning costumes & set pieces & engaging characters throughout the film reminiscent of the old-time Hollywood musicals. The musical numbers were exciting & boldly whimsical with each smooth transition from one number to the next. The performances from Emma Stone & Ryan Gosling were excellent & both of them have that classic Hollywood actor style. The winner of seven Golden Globe Awards, La La Land has been nominated for 14 Academy Awards including Best Picture, Best Director & Best Original Screenplay, Best Actress (Emma Stone), & Best Actor (Ryan Gosling. If you enjoy watching old-school musicals (1930's, 40's & 50's) then La La Land is a movie musical worth seeing.
Loved it; it made me cry!

The movie seemed very "slow" in the beginning, but the pace picked up. This film falls in the category of "see-it-soon" before all the hype and media attention creates expectations that are too high for what you actually get .......  I enjoyed it but expected more (if that makes sense).  I would really like to know how long they practiced and then how long it actually took to shoot the opening scene on the grid-locked freeway.

I was going into this movie expecting one of two outcomes. 1: loving this movie and calling it my favorite movie of the year. 2: Liking the movie, but not quite as much as everyone else seems to be living it. The result was completely different.

I was extremely disappointed in this movie, wishing I saw a different movie instead. I can understand why some people might love this movie. It starts exceptionally well. However, when the relationship starts between Gosling and Stones characters, it made absolutely no sense to me. All the musical/dancing numbers were executed quite well, and were the best part of the movie. However, without the movie making me believe in the love story from the get go, made the rest of the movie very lackluster.

*****May contain spoilers******

La la land is a poorly written fantasy relationship/hollywood dreams drama that was vomited on by a horrifically choreographed musical. It's way too long and unevenful, both hours dragged on forever and no one did anything. It was vomit inducing, starting with the very first scene with people singing and leaping off cars in traffic and then ending with a scene that I can only assume is tragically sad to viewers who like unrealistic happy endings. Definitely a movie for unrealistic dreamers, mainstream moviegoers, and the hopeless romantics. This movie wants to be a classic musical/love story about people trying to make it in hollywood. Unfortunately it comes out looking more like an unrehearsed highschool play.

It could have been a good, relatable movie if only they changed everything about it, added a plot, and took out the singing and dancing. Ryan doesn't come off as a jazz musician at all and Emma, unbelievably so, couldn't pull off a role about an actress. They both can't sing and their strange dance together was cringeworthy. This was like watching people with no chemistry read a script for the first time, each scene is just more tense, stiff acting that is unbearable to watch. They both aren't graceful enough for the dance scenes. It looked mechanical and forced. Ryans charm and comedic style tries to bleed through occasionally but it's held back by the lifeless character he has to play.

Even Emma seems to be holding back. The chemistry between them never happens which didn't make the ending sad like the movie intended with a ridiculous fantasy scene showing what could've been if they stayed together. The actors aren't completely to blame though, they were doing their best with what they were given. The writing is to blame. Without a plot and good writers even the best actors will look awful. The writing is the foundation of a movie and without that, you just have, well, la la land. A nauseating, pointless, plotless, terribly choreographed mess.

LA LA LAND, perpetrated by Daniel Chazelle 
   Having the Right Opinion is what Counts
    Reviewed by Alex Deleon

The new Hollywood musical with the intriguing title "La-La-Land. one of the most talked about motion pictures  in recent years with two of Hollywood's most appealing and popular younger generation stars, Ryan Gosling  and Emma Stone, can best be summed up in a single three syllable word ~~

PA-THET--IC!

-- Gosling, in spite of a name that makes one think of chopped goose liver, is indeed quite handsome in the 
traditional Hollywood leading man mold, but when it comes to acting or personality he is no Cary Grant or Jimmy Dean, and as far as dancing goes, passable, but he couldn't carry the jock strap of either Gene Kelly or Fred Astaire. 

His love interest and dancing partner, Emma Stone, a lissome skinny) redhead with gigantic blue eyes, and no breasts to speak of, is a much better dancer and generally a far better actor,  but seems to have aged considerably since her extraordinarily vivid interpretation of a sexy young college co-ed in love with her psychotic philosophy prof in Woody Allen's "Irrational Man" -- and that just two years ago.

 In this picture she is in facial closeup much of the time but looks haggard, worn, wan, and older than she is  supposed to be according to the story. The dance numbers seem to be an attempt at a homage to Astaire and  Ginger Rogers in retarded motion, but they are so badly staged and wanly choreographed that after a while they just become annoying. 

One particular Gosling~Stone duet set in the L.A. Planetarium is so ridiculous --  with the two traipsing in  defiance of the Law of Gravity on thin air against a galaxy of stars --  that it is downright embarrassing.                              

The young lovers are clearly meant for. each other but their divergent career dreams and aspirations -- she as  an actress he as a Charley Parker inspired serious jazz musician -- keep them apart in the wake of arbitrary  script  manipulations that seem so phony you get the feeling the actors had to keep asking themselves, "Hold  on a  sec --what were we supposed to be doing in that last scene?" 

Pathetic scripting, pathetic unmotivated dance scenes arbitrarily inserted, then ineptly executed -- pathetic  unfocused direction - no wonder Mia (Stone) and Sebastian (Gosling) wear such strained expressions on their  pretty faces all the time. I actually felt sorry for Emma in some scenes suspecting that she may actually have been physically ill while going through some of her motions.

 I kept looking at my watch wondering if this thing was ever going to end. The running time was 128 minutes  but it felt more like  five hours. The end credits with handsome art-deco lettering

were a great relief when they  finally came up and put this picture  out if its misery. No more Damien Chazelle for me. He also directed  another piece of masochistic misery entitled"Whiplash". Give me

Mondo Cane ... 

Bottom line: A film almost as dopey as its dumbbell La-dee-da title.  And if it cleaned up at the Golden Globes it only means that maintaining membership in the Hollywood Foreign Press Club by holding the right opinions  Is more important than having an understanding  of what the quality of film is all about. Ditto for the dopes (dupes) who at the academy have annointed this mediocrity with countless obsequious accolades and Oscar nominations.

All in all, if you do or have lived in L.A., it very much feels like a love-letter (over-used expression, I know) to the city and the industry that lured most of us there. Beyond that, it's a lackluster follow up to one of my favorite films of the last five years.

"La La Land" is the second highly overrated movie to receive an Academy Award nomination for Best Picture (The first being "Arrival".).  As with "Arrival" I saw this movie because of it's high rating on the Tomatometer and very positive word of mouth.  However I left the movie theater extremely disappointed.  Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are great actors.  I still say Stone should have won the Oscar for "Birdman".  However the two have no chemistry at all on screen.  I just did not buy them as a couple.  The movie also suffers from a painful lack of originality.  The script was loaded with old cliches and a plot we have seen before.  Ryan Gosling's character decided to open a jazz club after being inspired by Emma Stone's character.  The writers of this movie have obviously seem the 1980 cult classic "Xanadu".  Thoguth they love one another they ultimately don't live happily ever after but have a lasting impact their lives.  The writers have also seen "Lost in Translation" and the Academy Award winning classic "An American in Paris".  "La La Land" is a huge disappointment.  What's even more disappointing is the strong possibility the movie will sweep the Oscars.

In a world where people worship everything and value nothing, I have found that I value the many messages present within La La Land (2016). While simultaneously shining a harsh light on the hypocrisy of Hollywood and showing how our dreams and passions move us to make tough life decisions, I found myself deeply moved by the narrative presented within this film, not only as a lover of movies but as a creative artist myself. This film is for the dreamers. It's for the people who never give up in pursuing what they want out of life. It's for those who have a talent screaming to be noticed by others.

Aside from literally being the best musical I've seen in nearly more than a decade (Chicago (2002) is the only recent one that comes to mind), what I found most impressive about this film is that it is only the second directed by Damien Chazelle. For those who may have missed it, his previous work, Whiplash (2014), was an extreme look at the commitment a musician will take just to be a part of something bigger. With this in mind, we find that Chazelle has a passion for music that is easily grasped through his use of expert cinematography.

Much like The Young Girls of Rochefort (1967), La La Land makes me feel like the world would be a much better place if people sang and danced at the drop of a hat (or stop of a car). But even with the almost cliche "romantic comedy" beginning, where La La Land differs from these films is the depth that it explores the relationships between two dreamers. While we always want our life partners to succeed in their dreams, it can be difficult to find a balance between somewhat contrasting goals.

A must-see film for anyone who aspires to something greater in their life, I give La La Land 5.0 stars out of 5.

This sun drenched homage to the Golden Age of Hollywood musicals is a love story between an aspiring actress and a musician. And from its opening, shot in one take, show stopping scene where a gridlocked Los Angeles traffic jam bursts into a song and dance number, this musical pulls out all the stops.

Set in modern day LA but with a retro vibe, LaLaLand follows the romance between two dreamers - Mia (Emma Stone) a wide eyed wannabe, scratching a living as barista in a film studio coffee shop who dreams of being a movie star, and Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) a grouchy jazz purist who dreams of opening his own nightclub. The films follows them through the seasons as they meet, argue, flirt, fall in love, and face a growing conflict between chasing their dreams and settling into a relationship.

Director Damien Chazelle's follow up to his Oscar winning drama Whiplash, is a stylish, romantic and inventive tribute. Stone and (the irresistible looking) Gosling have wonderful chemistry and give effortless, elegant performances with stunning sing and dance numbers. Scenes are shot in a way that feel blissfully romantic and the transition from musical numbers to narrative is seamless.

This modern take on the classic Hollywood musical is a fabulous flight of cinematic fantasy. While this award contender is a movie about the movies, which Hollywood always adore and is sure to bag a lot of them, this love letter to Los Angeles, to romance and to big dreams is undoubtedly a triumph. One of the films of the year.

First off, I love musicals. I mean I love them and have seen them all. When a musical is made I am ecstatic and pray that there will be a revival of musicals. With that said, I hated this movie. Neither Emma Stone or Ryan Gosling are talented enough musically to carry this off. I'm not even talking about their ability to sing and dance which was slim, I'm talking about their musical energy. Their bodies seemed too relaxed when they sang or danced . Musicals need that energy that fills the bodies so much that you understand why the characters need to sing. They just seemed happy to know the steps. This musical also lacked, plot, interesting dialogue and humor . I understand what an homage is and this movie missed the mark . Based on nominations and some reviews, I guess this is a movie you either love or hate .

Honestly I don't even understand how he was able to spin this into a feel good movie at all, and maybe it's really not, because when you break the plot down, it's a SAD story, and capped off by a bit of lying and dishonesty.

So, Emma Stone is great, she's beautiful, she's a great actress who can be witty, funny, convey sadness well, and amazingly is a pretty good singer. She earned the roll, and plays it well.

Ryan Gosling however is another story. Ryan is a decent actor, one who for sure is where he is because of his looks. The only problem is he isn't a great singer. Unlike some people on here, I won't say he CAN'T sing. He can sing well enough that 99 percent of the viewers can, or even notice.

But for a singer or musician, of which I'm both, when I saw the movie, I couldn't help but snap back out of the trance where you forget you're watching a movie and thinking, "God he doesn't belong in a musical".

And there's the rub, then I realized, this isn't an accident, a miscast. If it was I'd probably give it a 4.5 stars. They already have John Legend on cast, who is a phenomenally better singer, AND whose acting skills don't seem to be much worse than Gosling anyway. 

Being that movie studios are experts in acting, singing, and dancing talent this leaves you with one or two possible reasons for casting Gosling as Seb instead of Legend. That's either that the studio figured thereally was upside to using Gosling's name to attract women to the film based on his looks knowing the majority of then wouldn't notice the singing,  OR that the studio dealt that even though Legend would better be suited in the lead rolr, the biracial couple thing in combinatiom with lack of Goslings name would hurt sales.

Regardless I view it as an intentional act with knowledge it was making the product worse from the get go. People can be cast thinking they can pull the acting off.

It's evident within the first few words of somebody singing whether or not they can sing. You can't miscast his voice.

Plot spoilers after this point, stop reading if you haven't seen it.

This movie is painted as a love story, and they pull it off by focusing heavily on that aspect, focusing very little on the breakup brought on by Sebastian'a poor relationship choices, and show a very curious "Dallas-esque" dream sequence in which we are led to believe in 5 years time Mia met another man whom she never mentioned her former Jazz Pianist boyfriend to, who then dishonestly doesn't mention this relationship to her husband when they inadvertently walk in Seb's, and then she sits there and dreams of the life she wishes she had with Seb while they watch the show. 

Maybe they should do a sequel where she sneaks back to Seb's as her marriage fizzles and rekindles the marriage.

The plot of the movie could be summed up like this.

Jazz musician who should stick to playing piano instead of singing, meets cute girl with far better voice who learns to love Jazz due to him. He stupidly gives up on his dreams to play a type of music he doesn't even like because he thinks she wants him to have a steady job, finding out once he has signed a contract that she just wants him.

The twist of the knife is she ends up becoming a famous actress due only to him driving from LA to Nevada to tell her that she got a call back to his number, and could have then helped launch his club anyway.

He lost the love of his life for nothing, and she regrets it as well.

WHAT'S LA LA LAND ABOUT?

An aspiring actress and a struggling jazz musician fall in love and inspire each other artistically.

IS IT ANY GOOD? (GRADE: A)

Featuring truly dazzling film-making and strong performances by Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, La La Land is an enchanting blend of modern and retro. Taking place in present-day Los Angeles, but made in the style of classic Hollywood musicals, it's a delight. The leads are merely passable as vocalists, but strong as actors and dancers. Their undeniable chemistry, combined with the sensibilities of writer-director Damien Chazelle (who places one foot in bittersweet reality and the other in whimsical fantasy) make for an unforgettable cinematic experience. 

The songs, choreography, wardrobe, production design, editing, and cinematography are top-shelf. It could use a bit tighter pacing and the ending may divide some audiences (I thought it was beautiful), but this unconventional love story is a must-see.

IS IT OKAY FOR YOUR KIDS?

La La Land is rated PG-13. It has one f-word and a few moderate profanities, along with two vulgar hand gestures. Swimsuits and dresses reveal legs, abdomens, and mild cleavage (frankly it's no more revealing than what's shown in old Gene Kelly movies if you go back and re-watch them). There's some drinking at Hollywood parties. Some couples dance sensually in the background, but it's not raunchy or explicit. A man and woman kiss and live together; we see them cuddling fully clothed in bed. There is no sexuality.

ANY WORTHWHILE MESSAGES?

Be grateful for the people who inspire you. Pursue your dreams with tenacity and integrity. The direction your life takes hinges on the decisions you make; choose wisely. Surround yourself with people who believe in you but also hold you accountable.

La La Land is a wonderful film. In a year desperately in need of it, it provides joy and possibility. The song numbers are catchy as anything, particularly 'City of Stars' and 'Another Day of Sun'. While it would be easy to dismiss this as your standard good-but-not-great, Oscar-bait-nostalgia film, La La Land is distinctly smarter and more nuanced than that. As it has to be, it is self-aware. But some self-aware films full face first into a pool of cynicism. La La Land is too smart for that. Damian Chantelle brilliantly keeps it from getting too cynical, even while it knows enough to gently question the tropes it dares to toy with. Gosling is exceptional as the lead, Stone also - though mostly 'playing Emma Stone'. JK Simmons has a sly cameo as the owner of a jazz club. Gosling doesn't quite play his tempo.

La La Land's fatal flaw is that it doesn't seem to quite know what to do to finish. I applaud the bravery of challenging the 'ride off into the sunset' finish, yet even as Emma Stone is considering her choices at the end of the film, there seems to be a shrug that everything is okay and we have all followed our dreams. La La Land's biggest problem is not its nostalgia, its pomp or its lack of realism, but its reinforcement of consumer, individualist culture. It seems to be the one thing Chantelle doesn't realise he's doing. 

Still - so far the best film I've seen this year, narrowly shading 'Arrival.'

In una moderna Hollywood fatta di sogni e sognatori, Damien Chazelle (il regista ndr) ci racconta con maturità ed eleganza un'istrionica favola sui sogni, la realtà e l'arte. 
Se da un lato le ottime performance dei due protagonisti ci ammaliano con delizia e stupore, il film messo in piedi, architrave di una matura ed adorabile storia d'amore, è un inno alle arti, quelle pure, belle, canore, danzate, coreografate con maestria da una regia intelligente ed affascinante. 
Erano anni che il cinema non si arricchiva di nuova linfa, perché Lala Land nel suo profondo non è solo una romantica storia dai toni vintage, è la celebrazione della settima arte, quella ingenua, manifestazione della bellezza, una bellezza visiva ad uditiva, che sa colpire al cuore dello spettatore ed imprimere nella sua mente un miliare ricordo.

La La Land is a great film but has decent acting from Emma Stone (5) and Ryan Gosling (6). These actors were the worst parts of this film. The lighting has personality on some scenes when you focus on one of the characters. The lights would fade either Gosling or Stone. The story of this film is that these  two character, who both want to hit it big in Hollywood. Emma Stone wants to be an famous actress and Ryan Gosling wanted to be a famous musician. They meet each other at this party and kind of build up this relationship that they have now. I'm not going get into spoilers'. So that's all you get from me and go see the movie, if you want to  know the ending of the film. 
     Referring back to the cinematography, there are many long takes without editing in this film and this is sprinkled throughout the movie. I did not like Emma Stone, to me she was not even acting but pretty much telling us that she wants a Oscar me and I liked Gosling . He had a good performance. I loved him when he would talk about jazz to Mia (Emma Stone).  I didn't think Emma Stone's what is so terrible that it's unwatchable, but she felt like an interesting character. I extremely like when she explains film to Sebastian ( Ryan Gosling).  I also love that this film went back to the film history and used a CinemaScope, which projects on the screen a full scope of the film with tons of detail of the film.  This film does have it's fair share of problems. First off, the beginning 30 minutes are a drag to get through. I almost stopped watching the film. Also, there's a  song  in this film that felt, thrown in and it it didn't work with the whole film. As well as, in the beginning of the film there was a tracking shot of people dancing on freeway and felt you didn't need that in the film. It did nothing for driving the story forward with the two main characters. 
        The editing for this film is pretty good, but nothing special. The director of La La Land , Damien Chazelle puts his passion into this film but personally I prefer his Whiplash movie over his La La Land movie. Movies like La La land, are Oscar bait movies. These types of movies that come out at the end-of-the-year. Will usually get nominated tons of  awards. In 10 years, I  think this movie will be remembered , but not for its acting.

Le phénomène qui poursuit La La Land n'est qu'un recommencement du phénomène The Artist. Oui, le film de Damien Chazelle est différent de ce qu'on voit depuis des décennies au cinéma et cela en fait un incontournable. Or, une fois passé cette surprise, il se trouve que La La Land n'est qu'une comédie musicale correcte, avec des numéros musicaux particulièrement fades et oubliables, une histoire d'amour qu'on a déjà vu vingt fois (rien qu'en début du mois, en beaucoup mieux, avec Born to be Blue) et Ryan Gosling, qui est effectivement un super acteur. Hormis deux ou trois idées réussies (dont la dernière séquence), La La Land n'est qu'un film différent, pas un très bon film.

I cannot see HOW this film is worth its 13 or 14 Oscar nominations, sadly. I think that Ryan Gosling was brilliant, acted perfectly in his part, and could deserve the best actor award; his opposite lead, Emma Stone, also excellent, if not quite as brilliant in her part - so she might be a good bet for best actor Oscar.
However, production/direction/cut/filmatography did nothing to help the film - too bitty; too long spent showing the early stages of of main protaganists' meeting; hard to follow as it was so bitty, and having spent 90% of the film going through ONE year, does FIVE years in less than 10% of the time, and has a blurred and almost surreal alternative ending, which is NOT a happy one.  Given its length there is not too much singing or dancing (good that there is not much singing, as what there is in NOT very good). So in summary it DOES NOT revive the glory days of musicals - nothing to compare with teh joy and the well-integrated plot lines, or the happy, happy endings of 7 Brides, King and I, the Great Singing in the Rain, or even West Side story, which could have been a good director/production/cut/filmography path for this film to have followed. 
I really did enjoy watching the two leads, but the film is too bitty, too time-dimension distorted and too lacking in soul and a happy ending [given its content] to be considered a great. A shame, as it could have bee so!

Lots of people have been asking if I've seen 'La La Land', so I thought I had better give it a chance, even though musicals aren't my thing - better late than never, right?

Sebastian (Gosling) and Mia (Stone) are easy to watch and are good in this, but I don't think either of them is a particularly good singer or dancer. My main problem with musicals is: why? If a scene's not interesting enough to sustain momentum without having song and dance, then cut it! At least in animated films, they seem to find ways to weave songs in organically - and they're catchy. Here, I didn't find any of the songs very catchy or interesting - most are kind of mopey. Otherwise, it's all quite predictable - they fall in love, they chase their dreams, the end.

The ending is semi-interesting, but every time I started to get pulled into the film when there's a stretch with no singing, it suddenly appears again - always out of context - and pushes me back out. It's definitely not a bad film, I just felt like nothing really happened - sure, there's some romance and they're good actors, but there's no real story or humour to be found.

Una gran película de jazz es una época donde la cultura popular ya la relegó al pasado, pero que sin dudas lo hará revivir con enorme gloria y grandeza.

Siendo un musical es fácil juzgar que no es algo más allá de lo tradicional, y no es así. Ahí maestría es cuanto a la música que posee con la que uno simpatiza fácilmente dando lugar a momentos de placer auditivo escuchando un estilo de música clásico pero bien hecho haciéndolo sentir novedoso y deslumbrante para nuestra época y acompañado de las coreografías que emplea, un diseño de producción que la verdad terminan con avivar el espíritu y nos coloca en su "mundo músical".

La dirección de Damien Chazelle es sorprendente y tanto su talento como su amor por el jazz se demuestran aquí. Ya nos había dado prueba de eso en Whiplash, pero aquí nos ofrece el una forma más armoniosa de situaciones para verlo. Si se le puede resaltar una cualidad que tiene este director fuera del resto, es que: Sabe como capturar una emoción. Esto de mano de la fotografía que maneja la película, hermosa y deslumbrante con un toque teatral que queda excelente en la película con momentos en la historia que sale de contexto para hacer escenas artísticas que se vuelven "poesía audiovisual" en su gran esplendor. Y en su mejores momentos, cuando solo enfoca a un actor y acompañado de la música sentimos todo en él, sus emociones, sus pensamientos, su asombro ante lo que están pasando... Un manejo de escena bien logrado, y varias veces. 

De las actuaciones no hay nada que discutir, no serán de los más originales dada la trama pero eso no quita lo bien hechas que están. Ryan Gosling logra encajar en su papel, que representa a alguien apasionado por el jazz haciéndonos deslumbrar por esta música y todo su mundo tanto como su personaje. Emma Stone encanta al público con pequeños detalles de ilusión y sueños que vive y por mucho logra de los momentos más sentimentales de la película, a veces con sola presencia o actuando con calidad artística, tanto como Ryan Gosling.

Como ya se recalco varias veces, esta película VIVE de su banda sonora, un trabajo musical tan sorprendente como admirable al ofrecer canciones de jazz que afloran el espíritu de lo clásico. Esta sabe como emocionar a un público en los momentos emotivos donde esta va acorde con el sentimiento que expresa el actor y lo potencia. 

La La Land cumple y con creces. Consolida a un joven director como uno de los nuevos talentos de Hollywood, ofrece una película romántica conmovedora, tiene una fotografía que deslumbra y encanta. Pero sobre todo, da luz a un trabajo artístico que revive un género tanto musical como cinematográfico y nos da una película que no es simplemente "un musical más"

Writer/Director Damien Chazelle's acclaimed throwback to Hollywood's golden age of musicals is surprising in ways one might not expect. I was actually taken aback at how honest/down-to-earth the story was. "Chicago" and "Moulin Rouge" this ain't. The whimsical nature of traditional musicals is tossed aside in favor of a realistic, adult take on a story about struggling artists. It's only during the musical queue's where the film finds it's whimsy. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling aren't exactly powerhouses in the vocal department, but they can both sing well enough, which is all that's really required for a story like this one. However, I can honestly say that it wasn't until Emma Stone sings "Fools who dream" where the film actually affected me. It wasn't necessarily that I finally "got" the movie, it's when the movie got ME. That fire that once burned so brightly within (I was once an aspiring rock bassist) returned for a moment to remind me that all the trouble, mistakes and drama was worth it. This flick is a love letter to all the starving artists out there that wanna keep the fire ablaze despite being beaten down by rejection. The filmmaker is simply saying "Don't fret, cuz this one's for you..." Is this whole thing worth (a historic) 14 Oscar nods? I personally don't think so. It's profoundly moving though, and that's worth something.

For about a full day after watching La La Land, I had a problem with it but could not figure out exactly what is was. La La Land is like your prodigy son; you recognize his genius but you ask for more. You want him to exceed all expectations; shatter all preconceptions and tower above in a league of his own; because you love him. La La Land is like that; its glorious but you want it to be more glorious; romantic but you want it to be more romantic. Described by its director Damien Chazelle (Whiplash, Grand Piano) as a "modern musical"; a modern musical is what it is. From the elaborate opening set piece which promises passion and color; to the twosome dance at the verge of the Los Angeles cityscape as promising as their dreams; Seb (Ryan Gosling) a Jazz pianist and Mia (Emma Stone) an aspiring actress, seem to be at odds with each other; but their fate is sealed and we already know how it will end; but it's ok because we know that some dreams come true while others remain as beautiful dreams. The soundtrack in La La Land is haunting but is also alive; you can feel how the notes of each music piece are connected as if one long song evolving over the course of the film. If anything, this is what La La Land is about: evolution. How our dreams evolve, how music evolves and how musicals need to evolve from the classicals we've all come to love to something that better suits the needs of today's audiences.

This isn't quite a masterpiece for the ages but Damien Chazelle was flawless in his execution, relentless in drama and passion. Sure, we all got sucker punched with his ending, but he atoned by showering us with an extended finale, a crescendo of how true happiness and love would have looked like, if it existed in Mia's world -- but we're happy, because both our leads are happy and content. The movie may be heartbreakingly painful for some, but for some others, they'll get a sense of closure too. Dare to dream, is perhaps the best message this movie has to tell. & to Damien Chazelle, keep on daring.

I loved this film and I hope that many people will watch it when they get the chance.

But as much as I wanted to hate this film going in and call out film snobs...I can't. The movie is a great effort and brings back a style of film Hollywood had long forgotten about. So for that I say, it deserves its praise. Now I'm not going to give it "best film of the year" nods while Hacksaw Ridge and Hell or High Water are in the running and I believe those are MUCH better films but La La Land is a fun blast from the past and if you can take anything away from it, stop being such prudes about Jazz music.
