At one point, La La Land's lead heroine, young aspiring actress Mia, does something unthinkable, at least from the point-of-view of her counterpart, musician Sebastian: she admits to not liking jazz. This prompts Sebastian to explain to naive Mia all about the genre, and how it's dying by abandoning its roots. This, quite fittingly, comes from a film that stands as a rare completely original live-action musical, another genre that many would consider dead in this day and age.

Not if Damien Chazelle has anything to say about it. In the same way Sebastian yearns for the jazz's days of old, Chazelle harkens back to the musicals of the 30s and 40s for this rousing jazz musical. Chazelle once again teams up with composer Justin Hurwitz, who scored Chazelle's previous two films, resulting in whimsical toe-tapping melodies that wouldn't be out of place in the Golden Age of Hollywood. Paired with the lyrics of theatre duo Benj Pasek and Justin Paul, the soundtrack is chock full of earworm tunes that are sure to be immediately stuck in your head, ranging from more simple tunes to emotionally charged ballads. Chazelle himself shows a flair that you don't typically seem to find in directors of his age range, capturing the musical sequences with awe-inducing choreography and camerawork that truly captures the vast Cinemascope angles of old. From the vibrant prelude Another Day of Sun (captured in three unbelievable takes edited together to form one Birdman-esque shot) to the tearjerking Audition (The Fools Who Dream), there's not a single song here that isn't immediately impressive as both a composition and as a performance.

It might come to a shock for some that La La Land's lyrical soundtrack isn't all that robust, made up of just seven songs (including one performed twice, once as a solo and once as a duet). In a way, it's a bit disappointing, but it also allows for the underlying story to truly come forward and take the stage. It's interesting to think that this film actually shares a lot in common with Chazelle's Whiplash, in that they both cover the same themes of chasing dreams and the sacrifices that come with that. But whereas Whiplash was an angry, intensely passionate story, La La Land is much more romantic and calm. Chazelle has written Mia and Sebastian as two immediately empathetic characters, and the performances from Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, and their electric chemistry, truly solidify the relationship: the Fred Astaire/Ginger Rogers comparison is truly valid. And it culminates in a truly impactful finale and epilogue, a kind of scene infused with passion that you just don't see anymore, and one that is sure to not leave a single dry eye in the house. As the film's tagline states, this is a film for the fools who dream, and for that, Chazelle deserves all the thanks for such a wondrous experience.

La La Long

When do I finally realize that I'm not enjoying a particular movie? This realization usually comes when a scene in the film reminds me of some other movie and I find myself longing to watch that film instead of the one I am desperately trying to enjoy. 

In the case of La La Land, this didn't take too long.

During the duo dance scenes between Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, I found myself longing to watch Fred Astaire and Eleanor Powell. 

During the jazz music scenes, I found myself longing to put on some music from Miles Davis or Dave Brubeck. 

Damien Chazelle's soufflé-light screenplay made me long for some sort of story with substance. Let's face it; even your longest allowable tweet would carry as much storytelling weight as this script. 

When considering Chazelle's direction, I found myself longing for a musical directed by Vincent Minnelli. 

And while all this longing was going on, I was longing for a shorter film. La La Land is not a long production when compared with West Side Story or The Music Man (and let's not make any further comparisons with those great films) but, it sure as heck seemed like a long, long movie.

Dictionary.com defines the phrase "la la land" as "a state of being out of touch with reality." I won't disagree with that definition. About halfway into this flick, I was beginning to drift off into Dictionary.com's interpretation.

Luckily, I had some severe arthritis pain in my right big toe that kept me alert long enough to long for some relief; algesic or cinematic, and to keep me awake long enough so that I could make a valid critique of this picture. 

Finally, I long for the day when someone will make a musical that's even half as watchable as the last good Hollywood musical - Hairspray (which really wasn't all that long ago, was it?).

7/7 agli ultimi Golden Globe, Coppa Volpi per la migliore interpretazione femminile a Venezia per Emma Stone e 14 (!!) nomination agli Oscar (record all-time) sono il biglietto da visita di questo musical che porta la firma della nuova scuola hollywoodiana guidata dal genio di Damien Chazelle. La La Land è un musical che rispetta e cita i grandi classici del genere senza rinunciare alla modernità. Tecnicamente e musicalmente fenomenale. La trama ad un'occhiata fugace potrà sembrare abbastanza banale e stereotipata (e non ci sarebbe niente da ridire in proposito) con i due protagonisti innamorati che cercano il loro posto nel mondo, ma è proprio questo il fondamento di una storia che pone una, ed una sola domanda al suo pubblico: fino a che punto ci si può spingere per i propri sogni? Che sia sfondare nel mondo del cinema così storicamente poco inclusivo o anche solo aprire un locale jazz per trasmettere un po' della propria passione, questo è poco importante. La La Land colpisce nel segno praticamente subito grazie a dei piani sequenza così ben congeniali da risultare irreali, con canzoni orecchiabili e facilmente memorizzabili che ti fanno patteggiare per i due protagonisti e, perché no, sognare di essere al loro posto. Questa pellicola è per sognatori, per chi vorrebbe cantare e ballare in mezzo alla strada, non curante del pensiero altrui almeno per una volta, come se si vivesse davvero all'interno di un musical. La visione di Chazelle potrà risultare un po' buonista per i più cinici ma lui non si accontenta (come anche in Whiplash) di descriverci il mondo come è, lui ci mostra come dovrebbe essere: con un amore sconfinato per il jazz, per la città che ti stimola di mattina e che ti culla la notte, per la donna (o l'uomo) della tua vita, così vuota senza di lei/lui, sicuramente più semplice ma anche meno eccitante, avvincente e delirante. La La Land è tutto questo, è colori (una fotografia d'autore come non si vedeva da tanti anni ci accompagna in questo viaggio per l'ignoto), è musica (la colonna sonora di Justin Hurwitz ci fa emozionare), è vita ricca di gioie e delusioni, di compromessi e sogni nel cassetto. La via più facile potrà anche essere mettere a tacere i propri desideri, ci spiegano i nostri protagonisti, reprimerli e sostituirli magari con qualcosa di più convenzionale, di più sicuro, ma se non hai mai rischiato almeno una volta nella vita allora, forse non hai mai vissuto; perché ci sarà sempre chi cercherà di farti a pezzi, chi ti dirà che non dovevi nemmeno provarci ed è proprio lì che La La Land ti lascia senza fiato, mostrandoti come non sia per niente facile mettersi in gioco in situazioni nuove e dicendoti, e questo vale da solo il prezzo del biglietto, che con un po' di perseveranza e, perché no, con la giusta persona accanto che ti prende per mano, si può fare di tutto. Questa pellicola farà la storia, ne sono certo ed è principalmente grazie alle tre star di questo film: Damien Chazelle, Ryan Gosling ed Emma Stone. Il regista/sceneggiatore stravolge le regole del gioco usando i canoni tradizionali e si catapulta, già al suo secondo film, nell'olimpo dei più grandi; strizza l'occhio ai suoi predecessori ma sa come innovarsi e, alla fine della proiezione, ci bisbiglia nell'orecchio distrattamente che ancora non abbiamo visto niente di ciò di cui lui è realmente capace. Per quanto riguarda la premiata coppia Gosling&Stone c'è poco da dire, una chimica difficilmente vista sul grande schermo che ci riporta alla mente le atmosfere di Casablanca; i due piccioncini infatti con i loro Sebastian e Mia si pongono come eredi spirituali dei vari Humphrey Bogart e Ingrid Bergman, ballando in simbiosi così bene dai tempi di Fred Astaire e Ginger Rogers dimostrandoci come l'amore sia il motore di tutto. La La Land vuole ricordarci quanto siano belli i sogni semi-dimenticati dei tempi andati, quei sogni fatti solo di facce, musica e movimento. Ha la testa tra le nuvole, e per poco più di due ore, porta il pubblico lassù con lui. Solo una parola: CAPOLAVORO.

I've always said Ryan Gosling was meant to do comedy. I think very highly of the guy, but I hold the unpopular opinion that he's not necessarily the best dramatic actor in the world. In La La Land he gets a chance to utilize some dramatic-acting skills, but strays away from his usual angst-filled characters as he showcases his humor chops.

It helps that he and Emma Stone have such great chemistry. With their third feature together (Crazy, Stupid, Love and Gangster Squad) the pair demonstrate why they may be our generation's Gene Kelly and Ginger Rogers--two actors that are paid homage to in this film.

La La Land is about a struggling actress, Mia (Stone), who is constantly being rejected at every audition she has, and a mercurial jazz pianist, Sebastian (Gosling), who dreams of opening his own jazz club. He is a talented musician but often finds himself going against his own integrity playing pop music and simple lounge standards. The two meet in a way that would make any classic cinephile proud, and over time develop a relationship, each dealing with his and her own floundering careers is the process.

The film acts as a love letter to Los Angeles. It's not necessarily a nice letter, but it's not a breakup letter either. More like a letter to an abusive partner who you keep coming back to for some inexplicable reason, only for them to spit on you and tell you you're worthless.

It pokes fun at the city, constantly saying out loud the things most of us would be tried for treason for ever thinking. But they've all been actual thoughts lingering in our minds at one point or another.

It's a quixotical view of what LA is supposed to be--or used to be. The two characters are old souls adamantly romanticizing what they view their ideal careers to be, only to realize that they view this city in an antiquated way that no longer really exists in today's world. Things such as technology and loss of nostalgia are ruining it, and they struggle to find the balance between the new and the old without wanting to compromise much.

The film, on the other hand, compromises the new and the old very well in its every moment. The songs don't feel modern, but they don't feel dated either. They're not necessarily poppy and affable at first--fitting well into the film's jazz theme.

Gosling and Stone are not fantastic singers, but they're not bad either, which makes their performances all the more appealing--they're one of us.

Much like a non-New Yorker can empathize with a film that pays homage (or lack thereof) to New York, one doesn't have to be from Los Angeles to get what the film is trying to say. Viewers can see where the movie comes from. LA is everywhere. We experience it in almost every movie we watch in one way or another.

La La Land isn't just for Los Angeleans. It's for dreamers and people with big visions. For people who have been rejected over and over and over again, told they're not good enough, and still, for some reason, keep going back at it. But like anything we love, it takes a lot of work. La La Land makes you believe in your dreams again.

There is so much to say about this movie musical, even without giving anything away. Just looking at my after notes, it's already loaded with comments and details telling me this is going to be a larger than normal post. (Possibly exceeding the IMDb word count of a thousand) let's see. 

Damien Chazelle does it again, firstly where he bashed my head in with a drumstick or two with 2014's Whiplash, which was so intense, it had me sweating in the cinema. Twice. I had to watch it again the very next day and wasn't any less sweaty the second time round. An absolute masterpiece. 

Now, Chazelle might be considered to be on the young side of being an accomplished director, La La Land being born during his senior year at Harvard University in 2010, along side friend and musical writer Justin Hurwitz, but with a smaller budget and compromising script demands, the idea was shelved, until, the successful Whiplash received such high acclaim, they got granted a budget 30 times larger than the previous, and freedom with their own script and screenplay. 

Chazelle again, displays his absolutely, stunning, visual brilliance whilst tilting the hat to classic cinema and musicals like Casablanca, Funny Face and The Red Balloon. Having been to L.A. countless of times, I find it to be my less favourite of the American cities I've been to, but, Chazelle manages to add a glossy, vibrant veil over the top that's inspired me with a new appreciation for the city. I still find it incredible and slightly unbelievable, but in a good way, that he's managed to take a modern, bustling and dirty city and still make it feel retro and vintage using abstract cinematography, like creating its very own time zone altogether. He even opens using the original 20th Century Fox logo and the fade out focuses make you feel like you're watching a theatre play. 

There's a long list of scenes that stay with you because of this style and of course, being a musical, Chazelle honours the classic musical methods with astonishing and exuberant long takes that makes your smile stretch from seat 1 to 20. The opening scene alone is a tremendous feat with epic cinematography and beautiful imagery. I could dissect the whole movie, recounting each joyful and pleasant scene by scene, but it's truly something that has to be marvelled at by seeing and not reading. 

The story is about a turbulent romance between Seb, (Ryan Gosling), a confident, proud and passionate pianist those ambitions sits with having his very own jazz club; and Mia, (Emma Stone) a struggling, aspiring actress trying to make her way in the superficial Hollywood. The cars they drive is a sweet analogy of their characters in way, Seb driving a classic '82 Buick Riviera and Mia driving a Prius. It must be familiar ground for both, playing aspiring performing artists such as they are in real life. Apparently the auditioning scenes which are torturous, were drawn from both star's actually experiences in auditioning. 

The chemistry between the two is as always, perfect. This being their third outing after Gangster Squad and Stupid Crazy Love. Gosling oozes a certain coolness but with quite the finazz of confident arrogance. Whilst Stone appears vulnerable, reserved and bashful but what's simmering is an audacious, creative and inspiring woman. It's so well balanced and enriched by both, you could be forgiven for forgetting John Legend is in the movie. 

Chazelle and Hurwitz love of Jazz shines through just like it did with Whiplash, now I know I keep referencing Whiplash, but please note, these are two very different films, which make this all the more impressive. It's the similarities such as the music being very much a subject matter to both films. I'm no expert but I'm a lover of Jazz too, and this soundtrack itself is utterly amazing, infectious and makes the heart glow with instantly recognisable tracks like "Someone In The Crowd", "City of Stars" and "A Lovely Night." Justin Hurwitz composes a mesmerising, enchanting musical that reminds me of sitting in Ronnie Scott's and has me weaving in and out of traffic whilst listening to the songs in the car. 

Gosling and Stone perform the songs and dances excellently, displaying a gracefulness that would make any non-musical fan a lover and a dancer. The choreography is majestic throughout, especially the two scenes at Griffin Park/Observatory, the tap dancing in particular. Gosling actually learning to play the piano for his parts entirely says a lot about him as a star and as an actor, getting the emotion to come through. 

The whole production is flawless and as I've said before, this zesty imagery is made up dazzling costume designs, great atmospheric sets and masterful use of lighting. The dresses Mia wears set against the plots she's on is just eye-candy and Seb's shoes! I want a pair of those shoes! 

Have you ever watched a film and thought it was a personally message to you, sent from the cosmos, whether it be a dig or a reminder. The conclusion certainly hit a few chords on my heartstrings, bringing a tear to my eye, it's the perfect ending to a glorious movie. It's only shame is not having enough song and dance, but it a good thing to leave wanting more, and the film already has a runtime of 128mins. 

As always, I haven't read any reviews but from what I can gather from the quotable taglines they are awarding the film with, they're absolutely right, it really is what everyone is saying. A dazzling, delightful masterpiece, that's amazingly good for the soul, heartfelt and a prefect blend of modern and vintage style. [edit] Being nominated for 14 Oscars, 11 BAFTA awards and won 7 Golden Globes should speaks volumes. I was totally swept off my feet and urge everyone to watch this film, at least twice.

Let's have a frank discussion of expectations, because there are 2 big problems that might arise when you enter a theater with expectations. The first of these is if you expect more than the film can possibly deliver. Nothing makes a movie feel more like garbage than going in expecting a masterpiece and finding it underwhelming. That gap between what you anticipated and what you got makes the quality feel worse than it was in reality. This problem certainly came to play with me and La La Land. It wasn't necessarily that the critics had begun to anoint this film as the second-coming savior of the entire free world, because I already had high hopes before a single critic posted a review. It was a musical (and I love a musical,) it was directed by Damien Chazelle (who I thought crushed it with Whiplash,) and it looked like a joyous escapist love story (some of my favorite types of film.) So when I got to the theater and had trouble understanding lyrics in the opening number, found the plot bland and derivative, and didn't sense the joy in the whole proceeding it deflated me like a balloon. I was angry, and felt betrayed. Although I wasn't quite as angry as the ladies next to me in the theater who loudly proclaimed "That was terrible!" as soon as the credits started to roll. In reality, the look of the film is marvelous, there were a couple of songs that worked, and I sensed the passion for the subject matter in Chazelle's heart. But because I expected near perfection, this film let me down a lot.

The second problem with expectations is when you go into a theater expecting one kind of movie and there is a bait-and-switch which leaves you with a different kind of movie than you wanted. It's easy to feel frustrated as you keep watching and waiting for the type of movie you wanted to get started. That also happened with La La Land for me. Let's be clear right here and now: This movie is a relationship drama first and foremost. Anyone or anything that tries to sell you on the fact that you will be enjoying a throwback to the classic musicals of old Hollywood is selling you a false bill of goods. While there are certainly a few musical numbers, La La Land does not feel like those delightful films from the olden days. In fact there is a segment almost an entire hour long in the middle of the film where it seems like someone forgot this was a musical. The film wilts on the vine and my wife and I started wiggling in our seats with boredom. Also, it's worth noting that the singing is not very good in this film, and the dancing is possibly worse. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone do not have strong voices, and I feel almost zero emotion in most of their performances. Long gone are the days of Gene Kelly, Fred Astaire, or Judy Garland. These people struggle to carry the tune, and certainly don't have any dance moves that impress. But getting back to the whole bait-and-switch thing, I just have to say (without spoiling anything) I at least hoped to leave the theater with a smile on my face, but they couldn't even deliver that in the end. To be clear, I recognize this is not a terrible film. It looks remarkable, and I might appreciate the story if I watched it again knowing what is coming. However, right now, the difference between my expectations and what I got are so dramatically different that it feels like I hated La La Land.

La La Land, a beautiful piece of art that combines some very good cinematographic resources, including excellent pieces of music, good photography and outstanding performances. Why is it so controversial? There's no doubt we have already seen that it has an extensive list of nominations and that it will certainly continue receiving awards. People wonder if it is the best movie or the most overrated film of 2016, so by analyzing it, we find in first instance that this film has an argument more than hackneyed and the subject that has being treated has been experienced too many times by dozens of directors. It is a charming musical that explains the spontaneous and inconsistently magical encounter of two people whose feelings will be threatened by the dreams they seek. In fact, that one is the key objective of this proposal: the pursuit of our dreams. For every person who has set goals, this film is wonderful while those who simply judge it by the innumerable clichés the film has, then they'll say this has an annoying and boring effect. As the film progresses you can notice several things: on the one hand it starts with one musical after another, this is fantastic, very fun and joyful, however everything is lost because there is not a good story beyond being a "simple tale" with a disastrous storyline. Then we have no music and it seems that the musical is over and now a romantic drama has begun. However it is during the final stretch of the film when it improves remarkably.
It is not correct to say that it is overrated, because in itself, the film really transmits a strong load of harmony and wonder with the fine performances that  Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling have and the good chemistry that appears between both. Nevertheless, it is based on so many musicals that we have seen like "Singing in the Rain" that the creators of La La Land did not even deny. The movie is not extraordinary nor leaves any kind of shocking message, and this is because it is a classic story where fame is sought with all the stumbles that the city of Los Angeles is characterized, but where white characters are used, developing a love story directed to the people of the same race. So it turns out that this becomes a musical of the style that Americans adore, serving as a symbol of what Hollywood loves to do and in which they are specialists, making the film as a compilation of the elements taken from the 50's and 60's but adapted with the new generations. Yes, La La Land is beautiful, but just that.

La La Land consegue transferir tudo que de há no cinema em uma narrativa repleta de elogios e referências a uma cidade apaixonada.
Damien Chazelle, que também dirigiu o surpreendente Whiplash, elabora seus planos-sequência com o mesmo gosto que seus personagens principais os executam.
Exibindo tudo o que pode em suas cores, fazendo uma analogia incrível com o uso das estações em uma cidade que não as percebe, o diretor as transfere em sua dupla principal que transborda química.
Emma Stone e Ryan Gosling atingem seu máximo, esbanjando carisma e atuação em suas expressivas características logo em suas primeiras cenas, deixando claro que este é o filme dos dois.
La La Land é um filme necessário pra qualquer um que acredita no que o cinema representa. Pura alegria.

Truly pathetic. What were they even thinking? Ryan felt bored with himself and the movie within 10 mins that he was on screen. It felt as though he had sung City of Stars a million times and still didn't get it pitch-perfect, and had gotten bored and had given up. Kudos to Emma for trying to hold the house of cards together. But in the end, it was her standing with 2 hands in the air, and all the other cards lying scattered irretrievably on the floor. Endured it till the end, but that's not a guarantee. So bad, so bad.

La La Land has a way of sucking you in even if you aren't a big fan of musicals. You have two characters, Mia (Emma Stone) and Sebastian (Ryan Gosling), who are trying to fulfill their dreams and find love in the process. I would argue, however, that the film is not a story of love, but rather a story of life. Life and how it comes at you from different angles. Life and the paths we choose to take. Throughout this film, you will laugh. You might even cry. Most importanly, though: La La Land will probably make you have an introspective conversation about your own life.

What kind of person are you? Dreamer or realist? Your answer to an extent may determine how you feel about the film's ending, which was the only thing I took real issue with. While I can understand the reasoning behind things shaking out the way they did, I considered the ending somewhat contradictory to the film's overall message. There is a good chance you may feel differently.

The visual imagery throughout the film is spectacular. Director Damien Chazelle relies on the usage of bright colors to pop during night-time scenes. It's a simplistic yet cool effect that subtlely manages to keep your attention on the screen. The film often utilizes Mia and Sebastian as focal points for shots that are both appealing and memorable. You'll see them dancing among the stars. Spotting each other in a crowded room while the rest of the world is paused. It's these small touches that move La La Land from good to great.

The film has a consistenly impactful way of evoking emotion. You feel like you're on a journey with Mia and Sebastian, rooting for them to succeed both personally and professionally. I can't recall many films that are simultaneously heartbreaking and heartwarming at the same time.

La La Land is far from forgettable. I have plenty of good things to say and I haven't even touched on the music. The songs will stay in your head well after the film is over. They say music has a way of telling a story without the use of words. After seeing this film, I couldn't agree more. The music coupled with stellar acting performances from Gosling and Stone set La La Land apart from other films I saw in 2016. I give it a 94.

This was only the first movie I've ever walked out of.Luckily, it wasn't too obvious, since just as I stood up the emergency lights came on and the fire alarms went off. Aside from the one "Well, it didn't take him long to push the red button," there were many sighs of relief from the maybe fifteen people in the theatre. Don't get taken in by the "record number of nominations"...it's AWFUL.

La La Land is in love with a bygone era and serves as a truly beautiful tribute to the minds, crafts and ideas that fuelled the golden years of Hollywood. The songs are all good and catchy, particularly the Oscar winning "City of Stars" that is revisited throughout the film as a sort of hymn to the romance of Mia and Sebastian, acted perfectly by Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling. Do I think Emma's performance was enough to earn her Best Actress Academy Award? No... I think there were other nominations more worthy of recognition, however in such a strong year all the actresses deserved recognition. The cinematography is TO DIE FOR and is probably some of the best I've seen in recent years, proving that La La Land is not just a postcard picture film but was also an incredibly hard film to make, as each glimpse of a Los Angeles sunset frames and fuels the story in every way that Gosling and Stone do. Musicals are dying and La La Land wants to resuscitate. The story is craftily done and is so vintage that I kept having to remind myself it is actually set in the present day, as one minute its The King and I with its purity and vintage playfulness, but then we catch a glimpse of a smartphone or a rendition of the 80's hit "Take On Me" . It's clever and pure.
If La La Land wasn't deserving of technical praise, I'd be disappointed I spent time with it. Pretty, nonsense, safe pish.

Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone give it their all in this modern day oldie. La La Land is enjoyable, beautiful and heartbreaking. Take the lead characters in this film and consider what could have been done, to perhaps make us care about them, and give the film a chance to succeed, in spite of the poor script and, as so often happens, a story that hits quicksand for an hour in the middle. These are two struggling, undiscovered talents, right? Does Hollywood have any clue how many dazzlingly talented actors, singers, and dancers are out there? Do they not understand that we love story and talent and don't care if Ryan Gosling is in the movie, singing and dancing when he can clearly do neither. These two wouldn't last a qualifying round for Dancing With the Stars and yet are cast as the leads in a blockbuster musical? Simply because of their name. And the film suffers in pain for it, along with the audience. This is one of those films that Hollywood loves because everyone in town has decided they're supposed to love it. This town is great at that; agreeing with itself. And critics don't criticize; they idolize. They're as caught up in the mirror gazing as the rest of the industry. The true tragedy about this film lies in what it could have been. You want to know how to make it? First get a script-writer. But, after that, call Broadway and find some real, legitimate, mind-blowing, musical stars and go from there. I got this for free and took three sittings to make myself get through it so I could see the ending that everybody hated. The film is excruciating, aside from Emma. It's like the makers of the film ignored the story the film was trying to tell and turned it into a multi-million dollar high school musical by casting the two most popular kids in school.

Remember that time your parents promised to get you fireworks for the 4th of July and they came back with sparklers? So much promise and so little delivery.  Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling's charm and the few times good jazz is played almost makes up for the mediocre musical numbers. The movie goes quickly enough because it feels like something good is just about to happen, but in the end La La Land doesn't quite know what know what's it's trying to be and when the climax comes the characters aren't rounded enough for you to care.
It's alright but not for all those oscars ...

A majestic film beautifully crafted and perfectly executed with great preparation by visionary Damien Chazelle. Each scene is captivating and enchanting unto itself. The visuals, music, and camera work alone are reason enough to see it. Add likable characters with aspirations we can all appreciate, and you are sure to get pulled in. Wonderful fun acting by Emma Stone, Ryan Gosling and even J.K. Simmons.
Let's talk about the music. The tunes are fun, catchy, and wonderfully suited for a story like this. You don't have to love musicals or jazz (which I don't) to enjoy this. Even if you don't love each song, there are sure to be a couple you will find yourself singing in the show later that night. I can easily see this becoming its own musical, which it should be.
The only flaw to this spectacle is the story. It's good, if not great at points. But in this case it's one of those films that the sum of its parts is better than the whole. Soak in the beauty of each scene for all its worth. 
If a movie's purpose is to make you feel something and distract you from your everyday life, then La La Land excels.

The movie had the the feel of a first rehearsal and did not measure up to even the most obscure television musicals that have entire series to produce on lower budgets. This was a sweet movie and it was mostly bearable to sit through. Perhaps it was amateur feel and appeal that was being sought, which is fine. However, this aspect was taken a bit too far.

LA LA LAND is undeniably well-crafted with a great vision and impressive realization. The film also arrived at the perfect time. The "Golden Age" of movie musicals was during the Depression and WW2, a time when people needed an escape. After a grueling campaign season and bizarre result, a lot of people encountering malaise and despair have found relief and pleasure in LA LA LAND.
As a fan of classic movie musicals, I bring many biases and quite a high bar. LA LA LAND fulfilled in ways I hadn't expected. Shooting dance numbers head-to-toe in long takes brings energy and excitement, VS the trend in recent decades to cut-cut-cut close-up shots. Frankly, in MOULIN ROUGE and CHICAGO, I could have done the "dancing," which is comprised mainly of closeups furiously edited.
I was also impressed by the establishing of musical themes that resonate throughout.
As expected, Hollywood is over-congratulating itself for taking a "risk" and making a throwback musical. Starts strong but bores later. Sing Street far superior!

It's so easy to be fashionably churlish about a film already laden with Oscar potential. What's not so easy is to admit is that it's wonderful. From the performances to the music this is a rare concoction of parody and pastiche blended with a huge dollop of heart. A sharp script adds to genuine poignancy to the fun whist some sublime flights of fantasy keeps its eyes firmly fixed on the stars. It's a delight.

And the year of 2016 in Films comes to an end with a surprising entry of a musical none the less. Yes it is a musical and no, not so much a chick flick just more of a modern musical feel with a splash of 1940's World's Fair feel to it. 

Mia (Emma Stone) is an aspiring actress trying to get into the industry of Hollywood, who runs into Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) a man literally driven by Jazz Music, both are struggling to "make it big"  slowly at first develop a relationship which takes them on a journey to go after their dreams even if a long the way things don't go the way they want to. Yeah Original Story...... 

I had heard two things about this movie. ONE IT IS AMAZING and Two it's Overrated but good.  I liked it. Didn't hate it. But don't think it is AMAZING in all aspects. Story it self everyone has seen before, especially in musicals. The cast is really good, Credit to Stone and the eye candy. The songs are....well I know the tune if I hear it again. But not something that I recall straight away.

BUT The cinematography and the editing of this is AMAZING! So rich in color makes it seem like it is a play on stage at times. It is like if Moulin Rouge took a breathe and slowed down and was actually good. The Dance numbers don't have any cuts and they are just continuous, will give credit where it is due BUT Broadway actors and fellow theater people do that all the time so not something I'll usually say it was amazing, but felt fresh. 

Again, It is a present day Musical that feels like a musical from the 30's and 40's with the world's fair style to it. Very well done but I don't 2hrs is necessary. WAY BETTER than recent musicals for films like Mamma Mia, Moulin Rouge and even Phantom of the Opera. Just didn't find it as New and Revolutionary as critics have made it out to be.

AGAIN I enjoyed it. Had my little nit picks with it but maybe that is because with musicals I tend to lean towards The Little Shop of Horror's, Sweeny Todd's, Avenue Q's or Phantoms over the Sound of Musics and King and I's

I usually spend my Sunday evenings in the bath or beside the fire.  This weekend I decided to do something different to warm the frozen cockles of my heart.  Or so I was promised.  Could it be that my heart is stone, unlike the busoms of the most acerbic of film critics?  I had dragged my musical-hating other half along, and alas this is not the film to send him leaping for joy into the aisles of Soho theatres, far from it.  Once upon a time, songs had lyrics which told a story.  Once upon a time, musicals had songs which told stories.  These stories were told clearly through clarity of diction and lyrical intelligibility.  La La Land is a cacophony of mime and piffle.  I could start with the relentlessly vacuous wide-eyed blankness of the heroine, or with the scruffy immaturity of its hero, I could begin with the criticism that neither has the slightest yearning to bring happiness to any character save their own self-pitying, self-indulgent, self-obsessed, worthless self.  But instead, I pity the actors, the pre-producers, the post-producers, the composer, sundry editors and the entire cast who had been given such scant materials with which to create a film.  The plot is thin (read: emaciated) and no matter how many tap dances, abrupt cuts, vibrant outfits or quirky sets the audience is presented with, a flatlining script is simply beyond rescue.  Put simply; I was bored.  Not once did my heart bound, not once was it touched and this was because the script was empty, bland and soulless.  Therefore, I write this as a warning; do not believe the misleading hype, lest you, like me, should be sadly disappointed.  As for next Sunday, I shall return to my bath.

I dragged my daughter to see this film, as it got such high ratings and won all sorts of awards. As we sat and watched the first 15 minutes of the film, my daughter & I looked at each other in utter amazement how awful the film actually was. Look...I get it. I really do. It's a love letter to old cinema & Hollywood musicals of the 50s and 60s, circa Singing in the Rain & such, that's fine. But that's just it...La La Land is fine, and nothing else. 
I wasn't expecting to love this movie, right off the bat; I don't particularly care for musicals, despite the respect I have for some of the classics. And I didn't hate this one, it's very technically well made...but I felt like it was playing a little too heavy on the style with very little attention to the substance, is all.
Aside from some impressive shots and one or two catchy tunes, it's nothing I haven't seen before starring two characters I have seen quite a many times. Emma Stone (Mia) & Ryan Gosling (Sebastian) are perfectly capable (albeit flawed, but nonetheless) people on their own, trying to make their way through the neverland of Hollywood, but when coupled together, are painted with very unrealistically forced chemistry that just does not work for me as the crux of this film. I found it both shallow & unbelievable how their arc unfolded while together, and by the end of the film, felt better that they actually went their separate ways.
If not for the message inspiring optimism to the dreamers out there, I probably would have written this off worse than I'm making it seem. But it does have that heart, and I get it. I get why this film is as loved as it is...I just don't think it's the greatest thing since the invention of the camera, is all. A little too much vanilla and a case of the member berries left me with a slightly bitter taste of overhyped, overrated, underdeveloped, and above all else, just an okay piece of cinema.

It's All About Mia!

Damien Chazzelle's new take on musicals is vibrant, original and involving from start to finish. It has a fresh, searing intelligence to it and is much better than his previous film 'Whiplash', which had some similar themes (male obsessions, jazz, etc).

It is a film of two halves, a bit like it's template (which it subverts) Singing In The Rain. In the first hour, its a romantic boy meets girl tale. But the second hour shifts into - which one of them will achieve their dreams? Both? Neither? And this is where it turns convention on it's head. Because in the traditional romantic tale, the boy and the girl get married and live happily ever after. No, this is 2017, and the feminist message prevails. Girl gets dream - but not with this obsessed jazzer. She gets success, husband, child - but not the guy who we saw in the first hour, but another, richer guy. Our hero, he gets success, but is left lonely masturbating his piano keys all alone. In the sexless world of romantic musicals, our hero bends over backwards for her love, and when she gets what she wants from him - she goes off to her success and he is left playing the piano. He pumps her up, sells out himself, makes her write her one man show, cooks her dinner, drives her to her successful (and for him, fatal) audition. She does zilch for him.Nothing. That's because it's all about Mia (me), geddit?

While Ryan Gosling is a handsome, contained obsessive (almost autistic), she is a flat chested, google-eyed baby. Neither and sing well or dance but somehow that does not distract too much. Nor is there any lust in this film, only 'romance.' That is enough of an explanation for the audience. But it seems a bit inadequate for me.

Now don't get me wrong, I was going with the flow like most other viewers of this film. I  loved its smooth surrealism, some of its tunes, and overall flow. In particular, the final flashback flourish of an alternative ending - the only way to resolve the ending in a way that was NOT tragic (for Seb, the 'hero') - this was astonishing, bravura film making. 

La La is a dead cert for Best Picture 2017 - it is too clever and in touch with the modern audience to lose out. Musicals without professional singers and dancers? You need a professional writer and director, and that's Mr. Chazz.

As a huge fan of director Damien Chazelle's previous work Whiplash, I eagerly anticipated the next piece of work to come from this immensely promising young director. Lucky for us all, that wait was blessedly brief with La La Land. 

Many critics will repeat what was said about the release of The Artist, which similarly "breathed new life" into the genre of musical film. However, Chazelle's modern yet nostalgic expression of a 21st century musical is genuinely refreshing. The Los Angeles depicted onscreen is unlike any one I have seen before, and yet the story feels so very familiar. Two star-crossed lovers, both artists struggling in their own right, trying to find room in a crowded Hollywood. Through it all, the film is imbued with an irrepressible joy, from the very first set piece right up to when the credits roll.

Emma Stone is the star of La La Land, with Ryan Gosling just about her match. The chemistry is palpable from the start, which only carries over to the song and dance routines throughout. For two actors of limited musical experience to pull off an achievement of this magnitude is tremendous, and their passion fills the screen.

Technically of course, the film is beautiful to look at. Chazelle made astute choices to marry the contemporary with the vintage, even down to the car Gosling's character drives and the long takes. With another superb Justin Hurwitz soundtrack, we have gotten the musical we never knew we wanted, or needed.

I was really hoping this was going to be an enjoyable movie, yet I'm surprisingly disappointed. Maybe because I just saw Singing In The Rain on the big screen last week that this is such a poor comparison to a superb musical. I appreciate the desire to make a movie that's a throwback to the musical genre, but it's too hodgepodge. There were moments, but just a few of them. They can act, but it was obvious they were pushing their chops with singing and dancing. THAT was not tap dancing. Ryan Gosling was impressive on the piano, but I was not sold on Emma Stone. If they wanted to sell the singing, then they shouldn't have had a professional such as John Legend in the movie. His pipes proved how lackluster the other musical numbers were performed. I enjoyed the ending sequence minus the obvious American in Paris cliches. The rest of it was very original. Thank god they didn't sing in the rain!  I wanted to leave after the first 45 min, but I just had to stay and see how it played out. I felt the actors needed another couple months of dance lessons (with the exception of RG's dance with the older woman on the pier. That was lovely.) I will leave this on a good note. I enjoyed the piano playing.

I did not think I was going to like this movie but it was fantastic! Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling are perfectly cast; they are not over the top as you might expect with a big movie musical! The story is touching and shows the harsh reality of "the business" and life in general, which is that all success is not without failure. We all wish we could have it all, but life is all about choices, this film shows us that! I am so very impressed, La La Land is a musical, a satire, a drama, a love story, a comedy, and everything in between!

Unfortunately I saw this movie after all the Globes fervor, and reading both positive and criticisms which colored my viewing experience. Despite that, I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. Gosling, despite his best, pales in comparison to Emma in basically every aspect. The score is amazing and will have you singing all the back home. Loved Linus's camera - especially the long takes, which compels you to soak in each scene. The creativity liberties taken with the movie magic doesn't hurt either. So despite what contrarians will say is yet another ode to Hollywood/LA, this is the definition of a fun movie-going experience.

I understand why the ending is the way it is, but in many ways it also betrays what the rest of the movie was going for. It leaves me with an unsettling feeling, but who knows? If you've heard people say that La La Land reminds them of classic Hollywood, they're right. However, it's so much more than that. A film like this is why people love going to the movies. It's funny, sad, joyous, and sullen whenever it needs to be. It's charming without being cheesy. It's a musical, but unlike most animated films put out by Disney, this movie is geared towards a more adult audience. That's not to say that you can't bring the whole family along. It barely earns a PG-13 rating.

Ryan Gosling delivers an exceptionally good performance, especially with the jazz piano he had to learn. Emma stone brings a lot of heart and soul, and really makes you feel during the lower points of the plot. And speaking of the plot, it was refreshing to see one where the focus was almost entirely character driven. This can be quite hard to pull off when you're not dealing with an ensemble cast, but Gosling and Stone did a great job. That's not to say that supporting performers like John Legend lag behind. Everyone in this film has a part to play.

If you're like me and not a musical lover, it's worth giving this one a shot. Unlike modern takes on Les Miserables, this film doesn't force you to sit through endless amounts of plot-device-songs. The musical numbers are tastefully used, especially the jazzy numbers. Definitely a worthy Oscar contender.

Maybe I liked it because I could relate to it.  Who knows.  My wife loves Ryan, so it was a definite "win-Win", ha ha.

To La La Land we go for the new film by writer and director Damien Chazelle (who previously made Whiplash), who brings us this new take on the classic musical films of Hollywood, that delivers a musical in the traditions of Hollywood but also with more emotional complexity and depth than  you would expect.

Gosling plays Sebastian, a jazz pianist who ambitions to start his own jazz club have recently faltered since he lost his savings to a con man. Stone plays Mia, an aspiring actress working in a coffee bar on the Warner Brothers lot, and working from audition to audition with little success. The two are drawn together through a number of chance encounters and so begins a love affair including some wonderful song and dance moments.

The two have worked together before in both Gangster Squad and Crazy Silly Love and their onscreen chemistry remains and works perfectly for this film. What this film brings though is a whole new level of both of their previous work with singing, dancing and on Gosling's part, piano playing.

The initial half of the film is stuffed with musical set pieces from the opening number with cars in a traffic jam, through to 'Fred and Ginger'-esque sequences between Gosling and Stone.  There is less a standout song, rather more a standout musical melody that weaves through the film (and is the basis for the 'City of Stars' song that does feature).

It also is as much a love story towards Hollywood itself with its references and usage of previous film classics and sentiment towards LA.

There is a point in the film where Gosling is discussing Jazz with a fellow band member. The band member says that although their music is different to the classics of the past, the people that created that classics were innovators. As a result, new work has to not just repeat the old, but create the new and be bold enough to be different from the past that inspires it...

This dialogue gives us context about the structure of the film itself. The song played at one point that starts as classic jazz, but then shifts into something new but with the spirit of the past, seems to capture the principle of the entire film itself.

Chazelle is clearly passionate about music within film and what he has made here is not just a traditional musical, but with stronger emotion and more of a character romantic drama than I expected. I suspect how Sebastian talks about Jazz in the film Chazelle may well in part feel about musicals in real life.

Not only is La La Land a love letter to the best and brightest of Hollywood and a re-emergence of the classical musical style, but it also shifts through the film and challenges the genre itself. This is the real strength of the film.

From both the quality of the film, and the generous sentiment towards Hollywood, this film will do very well through the awards season, and that's not unfair.

I really really wanted to love this and feel swept away, but I wasn't. It feels disjointed and shallow somehow, the underlying mood is sad and melancholy. There were wonderful moments, not enough though, I found it slow in places too. When it ended I just felt a bit empty and disappointed.

Tuve la oportunidad de ver La La Landa la Tan Aclamada y Galardonada cinta de este Año y realmente vale la pena? Realmente si, siendo casi una Obra de Teatro Musical en formato de Película, con Grandes Actuaciones, Química, Historia y Fotografía Espectacular.

La historia se centra en Emma Stone y Ryan Gosling quienes por cuestiones del Destino se encuentran varias veces en su Camino, y Terminan Enamorándose, Los 2 tienen Grandes Sueños como ser Actriz o ser un Gran Músico de Jazz pero tendrán que vivir con muchos conflictos ya que estamos hablando de Hollywood donde esto es casi imposible,.

Tenemos Grandiosas Actuaciones de todo el Elenco y una Gran Química entre los dos Protagonistas que se siente muy Real...aunque prefiero la de Andrew y Emma...La Trama es muy Cliché y muy Básica pero eso es lo que hace que la Película Funcione, Podra tener las cosas mas vistas o bobas del Cine, Pero el Director le dio un Toque, Una Chispa que hace que el Espectador ame la Cinta. 

Merece ser tan Galardonada y tan valorada? La verdad si, Por fin un Musical da de que hablar después de tantos años, Incluso si no te gustan los Musicales, Disfrutaras la Película porque No es Aburrida, No es Tediosa, desde el Inicio ves el Intro Musical en la Autopista y te adentras a este Mundo.

Pero si mi Único Conflicto con la Película es su Final, Podre ser lo mas Cursi pero quería que los Dos se quedaran Juntos...Y FunFact en la Persona en la que hayas pensado en ese Final...Es el Chico o Chica Ideal de tu Vida.

La La Land es una Gran Historia de Amor, Un buen Musical y algo que Vale la Pena Valorar, La Fotografía es Hermosa, Las Actuaciones son Geniales, La Música es Genial, Y creo que se Disfruta mas si la Ves con tu Pareja...Es por eso que Recibe mi Clasificacion de 4.5/5

La La Land is a very special film as it's something we never really see anymore. It's extremely rare for a big budget and high profile Hollywood musical to be made, but now we have La La Land. This is the latest film from up and coming director Damien Chazelle who previously directed the modern masterpiece Whiplash and wrote the brilliant yet underrated 10 Cloverfield Lane. La La Land is a fantastic movie! This is the kind of film that needs to be experienced on the biggest screen possible as this really is a masterpiece. This film is amazingly directed by Chazelle, he brilliantly stages all the musical scenes but is also able to tell a very heartwarming and mature film. It's a technical masterpiece with fantastic production design, costumes and sets. The cinematography by Linus Sandgren is a marvel for the eyes and the film looks amazing. It's the kind of movie where you could take a freeze frame and hang it on your wall as it all looks so amazing. The musical set prices are brilliantly filmed with lots of excellent pans, zooms and unbroken shots. The music is also amazing. This film will undoubtedly win the Academy Award for 'Best Original Song' and deservedly so as the songs are a perfect balance of fun, crowd pleasing and beautiful. The dance choreography is brilliant, the opening number is so well done and staged. The dance scene with Gosling and Stone is also fantastically done. Speaking of which the acting is superb. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone have previously worked together on Crazy Stupid Love and this film further cements what a perfect paring they are due to their fantastic chemistry. Both are excellent here and play off each other brilliantly. Emma Stone is truly excellent, she's charismatic, she's funny, she's charming, she's endearing and it's all down to the wonderful performance from Stone who will undoubtedly win an Oscar for her truly spectacular acting job here. Ryan Gosling is also brilliant, I was worried from the trailers he would just be playing a very sad character but while he is at times he's also unbelievably funny here just like his work in 2016's The Nice Guys. Gosling really gives it his all as his character is so likeable and funny and it's truly some of his best work. He has a few scenes where he plays the piano here and I wouldn't be surprised if he learnt all the numbers just like Miles Teller did for his drum solo in Whiplash. Gosling and Stone also have surprisingly brilliant singing voices which I wasn't expecting. La La Land feels really unique due to the unique look and honestly beautiful sequences that honestly make you want to watch this film again and again. The film is also a perfect mix of poignantly sad and unbelievably entertaining and fun. I don't think I've smiled at a film so much in a long time as this is a really heart warming movie. The ending however is very clever as it's so hopeful but also so sad. As for problems La La Land has very few minor ones. One was the film is a bit too long as it feels like you could cut about 10 or so minutes, also there's a boyfriend character introduced early in the film who feels quite unnecessary. There's also a bit where a character played by musician John Legend appears and a tension is somewhat introduced between him and Gosling but it never goes anywhere. However these problems are easy to forget with just how excellent this film is. La La Land is flawed and not quite as good as Whiplash but it's still amazing and one of the best movie musicals ever. A truly excellent film that should be seen by all and is proof of what talents Chazelle and everyone who worked here truly are. La La Land is a true modern masterpiece. A
I loved the music, the atmosphere and the picture! It is revolutionary. I like that it is very realistic as well. I can wait for the DVD and I can't stop listening to the soundtrack.

La La Land review. I was at the shops and I knew that it was the last day of the holidays. Neither Marie nor I were super enthusiastic about going back to work because the holidays had been absolute bliss. We wanted to finish on a high. So La La Land it was. I had already seen some comments about this movie being uplifting and just plain enjoyable. So it seemed like the perfect movie to launch us into the year. And I was completely right. From the opening traffic jam dance number to the closing sweeping montage of storytelling I was lost in a beautiful world of optimism and music. I had a constant smile. Well mostly. The film is still real enough and filled with enough varied emotions that you get to feel waves of sadness alongside all the joy. But even those beautiful heart wrenching scenes just make you appreciate this film more and want to leave the cinema skipping and dancing around street lights. I have been an Emma Stone fan for a while now but I love that I have been converted into a Ryan Gosling fan as well. Their chemistry is magnetic. I absolutely loved La La Land and you might too. I know at least one person who detests musicals and would probably struggle with this movie. But if you are normal like me, and love musical theatre, then you will get a big kick out of La La Land.

La la land impact as a singular kind of freshness to the quite fatigated film industry heavily based on reboot, sequels and beyond. The film shines through a well balanced story, a remarkable editing which makes the film always being perfectly paced; a nostalgic cinematography: shot on film, and supersaturated colors; adding an well choreographed camera movements, and always supported by a montage that reciprocate with the tone and mood of the film. Those latter elements build up for a loose and sober directing by Damien Chazelle, who it can be noted that he's perfectly comfortable with weighing in the responsability  of the movie to the protagonist, which in this case, are perfectly casted and impeccable performed by Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, who shows are fine chemistry to react with empathy throughout the film. To conclude, La la land, revitalize the musical film genre to empathize with new generations, its sobriety with telling of the story creates comfort with audiences with no familiarity of the genre; and the film has the equilibrium for both, music and film goers, who will not be disappointed. 

However, considering the film one of the frontrunners in the Award Season, La la land is quite powered up on technical categories (editing, production and costume design, cinematography, original score and song) but, on major categories the film start to languish: On acting categories, though Gosling and Stone give dazzling perfomances cannot be located on the powerhouse perfomance, there's a lack of range in the development of their characters, which their charms are based on the choreographies, music and suitable locations, lacking on emotional depth; the latter, helps on the directing side because of the momentum that the becoming of events rise on the sensation of catharsis; that's why director Damien Chazelle, plays safe with musical film genre and even more on the screenplay side, which is conveniently crafted to serve as reflection of 50's, 60's and 70's films which kept a similar mood in much of the design of the film (which is justified in a dialog in the movie), and must of all, this nostalgic and intertextuality create a poor challenging as a contender for this category. And finally, this very almost oversaturated nostalgia lacks  the transcendence, on what ideally, a best picture film must posses.

Reviewed 1.20.17. As a fan of the classic song & dance movies of yesteryear, I like everything the movie is trying to do. I just wish it did them better. It is indeed a charming homage, but it falls far short of actually replicating the genius of its inspirational material. 

I realize it isn't fair to expect modern actors to dance like Gene Kelly & Syd Charisse. They were trained as dancers, whereas modern actors simply take a crash course in the art. The days of Fred Astaire are long gone. But on the flip side, Emma Stone demonstrates how today's performers are actually better actors. And as much as Ryan Gosling seems grossly miscast, he does bring the classic Gosling charm to the role. 

Damien Chazelle deserves credit for taking these sort of bold chances, but he does not universally deliver the goods. The pacing slows too much at times, the dialogue has its weak moments, and the tone shifts all over. Abrupt tonal shifts fit masterfully in his wonderful movie Whiplash, but instead keep this movie off kilter throughout. And for a movie billed as a bold return to musicals, let's just say none of these tunes will be remembered as classics. 

The last moment with the two leads was also a missed chance. A classic Gene Kelly wink and Audrey Hepburn smile would have been the perfect cherry. The movie can't seem to decide whether to mine the melancholy or campy angle, but is at its best with the latter. 

Despite these short-comings, there are enough bits and pieces here for those enamored with the genre. I can see how the uninitiated would find it pleasant enough, it's basically the light beer of musicals. And it seems that in a bad year for 'academy-type' movies, it's drink enough for most. For me, I'm gonna mix up an Old Fashioned and pull the real deal off my movie shelf.

I was only going to give this movie a 1 star rating but I'm going to be generous.  Now before I get into this review I would love to say this movie had me in tears, it had me laughing, it was a beautiful tribute to the olden day movies/musicals. The singing was perfect, the dancing was adorable and multiple times I wanted to join in.  Truly a masterpiece.  Now onto the review.  I won't spoil anything but a fair warning to those who want to see the movie, the ending, sadly, ruined it for me.  In this film you had 2 people who started out as enemies really but due to some coincidental circumstances get to know one another and develop into these beautiful, passionate human beings.  As you watch their relationship flourish and watch their interactions, the way they build one another up and truthfully push each other to achieve their dreams, you're captivated and inspired and see the importance of each other in their lives.  But then, as the movie synopsis says, things get in the way.  Again I don't want to give anything away but the ending left me...wanting, it left me confused, it left me angry.  It's a must see musical, don't get me wrong, but towards the end of the film I wanted to walk out.  This could have been the perfect ending.

Maybe that was the subtle point but I doubt it. Certainly no chemistry between the stars, and the theme may have been plangent but I found it wanting. I was unmoved until maybe the scene where she auditions and sings, again clever rather than felt. I think the word I would use is manufactured, and the magic scene in the planetarium just seemed odd. I kept thinking about the innovative and wonderful Moulin Rouge and hoped for that sense of unreality and fantasy, but it never came. Sorry folks 2 stars max and utter incomprehension at the mass hype. And what about those odd Anime type eyes she has?

WHAT I LIKED: Damien Chazelle's 'Whiplash' made you so nervous you could burst, but the beauty of his 'La La Land' is that it manages to play with all of your emotions. I cried, I felt empathetic for the leads, I felt reflective, but most of all I felt happy; happy that this charming film exists, and just happy with myself for being a film and music-lover in general. Yes, the sheer fact great music and beautiful filmic moments can be put together so wonderfully had me catching myself looking up frequently in proud admiration of what talent can do.
And actually, this is a film that gets you to look at yourself rather a lot. Mainly, and pretty incredibly, the way it explores people's views of the past whilst also in itself representing a thing of yesterday means you feel the themes extremelly directly - in other words the affect the film's own nostalgia cards have on you make you realise what Gosling's character in particular is all about.
As for Stone's? Well her arc is about dreams just as much as Gosling's is also, and that's clearly something Chazelle is fascinated by. But don't for a moment think this is a film where the themes come at the expense of anything else, as they work organically with the characters to form genuinely poetic and beautiful arcs for them to go on. That marriage between theme and character is one of the most crucial ingredients in this kind of film, and luckily here I felt I understood the two enchanting leads right from the start. Their chemistry is magnetic, they stand on their own, and Gosling and Stone's pairing with Chazelle's genious writing and direction brings the very best out of an allready-great story.
Their development is also helped by the musical elements too, and whilst this was something I was slightly concerned about going in, the arrangements work because they organically explore and further the characters, but also because they're used in the perfect moments and never overwhelm Chazelle's ever-apparent ability to deal with nervous silences. Basically though, it never feels like a cheesy excuse for a song and dance, more an ironic neccessity (though I have to say the splendour of the score and coreography means I probably wouldn't have minded if it wasn't in this instance anyway).
In the end though, all this development and character enrichment builds two very dream-like characters, who yet also feel so real - which is one lucky thing, as their beautiful love story is the foundation for everything else. With that, and whilst using all the things I've talked about so far, Chazelle layers on top a brilliantly nostalgic and light-hearted tone, a visual masterpiece, a technical joy and a film that all-in-all won my heart as much as it did my mind. La La Land is an incredible yet charming movie that achieves so much so well, and if you haven't seen it, you should definitely go to the theatre and support it. Honestly it's brilliant.
WHAT I DIDN'T LIKE: Whilst its enjoyable light-hearted nature made it a real joy, there were a few moments where I felt it could have taken itself a little more seriously overall.
VERDICT: 5/5 - This encompasses so much and delivers all of it so expertly. How Damien Chazelle is allready this assured frankly stumps me... what a guy, and what a beautiful movie.
What fun to see a musical for our generation.

it was a magical journey , love it all . the performance was great .. the music was wonderful especially city of stars and the fools who dream <3
the end !! oooh it was heartbreaking , unbelievable and sooo realistic

La La Land is a film with incredible direction, outstanding performances, great cinematography, amazing musical numbers, and fun characters. That's about it. This movie gets a lot right. But it really gets a lot wrong as well. The pacing in this film is so uneven. I felt like I was in the theater for a whole day. The singing in this movie was very mediocre and really didn't blow me away like it did everyone else. The dancing in this movie is good but it could've been so much better. This movie is very slow and confusing. The whole end sequence dragged on way too long and made no sense whatsoever. If you're looking for a good movie by the same director, check out Whiplash. It is a lot better than this. La La Land gets a 6/10. It might get bumped up a little higher if I see it again.

Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are two of the most enjoyable people to watch on screen...even more so when they're together. La La Land is a throwback to the old musicals of yesteryear. Don't yawn...it's been pulled forward with all that was good from those old musicals but with a modern twist.

You know, there was a movie a few years ago.."Once"...a twist on the musical...a modern musical some said. I loved it for it's smallness and intimacy. I love La La Land for ability to be both big and small...draw you in with single spotlights on the character and it's creative way of telling the story. 

It's love story of sorts...love of jazz, love of the theater, love of dreams and finding love in different and unexpected places. 

Technically, this is a beautiful movie to view. It's almost filmed as a play...on a big stage. Songs come organically...and dance helps move the movie forward. It's just so well put together, the music is so good, visually it's beautiful and the characters are darn likeable that I had a smile on my face almost through the entire movie. I hope this movie makes gobs of money so that more are made like this.  I highly recommend it.

The title of La La Land couldn't be more apt. Damien Chazelle's awards season favourite takes place in a fluorescent, happy-go-lucky L.A. where prangs and pitfalls add little but a giggle to the daily grind.
The film is admirable in both its boundless energy and cheeky theatrical stylistics, with writer-director Chazelle's love of music seeping through every frame. At times we think he might take a shot at telling his story entirely through tunes. At times we think the film's musical aspect has gone completely out of the window. But, for the most part, we just sit back and smile while all the general breeziness distracts from the impenetrably formulaic romance at the film's heart.
La La Land takes an introspective turn in its latter reels, but until then, its no more than an escapist treat led by a skilled cast and a superb director, whose high concept permits his imagination to run wild.
aesthetics, soundtrack <3

My friend recommended this film to me (he absolutely adores musicals) and I must admit I was slightly sceptical at first... Nevertheless I valiantly trekked 40minutes to the cinema on a chilly January night and ended up having my heart thoroughly warmed by what can only be described as a cinematic masterpiece! The classy vintage feel to the film was a pleasant change from the modern cinematic trends of overused CGI and poor graphics. The relationship between the two protagonists was both believable and captivating, laying the foundations for an enthralling narrative without shortage of surprises. This film truly surpassed my expectations for what a musical could offer, so much so that my friend couldn't quite believe his ears when I told him I'd loved it!

You know how there are certain movies that give you the willies (maybe it's a minority thing).  For example, White Christmas.  I watched the movie because it's one of my mom's holiday fare favorites.  But it always bugged me.  For me it was literally white Christmas filled with extraordinarily white people, groomed to perfection.  The snow didn't make me feel any better either because all we have in Los Angeles is gray pavement.  I love old movies, but I hated that one.  Whenever I hear Bing Crosby's voice on the radio come Christmas time, I change the station.  That's because there's no room for me in that world.  That's the type of place where disgruntled America wants to go back to. 

 

La La Land gives me the same fluttery feeling.  The story is simple.  Nothing we haven't seen before about struggling artists with expensive 1950s new-vintage attire driving Prius' and trying to attain their dreams -- only it's peppered with song and dance routines.  The movie is so in love with the past, the good ol' past where people like me can't visit.  The movie was hugging the 1950s and 1960s like my neutered dog ghost-humping my leg.  If they chose to embrace the 1940s, people like me would've been thrown in Manzanar even though I'm not Japanese.  In the '50s I would've been exploited in the fields in Central Valley, California, picking prunes and cash crops. 

 

La La Land is pretty to look at.  I'm really not into musicals but the singing and dancing was okay.  No Astaire and Rogers there.  Emma Stone's voice was way too quiet, but what do I know, I sound like a duck in a tub.  Ryan Gosling plays the piano well and was a good student, but the music is not that sick.  I have records of jazz pianists like Art Tatum, Thelonius Monk, Dave Brubeck, and so on, and what Gosling played was pitiful in comparison for a supposed musical genius to lord over kolordz musicians.  Watch Jazz by Ken Burns and listen to what I'm talking about.

 

Since I love Los Angeles, I enjoyed the scenery (hey what's up, Watts), but the fluttering and feeling of fear that this kind of reverie about the olden days kept me sedated and worried.  They showed the good stuff,  Griffith Park Observatory which I'm never going to visit again, million dollar homes with swimming pools, and Watts Towers.  Watts Towers, you say?  I sure didn't see wandering dogs or the bleeding-soul neighborhood like the one I know.  The towers that symbolize courage and hope for the neighborhood who are gripped with poverty and prejudice was used as a dating background. 

 

That's what bothers me about this movie.  It's all too nice and clean.  My neighborhood is actually more colorful.  Paleta man, fruit vendors that offer lemon, salt, and chile in a plastic bag, and a lot of under-dressed Latinos and Asians that liven the neighborhood.  I didn't see my true city in the movie.  Even gentrified Grand Central Market looked too New York.  Gosling's interracial friends seemed so fake that whenever we see them, she's kissing him and he's looking static.  Tacked on. 

 

I'm worried that this damn movie might beat Moonlight for best picture of the year.  Moonlight is not a replica of anything.  It's a complete original.  Not Barbie and Ken busting it out on the backdrop of a famous Los Angeles view.  And yeah, I'll kill it and tell you the end.  They both realize their dreams.  You know why?  Because they are... 

 

Damien Chazelle, this is L.A. not New Jersey or New Hampshire.  We Angelenos are proud of our diversity.  There are folks worthy of film parts besides your windup ballerina dancer world.  To be kind, I loved Whiplash.  Best drum movie since Mickey Rooney's five-minute Andy Hardy impression of Gene Krupa.  Think Trump, man.  Make your next film about Kolordz people trying to get in the industry and getting passed on for white actors.  I really hope you don't win Best Picture, man.  You got enough Globes to feed your reveries. 2whitecinema.
Fiercely original, beautifully shot, well acted, great music, and pure emotional moments, La La Land is a new age masterpiece.

Question: What do you get what do you get when you mix classic silver screen nostalgia, old school jazz music, breathtaking cinematography, powerful performances, top notch directing, and a whole lot of feels?
Answer: You get the best movie I've seen in years!

When I saw the trailer for La La Land I thought, "hey, that looks like fun". How wrong I was. La La Land is so much more than fun. It is a beautiful, heartfelt tale told in incredible fashion. It is the kind of film that makes you want to laugh, cry, and cheer, sometimes all at once.

Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling may me the most relatable, young actors in Hollywood today. There is this sort of unassuming everyman quality about them that causes you to fall instantly in love with their characters and become immediately invested in their fictional lives. Both bring an incredible emotional range and realism to their performances and their on-screen chemistry is perfect.

La La Land is not merely well performed. It is also beautifully and artfully shot and lit. Writer/Director Damien Chazelle's use of light to direct the viewer's attention is highly creative and more akin to something you'd expect from a live performance. The overall visual presentation is wonderfully composed and features stellar camera work.

It should be noted that La La Land is a musical. It's an unusual musical in that it contains no catchy show tunes, memorable vocal performances or showstopping dance numbers. To be clear, the music and dance in this film is good. The jazz melodies are beautiful and the singers can all sing, and choreographer Mandy Moore (no, not that Mandy Moore) has crafted some very satisfying dance sequences. However, where many musicals from the "Golden Age" were big on spectacle and many of our modern musicals are more concerned with social/political commentary, this musical just wants to tell you a story. It's a story of two people with big dreams and the joy, pain, hope, despair, success and failure they experience on the journey to achieving those dreams. The story is the main attraction and the other stuff is just there to help tell it.

La La Land is witty, fun, intelligent, poignant, and authentic, a breathtaking artistic achievement with loads of heart. I was made to feel so many emotions, from sadness and regret to joy and hope and walked out smiling through my tears.Anyone who leaves the theater without a tear in there eye, a spring in their step, hope in their heart, and a renewed desire to chase their own dreams is dead inside and there is no hope for them.

A surreal experience. A well-made film that was a pleasure to see on the big screen. I am still not sure how I feel about the bittersweet ending though. (First and only viewing - 1/21/2017 in theaters)

Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone shine in a throwback to a time when movies like this existed. I'm going to have to have the grin physically removed from my face.

Wish we could just live in La la land!  I want to go take some dancing classes now.  Came home and started streaming the music.  Makes me feel excited like I'm a kid again.  I just wanna put on a dress and go dancing in the streets!  The only thing I didn't like was the "real" ending. I want the happily ever after!

There is a lot of charm, theres an honest reality to it actually, and there is this magical side throughout. I highly recommend checking this film out.
I hated this film, boring, bad singing not much dancing it was terrible. Can't believe so many people like it. Comparing it to Hollywood bygone genre is just an insult to the great.
