This was absolutely the most boring piece of schlock that's come down  from Hollywood in some time - and it's got a lot of close runners up. Not even an adequate love story. All fluff - no substance. This is far below the bar of such musicals as: My Fair Lady, Sound of Music, West Side Story, etc. - not even close.  But this is typical of the trash the film industry palms off on the public as so called "art" for a fast buck. Following the example of a couple of other couples, at 2/3s through, I got up and walked out. From now on, any time the "professional" critics rate a movie above the consumer rating, that's the one to skip.

Hit upon strange cliches but they weren't over done, and certain jerking vocals from R. Gosling, genuinely was very moved at moments, this film was very well scripted and acted, but too strange, and the opening scene was poor and didn't fit with the rest of the film

Well made, some great routines (along with several weak ones) and jazz performances - but you've definitely got to like song and dance musicals. 

Personally I find the story and connection with the actors gets lost a bit when the fake smiles and jazz hands come out - a trap that (eg) Moulin Rouge (or even children's classics like Mary Poppins!) managed to avoid. 

La La Land is only semi successful in this regard - but a strong ending. Though as my friend put it: "The ending, or it ending?" ð???

My cup o'erbrimmeth with the exquisite cinematography, thoughtful editing and sheer passion demonstrated by all involved. As good a musical-movie as one could hope for - though perhaps I prefer the directing and acting over the actual narrative.
A little bit slow and it's not really a musical...
A nostalgic feel to this Hollywood musical. A delightful dreamy alt sequence at the end that I sobbed my way through....

I did not fall asleep during the movie, but did not find it that entertaining.  I thought the acting and the singing were average, although Stone is better than Gosling.  The story line is not that interesting and is predictable.  The audience for the showing I attended was weighted 80%+ women so perhaps women find it more appealing.

After a lot of hype and a lot of awards, I was all set to be underwhelmed by what was bound to be an over rated Hollywood love letter to itself. Well, yes, it is a film in love with Hollywood, but it is also a charming and engaging tale of acting, jazz and love. Stone is especially good, while Gosling's rather bland blankness works pretty well. I liked the story telling structure and the wit and style. The musical interludes are not especially memorable apart from Stone's audition song at the end that is rather good, but in the context of the film, Stone and Gosling's good but not great singing and dancing fit well. 
Does it deserve to scoop all the awards? Well no, I think Arrival is a much more memorable and profound film, but LaLa Land is very appealing and Stone should be considered up there with Jennifer Lawrence as one of the best young actresses around.

If ever there was a cure for the January blues, this is it. One of the most magical movies I've seen that lives up to the hype and surprises and delights. The musical numbers are a big part of the film but it's also a cheery, sunny love letter to Hollywood. Makes you want to jump out into the street singing as you leap away in search of your dream. Bang on.

Placed in the genre of 'Musical', in which I am incredibly interested in and will indeed watch anything with a foot tapping, soul popping song in it; this film has caused me great pain. After watching the three different endings, I am now officially ready to off myself. The writer must have certainly been in 'La La Land' when he wrote this as I can genuinely say that it was most certainly the worst thing that I have ever seen, which is an accomplishment on its own because trust me, the day my own grandmother showed me '2 girls, 1 cup', I was very nearly close to throwing up as well as throwing my nan out the window of the world's tallest building whereas with 'La La Land', I was hoping that I would choke on my own vomit and die a sudden untimely death while being eaten alive by a raccoon and have no friends or family show up to my own funeral because I deserve to be harshly judged by not turning this film off as soon as I realised how terrible it was (about 30 seconds in) but alas I did not and I shall continue to live my life in misery but with the extra suicidal thoughts that this film has provided me with. The only thing that I thought was worth watching in this was the gorgeous Ryan Gosling but even so, I had to mute the screen whenever he spoke to avoid being put off during my wank. As well as being annoyed at how much time I'd wasted watching this film; each time Emma Stone's big bulging eyes were on screen, I found myself cowering behind the sofa, in tears and screaming for my alcoholic, abusive mother to come save me from this horror. There is much more I can say on how awful this film is but I shall leave you all with this, when the Police find my body hanging from a ceiling fan, point them in the direction of La La Land.

Do not believe the Rotten Tomatoes hype. The 2 leads are not nearly able to carry the entire film which is the burden that was placed on them. It is not their fault, I'm sure they are very talented people but there is no there there as far as the story. There's only a couple of big cast numbers and they fall flat because the music is all one note. Really very disappointing. Rotten Tomatoes should not do this to people.

A beautifully crafted movie ,a movie that shows the drive for success by our characters and  their love for each other at the same time.The technical aspects of this movie itself is stunning and not to forget that the movie also has a great story along with superb performances by the actors Ryan Gosling and Emma stone.This movie is a must watch if you're into music , a romance fan or just a film enthusiasts.Overall La la land is a musical to remember.

Sheer perfection, outstanding, mesmerising, excellent, Gosling & Stone are the new Fred & Ginger, you'll smile from start to finish. Genius filmmaking. You'll wanna watch it over and over again. And with 14 nominations I can't see why this incredible film can't break records and win 12 wonderful deserving Oscars. Charming and beautiful.
Excellent theme and fun to watch!  I never knew these 2 actors are so talended!

A fun throwback to the golden age of cinema, though I have to say that a movie about two unknown artists who are struggling to gain any recognition for their craft feels a bit inauthentic with the casting of megastars Gosling/Stone. I felt the movie was a notch above mediocre, but the bold, out-of-left-field last 10 minutes twisted my heart into a deep appreciation for the final direction of the story.
Excellent, and I don't even like musicals.

La La Land is Damien Chavelle's (Whiplash) love letter to Hollywood musicals, teaming up Emma Stone as Mia, a struggling actress and Ryan Gosling, as Sebastian a jazz musician who both share a goal of making their dream come true.

As someone who generally isn't drawn to musicals, I wasn't expecting to like La La Land and I did the find the opening quite jarring with so many happy, shiny dance numbers I was afraid I was going to burn my retinas.  Once you get past the tweeness of it all and the film settles down I really began to enjoy the film and the chemistry between the two leads.

The film looks gorgeous, with a rich colour pallet and I really liked the subtle nods to the films of 50's and 60's especially with regard to how the film is shot. 

As with all good musical what sets it apart is the strength of it's song and dance numbers and La La Land provides some memorable moments especially a scene which is featured on the film's poster of Emma and Ryan dancing against the backdrop of Los Angeles but I think my favourite songs are City of Stars and Here's to the Hearts.

La La Land is by no means perfect as many critics would have you believe, however it is very enjoyable and in an age of so much uncertainty it's a great piece of escapism.

Let's be honest. La La Land is good, but it's not as good as Whiplash. The film features a great soundtrack, great cinematography and direction, but the few songs that are present feel out of place. As someone who enjoys musicals, I had high hopes for La La Land but sadly the songs felt awkwardly presented. This is possibly because the lead actors are not the most natural of singers, which is easily noticeable. If I could change the film, I would include more of the Jazz soundtrack, and lessen the songs with vocals. Overall it's still a good film and certainly worth a watch for the style alone.
Great movie with excellent music.  The dancing and singing were pretty basic but it was fun to watch.
It's slow. I love musicals but this is an average movie if you were to compare it to the classics. It's also sad. Left me bummed all night.

While Gosling and Stone give fantastic performances and the music certainly gets in your head, with so many ideas and styles added to the film, the story often becomes light and too reliant on its end product.

I went to see this purely because I loved Damien Chazelle's Whiplash in 2014. Musicals are normally not my genre but after 7 Golden Globes I just had to check it out. I swore myself I would keep an open mind. I liked the story (albeit a bit too sickly sweet) and the actors were all good. Also visually it was a nice homage to Hollywood's golden age. But. I could have lived without the dancing and the mediocre singing. I didn't feel they added anything to the story itself. Leave those scenes out and you've got a decent film. And you would have had time to explore Sebastian's sister who was an interesting character in the beginning of the movie but then quickly forgotten. Also John Legend in a supporting role was a good choice but it would have been nice to learn more about his character's history with Sebastian. Now it was just noted in a side remark.The film was full of references to the true classic films of the 50's and I can see this going down well with the members of the Academy. I hope they can resist the nostalgia.

La La Land is just amazing. It is one of the best live-action musical films ever made since Mary Poppins. With an engaging story, likeable characters, excellent performances by Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, a lot of fun and catchy musical numbers, great cinematography, costumes, make-up, editing, art direction and production designs. Everybody should go and see it, no matter what. It's a must-watch. 5 out of 5 stars.

The most interesting thing about LaLa Land is the title.

I went expecting a visual feast and some great production numbers, the opening sequence provided this and I spent the rest of the film thinking was that it ? 
It felt very flat, very slow and I just couldn't engage with the two lead characters that occupied the screen alone for a large chunk of the film.
Because the plot was flimsy it needed to make up for this with great production numbers but instead we were given a half hearted pastiche of the old greats with dodgy singing and dancing.

After listening to my two friends fidgeting in their seats throughout the whole film, stifling yawns and managing to eat all their jelly babies I knew I would not be alone in my condemnation of the film as soon as the credits started to roll........when asked I said just one word.....
FLAT.
it's a shame because I loved the cinematic style used which felt very retro.

What a disappointment...........

A classy modern day musical. Now I don't like musicals that much. The idea of telling a story through song is old fashioned and so unnecessary. But I do love originality, great acting, and a new take on the same story. That's what La La Land is.
The movie is for both dreamers and romantics. Two people, one with a dream for acting and the other for music, meet by chance. There is foreplay, flirting, dancing, singing, and then of course love. It happens naturally and it is hard not to fall in love with these characters as they are falling in love with each other. Especially when played by Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, their third time around playing love interests. They live in Hollywood and they inspire each other to be best they can be and to keep chasing their dreams. But, like dreams usually are, they bring heartbreak and drama into their relationship. Real drama, not the usual Hollywood movie type, but the kind that nearly everyone watching can relate to. One of the best moments in the film is a painful dinner scene with Stone and Gosling arguing about how their relationship is going to stay intact while they both keep pursuing their dreams.
Now their was about 20-30 minutes in the middle of the film that felt dragged out and lost my interest for awhile. But, the ending is very powerful and deep. It is one of the best endings I have seen for a romance film. Loved it so much. You'll here lots about it at awards time, so if you want in on the buzz, go see it in theaters, it is worth it.

So, one of the most critically acclaimed films of the last few years has hit cinemas in the UK and I don't like it... In fact, I'd go so far as to say it's pretty wank... How edgy am I right? But seriously, on paper this film should be a fully fledged 5* from me. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone reunited, it's the new film by Whiplash's director Damien Chazelle and it's a musical centred around jazz music, a blossoming love story and creative hopes and ambitions. So why, to me, does it fail at every hurdle. First off i'll talk about the positives. The production design, costume design and dance routines are certainly well crafted and pretty and we haven't seen an original musical before in quite some time on the silver screen. Obviously you have the sumptuous eye candy of both Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone who are fairly decent and as it is their third time together on screen it is undeniable that they have good visual chemistry. Editing too is also creative as it was displayed in Whiplash and would expect nothing less from a picture from Chazelle. I also admire the fact that the film takes chances in story techniques regarding it's lineage and changes in perspectives which seemingly feels rare among 21st Century big budget film making. Oh! and the film has a tremendous trailers, maybe one of my favourite trailers of all time and still gives me goosebumps even though I've seen the film. 

However, laying it all on the line for you, I found the film to be one of the least engaging things i've seen and half the time I was quite frankly bored. This feeling is not from overhype or heightened expectations being let down. I went in extremely neutral and was hoping to have fun. But I just didn't and here are some of the reasons why. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone I found to be rather unlikable characters. Gosling more than Stone didn't engage with me on an emotional level and so I didn't have much investment in their plight regarding their relationship or creative endeavours. Regarding their relationship there also seemed to be the most minimal amount of effort put in, in terms of trying to develop their bond, in the form of several montages to show the passing of seasons without any actual real conversations or even visual stand out moments within the montages themselves. This gape in solid characters also didn't help the plot because there was barely any plot. That's not to say films with minimal plot are bad, but films with minimal plot HAVE TO HAVE good solid characters to keep the film afloat, otherwise you are left with a sinking ship like this. Secondly, to be a successful musical, one would assume the songs would have to be good or at least toe tap-able. Not in the case of La La Land though. What makes it worse is that the two memorable songs are featured in the trailer, so seeing the film in the hope to discover more hits leaves you dissatisfied. The constant reprise of "City of Stars" I also found to be rather heavy handed and made me think the creative team KNOW this is the only good song at their disposal. Lastly, the ending is quite simply insulting to the audience. I understand the juxtaposition of what Chazelle puts before us showing us two different perspectives of either follow your head or follow your heart but it is displayed with obvious bias that feels almost rude to those who might empathise with a certain path. Not to mention it undercuts the entirety of the film you've watched up until that very moment. 

There are other nit-picky issues and I could go on, but those to me are the biggest faults within this apparent "enchanting" escapade of cinema and while I understand the complaints about the film being "fascist", funnily enough, that to me is the LEAST of it's problems. Now, if there's one thing people know about me is that I am a sap. A big girly sap at that. So for me to come away from this film and have this response is quite sad when I know other people really enjoy it. The film for me is the epitome of all frosting and no cake. But hey if you enjoyed it then fair fucks and if you did, please argue with me as I would like to hear someone who isn't a critic for some blog or newspaper tell me WHY this is an awards contender. So please... If you've seen it, let me know WHY I'M WRONG?? Ta thnx bbz xoxo

Grade:  A
In a Nutshell:  With a theme song that will be stuck in your head for a long time, this unexpected romantic musical feels like one of those magical movies Hollywood use to pump out decades ago.   

Beautifully shot in CinemaScope, it features the glamour, hope, sacrifice, pain, and dreams found in Los Angeles.  

It's very entertaining and honest, already winning a Golden Globe for Best Motion Picture - Musical or Comedy, as well as a big trophy for both of its lead actors: Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling.


Uplifting theme: 
"People love what other people are passionate about." - Mia (Emma Stone)
Here's to the ones who dream...
"You gotta give this everything you got." - Sebastian (Ryan Gosling)
Things I liked:
Emma Stone's face can show a thousand different expressions.  She is so charming that you just can't keep your eyes off of her in every scene.
It's fun to hear some good jazz.  Sebastian explains, "You can't just hear it; you have to see it." 
I know they must be partially or even completely manufactured, but I loved all the pretty LA sunsets. 
Ryan Gosling.  Good on you.  He can do it all.  It even looks like he really played the keyboard. 
Ryan and Emma Stone have great chemistry.  This is not their first movie together.
I love the scene where they hold hands for the first time.  I remember those breath-taking moves from dates gone by.
It's really such a breath of fresh air. Keep those musicals coming.
John Legend!
Written and directed by Academy Award nominee Damien Chazelle.  Nice job!
I liked how the movie announced the seasons, reminding us how the seasons of our life come and go.
This film reminded me of last year's film Café Society that makes you ache with love, regret, and longing.
Is this film a love letter to Los Angeles or Hollywood or being passionate about your dreams? Or maybe all three?
The musical numbers easily blend into the traditional storytelling.
The sequence at the end was done so well.
I didn't expect to see J.K. Simmons in a musical!



Things I didn't like:
I love Emma Stone, but I'm just wondering how much more fantastic this could have been with Anna Kendrick in the female lead role?  Maybe match her up again with Justin Timberlake like when they were together in Trolls?  Wow, can you imagine how great the soundtrack would have been?  As it is, Emma and Ryan aren't what I would call "powerful" singers.  If Director Chazelle was going for "sweet and simple", then he nailed it.
That string of hair that constantly droops in Sebastian's face.
The sound isn't always quite in sync with the lips.
It was funny, but also super annoying how Sebastian would honk loud and hard when he went to Mia's house and pick her up. Really?  Be a gentleman and go to the door, Bud.
It conjured up images of great dance numbers with Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, although not nearly as good.

If you specifically hate musicals, this movie isn't going to change your opinion. In fact, it very well may intensify it. But if that is not the case then it's almost a fact that you will love La La Land.

Writer/director Damien Chazelle, hot off the acclaim of his previous film Whiplash, showcases that the precision and tenacity he displayed with that film was no fluke. La La Land is handled exceptionally from start to finish, both as an homage to musicals of the Golden Age of cinema and to modern Los Angeles, its beauty and its numerous pitfalls.

Right off the bat, we're tossed into the action with a massive, jubilant opening number, that tells us we're in for a ride and to strap in. La La Land doesn't shy away from being a musical, and any skepticism I had about Chazelle's ability to balance the musical and non-musical aspects were washed away within minutes. It's the brilliant rom-com, musical hybrid we hoped we would get.

Stars Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone show off the chemistry they've honed that have made them one of Hollywood's great on-screen couples. Singing, dancing, and acting up a storm, they prove they've earned their clout. Stone gets second billing, but she's really the star, surely on her way to a second Academy Award nomination. She commands the film with incredible range, often funny with the ability to turn on the waterworks at the drop of a dime. Gosling is as charming as ever, though not the most fleshed out character. He had motivations, he had a plot, but aside from being love struck, he lacked a ton of emotion, though that could totally be in part due to the exuberance Stone displays throughout.

I could throw praise around for everyone. But even more important than Chazelle's masterful direction or Gosling and Stone's charm, is the actual music, and Justin Hurwitz deserves a trophy, a medal, a blue ribbon, every award out there because his score is spectacular. It is was carries the film into the realm of the extraordinary. It actually might be so good that it could be perceived as a detriment, and I mean that in the best way possible. It's so good it almost brings down the movie by comparison.

If this movie has any flaws, it's an over-abundance of ambition. There are a few scenes that depart the film's overall grounded tone that, while visually stunning, pulled me out of the film. I am fully aware how insane that sounds when talking about a movie where people break into impromptu song and dance, but it's an honest opinion. The story is also nothing that's going to shock or awe. It kind of falls in line with most romantic comedies.
What differentiates it from most romantic comedies though it how expertly it's handled. Everything in front of and behind the camera works because it was meticulously crafted to be perfect. La La Land goes above and beyond what is expected of it, and the result is a musical everyone can fall in love with.

this charming movie is an unashamedly nostalgic love letter to years of cinema gone. The musical numbers to the impromptu dance routines make this a throughly enjoyable film for lovers of film old and new.

the 2 leads in this film Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling are superb. They both manage beautiful nuanced performances. They have fantastic chemistry as shown in previous films (crazy stupid love & gangster squad) but it really comes alive in this film.

the direction and cinematography of this movie is sometimes visually breathtaking. Damen Chiselle has proven what a versatile director he is with this movie and is willing to take a real risk.

where this movie does fall flat unfortunately is the pacing. At times the movie feels like it drags and could do with slimming out. At just over 2 hours this film is fairly long for a musical of modern standards. Also I felt the ending to be rather disjointed and jarring.

That being said I still found this movie to be absolutely charming and has a brilliant musical score you will be humming and whistling for days to come.

So now I know the secret. This is the film widely expected to clean up at the Oscars. But, surely not; after all, it's a musical and the archives are full of musicals!
So they are; it's just that they are not quite like this one. Despite a beginning that suggests there is nothing new here, this is not exactly like other musicals. As it settles down it becomes clear it is beautifully understated. The pairing of Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone is inspired. They run with a first-rate script but never let it take control. Emma Stone is brilliant, Gosling equally so in a laconic and endearing fashion. They gel to such an extent, that one wonders whether this film would have made quite such an impact if the leads had been different. 
This tale of two wannabes in LA, enduring all that Tinseltown can throw in their faces, captivates us throughout. As Mia, Stone has the weightier part to shoulder, something she does with the assurance of a seasoned actor. Whilst Gosling is so cool - so entirely likeable - that he wins us over by just rolling up his shirt sleeves and tinkering with the keys on his piano. 
This has all the shmultz, but none of the shmutz! 
A rating seems irrelevant. If you like well-made movies with a popcorn container-full of emotion, you will love this. If not, you won't be seeing it in any case.

There have been plenty of movies where I've said, "Oh. I liked it." La La Land is a step above that as it is a film I will remember for a while.

La La Land offers a stunningly beautiful portrayal of the joy of falling in love, as well as the agony of trying to follow your dreams. This throwback to classic musicals features an impressive opening number and powerful performances from both Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling. It gives us the sweet without being too sappy and shows us the bitter without being too pessimistic. Here's to the ones who dreamed up this film.

So I'm not going to say musicals are my favorite genre of movies, but it's not like I don't like them either.  When a musical is done as well as La La Land, it is hard not to like.  First, I liked the music, but I wouldn't say there was one song or number that I would want to hear repeatedly, but the quality is very high.  Next, the set pieces and backdrops are incredible.  It sure likes they did these scenes on location, and if so simply amazing.  I just was impressed by the sweeping crane shots and continuous single camera action that didn't dominate the film, but when used was extremely effective.  The opening sequence, while tacked on, is an amazing single shot.  What this movie comes down to is the relationship between Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling.  These two nailed their performances, and I was was impressed with Gosling.  His piano playing I hope was real, and not sure how he could've faked it with that many tight shots of his hands.  The movie drags slightly and I wasn't crazy about the scene at the planetarium.  However, the ending for this movie is simply incredible and makes up for any flaws the film might have in my book.  This would have been a five star pick had I enjoyed the actual music more, but in this day and age of sequels and do-overs, this is such a refreshing stand alone film it is hard not to enjoy.

Many have praised La La Land's hopefulness ... It's actually a deeply cynical work, positing that love between two ambitious people is impossible and must forever remain a fantasy. That Chazelle can make his point so artfully is what sets the film apart.
Exceeded all expectations

I absolutely love this movie! It is musical theatre perfection. Love the stars, love the music. I've heard some critics say that Ryan and Emmas voices aren't perfect, but that's one of the things I love about it. They seem like everyday people, not operatic stars. Magical!
Excelente em quase todos os aspectos, mas esperava mais do roteiro e da construção de personagens.

I waited 6 months to see this movie.  I love musicals, love Emma Stone, love romance.  How could I go wrong with this?  Well, first off, I really want to rate this 2 stars, but the only reason it's getting 3 from me is because there are just too many awfully depressing and boring movies getting huge praise during this awards season, and at least this film is light and airy.  La La Land may be a "darling" of a movie, but it's just not strong enough for a Best Picture in my opinion. It just lacked passion, true love, and real romance for me. I didn't feel it (mostly Gosling's fault).  Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling are super hot and gorgeous.  Where was the passion for each other?  Heck, if Eastwood and Streep can heat up the screen in Bridges of Madison County (I know, ancient reference), then so should Stone and Gosling. I feel the writer/director (Chazelle) doesn't know (due to being young and naive maybe) how to portray that kind of romance and love that makes our hearts burst with emotion. I mean, if you watch Castaway's ending, you know what I mean by two people who've loved and lost (Hanks and Hunt).  Now that's a scene!  La La Land's ending didn't have the effect on me that it should have had (and I'm the biggest cryer, and I happened to also be PMS-ing when watching this, which would have heightened my emotions greatly). I didn't cry.  I should have.  So now let me mention also that while I understand the throwback to classic Hollywood musicals, I still wanted to see new and cool choreography.  I've seen plenty of Mandy Moore's work and I think the dance numbers were extremely "safe."  Even pedestrian. I don't think Stone and Gosling even worked up a sweat (wanna see someone work up a sweat -- watch Catherine Zeta-Jones in "Chicago" and then tell me who kicked ass more).  I could tell that Stone could have done so much more (physically).  I really wanted to see a twist on the old and not just the old.  Yes, the sets were cool.  But the dancing and singing -- not.  Now onto the singing: both Stone and Gosling can carry a tune, but I didn't hear anything extraordinary (again, referencing Zeta-Jones in Chicago -- she sang her face off!).... Overall a disappointment for me.  I think Chazelle will go on to do greater things in Hollywood ("Whiplash" had a lot more passion for me!), and Stone will get her Oscar either with this movie (ugh) or a future one. She is a mega star, but I wish I saw some great stuff in this... like Viola Davis in "Fences."  Sorry, but I didn't think the screenplay was strong enough to bring out those "Oscar moments" in the actors.  I so much wish there were quotable lines.  Wish there were scenes that just make you cry because you want these two to never stop loving each other, but there were no such scenes written or directed.  I've got more screeners to watch... let's hope I find something this award season worthy of 5 stars.

In my opinion, this movie is deserve to swipe all the awards. First, I really love all the retro color's domination that Chazelle bring into this movie. Second, The choreography are so unison yet not too exaggerate so that brings so much energy to the audience. My favorite part is the beginning scene where the dancers are dancing in the traffic hour.Third, I have to say that picking Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling as the lead role is a smart choice. Stone's acting is undoubtedly stunning as Mia Dolan, same goes to Gosling playing Sebastian. Their characters are fit together and looks funny(Remember the tap dancing scene!). On the other hand, the performance of All of Me singer, John Legend as Keith (Sebastian's friend and lead vocal of their band) is pretty good and I cannot say that Legend's appearance is not just "an appearance".Legend showed his skill as an actor on this movie (we know he is a very talented singer and musician). Apart from the cinematography aspects, actually the most interesting part for me is the message, when Sebastian supported Mia to stay motivated to reach her dream as an actress, which is "If you have passion about something, just go for it and don't give up upon your dream. It is such a strong message for anybody who wants to pursue and reach their dreams, including myself. So,  I really expect in the future Hollywood will create more creative stuffs and peculiar ideas like this movie. In sum, I dare to say that La La Land is a perfect musical romantic movie that brings it's own peculiarity yet inspiring to enjoy in the end of 2016 and the early of 2017.
Not as great as they'll have you believe. And the ending sucked!
So boring movie, give fake inspiration.

I didn't expect to like this movie as much as I do. A beautiful love letter to jazz and the city where dreams are often broken. Emma Stone & Ryan Gosling are perfection! It didn't feel like a movie to me, it felt like I was in a dream.

a simple tale with proper picturisation..  a film with lots of fun of a relationship but a sadness beneath it.. maybe not so perfect but it is what it is.. this film defines itself. it shows the true quality of performance and direction.. how to make a simple film into a masterpiece.. but the last act of the film just blows everything.. it makes me happy but with an incredible amount of sadness!! it makes me smile but feels like something heavy on my chest!! a film with proper building up of character...hats off to ryan and emma for their incredible journey of this tale!! and there is nothing to say to Damien Chazalle!! he is a masterclass!! incredible!! a must watch film!!

This movie for me is an anomaly, it's already hard enough to find someone who likes classic, musical or jazz then how much more for a movie that is all about those three things, finding the audience who will like this film is almost impossible. This is a type of movie that should be just a niche with a cult following and it should not be this good or let alone be this popular. It is a modern film with classic undertone, okay a cliche romantic-comedy with singing, dancing and jazz. The main characters are not perfect, the relationship is far from ideal and both the singing and dancing of Emma Stone, who gave her best performance, and Ryan are not "professional" looking. Don't expect for the singers to belt a high note or expect a Step-up type of dancing and that is why I love this film, the character's imperfect singing and dancing was perfect for me because it represents their imperfect relationship but both tried to make it work and this movie works because of that. I honestly could not find anything that is wrong about this, from the awesome continuous shot at the start to the one of the best ending sequence ever. It is as good as a movie could get.

this film is OK. it's quite slow moving and pretty boring at parts. the hype in my opinion is pretty overrated. there are better performances this year and better films out there. I know this is a homage to old musicals from the 50s, but it's really not on the same level.

La la land is a delightful treat to the eyes and the ears! It's a fun homage to the musicals of the 50s set in contemporary times. Gosling and Stone's chemistry has even gotten better since Crazy, Stupid Love and who'dathunk they had the musical and dancing skills to pull this all off?! Director Damien Chazelle does impressive work fusing the lively soundtrack, the fun dance choreography, and the insane camera work into one amazing package! Still, it would have felt all very formulaic except for the climax which really packs a real emotional wallop and makes this musical stand out from the rest of the crowd.

Damien Chazelle continues his artistic love for jazz and grand musical compositions, following his success in Whiplash, with an all-new or in this case, old-fashioned musical comedy. La La Land includes two talented performers with both Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, who are exceptionally perfect for one another both romantically and professionally. This is a film that begins with a jovial tune, but ends with a bittersweet note. It is highly commendable that the audience's expectations are adrift until the very end of Mia and Sebastian's journey into the bright lights of the city of dreams...the city of angels. Although there are scenes that often drag, a compelling tale and a great deal of detail in each scene enables La La Land to triumph not only at beckoning to modern moviegoers, but also at capturing the hearts of many ambitious dreamers.

A follow-up to his Oscar winning film, Whiplash, Australian film-maker, Damien Chazelle has daringly written a beautiful and audacious story about dreams and hope.

A movie making can be an art-form and a beautiful one, and La La Land captures all of that. Every musical number is filmed in single takes including its sensational opening scene where Linus Sandgren's camera swooping, swerving, weaving and flying around the performers (once of the best musical numbers ever filmed & one of the best scenes all year).

The moment it was over, the moment I wanted to see it again.

La La Land is a story about two struggling artist and dreamers, Mia an aspiring actress who serves lattes in between auditions and Sebastian a dedicated jazz musician who's trying to save the dying jazz music. Both found themselves in love, but as success mounts they are faced with decisions that begin to fray the fragile fabric of their love affair, and the dreams they worked so hard to maintain in each other threaten to rip them apart.

This 31 year old dude, Damien Chazelle has masterfully crafted the usage of color, sets, costumes and music to tell an emotional story. The film uses old school techniques that were used in 1920's and 1930's to tell a contemporary story to modern audiences that doesn't feel derivative. With modern day Los Angeles as the backdrop, this film captures the beauty of the city that feels unique and magical. One of the strongest elements of the film is the orchestration, Justin Hurwitz score captures the authenticity of the story. It's playful, touching and thrilling.

Mia Dolan, played impeccably by Emma Stone who gives the best performance of her career. It is fun to witness how she grow in every film she's in. In this film, you won't remember her as, Stone, you'd remember her as a mature and aspiring actress. Sebastian Wilder played by (never been better) Ryan Gosling who had been practicing playing piano for months to perform several pieces in the film including the film's theme, gives an excellent performance as a struggling jazz musician aiming to save the sinking world of jazz music.

La La Land is irresistible and unforgettable piece of cinema and a wonderful gift to all movie lovers. It is brisk, spectacular and breathtakingly crafted. It is unlike any other musical movies you've seen before. La La Land is truly a musical triumph!

We don't get films like this anymore. Please do not wait to see this on a device on can hold in your hand.

Here are the critics I agree with. "The cinematography and special effects are fantastic, but don't actually compensate for a weak storyline, and forgettable musical numbers." "Sometimes a movie comes along that is so different, so refreshingly light, so right for the moment that people can happily forgive it for not being very good." I guess "I believe people when they say they are moved or enchanted by the film; it just didn't move or enchant me."

I love the chemistry Emma Stone and Ryan Gossling have on film...but I was disappointed in this one. All the hype did not prepare me for the poor writing and bad singing. The atmosphere provoked a feeling of old technicolor musicals without keeping my interest. One star for the casting, and another for costumes, the rest fell short for me.

What to make of La La Land (2016)? It's a mixed bag. The presence of Emma Stone keeps afloat this film. The camera clearly loves Emma Stone, especially a dancing Emma Stone. I would have been happy with two hours of dancing Emma Stone. On the other hand, honestly, her singing voice is weak. Talking Ryan Gosling is charming (for the most part). Dancing Ryan Gosling is OK, too. But a singing Ryan Gosling is an excruciatingly experience, which can only be described as painful. What about the music? Well, we have to make some distinctions. The non-vocal compositions are pretty good. The best singing performance is a song reserved for John Legend. When his 'band' plays on-screen, the film briefly soars as a music video. Then, there are the showtune songs, which are really not good and forgettable (one can only hope). As to the story, it is uneven. The best scene involves Emma Stone pretending to lip sync to "I Ran" by A Flock of Seagulls (and the best joke references said song moments later). Honestly, when the best songs with lyrics in a musical are 80s cover songs (in a pool party scene), then the showtunes component of your musical is not up to snuff. The 'conflict' brewing between the two principals two-thirds into the film is completely contrived ("you're not following your dream" "No, you're not following your dream" "I know you're not but what am I?"). La La Land continually hints at a charm that it fails to fully achieve, dropping it into the lower-middle tier of Hollywood musicals. So yes, La La Land is overrated. However, as a promotional film for Los Angeles tourist spots, it's quite good. Mark's Grade: C
Very slow to start, and as a result left out a lot of major plot points at the end.  Very disappointing considering all of the awards it has won so far :-(

"Here's to the fools who dream", sings an anxious Emma Stone as she auditions for her numerous role after picking herself up from a destructive Hollywood town that beats her spirits down with no remorse in the alluring film "La La Land". Director Damien Chazelle, has had enduring effect on the jazz films with his hypnotic  Academy Award Winning Independent film "Whiplash". Much like that film "La La Land" moves with not just breathtaking musical numbers but with as a amazing love letter to other musical films that inspired it such as Jacques Demy's "The Umbrellas of Cherboug" and "The Young Girls of Rochefort". The film however isn't like the other "love letter films" like Quentin Tarantino or Robert Rodriquez where it mimics the films that it loves then becomes its own classic. Chazelle however knows how to make his film stand out and be its own, with its colors, set pieces, its realist narrative as well as it keeps itself at  tone, its not trying to be "meta" or "self-aware". Instead the film stays confident in itself and its audience showing it's audience an original story that feels like a genuine Broadway show. The film stars Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone as Sebastian And Mia, two L.A. artist's trying to make it in the town full of dreamers with broken dreams, one is an aspiring Jazz Musician who wants to keep the original form of jazz alive while also opening his own jazz club, while the other is an actress trying to get a role but keeps getting shut down. The film does an amazing job of keeping everything grounded in realism not being stray from showing the dark side of life in Hollywood, while it also shows this prepossessing imaginative musical numbers. Much like "Whiplash" this film shows the struggle of being an artist  and reconciling your dreams with the need to be human. He shows this with both characters and their drive for their passion and the floating high of what its like to be a dreamer in the modern age. Stone has been flourishing on screen since here best supporting actress role in the 2014 Academy Award Winning Best Picture "Birdman Or The Unexpected Virtue Of Ignorance) and she doesn't shy away from it here, she has amazing chemistry with Gosling (whose character have a slight resemblance to his characters he's played in the "TheNotebook" as well as "The Nice Guys"  as if they were all from the same blood line which is perfect mix of romance and humor for this role.) the two bounce off of each other like a ball dribbling  on the basketball court. They are both humorous and love able as their sparks fly off the camera. To follow all of this up the film also has magnificent song and dance numbers, each one surpassing the other. This film is awe-aspiring, astonishing and impressive, it also is a beautiful slice of passion for jazz and thoughts of modern day music. Worth a watch 10/10.

OK.. Musicals are NOT my thing... in fact I'd say that I generally loath the experience of sitting through an entire musical. A musical play? forget about it.. don't get me started. Anyway, I was concerned in the first two minutes of this movie when its first large-scale choreographed number broke out "uh oh.. here we go..", but by the five minute mark honestly, I was completely enraptured by its splendorous genius and magic.

This is the first pretty much flawless(?) movie I can remember in recent years, from the casting to the fine line it perfectly danced (literally) between its heightened reality and pure fantasy. It was beautiful, it was funny, charming, clever and convincing. The musical numbers were the perfect length (not too long) and the songs were great. The choreography was perfectly not too over the top and over refined. It was restrained yet incredibly ambitious. it was grand but at the same time it felt very intimate and quaint at times. I was completely invested in the chemistry between Stone and Gosling. It's obvious to me why these two continue to keep working together. Really, I'm just hard pressed to find something to critique negatively about it. 

When it ended I leaned over to my girlfriend after, half choked-up I coughed out the words "Holy shit that was good." (I know, I'm a romantic). Anyway, this movie is definitely now in my top 20 of all time favourite films. If this movie isn't destined to be a modern day classic than we're all just too jaded and dead inside.

I do not understand why everyone is raving about this intensely boring movie. I want my two hours back. SO boring, I cannot stress that enough. Love me some Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, but not much chemistry there. When you have such incredibly good looking people playing love interests, there should be chemistry galore! And they are not good singers or dancers. The music is irritating and repetitive. I will never understand all the rave reviews about this bad movie.

This is another example of Hollywood's amnesia.  A few years ago, Tinseltown went bananas over an insipid French silent movie, forgetting that it used to create true masterpieces of silent film.  There was a time when studios like MGM pumped out glorious musicals with stars who could sing and dance.  The stars of this film can do neither.  Rather than Oscars, let's give the two of them Participation Trophies for being good sports.

Although the music and dance was refreshing and a tribute to the golden years, the dynamics in how  this film was put together and most importantly, the ending, was a major disappointment to myself and others. You would think that the powers that be would give the fans a happy ending that mirrored the past in many of these types of films.  But that's Hollywood for you  ---- them all.

---- them all.

Electrifying from start to finish, "La La Land" delivers a fresh, modern take on the movie musical.

It has an infectious energy and passion for its themes, and we see the magic it creates for the world and characters it has built in almost every scene.  Each shot is mesmerizing in tone, composition and colour. 

With a great storyline and fantastic direction, this musical has it all.  It was real, emotionally and deeply engaging.  I will most definitely see this again and highly recommend it!

4 ud af 5 blå toner. Denne genoplivning af den næsten uddøde hollywoodmusicalgenre er noget af et vovestykke. Selve historien er bestemt ikke noget at skrive hjem om: Dreng møder pige, dreng mister pige og ... siger ikke mere, da det måske alligevel ender lidt anderledes end forventet. Den meget lange og forholdsvis begivenhedsløse forestilling er totalt afhængig af de to hovedpersoners udstråling og charme, og havde det ikke lige været Stone og Gosling, kunne det nemt være gået gruelig galt. Men de klarer det til bravur, og selv actionnarkomanen her var fanget, og det siger ikke så lidt. Instruktøren Damien Chazelle, som også skrev og instruerede mesterværket Whiplash, er først i trediverne og har indtil nu kun lavet tre film, så ham bør vi have store forventninger til.

My Grade:  A (98%),...Struggling actress Mia (Emma Stone) and aspiring jazz pianist Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) begin a whirlwind romance as they both pursue their dreams in Los Angeles. However, their blossoming relationship is challenged when their careers pull them in different directions.

wow.....just wow! Old golden Hollywood perfectly mixed with modern day. It has left me feeling full of life. Fascinating, magical, feel good film. Innovative, nostalgic. What a film! I am truly shocked as I was not expecting such a masterpiece. Modern romcom meets mary poppins ??pure brilliance ???

I hate musicals and I heard that this was different... It's not (on the surface) but what it is, is very, very good. Almost perfectly brilliant. The problem I have with musicals, is that who would randomly break in to song and dance, and everybody just joins in, in perfect harmony. With this film, it does feel like you're watching an old classic romance musical, yet the songs feel like, an obscure dream of the character's. Almost how they wish they could interact with each other or how they wished they'd show their emotions through song and dance. Or another way of looking at it is, when there are happy interactions or passionate expressions from the characters, we see this metaphorical song/dance number, to reiterate how they feel.
It's a musical, done in a very clever and artistic way. Unlike anything I've seen before.
I was very impressed and the story was so engaging, which probably helped. I liked it so much because I could relate with the characters. Someone that is passionate about his own art and wants to create something, to share with the world.
I'm also not the biggest romance fan but boy, oh boy. I really got in to these two character's lives. It was a bittersweet ending, oh man. The ending! What is it, with this director? First Whiplash's ending and now this. La La Land's final scenes really pulls at your heartstrings and gives you what you want, even though it could never be in a realistic world. Which is the real difference with this film and musical's before it. This is incredibly grounded in reality, which makes it even more relatable.
I was teetering on the edge, of giving this film 5 stars but I'd feel I'm just hyping it up. Even though, I can't actually fault the film. If you really dislike musicals, then maybe stay away. Though I think you might actually be impressed because I can't stand the likes of Grease or Into The Woods but I was really impressed and entertained with this one.

did not live up to hype. mediocre dancing and singing. a shadow of the great musicals of the past.

I really wanted to hate this, suspecting it was Hollywood onanism. The auto tune start played to this but came to make sense. Sorry to say the film was utterly charming and yes curiously uplifting. Emma Stone is fab.
One caption said, "they don't make movies like this anymore." Now I know why. What a bore. Wife poked me twice for snoring.

I have honestly never been so disappointed by a movie in my entire life. I adore musicals - Fred and Ginger, Gene Kelly, Busby Berkeley - for me, nothing compares to the joy and escapism of masterfully delivered music, dance, cinematography and narrative, coming together in perfect harmony. When I heard there was a contemporary musical cleaning up at awards ceremonies, I couldn't wait to see it. But sadly, I felt that La La Land failed to deliver in just about all of the categories you would expect of a musical or indeed, of a basic rom-com. 
It is no use protesting that Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone aren't song-and-dance actors - if this is the case, why on earth were they cast? What they delivered was not beautiful, it was a clunky, half-hearted, uncoordinated output which, far from a homage to the golden age of the musical, was actually kind of an insult to the craft. 
Of course, that might have been forgivable if the musical numbers and narrative plot were both strong and in sync with one other but again, unfortunately, they were trite, unoriginal, dull, forgettable (I could go on and on with negative adjectives here but whatever - they were just bad, the music did not combine with the emotional story to produce an alloy of film musical. It was lazy. I was actively bored which I very rarely am in a cinema. 
The fact that the media, the 'critics' and Hollywood generally have been singing the praises of this movie (presumably due to studio investment) demonstrates for me how deluded and corrupt the industry has become. This was not worth the price of the cinema ticket, and I'm annoyed I wasted my money based on the reviews provided. 
Oh, and as one final comment (as a number of critics have noted, and with the crucial topic of diversity in mind)  if you're gonna pick a guy to 'keep jazz alive', you really ought to cast an African American in the role, no?
Amazingly good, should have won Picture of the year but Hollyweird gets worse every year.

Orijinal bir müzikal izledik bu filmde. Müzikali sokaga tas?maya cal?sm?slar. 6 yillik emekle gelinen mukemmel nokta.

La La Land was a glittering showcase of everything good in Hollywood- emotional, thought provoking, theatrical in the highest. The electrifying chemistry between Emma Stone (Mia) and Ryan Gosling (Sebastian) was utterly convincing, drawing the viewer in to the mesmerizing love story- the happy couple transitioning throughout from Mia and Sebastian to eventually Mia and her career, and to a lesser extent Seb and his. 
	As a lover of Broadway and a true believer in the power of music in storytelling, I did find myself disappointed in the under-utilization of this medium throughout the film. Only approx.. 2 of the 12 or so songs in the show are used in the typically musical fashion. This may have made the movie more palatable for less musically-inclined audience members, but it took a bit of the charm from the experience for me.  The music itself was also underwhelming, particularly in the warble of the ever-handsome Ryan Gosling. The dancing, however, of both Stone and Gosling was beautiful and their precision and talent in execution was clear- lots of work went in to this movie, all well worth the end product. 
	Despite this disappointment, La La Land remained charming to the utmost and I left the theater spinning, wishing only to return to that colorful and dramatic City of Stars.

What a disappointment - what is the hype about?  It didn't leave the three of us feeling uplifted, as the ending wasn't happy ever after.  The last 10 minutes was totally bizarre - i.e. what could have happened.  The singing wasn't strong, but the main song, which reoccured was a good tune.  6 people even walked out of the cinema whilst we watching it.  Quite frankly it was far too long and too slow.  King's new clothes springs to mind.

I thought this movie was a beautiful combination of Art, Hollywood, and Jazz. Great movie! Both Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are great and perfect! This is a great movie, it a great work of art and dancing. Just wow! Call me impressed! I am such a musicals and dancing fan. BRAVO! BRAVO! BRAVO!

There is some spectacular choreography in the first three opening musical numbers, an array of block colour and joyfulness, then we settle down to story telling and the remaining songs are applied with less full-on chutzpa. What great songs they are too, once in your head you will be humming them for months to come. It's girl meets boy, both are trying to make it big in Hollywood and their relationship goes through seasons of Spring, Summer, Fall and Winter ... plus a five years later, Mia (Emma Stone) comes across Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) by accident, and we go through an emotional and bittersweet 'Could have been' reverie before the film ends. Gosling is charming and effortlessly dances his pants off, but Stone really really shines - such expressive eyes! One of this year's must go see films that is so hard not to LOVE!
Timeless. Beautiful and Exceptional.

Posing as an homage to the classic Hollywood musical, this film is such a thin shadow of the genre it pretends to emulate that it almost is a satire. Cinematography strives to compensate for music that is not memorable, cardboard characters and very little plot. The principal actors' lack of strong talent could have been compensated for by appropriate music and choreography; the director deliberately chooses to show the squeaks and stumbles. Why? What cannot be compensated for is the complete lack of chemistry between the two stars. I'm happy for Chazelle's success but very sad that his audience thinks that this is all Hollywood musicals can do.

La La Land caught me by surprise. As much as I loved Whiplash, having only seen one movie directed by Damien Chazelle I was skeptical in his ability to produce another movie of that caliber, especially a modern day musical. Boy, I was wrong. La La Land brings everything we love about classic musicals with a refreshing modern feel. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling once again have amazing chemistry with the romance aspect of the story, but the romance isn't the best part of this movie. The passion these two characters have for their dreams is the best part of this movie. La La Land also has an amazing soundtrack. As soon as I got home from my viewing I immediately purchased the soundtrack on vinyl, it's that good. Overall, La La Land is a modern day masterpiece with amazing music, direction, performances, and visuals. I strongly recommend this movie, by far my favorite movie of 2016.

There are 7,465 things wrong with this movie, and emotional drama is one of the main problems. Instead of describing the problems I will list them one by one:

1. This is not a movie - it's a play in movie form. It's not made clear that this is effectively a play in style.

2. Too much bland emotional drama - emotions are important, however this experiment of a "movie" showcases a cheesy, boring atmosphere in fantasy that is just not relevant and lacks any sort of emotional or substantive content.

3. The end of the movie - yes, it's a bit surprising, however, it DOESN'T MATTER! The whole movie is based around cheesy emotional drama and the idea of time being taken back only randomly appears near the end. I believe the ending is even worse than the rest of the movie simply because they pretend that there is somewhere else to take this movie other than the feel good emotional .

 There is one good thing about the movie - the music is very well produced (but again, it only suits the movie for the style they achieved - which is the lame style that has no purpose other than to emotionally attach and release.

La La Land is a film for the creative mind and The Dreamer. It was brilliantly original and wonderfully directed, acted, dressed, and shot. Life isn't always glitz and glamour. Sometimes it's someone else's latte down the front of your shirt, a break up, a text message they just can't wait to reply. Life takes us on journeys that we aren't prepared for, expecting, or we are expecting to go a certain way and when it doesn't it leaves us spinning. Hot damn, Damien Chazelle knows how to end a movie. Whiplash, the best movie of 2014, ended with one hell of a bang, a rebellious drumming extravaganza that hit an insane number of climactic character beats while also working incredibly well of sheer spectacle alone. Chazelle's latest, La La Land, similarly sticks the landing, and its final ten minutes left me an absolute wreck. In that final act, Chazelle brings together two hours of somewhat meandering story and turns what looks like a curtain call into an emotional crescendo. If you subscribe to the school of moments-make-a-movie, La La Land is probably the best picture of the year. But while the rest of the movie builds beautifully to that last hurrah, its less engaging than one might expect, with most of the musical numbers working just well enough and the plot mechanics feeling all too familiar.

La La Land opens with a big musical number, as commuters hop out of their cars in L.A. to sing a sunny ditty about their dreams to make it big, putting a smile on their professional anxiety. It's a fun sequence, if not a bit over-hyped, but after that and an opening number for Stone at a Hollywood party, La La Land turns into much less of a theatrical musical than advertised. It wouldn't be a Chazelle film without a reliance on music, but only on four or so occasions throughout does it call on its characters to sing (at least in a non-diegetic fashion; on a related note, word of the day: Diegesis). This might disappoint some of the musical theater fans out there, but it works for the film. In their first real meeting, stars Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone get to connect through singing in an adorable and adorably rickety meet-cute (they aren't quite Rogers and Astaire). But their second big coupley moment is entirely instrumental, and finds Chazelle at his most directorially creative. And it works perfectly for Gosling and Stone, who have an immediate chemistry that the entire film is built around. Stone in particular fleshes out a familiar character type in interesting ways, becoming the true beating heart of the film.
La La Land is nakedly in love with the past, and some of its more interesting moments come from mixing old-fashioned tropes with the new (such as key fob woes translating to spontaneous tap dancing). Chazelle also has occasional unromanticized streaks, letting his camera focus on the cracked sidewalks that could come from anywhere in the world (and, you know, that whole traffic jam musical number). But this is a movie where an attempt to modernize jazz is mocked (if not utterly dismissed), and Chazelle seems to take that sentiment to heart. While it modernizes some old tropes, it doesn't reinvent them, and comes up a bit short of a revolution (which is a lot to ask of any movie, but the buzz around La La Land earns the request). It takes more time in the middle than it should, and by the end, maybe believes in the dream of Hollywood a bit too much itself. While not as optimistic as its cast of commuters, this is certainly a less cynical film than Whiplash was. But, once again, I keep coming back to that final act in my head. Even if its a bit of an uneven journey, the destination is an absolute triumph.

Undoubtedly the best film of the year. There is absolutely nothing negative to say about this masterpiece. Everything from the acting to the directing to the writing to the music, it's all magnificent.

Mia (Emma Stone) is a wannabe actress who works in a coffee shop on a movie studio lot in Los Angeles. Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) is a jazz pianist who dreams of opening his own L.A. jazz club but has to play gigs with an eighties cover band to make ends meet. After a series of wild coincidences in which they repeatedly run into each other, they start dating, fall in love, and become each other's biggest cheerleaders.
 
They also break into song and dance at regular intervals, because, in case you haven't heard, "La La Land" is a musical. Though I'm no expert, in the opinion of my untrained ears, Gosling's singing is on par with that of a sports star making a music video -- not cringe-inducing, but not the caliber of voice you'd expect to hear in a musical. He's no Fred Astaire either, which oddly helps even things out, like he's just some regular guy who happened to walk onto the movie set.

Fortunately, I wasn't there for the singing and dancing - in fact, I find random singing and dancing to be an awkward distraction, whether in movies or in real life. In the opening scene, traffic is backed up on a freeway on-ramp and all of these actors and actresses start get out of their cars and start singing and dancing and all I could think about was the hundreds of regular people who were probably stuck in traffic behind them. 

There's another scene where Mia and Sebastian go to some planetarium after hours but somehow they're able to get inside and naturally they start dancing and I'm obsessing over whether perhaps it's an open-air planetarium or how they got in when suddenly out of nowhere they start levitating and then they're dancing in mid-air, and I then I realized ohhh, I guess anything goes because this is a musical. (Coincidentally, Google just confirmed that "Anything Goes" is also the name of a musical. Thought so.)

But this didn't stop me from puzzling over the fact that even if one could levitate because of magical musical gravity-defiance rules, it doesn't make sense to actually waltz in mid-air since you couldn't actually push off to twirl and stuff. I know I was probably supposed to be thinking "oh gee, isn't this oh so magical and whimsical and romantic" and maybe I did for about a nanosecond but the scene went on a whole lot longer than that.
 
To be fair, it's not just song and dance numbers that cause my mind to wander off trying to amuse itself. I'm equally mystified by the supposed entertainment value of car chases and fight scenes. 

That said, the fact that this is a musical didn't bother me as much as I thought would. Most of the dialogue is spoken, not sung, and the musical interludes seem to be concentrated more in the beginning. 

My favorite scenes were Mia's comically bad failed auditions. Stone was tremendous throughout the film and deserves any awards they throw her way. I also liked the last ten minutes very much - more than the entire rest of the movie. And I liked the soundtrack.

I'd be lying if I said I don't see what all of the hubbub is about. "La La Land" is good clean entertainment, the sort of thing you can take your grandmother to. All of the dazzling on-location shots and vivid colors and swelling music belie the fact that the story itself is rather bland and the characters are thinly-sketched. 

Though I only saw this movie because it was the only convenient thing playing in the oddball 5pm time slot, I liked it better than I thought I would. The 2+ hours didn't fly by, but nor did they seem like an eternity. I was mildly entertained throughout. I'm glad I saw if only because it spares me having to listen to people telling me I have to see it. But I have no desire to see it again, not even for free. Not even for a small stipend. 

Is it deserving of all the hype? No. But it won't kill you to go with your wife or grandma or friend who is only available to see a movie at 5pm. If you're bored, you can put your time to good use by contemplating the laws of physics as they apply to dancers with truly amazing hang-times.

This has to be the most overrated film this year. I like Ryan Goslimg and Emma Stone. I loved Whiplash. However this film provides a mere shadow of the wonderful films it references. Gosling and Stone display pedestrian skills in singing and dancing. There are therefore none of the set pieces found in the iconic films of Gene Kelly and Fred Astaire. Apart from some beautiful shots of LA I am struggling to comprehend where the love is coming from.

With a good story idea showcasing the difficulty of trying to make it in Hollywood mixed in with a love story and two well known actors to bring it all together. The movie has all the ingredients except it lacks the chemistry of it all coming together and shine. The best parts of the movie is the 80s songs and piano music. Hopefully this movie will lead to other old school musicals to be produced and those will have the chemistry needed to be a real success.

La La Land: For those who dream and dare 

A movie set in the contemporary LA but whose heart and soul remains in the 40's and 50's retro glamour and style. Damien Chazelle made a daring move with this musical in a time when still there are a lot of people who consider bustling into a song and dance number in the middle of a motion picture to be eccentric or think them to be quaint. It simply puts new life in a dying genre of theatrical art.
With its flowing setting and light costumes it is a beautiful movie which should be watch with family and friends alike. With the characters swishing into magical moments it puts forward a lovely message.  
More for those who still haven't seen the movie, what are you waiting for? Go to your nearest theater and if it is out of the theatres, grab a cd but don't miss it. And those of you who have seen it would agree with me.

I just finished experiencing LA LA Land.
It was truly an experience, it left me happy and sad.
What a fantastic homage to historical Hollywood movie making with an amazing modern twist.
This movie needed to be made and now we can enjoy it as it becomes a classic.
Beautifully shot and a visual delight. Emma and Ryan are great but I would preferred a happier ending and maybe better choreography but the whole thing works beautifully.

Lalaland, the magic land of those foolish enough to believe in dreams, who love jazz, The Bird's jazz, who love Damien Chazelle and his art. I've seen it twice and both times I felt the truth echoed inside the song:
Here's to the ones who dream,
Foolish, as they may seem,
Here's to the hearts that ache,
Here's to the mess we make.

I cried and smiled and laughed and loved the music. Last year "Whiplash" movie directed by the very same Damien Chazelle made me feel sorry that I did not follow my own dreams. This year, "Lalaland" made me believe in magic, that all dreams may become true if we keep being faithful to them, to ourselves.
Ryan Gosling and Emma, wonderful Emma Stone are amazing. They are not simply actors: they are Artists, which is so rare and refreshing in this 3rd millennium. Le Caveau de la Huchette,  a jazz club in the Latin Quarter of Paris is mentioned as « the » place of real jazz. I've been there. Indeed, it may be "Seb's " jazz club. I hope that Ryan Gosling, Emma Stone, Damien Chazelle, Justin Hurwitz, will be the Oscar winners of 2017.
Just beautiful!!! I am not fan of musicals... this movie is much more than that.
Very entertaining and enjoyable movie.

An homage and a revival of the classic musicals from the Golden Age of Hollywood. La La Land provides a whimsical story with wonderful performances in music, acting, and storytelling. While not the most professional of singers, both Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone provide enough charm, humor, as well as emotional range to continuously hold viewers into a state of awe in the film's story and characters. The film successfully manages to take an old premise, add a modern setting and theme to it, and create one of the most memorable movie experiences of the past several years. With a modern twist on Golden Age music, the film distances itself from being a gimmick and instead provides a soundtrack that not only enhances and heightens the film, but will also stay with the audience long after the credits have rolled. Overall, La La Land is a magical and marvelous film that will quickly become a timeless classic for the fans of cinema.

This is like the steak you can cut with a fork, the glass of fine wine with a hint of lust, or the song that brings back a old memory - you either love it or you do not wish to partake.  Either way, it is not about the movie, which is what it is perfectly.

"The World you have entered...is dedicated to Hollywood," former Walt Disney Company CEO Michael D. Eisner declared at the 1989 opening of the then-Disney MGM Studios. "Not a place on a map," he continued, "but a state of mind that exists wherever people dream and wonder and imagine." He concluded his remarks by welcoming all to "a Hollywood that never was-and always will be." Eisner very easily could have been describing the world created by Damien Chazelle in the new musical, La La Land. Not since Singin' in the Rain, has the magic and essence of Hollywood been so effectively captured on film.
Simply stated, La La Land is a masterpiece; a stunning sensation for the senses, both visually and audibly. It's a whimsical tale about two ordinary people with extraordinary dreams, achievable because of the effects that a series of chance encounters they share with one another has on each of them.
As the film opens, audiences are transported to a musical world in which drivers, stuck for hours in one of Los Angeles' infamous traffic jams, abandon their vehicles for song and dance in the kind of ensemble performance that's all too rare in today's motion pictures. It's on this LA freeway that Sebastian (Ryan Gosling), a down-on-his luck jazz purist and pianist, and Mia (Emma Stone), an ever-auditioning, aspiring actress, first meet, as Mia flips an annoyed, horn-honking Sebastian the bird while he cuts her off. After a few more false starts and a little flirtatious banter, the chemistry between the two builds to the point of becoming almost tangible.
Eventually, against a sunset sky specially crafted for lovers, Mia and Sebastian sing and dance their way into each other's hearts. Despite their initial belief that such "A Lovely Night" is wasted on two people who could not be more incompatible, through a tit for tat tap dance, they begin to recognize that when working together, the routine is stronger than when apart. Each recognizes the potential for greatness in the other, while doubting the potential residing within themselves.
While neither Gosling nor Stone have the vocal or rhythmic talent of Astaire or Rogers, that works to their advantage. Their performances provide the audience an opportunity to see themselves in their characters; we feel as though anyone could sing and tap dance in front of the Hollywood hills at sunset and be a star. That's not to take away from either performer, however, as both were nothing short of mesmerizing. Still, there's a sort of humility that they portray that, when coupled with the simplicity of the choreography and of the lyrics, provides Gosling and Stone a special kind of charm.
Equally as mesmerizing as the film's co-stars is Justin Hurwitz's score. In recent years, so often music seems to be nothing more than an afterthought in the filmmaking process. Not so in La La Land, where it often feels as though the film were constructed around Hurwitz's melodies. In what may be the most memorable scene of the movie, the score quite literally soars through the star-filled skies of Hollywood along with a waltzing Stone and Gosling. There's such an elegance and timeless quality to the scene; save for technology, it could very easily have been filmed during Hollywood's golden years, and deserves to go down in history as one of the most memorable scenes of any movie musical. Hurwitz is definitely a composer to watch for in the future.
Hollywood itself also takes centerstage in La La Land. The City of Los Angeles has never looked so stunning. Chazelle fills the city with bold, vibrant colors, evoking imagery of Hollywood at her prime. This is the sort of backdrop that dreams are made of; it's not at all hard to imagine Humphrey Bogart or Katharine Hepburn walking these streets. It's fitting, considering the movie as a whole serves as a reminder that Hollywood is a city built on dreams.
Therein lies the brilliance of this picture. Just as Hollywood is a city of dreams, La La Land is a movie of dreams. In an era of cynicism, La La Land reminds us of the joy and beauty that can be found in everyday life. It reminds us of the power of friendship and love, and of the difference that one person can make in the life of another. And it does it all through beautiful imagery, song, and dance. In La La Land, every day is a dream come true, and despite the difficulties they face, Sebastian and Mia live life as though it is a dream. Perhaps here in the real-world, we should strive to live that way as well.
Loved this movie. Music was great and so was seeing Emma Stone.

Best movie of the year.  Captivating, unique, magical, heartbreaking, feels like you are in the clouds.  Emma Stone is the star, Ryan Gosling isn't too shabby either. They take you out of your every day mundane life and transport you to another realm, another dimension and you get lost feeling like you are in a fairy tale.  Go see it at the theatre. La La Land est probablement le film le plus surévalué de 2016. Il possède certainement plusieurs qualités, notamment à la réalisation mais on ne s'attache pas du tout aux personnages principaux, particulièrement celui de Ryan Gosling et si quelques "morceaux" sont sympathiques, le film est bourré de longueurs et ceux qui ne sont pas fan de comédies musicales s'ennuieront rapidement
Your blood will flow like electric waves through your veins while watching this movie!

La La Land breathes new life into a bygone genre with thrillingly assured direction, powerful performances, and an irresistible excess of heart. Audacious, retro, funny and heartfelt, La La Land is the latest great musical for people who don't like musicals - and will slap a mile-wide smile across the most miserable of faces. Utterly magnificent and intoxicating. Chazelle's script is hopeful and sweet and clever and rich. His direction is innovative and captivating. Gosling is terrific as the coolly introspective yet disarmingly charming Sebastian. And Stone is deservedly generating Oscar buzz for her portrayal of an artist who can't quite believe she'll ever be anything other than a barista. The fact that neither Stone nor Gosling are tip-top song-and-dance artists is, in some ways, integral to their appeal. If they were Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire, we might not feel as much of a kinship with them. It's a beautiful and hopeful film, coming at a time when there isn't much beauty or hope in our movies, and it's the type of picture - a sprawling, exuberant musical drama - that hasn't been seen in decades. Damien Chazelle's musical, consistently daring and occasionally sublime, does what the movies have all but forgotten how to do - sweep us up into a dream of love that's enhanced in an urgent present by the mythic power of Hollywood's past.

VERDICT: "Instant Classic" - [Positively Acclaimed Reaction] Usually I give this rating to a movie that I believe is absolutely outstanding and has little to no flaws in it. Audiences, who haven't seen this film, must see it right now! (Films that are rated 4.5 or 5 stars)

over rated and poor. This film is a muddle with elements of fantasy it doesn't really know what its trying to do and looks a bit budget.
