I had a smile on my face throughout this movie. I'm not too much into musicals but this one blew my mind completely. From the performances, the choreography, the story and the music, everything was pitch perfect. While Gosling is fantastic in the movie, this is more of a showcase for Emma Stone, who has put her heart and soul into this movie and has delivered one of the finest (and award worthy) performances in her impressive career. Hats off to Director Damien Chazelle (his previous film Whiplash was outstanding too), who has been able to create pure magic on screen. Absolute MUST-WATCH!!!!!
Chazelle's new odyssey is truly spellbinding in its beauty.

Mostly loved everything about it. It's funny, the story is relatable, and the whole thing is bursting with an engaging vibrance. Direction is top notch, as are performances, and the music fits perfectly. The only criticism I'd have is the songs themselves aren't particularly memorable, there isn't a song that willnbe held up with the all-tome musical greats. I'd have also liked more songs, as I felt for a musical there were more opportunities throughout the story that could have used them. Otherwise I really enjoyed it.

The pace of the film was quite disjointed and different elements seemed to not flow properly. The acting was quite good and Gosling's piano playing was exceptional, however the vocals were a huge let down. It would have been nice if such a highly rated 'musical' could have had a leading actress who could actually sing.

I must admit that i went to see La la land a little biased. I'd been waiting for this movie for more than a year, may be since i heard that Emma and Ryan were doing a musical together. Mind you i'm in love with the three of them. I had read all the critics all the interviews and opinions, so may be i was apprehensive and anxious at the same time. 
Well, let me tell you something, it did surprised me far more that i could have anticipated. The music and cinematography are sublime, Chazelle directed a movie with the same tempo its central piece of music has. A dashing and exhilarating opening number that keeps up it pace till it suddenly  becomes quiet, still that has you on edge knowing that somehow it pick up again its quick pace towards the ending, that it will grow toward its heartbreaking, breathtaking finale. Its a dance of emotions and feelings, a fairy tale of dreams and reality, and i could not be more glad. 
I think Ryan is superb, but in my honest opinion, the very star of this movie is the music and Emma. She is astounding in every scene, quite particularly in her auditions. She slides through a range of emotions in mere seconds, she is a breath of fresh air in every scene, funny and quirky, and i think that with that monologue in Birdman, its the very best i've seen of her.
I can understand why people may not like it, but i can only be thankful that i went out of the theatre with my heart so full of love for music and old classics, an movies, and stories that are not afraid to make you feel, not only laugh and sing, but also cry and hurt. I can only wait to see how will this months unfold, but i can say, that it only gets better with every time you see it

I loved this movie. It's along the lines of Singin' in the Rain.  The acting, the dancing, and the singing was great.  Maybe not as graceful as professional dancers, but it was great fun to watch. The singing was also not as great as professionals, but it was great considering it's not their first love.  We watched it twice, back to back days. And we'd watch it again given the chance.

Damien Chazelle's 'La La Land' (2016) is a must see film. 'La La Land' is a rarity when it comes to modern cinema, an original film musical that isn't a Disney animation. The songs featured work tonally in the film and are well composed. Basically, 'La La Land' is a joy to watch, and I was smiling throughout. Great acting, great camera work, great music, great everything. Superb. I wish I could say more, but I'm worried I'd accidentally spoil something, whether that be that be the tone of the film or pivotal scenes.

I wrote music (and lyrics) for a musical so I know whereof I speak when I say that Lala Land is pretty good. The music, in particular, has to be good or you've wasted your time. If the plot is also good, then you've got yourself something special. To me, the movie is more a series of set pieces or music videos of varying quality that mostly improves as the movie progresses. Gosling and Stone are good onscreen together, and there are a few great songs in there. But if you don't lover all musicals, there are a few problems. 

The opening sequence is nonsensical. The song where they meet is weak, complex, and just didn't work for me (nor those I was with during the viewing). The scene after midnight in the planetarium was uneven, illogical, and jarring. The scene of them dancing in the stars was just stupid and inconsistent with the rest of the film. 

However, the rest of it was magical. I laughed, I cried, and I was transported by the cinema. It's very difficult to write great songs and strong stories and cast great actors to pull off a movie musical. It was a goof effort. O look forward to further work from these artists.

What to say.....Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling are great - but somehow the film fails to connect. The songs are unmemorable - how many will you recall/be singing. There is some amazing camera work. Spoiler - would have liked the sweet rather than the pragmatic end.
One of the most brilliant charming movies ever
Very charming and engaging. It's wonderfully told.
One of the most devastatingly beautiful and dazzling films of recent years - a mesmerizing whirlwind of romance, nostalgia and sorrow.

With toe-tappingly good numbers, stirring score, stunning visuals, and remarkable performances, one might think that La La Land is just a razzle-dazzle-filled homage to those classic Hollywood musicals. But the film's beautiful and bittersweet conclusion made it more fresh and genuine.

Remember the last time you watched Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers and said, "They don't make movies like this anymore"? Well they did with La La Land. Best film I have seen all year. It was enthralling from beginning to end, without any visible mistake. Amazing performances, both acting and musical performances, great scores, great cinematography, my God it's just an almost perfect film. It could've been a little bit longer though in my opinion.

Saw it, enjoyed it, but wasn't THAT in love with it after all the Golden Globes hype.  I actually enjoyed three other movies more over the last four weeks. Fun to watch, but in my humble opinion, not quite so "award worthy."

La La Land shines a light on the glamour of the Golden Age musicals with incredible authenticity, grace and amazing storytelling.

One of 2016's masterpieces, Damien Chazelle's beautifully-directed gem is filled with incredible writing and breath-taking performances that dive deep into our hearts and make us feel like we are a part of their world.

A movie that is set to become a modern-time classic, La La Land redefines an entire genre and shows that Hollywood musicals are still as beautiful as they were in the 40s.

I was very tempted to start my review like this:
"I am a committed patient in an asylum for the
criminally insane and I thought this movie was 
brilliant!"

I guarantee that a hefty majority of positive non-pro
reviews come from eager showbiz aspirants who leave 
a positive review as an ersatz form of ass-kissing they
hope will get noticed because they imagine this film's
producers poring through the reviews looking for daily
ego-boosts and these same producers will somehow 
subconsciously connect a reviewer's name with the 
headshot when it arrives (again) in the production office.  
I also guarantee that those same producers knew that 
they would get a lot of ersatz positive reviews by relying 
on the circumstance I described in the lengthy sentence 
that opened this paragraph and the only ego boost will 
come from seeing how well their scheme worked as they
watch headshot after headshot go from the inbox to the trash. 
For the producers to have to rely only on positive reviews 
from the real version of the notional construct I was tempted 
to use as described in the first paragraph would leave too
much to chance and potentially ignominious irony. 

If by chance the ersatz success of this film sparks the
reincarnation of the modern day equivalent talents of 
Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers (Emma Stone comes
very close, sans the dancing lessons and maybe relying 
too much on her formidably admirable smart ass gifts), 
then it's ersatz story will have done some genuine good. 
You know, like how roses grow better outta fertilizer?
Try to think of this film as fertilizer....
Romance jazz part musical part movie nostalgia. However you look at La La Land it's a nicely paced different film that well deserves its nominations.
La La Land rides the difficult task of being both ecstatically joyful and uncompromisingly melancholy; making for a magically in tune experience in these modern times.
Suitably old-fashioned and potently directed, La La Land benefits greatly from gorgeous visuals, extravagant music, and outstanding chemistry between its two leads.

I love Old Hollywood movies. I love Emma Stone. I love Ryan Gosling.

I hated this movie.

About 2/3-3/4 of it was flat out boring and nonsensical. People came in and 
then disappeared. There was dancing without words for minutes on end. It went from real to fantastical and back again. It skipped over major chunks of time. It did t develop the characters thoroughly to where major decision points left you wondering why. And I didn't like the ending.

The actors were great (though singing just so-so), but I felt the script, though it has some good moments, was generally a disservice to their abilities.

I do not understand why this is winning so many awards - it doesn't deserve them.

really way to much hype about this film. just all very very average, story, characters, dancing, songs, all average. was looking forward to a good musical which this film was not. Cannot understand the awards and hype.

Simultaneously fresh and nostalgic, Chazelle's La La Land is a beautifully shot, directed and edited musical that still manages to deliver a poignant message about the costs of following one's dreams in the artistic industries.
Film je remek-djelo.
I'm a musical lover and this one just hit home for me. I loved it!

Harking back to a glorious time in the history of cinema, where bumping into someone in the street inevitably lead to a lavish musical number, La La Land is a sensational piece of work, a love letter to the golden age of film and a toe-tapping journey around the City Of Angels. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are perfectly cast and utterly compelling in the lead roles, telling a story which is equal parts heart-breaking and uplifting, filled with emotional moments, passionate songs and some of the best choreography I've ever seen in a film.  You feel everything they do, love every high and lament every low, but through it all the film is about that very greatest of things: Dreams. Not necessarily achieving them, but how important it is to have them in the first place, to always give us something to aim for and strive to accomplish. It may be heavy at times and not always as cheery as the critical consensus would have you believe, but it's very rare to find a film that can truly pick you up as much as this one does, and from the opening musical number to the closing credits, it's a film you won't be able to tear your eyes, ears and heart away from.
delightful! every single moment.
Opulent, gorgeously staged, beautifully performed, sang, scored and presented, this film defines perpetual joy. Must see!

I wasn't expecting to like this movie as much as I did. It pulls off a remarkable shift in tone around the midpoint, and I come away from it thinking that the main characters aren't Mia and Sebastian so much as Hollywood itself. The dramatization of the sacrifices made--the real cost--of becoming part of the fantasies of making it in Hollywood hits hard in the end, but it's not a downer, somehow. Lively, creative, and visually beautiful in places. If only these actors could sing, too...

It blew me away, the exciting emotion it made me feel, it was pure amazing! There was laughter, tears and other fantastic emotions all happening at the same time. You should definitely put it on your Must to See list.

This movie drug on and on, painfully.  The end was a relief!!
I like Ryan Gosling, but his dancing and singing were cringe-worth at times.  Emma Stone as singer, was incorrectly cast.  The dancing was sloppy.  The plot was tired.  Save your money, or see something else.
It's almost as though Hollywood decided to make a musical they knew had no real story and then cast people the felt would save it.  That did not work.
While I usually highly dislike musicals, this film stopped singing and really just put on a great performance about half way through. Thought provoking and beautiful film
This movie was great but Imo it was a little dragged out and I felt like Emma stone was trying way to hard, that it was comedic to watch! Maybe that was the plan? See it in theaters for sure !

Wow, wow, WOW! If I were to describe this movie in three words it would be: Future Classic Guaranteed. Honestly, going into this movie I didn't know an awful lot, I certainly didn't know it would be a musical, I just thought it would be about music like Damien Chazzelle's last movie Whiplash (which I loved). So when the first scene began with the huge dance number and singing, I wasn't sure how the whole movie would pan out. But as it went on, I realised it wasn't just a bog-standard musical cringe-fest, it was incredible storytelling with a musical slid in which was fantastic. I don't usually like musicals but this one is in a league of its own and it's brilliant. DO NOT miss out on this one; Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are flawless in their singing, acting and dancing. My favourite aspect of the movie was that it didn't lose grips with reality, if you've seen the movie you should know what I mean if you were looking out for it. Things like Ryan and Emma about to kiss while sat in the movie theatre with the romantic music playing in the background but then the screen breaks which ruins the moment, in a normal musical moment they would have just kissed but as I sad before this movie is so much more than a bog-standard musical. Another moment that doesn't lose grips with reality was when Emma and Ryan did their dance number together as seen on the poster looking over LA, they are both dancing together brillaintly being all romantic again but then Emma's phone rings and the whole dance number stops and goes back to reality. Just really great direction from Damien Chazelle once again.

Damien Chazelle is the Lin-Manuel Miranda of movies: a young newcomer dazzles with a brilliant small project (Chazelle's Whiplash, Miranda's In the Heights), then comes back swinging with a larger and arguably even better project (Chazelle's La La Land, Miranda's Hamilton). La La Land is one of the most fun and entertaining movies I have seen in a long time. The acting was lovely, the music was superb, and the direction was flawless. The film manages to expertly balance the feel-good homage to Old Hollywood with the genuine moments of "real life." It was an excellent piece of cinema that gave me enough warm-and-fuzzy moments to last the rest of the month, and it proved yet again that superb writer/director Chazelle is not going anywhere.
Quite good actually. Not cheesy at all. Emma Stone is wonderful as always. Gosling, well, if you take away his singing he was actually good.
I don't understand the hype. Saw it last night and almost fell asleep 3 times. 2 hours of my life I'll never get back!
Fantastic - best movie I have seen in years:) Emma stone and Ryan Gosling = oscar performances.

This movie was just ok, and I don't see what everyone is going crazy about.  The music was flat and the dancing was just ok.  The best music was the piano playing.  Acting,  now that's where it was great.  Gosling and Stone are funny and believable and have a unique love story.  I HATED  the end and I mean HATED! I understand LA is about dreams and yes,  they both got theirs,  but who doesn't keep in touch with someone they love that much? How did she not know he had a club? So much love wasted in my opinion... you don't ignore that kind of love. 
O well,  guess they both got what they wanted.  
Overall,  an ok movie with ok dancing and music and very good acting.

Very excellent! The story is as complicated as life itself, and it relates to many people. Heart touching! The songs are beautifully written! The actor and actress perform well! This movie is haunting!
This movie is Beautiful. I wish one day Damien will collaborate with Wes Anderson and make more beautiful "babies"
Undoubtedly charming but not the masterpiece I keep hearing it is. Emma Stone is nailed on for the Oscar.

La La Land is absolutely spectacular. That a 31 year old director (30 when he wrote and filmed it) is capable of imagining and so magically executing a musical that tows a beautiful line between the old and new, the real and a kind of Hollywood fantasy, is astounding.  Music was great, definitely a case of quality over quantity. Both leads are terrific, especially Emma Stone who has a scene to herself that blows it all away. The middle is a bit simple and montage-y, and it's a little hard to sympathise with the character's struggle when they live such wonderful lives, but as a piece of entertainment it's an A+. Go see it, have some fun. (9.5/10)
Did not like this movie at all. Well, ok the last 1/3 of it was good.

I don't want to spoil this one for anyone, you should just go and see it. What a rollercoaster of emotions this movie is. Let me just say I got goosebumps on so many occasions while watching it... You know a movie is good when you leave the cinema speechless, in awe...

Fantastic film. I was skeptical when the trailer was first released, but after it did so well at the Golden Globes I thought I better give it a watch and I'm so glad I did. Charming, romantic, funny and old school without being nostalgic. Stone and Gosling are great as the two leads: think Stone could be due a little golden man come March time. 
One of the best films I've seen in a long time and I have to say I hadn't stopped listening to the soundtrack since the movie finished.

A tired plot line, executed in a slothfully slow fashion, interrupted by spurts of frenetic motion masquerading as homage to the golden age of the silver screen, all tied together by an insipid earworm of a melody.  The first glimmer of a story line came fully forty minutes in to the film.  I know this because I actually checked my watch.  All that preceded it was noisy drivel.  I'm not criticizing Gosling or Stone -- I think they both made lemonade, though neither seemed particularly confident as either singer or dancer.  Each provided a journeyman's performance.  John Legend's performance was similarly competent, though I thought casting that particular musician for that part seemed a bit gratuitous.  After reading the glowing reviews and watching  as the film garnered numerous awards, I was disappointed by the actual product.  At best, it was mediocre.  My grading scale is based on ticket price.  Really good films are worth a full-price ticket, on my scale (five stars).  Awful films, by contrast, are worthy only of late-night re-run showings on local access television (zero stars).  I gave this film one-half star.  It's worth watching on Netflix.

Hello Hollywood, La La Land is your typical type of movie. Okay, Best movie...hmmmm... not very sure. Emma Stone Oh yes ..BIG  YES  to her . Ryan Gosling..hmmmm Just ?. Good movie ? but won't say too great.. I enjoyed it but........

Absolutely Loved La La land. It's a perfect mix of an old school movie musical with a current feel. Both Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are incredible actors. The on screen chemistry between them, makes you love them and want them to have a 'happily ever after' life together. Emma Stone should be nominated for best actress at the Oscars. She makes you feel her pain, joy, uncomfortableness, and love throughout the film.  Gosling is also a great actor, but what really stood out is how accomplished he is at being a jazz pianist. The music throughout the film was great and I especially loved hearing the old school jazz.  But, what I really loved more than anything, was how Damian Chazelle directed/shot this movie. The colors, the storyline, the cuts, the beautiful wide shots, and those fine detail shots that were like metaphors of their relationship were so spot on and thoughtful, that it makes this film a must see. The only snare for me was the ending.... I know there is a reality to the storyline there, but it puts a bit of downer and sadness as you walk away on what was a very uplifting film. But the ending doesn't take away from the beautiful direction and the incredible acting, so go see it and enjoy a film that stands apart from today's crowd of hollywood formula movies. This one is a classic that will be watched over and over.
Surprisingly good. A nice movie to see with your wife / girlfriend

This is a huge year for the musicals world. This could be the year a musical could win an oscar. This could be 2003 all over again. And it is all thanks to this amazing amazing (did i say amazing?) thrilling rollercoaster of a film. This is Emma Stone's year. I bet everything I have on it. This is Damien Chzaelle's year after Whiplash came up short. Great stuff all around. I have the amazing music playing in my ears ever since I left the film theater. Great chemistry between Ryan and Emma. ridiculous chemistry! There is nothing more you could want from this film, except for slight drop of pace but you can barely feel it, a higher level (slightly higher) of acting from Ryan and a justifiable explanation for why the film ended up the way it did. But does it matter? It is a thrilling experience with a fairy tale atmosphere that  got me smiling till this very day :)

La La Land is timeless because of the rare formula the director has given to the movie that gives that 50's and modern set and vibe to it. The cinematography, lighting, art and choreography were outstanding not to mention the musical numbers performed.

Feels so old and yet so fresh. This is simply a beautiful film to behold. Such a simple and sincere story told in a technically-difficult way. Finally, a Best Picture contender that doesn't make you want to shoot yourself in the head after watching it. 

At a time when people's self-worth are dependent upon Facebook likes and Instagram hearts, a story like this reminds us to act upon our dreams without fear. Bittersweet, with a lot of nuts.

The professional critics who reviewed this movie must be IN la la land: it's massively over-hyped.

I love musicals but got so bored I almost walked out. Most musicals have a questionable plot but you don't notice. Why? Because the dialogue is witty, the dance breathtaking and the music uplifting. A good musical has charm, heart and soul - it reaffirms the joy of living. This musical has none of the above. 

La La Land also falls down technically. I highly rate Gosling and Stone as actors but the cringworthy script left them hanging out to dry. They are also not exceptional singers or dancers.

The musical score is 'random' - with songs noticeably appearing out of nowhere. The lyrics are dull and repetative - in large part a homage to Los Angeles. Luckily you often won't understand them due to the poor enunciation.

The Direction and editing are also noticeably random. A one hour 'haircut' would probably have improved things a bit.

I nominate this movie as one of the worst big movies of 2017. Don't believe the hype.

Great movie up until the last 15 minutes. If you're looking for a feel good movie with a happy ending. DO NOT SEE this one. I was so angry at how they ruined a perfectly wonderful experienced. Still upset about it.
Stunning, engaging, emotive, flawless lead performances and on screen chemistry
Too long.  Story line drags.

A love letter to the classic musicals of the 50's "La La Land" is an uplifting and emotional experience which I greatly enjoyed. It's beautiful to look at and that's not just because of its two stars. Every shot is gorgeously composed and the musical numbers are supremely entertaining. 
There is a fluidity to everything on screen and so much love and attention to detail is in every shot. It's unique amongst our current climate of films and perhaps this is partly why so much praise has been given. 
It certainly deserves all the success it gets and perhaps it will spur on a reinvigoration of the genre. I hope so, we need more films like this.

Nostalgic and romantic and dreamy. Gosling and Stone have so much chemistry and completely believable..... They might not be the best singers, but they sure dance up a storm. 
It's probably a touch too long, with some sequences lingering. But overall, great.
I la la loved it (see what I did there Pixies fans?)

One of the worst movie that I have ever seen!
I actually was sleeping for a long while !
It has never deserved !
It's a love letter to cinema.
I would have given it more stars but that ending just didn't work for me. As beautiful as it was the hopeless romantic in me left the cinema fuming.

I've been holding off on my top movies of the year list just for this film and Silence and thank god I did. This movie was beautifully made and not one flaw in it. The music was superb and the acting from Gosling and Stone was great as always. The cinematography was fantastic too. I absolutely love the story as well with two young talented people trying to pursue and achieve there dreams. Damien Chazelle's first film Whiplash was superb and thus one surprisingly tops that. 
100/100
Thought the film was tedious, no mean full dialog, not even a good musical, end 5 min was good if you can sit through rest.
Saw this in theaters a while ago and can't believe I forgot to rate it!! Absolutely fantastic! I loved it!

I go to the movies to feel good at the end when your watching a love storey. To have the two love birds get there life goals but not get to be with each other really sucks. And the sadness in both main characters just carries with you as you leave. I know that's a sign of great acting but really can't the real life be left in real life and let the love of two young souls lift your heart as the ride off in to the sunset together.

2/3 of this was a great movie.  First third not so much.  Some of the songs felt forced,  and were disorienting due to dreadful camera work.    The performances were great, however I feel this was overhyped and mildly disappointing

Beautiful, emotionally moving and without a doubt a masterpiece, La La Land is a phenomenal cinematic experience that not only honors an iconic past but outdoes the contemporary style of today's movies.
Was pretty and Hollywood glamorized themselves but lets face it Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire don't have to worry.

A spirited and at times inspired homage to the films of Stanley Donen and Jacques Demy, "La La Land" excels in part because it achieves the proper balance between the constituent parts of a romantic musical comedy/drama.

The editing, choreography, original music and cast are all very good, but really, it's the performance of Emma Stone that carries the film. Making art, like making love, requires as an essential ingredient the willingness to be vulnerable, and it is Stone's brave vulnerability (both in her performance, and in her performances-within-the-performance) that anchors "La La Land"s most compelling scenes, hitting its most winning, poignant notes (figuratively--the singing from the leads is merely OK, but the rest of the film is executed with such panache that it doesn't matter; see: "Moulin Rouge" for another example of this).

A film that's easy to root for in a genre that recalls the glories of yesteryear Hollywood, if "La La Land" (as seems likely) cleans up at the Oscars at the expense of a few other movies that are a little bit better, that's OK. It's an excellent picture.

Absolutely Stunning! Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling succeed again at entangling you in their romance and drawing you into a world of swirling emotions. You truly enter into, one might say, your own La La Land.
The music springs less from plot stakes and sort of just emerges into a scene to save it from its mediocrity. It has its moments but they don't make a strong whole.

Now three weeks have passed and I have seen 25 films at Cannes, most of them attempts at greatness, and I sit here staring at the computer screen and realizing with dread that the time has come for me to write a review justifying that vertical thumb, which is already on video and will go out to millions of TV viewers seeking guidance in their moviegoing.

I do not say that I was wrong about the film. I said what I sincerely believed at the time. I believed it as one might believe in a good cup of coffee; welcome while you are drinking it, even completely absorbing, but not much discussed three weeks later. Indeed after my immersion in the films of Cannes, I can hardly bring myself to return to "The Longest Yard" at all, since it represents such a limited idea of what a movie can be and what movies are for.

Yet there are those whose entire lives as moviegoers are spent within the reassuring confines of such entertainments. In many cities and some states, there are few ways for them to get their eyes on movies that can feed their souls. They will have to be content with a movie in which Adam Sandler plays an alcoholic has-been football hero who gets drunk, drives dangerously, is thrown into jail and becomes the pawn in a football game pitting a team of fellow prisoners against a team made up of prison guards. As I sit here, so help me God, I can't remember who got the idea for this game or why. I could look it up, but it's fascinating to watch myself trying to reconstruct a movie that was not intended to be remembered as long as it takes to get to the parking lot. This is how you learn. Through experience.

ADVERTISEMENT

I recall that for some reason the big game is broadcast live on a sports network, maybe because the Sandler character was once a football hero and went down in flames over the drunk-driving scandal, and so there is a possibility of good ratings. His mentor is a former prisoner, played by Burt Reynolds, who starred in Robert Aldrich's original "Longest Yard" (1974) and whose character this time is described in my notes as the Heisman Trophy Winner of 1955. Assuming my notes are correct, he was about 21 when he won the trophy and it is 2005 now, so that makes Reynolds about 71, although now that I have done the math I don't know where to go with it. Certainly he is older than Sandler and younger than God.

James Cromwell plays the warden. I have met him on industry occasions. He is a militant Screen Actors' Guild spokesman and a fiercely intelligent man who takes roles like this for the same reason I review them, because we are professionals and this is what we do. He would rather be in better movies and I would rather review them, but we have both seen a lot worse than this. There is a sense in which attacking this movie is like kicking a dog for not being better at calculus.

You think you know where I am headed. I am going to admit that I was wrong. I am going to withdraw that upturned thumb even as its ghostly video image beams out across the nation. I will compare it to the shimmering authority of a hologram of Obi-Wan Kenobi, expressing wisdom that was true enough when the hologram was recorded, but may not be helpful by the time it is seen.

ADVERTISEMENT

But no, I am not going to do that at all. When the show was recorded I said what I believed, and for my sins I am appending three stars to the top of this review. I often practice a generic approach to film criticism, in which the starting point for a review is the question of what a movie sets out to achieve. "The Longest Yard" more or less achieves what most of the people attending it will expect. Most of its audiences will be satisfied enough when they leave the theater, although few will feel compelled to rent it on video to share with their friends. So, yes, it's a fair example of what it is.

I would however be filled with remorse if I did not urge you to consider the underlying melancholy of this review and seek out a movie you could have an interesting conversation about. I have just come from 12 days at Cannes during which several times each day I was reminded that movies can enrich our lives, instead of just helping us get through them.

It may be that your local multiplex is not showing any films that have, or will, or would, qualify for Cannes. There is a studied unwillingness among the major distributors to rise very frequently above the lowest common denominator, except during Oscar season. But there are actually some very worthy films in national release right now. If "Kontroll" is playing in your town, for example, that would be an idea. Or "Brothers," or "Dominion: Prequel to the Exorcist," or "Layer Cake," or "Unleashed." These are not great films, you understand, but they exist in a world that knows what greatness is, and they urge themselves toward it. If you can get to "Crash," that is the movie you must see, and you should immediately drop any thought of seeing anything else instead.
Gorgeous and inspiring.

Disappointed, especially after all the hype. It lay flat; the music (except for  John Legend's) not catchy. There wasn't much singing from either actor.   There was not a feel good after this show; the audience was pretty much silent when the show was over. Good chemistry between the two
Would be five stars but the ending is bullshit

La La Land dazzles with sight and sound. Gosling and Stone don't miss a beat as this film harkens back to the golden age of Hollywood. Damian Chazelle has cemented himself as one of the best directors in the business.
If you don't see this, you're doing yourself a massive disservice. One of the greatest works of art I have and will ever lay my eyes on. Also I'm in love with Emma Stone.
I'm not normally into musicals, but this movies was amazing! loved it from start to finish and definitely one of the year's best movies from an amazing director!
Phenomenal modern musical with deeply developed characters and excellent pacing. Will definitely own this one.
More like Blah Blah Land.  Emma Stone did a good job. Ryan Gosling acting was fine as well but the singing - Good God man take some singing lessons. The dancing was also below par.

This is basically a 1950s style musical (a'la Singing in the Rain) set in present-day Los Angeles and I'd say it's already a modern classic. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling put in fantastic, almost heart-wrenching performances and have great chemistry, they work off each other really well. LA itself looks amazing and romantic in this movie, especially during the scenes that take place in Griffith Park. The music is also extremely catchy and memorable. Overall I think everyone should check this movie out, the fact that people in the theater I saw this in were applauding at the end says it all.
I CAN'T EVEN...IT WAS TOO BEAUTIFUL <3!!!

On the surface La La Land looks like the quintessential musical/romance. While it may be a musical and a romance, I would say it's a story about following your dreams. The world is full of cynics and critics. The world also has a plethora of dreamers and optimists. This movie is for the dreamers and optimists. Emma Stone continues her rise to Hollywood superstardom in this film. Her eyes tell most of the story. It is easy to empathize with her character, to root for her character. A wannabe actress/barista that goes from audition to audition always losing out to girls she thinks are prettier or more talented. She meets another dreamer, Ryan Gosling's character, a wannabe jazz club owner. I expected their to be more singing between the two of them, that was a disappointment. Their chemistry seems forced at times, but their playfulness is infectious. I can see many movie goers not liking the ending but appreciating it. The acting gets an A, the singing gets a C-, the fantasy of it all gets an A+! I don't see Best Picture in its future but I do see a ton of Oscar nominations.

Whiplash, Chazelle's first film was far more accomplished, polished and superior in every way. La La, was enjoyable, but severely disjointed, a bit too corny (at times) and has a run-of-the- mill story with only flashes of the brilliance seen in Whiplash. Emma Stone is amazing and it's worth seeing for her. Gosling did not show the depth of character to warrant his reviews. It was almost like watching different skits as the set pieces changed.

Very slow start but got much much better.  Music was mixed bag.  Story was well done but not kind of heartbreaking.  Ryan Gosling steals the show I think.  Purposefully hearkens back to old-fashioned musical movie styles - you'll get why if you watch it.
Storyline was great, acting was phenomenal.. just a bit dragged out and didn't quite yank on the heart strings like I anticipated.. kudos to Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling on a job well done though!
fantastic it was amazing I will buy it when it first out
9/10 Best Film of 2016.

Well-acted (good chemistry between stone and gosling in a couple of scenes), nice pace, shy singing (except for John Legend's performance), predictable plot. It's a delicate movie that reminds us of the Artist.

The whole movie felt...contrived. As an actor in LA that is a fan of musical theater, this movie attempted to pander to those like me. I guess the producers think all actors in LA are too stupid to see what a pile of feces this movie was. The songs had no point and didn't help to move along what little plot there was. The dancing was sub par compared to the spectacular performances musical theater goers are used to seeing on a regular basis. I am a fan of both Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, but one can only do so much with a bad script and bad songs. I appreciate that neither are strong singers but it was going to take more than a strong voice to make the songs in this movie bearable. The story makes actors, musicians, and "dreamers" seem like vapid morons. La La Land was advertised as a "love letter" to Hollywood. Instead it was the entertainment industry masturbating on screen for two hours. Definitely the most overrated movie of 2016. To be honest it's could be the most overrated movie of all time. 1/2 was way more than this train wreck of a movie deserved.
It's the process that dreams came true.

La La Lance é um filme sobre sonhos, um filme relacionamento e um filme momentos que não voltam. O roteiro é incrível,  as magníficas a ainda por cima o filme nos mostra a magia do Jazz. La La Lan é nota 10. VIVA O JAZZ !!!

Need to get away from most of today's cinema of violence? Then this is for you! Great nostalgia with an updated view. Even if you don't like this kind of music, which I do, then you will appreciate the wonderful storyline and ending. The chemistry between Stone and Gosling works well in their third movie together. Get the soundtrack!
This film is Awesome

I love Emma Stone and I love musicals,  but I did not love this movie. I found the story slow and hardly engaging. The only stand outs were the song sung by the band The Messengers and Emma Stone's song when she was doing the audition.

I know I will be in the minority when I say that this film was awful. Now I am a fan of musicals but not every one is an instant classic in my opinion. For me a musical should be joyous, energetic, each song sounding different, have an upbeat ending and not be too long. La La Land only succeeds on one of these, being energetic. Everything else is bad, the songs sound the same when you hear the cheesy number in the first 2 minutes of the film, you have pretty much heard the soundtrack, its joyous for the most part but the ending is depressing. If I wanted that, I would watch Les Miserables. Its also far too long, it felt like a 3 hour film not a 2 hour film. The dance routines all feel samey and offer nothing new and I hated the use of the handheld camera to give the illusion of a long one shot. The only saving grace is the fact that I love both Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling and they do their very best. For me I knew I was going to hate it from the opening song and hate it I did. If you like the old style Hollywood cheese fest of musicals then you will love it, if not steer clear. This is one of the most overrated films of the year and definitely not worthy of all the praise and awards its getting.

Way, way overrated.  Most of the singing is breathy and uncommitted like someone not confident singing.  There are aspects of the movie I like but I think it would play better as a drama vs musical or get better singers.  Incorporating musical into it can feel contrived unlike better musicals where it flows seamlessly.  Emma Stone is a gifted comedian and should stick with that IMO.

So you can tell by the stars that I did like this movie.  All the elements were there.  The story line was compelling, the music was well done, the acting was awesome.  Directing, sets lights - all very good.  It was just enjoyable to watch.  Aside from that though.....I have to hold one start back just out of principle.  Look these romantic fantasy films are why our younger generation has a distorted view of what it really takes to make a life together.  Its not all dancing in the stars and roses! lol   Secondly, I have to complain against Hollywood awarding itself again.  OF COURSE it will win lots of awards - it is all about Hollywood, and Hollywood loves movies about itself!
I thought it was a feeble attempt to duplicate the great musicals of the past. Gene Kelly and Donald O Connor are rolling over in their graves.

Not for everyone, but very beautiful. Found at times I was slightly bored and was waiting for the end. Gosling & Stone are fantastic together. Stone's humour especially shines through, as does Gosling's. Neither's singing voice is anything to shout about, their dancing, however, is fantastic!
Not what I imagined but I still LOVED it!!!!
Very melancholy and slow, not an upbeat musical I was expecting...wait for the DVD
outstanding! a must see

SECOND VIEWING - upping my rating significantly from 7.2.  It's really good.  Seems like I always need to hear music a few times to get used to it and now I have got that part - and I don't agree with my initial assessment that it is too talky.  It works.  There are moments of inspiration throughout.  The story itself has integrity in terms of the relationships and the Hollywood backdrop.  I see many rewatches in my future.  9 out of 10.
What an amazing love story during such a divide time in our nation.  This movie tugs at every emotion and I absolutely loved every minute of it!
As beautiful and wonderful as I expected.

Entertaining enough, but I expected so much more - I really struggled to see what all the fuss and hype was about.  It's a good film with lots of nostalgic touches and themes with a passable romance story and two very likeable characters.  Lots of great music, but not enough musical numbers or spectacle, and as a lot of the songs and scenes end on a down note, there's an almost constant bitter-sweet atmosphere.  The "what if" sequence looked a lot more fun, upbeat and lively and with a few more musical numbers, would have been a much more enjoyable film for me.
singing left something to be desired, dancing was a hot mess, acting was good. biggest downfall was casting emma stone and ryan gosling for roles that are outside their field of expertise

Hyvä, muttei elämää suurempi. Rakastan musikaaleja, ja tästä oli suuret odotukset. Leffa alkoi upeasti hienolla musikaalikohtauksella, lukuisilla tanssijoilla ja pitkällä kamera-ajolla. Värikäs musiikki-iloittelu jatkui näyttävillä tanssinumeroilla ja tyylikkäillä jazz-pimputuksilla. Jossain kohtaa päädyttiin kuitenkin vähän hakoteille musikaalin maailmasta, harmaaseen parisuhdeongelmien vatvomiseen. Olisin kernaasti nähnyt enemmän musikaalinumeroita, mahtipontisuutta ja visualisuutta, vähemmän jaarittelua. Loppu taas pelasti, joskin se oli hyvinkin erikoinen, mutta ... hyväksyttävä.
Ryan Gosling oli edelleen yhtä ihana kuin Notebookissa, laulu, tanssi, piano, kaikki toimi. Emma Stone jättää minut vähän kylmäksi. Lauluääni oli hieman hento, ulkonäkö ehkä liiankin persoonallinen. Kaunis, nautittava, viihdyttävä, visuaalinen musikaali. Näitä ehdottomasti enemmän!

Working marvelously as both a joyous ode to Hollywood musicals of yesteryear, and a thrillingly unique and poignant modern romance that ingeniously incorporates one of America's most colorful cities into its backdrop, La La Land is a passionate and grand cinematic experience and easily one of 2016's standout films

I liked it but ... there is a bit of difference between musical and La La Land.
I have seen several musicals and this one is part-musical. Intro and first 30-40 min are amazing, the middle part was well done but you can't pace 2 hour musical in non-dragged way. 
Movie has amazing technical quality, scenery and performances. 
And sadly it relates (at core) too much with my life, to a point when I pause the movie and started deep thinking. Having a dream is good and sadly not all dreams come true and even if they do - not the way we want it to see happen.
And this movie clearly shows that. And finally, I would say that this movie lacks ... movie, Having more "movie" in it (to me) but of course if you take it as a musical then it is a perfect musical that you can view as a movie. 
Mama Mia is the best musical I have seen and you can clearly spot differences in how less movie it is and how more movie LA LA Land is. I think 4/5 is fair enough (if I have to rank somehow).

This is the first film I walked out on since The Musketeer in 2001. I gave it an hour and literally nothing happened. No character development, no conflict or plotline development.  I tried, I really did.
Made me cry and laugh and feel happy. Incredible movie
Very average as a film and not very good as a musical. Casting singers and dancers rather than movie stars would have benefited this film a lot.

Modern urban feel accompanied by a visceral throwback to the old musicals, films that has been extinct since filmmakers eschew the element of light-hearted mirth from their films in a bid to complement the public taste. A heart-warming hat tip to Hollywood and Los Angeles. Ambitiously transforming the supposedly mundane urban surroundings of people and concrete into vibrant dancing figures, something we thought only can exist in the past. The tear in my eye is genuine, I'm talking about the end. Best film of the year...

A beautifully shot and choreographed musical carried almost entirely by the charm and chemistry between Gosling and Stone. Not all the songs are particularly memorable but the main song, City of Stars, which sort of acts as the film's leitmotif, I couldn't stop humming once it was over.
If I had one complaint, it'd be the semi-downer ending which I can't imagine anyone expected or felt good about. For a movie that assume is intentionally cliche as far as romance/musicals go, I don't understand why they didn't just go all the way and give us the happy, cliche ending we'd expect.
Regardless, I enjoyed the movie for Gosling and Stone's performances, charm and undeniable chemistry.

I was surprised by how much I liked this movie. The acting was very good and the story was well designed. The music was very good as well. The film felt kind of magical in a not-corny way. I definitely recommend it and I look forward to seeing it again.
http://cinephilecrocodile.blogspot.co.uk/2017/01/la-la-land-dir-damien-chazelle-2016-i.html

Saw this last night. I enjoyed it from start to finish. I was once a struggling artist in LA. This movie hit home hard. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling portray the young struggling artists perfectly. The sets, music, dancing and most of all the acting were perfect. This has set the bar for modern musicals. It took from some of the best musicals of the golden years and introduced a modern flair. A far cry from most musicals produced these days that are either pure Broadway or extremely abstract. 

The fantasy elements mixed with dramatic realism are incredible. It's a perfect date night film.
Great dancing but zero plot

Warning : be prepared to see the best movie on 2017 . Specular, brilliant , fantastic , very very cool . Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling give their best performance.  Very hard to top this year . Must see movie of 2017 .
An awe inspiring film with mesmerising visuals and a story you just won't forget. This movie will keep you engulfed in La La Land long after the film has finished.
it's easily my favorite movie of 2016
Really different sort of movie for a change and I really enjoyed it, especially the music!
Cerebral as it is charming. You get so caught up in La La Land that only when it ends do you realize you never ever wanted it to. Pure magic.

Having seen the occasional negative review I was a bit concerned, and I was concerned about my own expectations after this film has won so much already. I have to say I wasn't disappointed at all. My only criticism would be that the opening song doesn't really fit in, but other than that this film is pure magic. I have to appreciate that if you don't like muscials at all then it probably won't be your thing, and if you expect a musical that is nothing but the world's best singing for 1.5 hours then it won't be your thing either, but that isn't the point of this film. The story line is brilliant (not giving spoilers) and honest, whilst the singing and dancing is not top notch I feel like this is a good thing as it adds a certain purity to it and sense of spontaneity rather than manufactured and over-rehearsed glee. Emma Stone is absolutely phenomenal and I would expect her to be in contention at the Oscars. Most of all this film just has so much heart and soul in it, and you can't help but leave feeling like you've been on an emotional rollercoaster ride with a backing track of really catchy songs. Overall, definitely worth watching for anyone. If you don't like it then fine but if you do, you will REALLY like it.

One of the best films I've seen years. The music is contemporary, the choreography is reminiscent of the old Hollywood musicals, and Gosling and Stone have perfect chemistry. The whole movie is a celebration of Los Angeles, the movie industry, falling in love, and working toward your dreams all at the same time. The script and lyrics work on all those levels at the same time. The costumes and sets look timeless, like this could have been done in the 50's or today.
Despite the bittersweet notes, the word I'd use for this movie is "Fun."

After seeing La La Land I was astounded about the performances, story, and mainly the music. Everything flows well together to tell an amazing story about two individuals who have dreams and goals in a town that often times forces some to compromise on it. This movie is a tale for those who are dreamers and tells them to go for it and it is a beautiful call back to old school musicals. Most importantly, to me anyways, this movie made me smile, something that I always love doing in the movies, this movie made me feel good with the story and the music and I recommend it for all.

Emma and Ryan are not singers nor dancers. Compared to real musicals with REAL singing and dancing, this is an amateurish romp with much hype but very little to offer. Nothing to see here people. Keep moving.
A charming musical with two brilliant performances by Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling.

The movie started off colorful, magical, and entertaining.  Unfortunately, the main characters singing, I could not hear because it seem at times they were mumbling or the tone was off.   I cringed a few times with Emma Stones singing sometimes.  The dancing was ok, but not spectacular.  Overall, the movie was ok.
Very entertaining, fun movie. The leads didn't have exceptional singing voices or dance skills but it didn't matter. It's  a sweet romantic movie about the choices we make to follow our dreams.

"La La Land" is a little clichéd and relies on Golden Hollywood-era nostalgia a lot, but that works in the movie's favor. My goodness, what a film. A gorgeous score, wonderful cinematography, great performances, incredible songs, beautiful sets, and an ending that isn't perfect as an ending itself, but is perfect for the film. It's a love letter not only to classic Hollywood, but to dreams and aspirations. And man, does it shine.

I gave it 1/2 star because there is no option for giving it negative-6 stars...absolutely unwatchable and a complete waste of 2+ hours of my life.  I kept waiting for it to finally end..but I just wouldn't.  It was better than being tortured...but not a lot.  Unfunny, unsophisticated, not entertaining...just not good.  Apparently others thought it was good, it won 7 Golden Globes, and it has about a 93% rating on Rotten Tomatoes, so apparently I'm in the minority, but I still feel that any movie would have been better than this one. For those special song and dance moments, we often have to hark back to the golden age of the Hollywood musical, where spectacle and showbiz tap danced along the forefront of the cinematic landscape. Compared to today, where the genre is barely touched upon, musicals can often be seen as a risky venture or a style that can seem out of place amongst its peers. However, that could soon change, as La La Land has not only reinvigorated the brand, but it has done it in such style, craftsmanship and panache, that it can rival the big heavey weight features that have dominated the screen for some time now. With an engaging story and characters, beautifullly-composed art direction and an array of hip-swinging and finger clicking melodies, this is a movie experience that will make you want to sing and dance your way back to the cinema aisle. Bravo.

A postmodern musical with the style and attitudes of today smoothly blended with the singing and dancing of another era of Hollywood. Hat tips abound to Astaire and Rogers, Gene Kelly, Busby Berkeley, and many many others. A love letter to Hollywood sealed with a kiss.

lots of 5 stars - but not from me.  Not my genre, for one thing.  And I haven't heard such mediocre singing since Jo Brand was on stage in London's West End.  

It is, however, a touching and difficult-to-watch love story.  And the highlights are Gosling's dancing and piano work.
Loved this movie! The small sequences of song and dance throughout with a nice whimsical feel, made this movie so wonderful to watch. I had a smile on my face almost to the very end!

This is the movie musical I've been waiting years for.  An original (glorious) score. A great book. Beautiful cinematography. Wonderful choreography. And perfect casting.  If this movie was made 60 years ago it would have starred Gene Kelly and Debbie Reynolds. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling are not perfect singers or dancers, but in this setting they are magical. Their chemistry makes this a movie I will watch over and over.

Whiplash was my favorite film of 2014. It showcased a filmmaker that could control audience emotions with brains, tone and brilliant pacing. So I was very much anticipating director Chazelle's return to the big screen with La La Land, a decided change-of-pace that is getting almost universal acclaim, and rightfully so. Where Whiplash was an intense drama about ambition and loneliness within the jazz world, La La Land is bright musical about ambition and loneliness within Hollywood. Fully embracing the constructs of old-fashioned Astaire / Rogers pictures while floating them effortlessly into the 21st century, it's a joyous song-and-dance rom-com that dances far beyond its pretenses.
Gosling and Stone are phenomenal, playing two wide-eyed dreamers looking to make something of their artistic abilities. With the lovely romantic melancholy of Once, the dreamlike song numbers of Singin' in the Rain, and the character motivations of each, the film wraps itself around our nostalgia before nudging us out of our familiar comfort. The songs are lyrically moving and ready-made for Broadway, and the sets and dances accompanying them would be considered experimental if they weren't so charmingly classic.
If it seems like La La Land skates by on its charisma, think again. Playing effectively with the line between romance and reality, both in relationships and in aspirations, it asks us if one is inherently better than the other, and is it truly possible to have both? In our search for purpose, must we apologize for every mistake, or can we accept them & even love them? To quote one song directly, "Here's to the messes we make." That's where true love is found. That's where life is found.

I'm exploding from this movie. It was just so fabulous and I'm literally shaking with the emotion of it all. A film that has had such rave reviews and word of mouth and a hatful of awards already. I had to see this film. Or so I thought because my point of view changed after seeing it.
I was mesmorized by Whiplash in 2016. La La Land has the same director, Damien Chazelle and writer and stars J.K. Simmons. However his part in this film is strictly limited compared to his performance in Whiplash.
The plot basically is set in present day Los Angeles and surrounds a jazz musician Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) who through random events develops a relationship with Mia (Emma Stone) an aspiring actress.
They both have dreams of fulfilling careers. For Sebastian or Seb it is jazz music and opening his own jazz bar (surprisingly called Sebs), for Mia it is becoming a well known stage/film actress.
To achieve there dreams they have to live apart and drift apart. Mia getting married and having a child in the process.
The film reminded me of Fame with random acts of dancing and singing in the most inappropriate places (a LA traffic jam?). The part musical genre is just not suited to me perhaps!

The lead actors put in good performances but the architecture of the screenplay left me lost. It really did come across as Fame at times rather than Whiplash (the film).

I was there and after I left the cinema I was still there. I haven't cried watching a film for a long time, and this one made my lip quiver. This is real cinema. Bravo!

4.5/5; Definition of bittersweet, tears will be shed, a MUST SEE.

Electrifying from start to finish, La La Land delivers a fresh modern take on the movie musical. It expertly walks a line bordering whimsical and melodramatic, as we see the romance Gosling and Stone seamlessly form as they balance their relationship with the Hollywood careers they have dreamed for themselves and each other. The film carries with it an infectious energy and passion for its themes, and we see the magic it creates for the world and characters it has built in almost every scene. The movie itself is gorgeous, with each shot being mesmerizing in tone, composition, and color. One might be skeptical regarding the ridiculous amount of buzz La La Land has been getting, but the movie ultimately delivers what it sought to achieve, to share its love for the City of Stars as it shines for the people that gaze at it through the smoky sky.

My first 5-star review here at RT. I went into it sort of skeptical at first but wow, what an upbeat, fun and magical movie. It reaches the ultimate goal of going to the movies and that is to just be fully immersed into what is in front of you on the screen and the world could be falling apart outside yet you are totally impervious and at ease. Time is frozen for the two hours you are watching this movie. Bravo for bringing back some old Hollywood wonder and making it work. Emma Stone was the lovable "girl next door" character and it was very fitting to her voice. And Ryan Gosling? How do I begin to explain Ryan Gosling? Ryan Gosling is flawless... [feel free to continue the quote in your head] :)

Place was very busy with Old Geezers Who Go To The Matinee Alone, many of whom only go to one movie a year so they think they are sitting at home and can give a running dialogue. I'll be honest and say I don't really like musicals. I do like the 1940/50s ones and this one certainly tried to capture that. The acting and such was mostly terrific but the music left me annoyed. I'm told that Ryan Gosling practiced for four whole months for his part as a struggling jazz musician and his playing shows why he is struggling. I have to wonder if he'd practice for four whole months and then try to play Chopin. The idea seems to be that Jazz is easy. Other jazz in the movie are not only good, they are damn good but when Gosling plays it is obvious you are listening to an amateur who has memorized some good player's riffs. The dialogue about jazz is right on, but Gosling should have faked it. Most of the other music is cute, but not really memorable. There are a couple of really good pieces, 'City of Stars' for one, but I kept thinking how much better they were be with better singers. All that is nit picking I guess but I just found that given all the hype this would be much better. Look I have friends who's (or is it whose?) opinions I value who disagree with me and they are as much right as I am. So don't pass this up because I didn't like it, I'm too picky about Jazz anyway. Overall a well done movie and a good experience. You can expect to see this in the awards but I have to scratch my head on that.

There are a lot to like about this film. Its realistic plot. Jazz. Musicals. Chemistry between Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone. 

However, it's the stories about its production and its director that make me like this film even more.

The director was a drummer and drew from experience and favorite inspiration to direct this movie.

He was persistent. He had the theme and script for this movie since 2010, but because it was about jazz which no distributors / studios liked (the same sentiment toward jazz was also used in the movie), and he wasn't famous, he folded and kept this dream within him while working on other films. Eventually when he had a big success from another movie, *Whiplash*, that's when people started to take him seriously about his idea of *La La Land*, with the theme of paying homage to people who risk it all to have a success in neck-breaking competitive environment in Hollywood, and "*to take the old musical but ground it in real life where things don't always exactly work out*". The bittersweet ending is what makes this movie so great, because that's real life that everybody can relate to, not some perfect love story that you *wish* it'd come true.

I respect the director Damien Chazelle a lot that he didn't compromise to fulfill his dream. Initially, a studio offered to finance his film but they wanted heavy alterations. Jazz. Nah. Change to rock. Bittersweet also had to be dropped. Instead of compromising, Damien moved on until he was presented with a perfect opportunity years later. Persistence in action.

I appreciate the process of recruiting and training the lead actor and actress. Ryan Gosling had no prior experience in piano, neither did Emma Stone in dancing, so both had to learn from scratch just to shoot the film. Both of them drew from the experience to act so realistically in the film too. Emma remembered when she kept getting rejected from so many auditions, and Ryan told the story of him getting interrupted with conversation about lunch while he emoted passionately -- a scene ended up in the movie which Emma acted.

Overall, this is a masterpiece that has great stories both within and behind the scenes. Entertaining and inspiring. Easily 5 stars.

A gorgeous movie with a talented cast, La La Land is escapism at its finest until it stumbles at the finish line. As a musical, I found it mediocre. Every character had the unpracticed voice of someone auditioning for a high school play. The instrumental soundtrack, though, was phenomenal. This movie makes me want to find all those jazz greats on vinyl and listen to them on repeat. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone have chemistry, which is not a surprise from how many movies they've been cast for together. We get tied up in their hopes and dreams; we feel when they fail. Then that ending nearly ruined all my good feelings for the film. It's as it they thought the ending they've been building up to, that they've set the stage for, is too easy...so they throw it in the dumpster outside. We leave wondering why in the heck they even wrote and filmed an ending at all if that's what they were going to give us. 

My final verdict is to see this movie. The cinematography and acting is stunning, so focus on that and let the ending fade from your memory entirely.

I went into La La Land with incredibly high expectations and a negative agenda, particularly after its sweep at the Golden Globes. In many ways, I didn't want to enjoy La La Land, bracing myself for ways to criticize this film that's received a ridiculous amount of critical acclaim. Suffice to say, I walked out of the theater with tears in my eyes and my tail between my legs. La La Land is by no means a perfect film, but it is damn near close. 

The opening number of La La Land was everything I initially expected of the film--a gushy, colorful, euphoric mess. I was convinced I'd be annoyed for the remaining 2 hours, before being blindsided and proven completely wrong. In all honesty, La La Land is at its best when it isn't a playing the part of a musical--partially due to the fact that Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling aren't the best singers. (Ryan should probably stick to his awesome, spooky Halloween band and low baritone.) The two are an emotional tour de force in La La Land, which was a much unexpected surprise inbetween so many whimsical musical numbers. 

La La Land is the epitome of artistic expression and escapism as much as it is a cinematic embodiment of aspiration, growth, love, and heartbreak. It starkly contrasts beauty with grit, comicality with sorrow, and dreams with solemn reality. La La Land is a bittersweet beauty, and I was wrong to ever doubt it.
One of the rare films that will have you singing, dancing, laughing, crying, and literally cheering all throughout. It's one of the year's best films and the best musical since the 50s.
Gosling and Stone are amazing individual talents, but they become so much more when they are together, and La La Land is no exception.
