Thats about the only thing I can say negative on it, which isn't even a negative really. Personally in my opinion it doesn't pass Whiplash as one of my favorites but it is still a stellar film.
Music was simply perfect fun and the story is relatable to anyone who has a dream. Simple,  and perfect!

How do you define such a unique film?  It's an homage to classic musicals but doesn't follow their structure.  From the first beautifully filmed traffic jam sequence, you get the sense this is going to be different.  You immediately notice the singing voices aren't strong, and certainly Emma Stone won't be releasing any records--but this new style flows comfortably through the first few scenes, and you let it take you.  The strength of Gosling and Stone's performances are what carry us through the simple plot---they absolutely deserved their Globes for this.  I can't imagine two more compelling faces to light up this project.

I was loving this movie until it got to the ending. I think is such a beautifully shot movie. It does look and feel like old Hollywood musicals. The songs, the dancing, the story, it was all wonderful. The best part is the chemistry between Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone. These two are fantastic together. You believe their love. Everything was great, literally everything, but the ending ruined it for me... Well it didn't ruin the whole movie, but because of that ending I doubt that I will ever watch this movie again. At the beginning I was thinking that I was gonna buy this movie on blu-ray because I love old musicals and this one was just like that, but because of that ending, I just don't want to experience that again. It is still worth watching because it proves that we can get that magic of the old classical musicals again in modern movies, I just don't agree with the "Casablanca" type of ending for this type of movie. I love Casablanca and is ok to not always have happy ending, but I don't know, is just not ok for this one.
Refreshing and entertaining film.  Acting was superb.  Loved it.

For someone who loves musicals, we were baffled by the accolades this movie has been getting. The idea was sweet, and there were some nice moments, interesting cinematography and charming references to old Hollywood. But the two lead performers, Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, both of whom we've enjoyed in other movies, had very little chemistry, and not that much singing or dancing ability. The movie also lasted about twenty minutes too long, although I did like the way it tied up lose ends at the end. But overall, we're scratching our heads at how much the critics love it and a large percentage of moviegoers.
I love the dance, music and the story. The movie is very beautiful and moved.

Let me disclose something right off the bat.  I HATE MUSICALS.  Always have, always will.  So, take that in consideration when I say that I did not hate La La Land, which has become the most celebrated film of award season 2016 and has been hailed as a revival of sorts for Golden Age era musicals.  Part of the reason I was okay with La La Land may lie in the fact that there aren't as many musical numbers as there are in other musical films.  It has just enough pleasant, entertaining song and dance tunes to keep that crowd happy and just enough story and you know...acting to keep someone like me from walking out.  I would argue that Land has more in common with old school melodrama pictures than it does a musical of that same period, but that's just me.  Anyway, La La Land focuses around two 20-something hopefuls living in L.A.  Emma Stone is a barista trying to audition to become an actress, while Ryan Gosling is a pianist who wishes to revive pure old school jazz and open a club displaying it.  Stone is the MVP here, doing most of the emotional heavy lifting, and doing it effortlessly.  Gosling's character seems to be more the absurd and insufferable one at first, but as the movie progresses, he turns out to be the more practical person.  

Of course, this movie is rooted in starry-eyed romance and yes, Stone and Gosling have the kind of chemistry that will get general audiences to buy tickets, when they normally might avoid this kind of fare.  It's a generally pleasant movie, but it becomes quite heartbreaking and bittersweet toward the end.  The last ten minutes proves gut wrenching as both characters view what may have been and what will never be.  I thought it was alright, which says all you need to know for this one.  Though I do think that if the media and entertainment press sincerely thinks that this movie is the best of the year and will lead to a revival of musicals, then it is they who are living in La La Land.
8,7/10. A masterpiece, maybe my favorite opening of all time.

Damien Chazelle's joyous, unabashedly romantic modern musical about hopeful dreamers in Los Angeles. Ryan Gosling is a jazz pianist with ambitions of opening his own club. Emma Stone is a coffee-shop waitress and struggling actress. The movie opens with an exuberant, improbable song and dance number, "Another Day of Sun," on an LA freeway where Gosling and Stone first meet. This sequence is filmed in one seemingly unbroken shot and is filled with so much gaiety that it sustains you throughout the movie. Chazelle has made an original, romantic musical comedy with the vibrant colors and lyricism that reminds you of Jacques Demy's "The Umbrellas of Cherbourg." The dances are funny and beautiful and shot in fluid long takes. Gosling is more alive and affecting than usual. He tampers down on that Steve McQueen nonchalance. Stone is a charming, lightly self-mocking comedienne but she's never been as lovely, graceful, and touching as she is here. It goes on too long as the romance fades but there is a concluding passage that shows what might've been that is almost peerless in its poignancy. Written and directed by Chazelle. Music by Justin Hurwitz. Choreography by Mandy Moore. Cinematography by Linus Sandgren in gorgeous Cinemascope. Songs include: "Someone in the Crowd," "City of Stars," "A Lovely Night," "Planetarium," "Audition." With John Legend, Rosemarie DeWitt, JK Simmons. Won Oscars for Best Actress (Emma Stone), Director, Cinematography, Production Design, Score, Song ("City of Stars.").

I admit I was not that enthralled after the first hour or so but it does come together better if you hang in there till the end and you find yourself wrapped up in there relationship it's visually great to look at aswell very vivid.
I may find I up it to 4 stars when I watch it a second time.

Simply beautiful. They managed to place a 1950's romantic movie musical in 2016 without it feeling forced in the least. Emma stone and Ryan Gosling did a fantastic job. Neither one is a particularly strong singer, but the songs don't really call for it. Really loved this movie.
Good movie, great music and flowed very well.
an excellent movie; ryan and emma was perfect casting; I am still hearing the songs and music
Fun, Cute, and Simple.....great date night movie...you'll have the theme song in your head all night!

Great opening dance sequence-they should have stopped there.  Too bad they spent so much time on the bland story about two bland people trying to be "pure" and "follow their dreams" in the blandest possible way.  Light fun until the filmmakers start to indulge in annoying power games at the end.  A high-budget but failed attempt to bring new life to the tradition of musicals.  Highly derivative music, unexciting plot-line, and WAY to much face time with the cute stars being cute and semi-tragic without any real sense of drama and zero sexuality.  I recommend first spending time re-watching the old classics or newer musicals like Hedwig or Chicago to get a modern spin on the genre.  This is just cloying movie fodder, nothing special except for the high-budget effects and pretty face on Emma.  And you can get sick of that too when they shove the camera into it for the five-milionth time.
Makes your heart swoon ??
ABSOLUTLEY fantastic. I'm completely blown away.

When you look around to see what kind of movies are coming out today, you're mostly going to see stupid (but crowd pleasing) action thrillers, very poorly written party comedy movies, pointless money grabbing remakes and a handful of top notch biopics and drama films. Notice how movie musical was not included. What happened to them? Not counting biopics, I believe the last movie musical was Chicago (2002). So what do we have here? We have a delightful new, original musical which recently swept the golden globes and which, if you're like me, probably need to see twice in the theaters. We already are familiar with the boy meets girl premise, and we're familiar with the great chemistry Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling share. However, Damien Chazelle reinvents the movie musical and that premise and makes it brand new. Sure, they're no Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, but think about it. When was the last time you were tapping your foot and smiling so much during a musical since Chicago? When was the last time you saw tap dancing? Dancer in the dark? (I know I said that was the worst musical and movie ever made, but since there was no music playing at that point, I mildly enjoyed that part) You will hear from some people that this movie is overrated. That is coming from people who were expecting it to be like Chicago, or even pitch perfect. Yes, it doesn't have much story. Yes, there's only two real scenes of dancing. Yes, the music and lyrics aren't Broadway quality. However, what's there is excellent. I will admit, I thought pitch perfect was just a little overrated, but believe the hype this movie is getting. Watch it and escape into a fantasy world you haven't seen since 2002. Oh yeah, and it's styled like a musical from the 30s to the 60s, so it'll provide some real nostalgia. Best movie of 2016!

A sensational tale of every star. While the end was obvious, what wasn't was the chemistry between the two leads and their relationship was true fantasy. Homage to classic Hollywood is good, but this movie is what classic Hollywood was.
A spectacular film, what it lacks in emotion it makes up for in performance.

I love movie musicals and I was loving La La Land until they pulled the rug out from under me with the ending.  That said I am still humming the music and Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone were a joy to watch.  The moral don't stop trying to achieve your dreams!  From the director of Whiplash comes an homage to the movie musicals of the past.  Despite the ending this is a love letter that I would watch again, if nothing more than to sing along.
Starts off as a musical, but then goes at it half-heartedly.  Ryan Gosling playing the piano is fantastic, but that's about it.
Amazing cinematography. Ryan Gosling's best romantic film since "The Notebook".

La La Land is the new version of the classic "Singing in the Rain". Emma Stone & Ryan Gosling were spot on with this film! Music made me want to dance so much! Storyline is pretty good and it's on my prediction list to take home the most Oscars!! It deserves every award!
My favourite movie of all time. Absolutely, positively, beautiful.

I was afraid I'd made a mistake when I saw the opening number.  I thought the opening number was silly so I was really afraid I would not like this movie.  I ended up loving it, although I hated the ending.  So terribly disappointed in the ending.  I gave this 4 stars because overall I loved it.  You felt the love and the heartbreak.  I thought about this movie all weekend so it definitely touched me.  I probably will see it again.

La La Land was amazing. The opening scene really sets the tone for the movie with its jovial music and dance. The music is so good, City of Stars is stuck in my head and i'm not mad about it. I adore the costumes, they are simplistic and bright. They give the feel of an old Hollywood musical, while giving it a modern spin. Which is one of the common things with this musical. It gives you a taste of something old, while not being cheesy. The chemistry between Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling is amazing, they really work and you buy them as a couple. The choreography is great. Mandy Moore knows how to make the movement as light and elegant as possible, further emerging you in the story. I loved this film. It was directed beautifully. The acting was great.  The cinematography was gorgeous. Everything from the editing to the color grading was done amazingly. I highly recommend this to everyone.

Although perhaps not as mind blowing as I had expected from the hype, it is still probably the best Hollywood film overall that I've seen yet this year, taken in its entirety. The music is infectious , but I wish there were more of it. The story in between the musical numbers is not as strong as the numbers themselves, although it was pretty darn cool to see a shout out to my hometown of Boulder City as the hometown of Emma Stone's character and the title of her one woman play within the film.  Still, I am a Ryan Gosling fan- he is amazing as usual and even became quite an accomplished pianist just for the film, in keeping with his abnormally immersive acting style, and the film delivers a much-needed dose of lightness at a rather heavy time in our national history.  Plus, it's great to see the musical genre  brought into the 21st-century.
Best movie of the year! So happy to see it set record at the Golden Globes. Everyone will love this movie for its songs, actors, and beautiful cinematography.
Very good, romantic, nostalgic, and colorful.  A little too long.

Just saw this last night, the same night that it won 7 golden globes, and it deserved them all.  I'm no movie expert, I just go based mostly on how I feel during and after the movie, and I can tell you that La La land had me smiling, dancing, singing, or crying, but ultimately happy the whole way through, and thats why I go to the movies!

This movie is like a set of gifts so perfectly thought, prepared, packed and delivered. The only disappointing part was singing was not as great as I had hoped. I do love that this movie pays homage to musical moviea from the past which is so hard to find nowadays.

La La Land is the first musical to have success in a little while. I think Les Misérables was the last musical to do well, and that was 2012, and it wasn't an original. The two leads of Gosling and Stone were the center piece to this film, and while they weren't the strongest singers, their chemistry and performance stole the show. I really enjoyed the music, I have it downloaded and have been listening to it while I write this. The plot flowed well and while the ending is a source of a little controversy, I thought it summed up life pretty well. La La Land is sure to be the big awards winner this season, and all I can say is that for a director who is the ripe old age of 31, count me impressed.

(Also, big shot out to the costume department for Ryan Goslings suits, I'm sure they said Suit Up!)
wow one of the best movies I've seen in years! Goes back to the good old days of musicals :-)
Beautiful movie. Well acted with great singing and dancing master class. With a great ending. What do you choose true love or financial success? Watch for the answer!

If you want an original movie, like a lot of people these days do, than this movie is just for you. Don't complain that there isn't enough original movies in Hollywood and then one comes out and you let it slip under your radar. Go see this movie...

A reminder of the forgotten beauty of old Hollywood. It's actors shine, there direction is assured and the nostalgic feel hits the spot. The only negative would be the songs. They won't be remembered anytime soon as there not very catchy or hummable like a Singin' in the Rain for example.
This movie is reminiscent of the classic musicals.  It draws you in, takes your breath away, and leaves you with a thought provoking ending.  Highly recommended.

Mia (played by Emma Stone) is an aspiring actress, working in a coffee shop.  She gets auditions but nothing has come of these.  Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) is a struggling jazz pianist, playing small venues.  His dream is to open his own jazz club.  The two meet, but don't hit it off.  Over time, however, things change...

I generally dislike musicals and romantic dramas.  Romantic dramas tend to be incredibly formulaic, schmaltzy and unrealistic.  Musicals are irritating because instead of spoken dialogue you have someone singing words at you, and it all seems so contrived and out of place (thus is if you're lucky.  Many musicals just use music as padding).

So it is with some trepidation that I watched La La Land.  The opening few scenes didn't help my fear that this was going to be a campy West Side Story-like implausible song-and-dance fest or a Les Miserables-like constant stream of nails-on-blackboard irritation.

However, it soon became clear that La La Land is better than that.  The answer to "How much better?" increases the more into the movie you get.

What sustains the movie initially is its warmth: the wonderful, often-funny dialogue and the interaction between the two main characters.  The chemistry between Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling is fantastic and their performances (especially Emma Stone's) alone are worth the price of admission.

Even the music is okay - sporadically used, not as intrusive as it could have been and it seems to integrate into the plot well.  Moreover, rather than just serve as padding, it helps move the plot along. (This all said, I would have preferred genuine dialogue!).  

At this point the movie was still heading down a rather safe, predictable "boy meets girl...yadda yadda...happily ever after" route.  The stuff of easy box office dollars rather than genuine art.

Then writer-director Damien Chazelle (of Whiplash fame) ups the ante, moving it from a mere romantic drama to a drama that covers a host of themes - artistic integrity, the price of fame, chasing dreams, the trade-offs between relationships and careers, missed opportunities and life's big "what if?" moments.  An incredibly emotional, bitter-sweet ending ties it all together perfectly. 

What appeared to be a quaint-yet-innocuous film turned into a wonderfully profound, hard-hitting work of art.

I love musicals but La La Land is no musical. It's opening scene is mildly engaging but it's all downhill after that. The leads do not engage hence the audience doesn't care. Their singing and dancing "ability" would have them gonged in any amateur hour, and this movis is supposed to be an homage to the musicals of the past. Don't believe the hype. It's a colossal waste of time. Somebody should also teach Ryan Gosling how to use a razor. Designer stubble aint a good look.

I grew up in jazz cafes as a little four year old boy when my father was playing piano and don't call this la la land music jazz, I call it "we know how to photocopy real jazz and pretend this copy is also real jazz". They play the same song with same riff and repeat the same offnote continuously in this movie.
We are very accurate at guessing what scores BBC strictly come dancing judges will give and are rather certain la la land would have gotten not really bad but only mediocre scores like seven, maybe an eight.
The singing and orchestral musical performance were only just OK, not bad, but it did not swing and certainly was not passionate.

Again a perfect example of a movie where the reviewers who are getting paid by the public are too scared to be honest and individual and give a movie that is only just OK a high rating out of fear that if they are don't they will lose their job.
I'm not always keen on musicals, but La La Land is one of my top films! Gosling and Stone are fantastic and the score is spot on.

One of the best movies I've seen in some time! Great story line and fantastic directing. This Musical has it all. Emma Stone and Ryan had stunning performances throughout. Definitely worth watching twice..if not 3 times!
A late 5-star review for what should have been my favourite movie in 2016. Breathtaking. Emotional. A true delight of a cinematic (and musical) voyage.
A whimsical look at two people whose lives are brought together by a chance meeting and their dreams of appearing on stage.
Everything I ever dreamed a movie could be. Can't wait to see it again - on the big screen!

Absolutely loved this film!
The moment that ending cut happened, I just dropped and drooled. As an editor that gave me chills. The Story was an A rating for me, that ending was an A++. It was REAL, emotionally and deeply engaging like no other movie has ever done for me before. I wanna watch it again, and more! I really hope it wins Best Picture at the Academy.
How could this masterpiece not win best picture?!

From its flawless and outrageous opening shot through the conclusion of its second act, La La Land impeccably establishes a magical realism that affirms its title and showcases the industry's best ode to romantic Classic Hollywood in a decade. And then, for reasons unclear and which betray the foundation upon which the film had build itself, the third act detours into the murky and artificial land of New Hollywood's Anti-Hollywood, where lives the dopiest contrarian cliche: the ending that's intent on being "against expectations" -- even at the cost of thematic continuity and, in this case, my recognition as one of the great films in years, which it surely could have been.
This movie was a jack of all trades, but a master of none.

Simply awful.  The stars have no chemistry, they can neither sing nor dance and the story was total crap.  There are a lot of good movies that have received lousy reviews.  This is a lousy movie that received great reviews.
Delightful movie. Music/choreography not as strong as hoping and expecting but entertaining nonetheless.

It started some what rough for me, opening with a staged musical number right out of a broadway play.  While each frame was composed with care I felt like this wasn't a movie made for me.  Towards the middle, the story started to develop and it being a musical bothered me less.  The last few scenes sealed the deal, and I have to admit I liked it.
A new take on the standard throw back to light hearted musicals of yore. It had fantastic tracking shots, good lighting, and a suprisingly modern ending.
Not sure how this is so well rated. I really wanted to like it. I like musicals but this was not as good as all the hype.

So beautiful! Every frame could pause and be a picture. The lighting, the music, the dancing, the costumes, the story - perfect! I wasn't ready for it and thought it would be another musical done ironically and stupidly, but no. This was perfectly honest in it's beautiful modern throwbacks, done with the effortless simplicity that comes with brilliant minds and hearts hard at work.

At the end of the day, a story of loss, the impossible dream, and how life could have always gone a different way. The musical numbers are exceptional, the theme is intoxicating, and Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are at their most phenomenal.

This is what I want to see from Hollywood! ORIGINAL AND ENJOYABLE work! While the singing wasn't my favorite, the story is great. It shows the hardship of living in Hollywood, but the most important message coming out of this film is that passion is key to life. No matter what you do, you shouldn't feel ashamed of your passions! Great performances overall from Gosling, Stone and Legend. The choreography was very well done! Another thing I LOVED was that the film was shot like a Hollywood film from the 50's! Damien Chazzalle is a genius young filmmaker and I cannot wait to see his next project!
Energetic,  big hearted, with silverscreen bravado!Emma and Ryan step up to the plate and hit a grandslam!
Horrible!! Absolutely abysmal!!
Great performances but not the perfect ending.
Magically and beautifully done!!!

In what may be the most startling career 180 in recent memory, Damien Chazelle, who made music school feel like Full Metal Jacket, harked back to the classic musicals of the 30s and 50s with La La Land and breathed life into a forgotten genre. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are perfectly matched as down-on-their luck lovebirds Sebastian and Mia who sing and dance their way to their dreams as they slowly find out their dreams may take them in opposite directions. Your eyes, ears, brain and heart are exposed to a domino-ing burst of skin-tingling charm, retina searing color, incredibly choreographed musical numbers, thrilling directing, and a surprising amount of depth. Much like Sebastian's attitude towards jazz, rather than modernizing the musical formula to appease contemporary expectations and attention-spans, Damien Chazelle pours his passion for the revolutionary charm of the classic musicals, bringing it remarkably to the present. The result is a film with all the charisma and character of a classic musical, endowed with 21st century technology and relatability. It's a jaw-droppingly, head-swimmingly, heart-thumpingly beguiling recipe that will soften even the hardest of hearts.
Way to long, too many close ups. Just a sad musical.

A spectacularly beautiful and artistic film that breathes new life into the musical genre. Both the story and cinematography are moving - backed by an amazing soundtrack. The vibrancy of the scenes and fun attitude that is conveyed through the dance choreography really make La La Land a joy to watch.
I truly loved everything about this movie!!
Magical. Refreshing. Great acting. Unique. Loved it!
Loved it!  Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling were wonderful.  One of the shows that you don't want to end

La La Land is a movie far from the typical. While most highly popular movies take the standard approach to a smash hit, with a predetermined pattern for box office success, La La Land has an almost Indie film vibe to it. It has the essence of a musical, yet it doesn't trap itself within these confinements. The movie pulls on our heartstrings, playing into real life issues, but maintaining its whimsical feel. For not being singers or dancers, Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling manage to pull the moves and songs off with ease. The chemistry between these two add to the enjoyment of the movie, as they pull us into their wonderful and vibrant world. While the movie does end in heartbreak, it works for the movie. It contrasts with the general vibrancy of the movie and plays into real experiences of real people. Life does not always end the way we want it to or the way it should. Our choices affect us, and we have to live with those choices. At the end of the day, La La Land was an artful and fun interpretation of struggles that the average person faces. In my opinion, the movie was a success.

Beautifuly sang,with gorgeous cinematography. it had everyone in my theatre literally dancing and singing as they walked out. The ending although at first made me throw my fists enraged but after contemplation, a truly great sendoff for the film. An excellent musical with fantastic characters only outdone by its everlasting impact
Amazing movie, best of the year.

This love letter to musicals is a no holds barred tribute that is also dripping in melancholy and bright colours. The performances are excellent, the music is never boring, and the movie has wonderful characters and dialogue. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling sizzle on the screen for a fantastic film that is more than just a garden variety musical, its got a lot of depth to go with the flash and music.
The movie of the year. Perfection!!
Just okay.   For a musical no memorial tunes.   Got bored
Beautiful love story
This was a whimsical poem about how genius, talent, creativity and love can get buried in capitalist routines. Refreshing and invigorating. My new favorite movie.

LOVED it!!!  This movie had me laughing, cheering, crying,... and dancing in my seat.  So fun.  Loved the music.  And while I wish it had ended differently, I totally get why it went the way it did.  Sometimes people come into our lives to help get us where we need to be.  It's bittersweet at times.  Can't say enough about this one!
Often joyous, but a little shallow and frivolous... L.A. and La La land both.
Performances excellent, but did not find this movie as good as the critics rated it.  Music mediocre, story boring.  Left the theatre feeling deprived of my time.

I don't get it. It tried to be a nostalgic musical, but it just didn't work, perhaps because the two leads are neither singers nor dancers? At least half an hour could have easily been cut. Our whole group had naps.

An instant modern musical classic. The chemistry between Gosling and Stone is astonishing. The story and the direction moved with great pace. This is truly one of the best movies of 2016. Love builds up through the seasons, and even though it may paused, it's always in the air. Always. A-

Great music.  Engaging story and characters.  Blends interesting stylistic elements from the article deco 40s, and from today.  Makes you think about life dreams and love considered, pursued, achieved, and lost.
Enriched with a loving romantic nostalgia for the glory of old Hollywood. Charm. Heart. Beauty. Whimsy.
Visually stunning, written with good humour and great lines. The acting it top notch and you can't help but leave the theatre smiling with a skip and step. Love it.

It really was a great movie.. it was very moving and I found myself walking out of the theater haunted by the characters. I loved the music theme that would repeat throughout - it really carried the romance through. I longed for it to have a happy ending but that is what made it more beautiful and real

Visuals and dancing were well done. Acting was above average. Emma stone and Ryan Gosling being star power to any role they take. Storyline was very self indulgent. The movie was one giant, hubris filled self tribute to Hollywood. Decent movie, no where near deserving of the acclaim and attention it's receiving.

How does this movie exist? It is so many things at one time. First, it's a love letter to Hollywood, and from the ashes of the past and among the jaded wannabe actors and musicians, rises music and performances that focus on the ability of the performers, flaws and all rather than polished movie magic that over compensate. 2nd, it's a love song to jazz and how it was Louisiana born and permeates music today. A well known musician appears to show how old music is kept alive by making it new, while the purist is forced to adapt and lose his way. The way they show it with so many subtle details and focus is amazing. 3rd, it's a realistic love story. It shows how someone can arrive in your life and change you for the better by inspiring you and also help you avoid a path. The conversations seem so natural and real. 4th its a reflection on nostalgia that should be done with respect and innovation, otherwise it is just copying. 5th it's a story about taking risks and doing what you know and love.
It's not an overwhelming musical where they break it into song and dance in unusual places, it's all grounded after two initial fun numbers. It's entertaining and real, instead of just being crowd pleasing, unlike the recent recycle of old movies that bring little new to the table.

Wonderful movie. Gosling's performance dazzles. It seems as though he actually learned the piano for this. Stone does a great job along side him, and both dance so well. They have great chemistry, and the songs are infectious. The production value is simply off the charts in this movie.

Best directed film of 2016, scenes of musical numbers are incredible, great performances n characters and just beautiful from beginning to end it's a must see. I don't care if you don't like musicals if you like great movies then you'll watch it

Entertaining and compelling from beginning to end.  I was engrossed within the first third of the movie, enchanted by the cinematography, costumes, staging and actors, and weeping at the end because of it's themes - it had many layers.

My heart strings were being struck as the plot of the movie was entangling. If you're silly romantic in the time of smart phones, you'll embark on a trip of soul-searching trying to capture the nuances of the little beauties we have at this time and age.

Dancing our lives away and painting every minute details of our dreams with music is the most transcendental embodiment of sublime. 

Dreams are made to be lived and experienced. Love is perpetual in all it's forms and shapes. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are the best manifestation of that.

This movie probably deserves 1000/10. My heart palpitated throughout and I know that I want to watch it again and again.

2nd best movie 2017.

Words cannot justify how much I love this film. I could write for hours and hours how passionate I am about film, I feel as though I can relate to Seb in the way that you feel so passionate about something. For me, it's film. That's what I want to spend the rest of my life being, a cinematographer.

ps. the cinematography in this masterpiece is something else, it is just simply wonderous.

La la Land was a very unique movie in that it had several musical numbers that helped move the plot along. It could be compared to the musical numbers that accompany most Bollywood films. The move is about an aspiring actress and a piano player who dreams of opening his own jazz club. The movie follows their path toward realizing their individual dreams and in the process they grow apart. The characters choose to be happy by achieving their own goals and aspirations even if they can't be together while doing so. The movie makes you laugh, think, and maybe even cry. It really puts you in your feels. The ending was outstanding in that it wasn't the usual expected happy ending. The two main characters didn't end up together. They chose individual happiness instead of happiness in each other and it was ok. There is this idea that you have to have love to be happy and this movie challenges that. The characters end up satisfied, fulfilled. Overall I would highly recommend seeing it in theaters, well worth it.
An exhilarating, enchanting movie that ripped my heart out at the end. I didn't leaving the theater singing, I left crying.
Beautiful music, beautiful cinematography, great acting. I just wish there was more of a storyline

Spoiler Alert - this is a movie MUSICAL.  Characters randomly SING and DANCE in said MUSICAL, frequently with no warning.  There are several occurrences of HOPE and JOY in said MUSICAL.  Such occurrences may be an anathema to your personal world view.  This review is an attempt to defend the aforementioned motion picture MUSICAL specifically, and the above referenced occurrences, generally.  You have been warned.

Hell yes, I am bitter.  How could I not be, with practically everything I love being cheapened or destroyed by going digital, with America (or is it 1933 Germany) days from being governed by the most amoral kleptocracy imaginable, and with the human race basically shrugging off finding practical science-based remedies to save our only planet?  I know I am not alone.

And so it seems appropriate, even fashionable, to be cynical.  Survey the sum output of the Hollywood juggernaut and ask yourself how many films, TV shows, and recordings are steeped in a nihilistic world view, and conversely how many are at their core hopeful.  Between dour entertainment and the-sky-is-falling social media, it makes one want to never wake up.  Yet when something different comes along - a piece of work that tries to embrace joie de vivre, people can't wait to trash it.  A few of my friends claim to have walked out of La La Land, and several more hated watching it.  It begs a question: what would they prefer instead?

Writer-director Damien Chazelle has emerged with a singular gift for creating characters driven to the edge of disaster by their fervor to do good work.  In Whiplash, both Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons found profound inspiration in their characters' drive.  In La La Land, the auteur has written Emma Stone's aspiring actress Mia and Ryan Gosling's jazz pianist Sebastian with similar uncompromising passions, and in a story arc as old as the movies, they must each lose his way and almost give up on her dreams before finding, at their lowest ebb, the missing piece that leads them to artistic fulfillment. Cliche, yes, but isn't that still the dream of the adventure we call Hollywood?  Isn't that why thousands still venture to the coast from every corner, willing to subsist on PA and extra work while taking acting classes, mounting original plays, making short films, performing songs at open mics, or burning the midnight oil working on screenplays?

In a world scarred by relentless cynicism, how can one not admire the ambition and unabashed optimism to make an old-fashioned musical?  Even if it's far from perfect?  Even if some songs are just passable?  Even if the lead actors aren't the best singers or dancers?  Even if Mandy Moore's choreography is only sometimes inspired?  Even if, and this is a big one for me, Gosling's fingers aren't anywhere close to matching the sound coming out of the piano?  Ryan said he took three months of piano lessons to prepare for the role, but the directorial choice to use his hands in closeup when he clearly can't play is a head scratcher.  But still.  This movie got made!

The true star of this show is DP Linus Sandgren and his team's exceptional, fluid cinematography.  While not the most technically perfect images of the year, the sheer effort of precision required to choreograph and capture a five minute thirty second dance routine with hundreds of dancers, and dozens of camera marks to hit, in focus, in rapid succession, perfectly in sync with the music, and all without hitting anyone in the head... in a SINGLE TAKE... is mind boggling.  Several of the dance routines are single take affairs... at magic hour.  No pressure there!  Sandgren's bold color choices and complex lighting cues make the film a joy to watch.

If we can, for two hours, believe that people can fight battles with light sabers, or that Spiderman can scale buildings, why is it so hard to believe that friends can break into song to express how they feel?  It's all movie magic, all make believe, and it all requires that good old-fashioned suspension of disbelief.

Mia, at the end of her rope, poignantly sings her way through an acting audition in a moment of magical realism that is the crux of this picture.  It's a perfect distillation of the requisite sacrifice required to live as an artist.  It is her Somewhere Over the Rainbow moment: the universal longing for a life less ordinary.  For me, it was heartbreakingly real.

Hollywood friends, if your sense of hope is not hale, if your lust for the dream not vibrant, if you are unwilling to let your heart be broken with every audition, every pitch, in the hope that out there somewhere lies a big confirming payoff for your endless sacrifice, then why, seriously, are you still at it? 

This movie rekindled my fire.  Here's to the ones who dream.
This was the easiest 5 stars I've ever given on a movie. La La Land was so amazing

You can't train two actors to sing and dance well enough for just a single film this takes years of practice. Bottomline, the parts of this movie that were good were the acted scenes but the singing and dancing scenes were a huge disappointment.

Wonderfully nostalgic and gloriously choreographed, La La Land presents itself as a love letter to a Hollywood golden age, a time past when musicals were written for the screen and production numbers were full of Tinseltown glamor. For a sense of reference, there is an interview that admits the movie's appreciation of That Thing You Do, and we can even see some odes to that film sprinkled in along the way (watch for an appearance by an actor in that film, and similar blue backdrop). 

I might think that anyone would be hard pressed to resist this film's charm and toe-tapping energy (evening considering those I know who hate musicals with a passion), but the true wonder of the film actually lies in its ability to masquerade as a rather complex and affecting human drama, a drama that uses the music to enhance it rather than simply accentuating the musical itself.

It might be easy to miss the fact that La La Land is Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone's third film together (Crazy, Stupid, Love and Gangster Squad), but it would certainly be near impossible to deny their ever-growing chemistry. The young actors light up the screen with their unpolished voices and humble dispositions, managing to strike an imperfect balance between the charisma of song and dance and the ongoing development of their characters. The fact that they don't have the perfect voices adds a sense of raw honesty to the picture that makes it all the more enjoyable and allows the magic of the set to feel all the more real.imgres

La La Land is definitely not your average rom-com, and director Damien Chazelle (Whiplash) uses a raw and uncalculated approach to colour the movie with an irresistible charm. For example, there is a rather large portion of the film (in the middle) that is absent of any music at all, and within the musical portions he uses the power of music to layer the unconventional love story with a rather bold mix of melancholy and romance that filters between realism and the fantastical. It allows the story to move fluidly between both realms, and provides the musical numbers to feel like they have a place and purpose in the story (rather than just spontaneously breaking out into song).

The film opens with a busy (but memorable) musical number set on an L.A. freeway, and then abruptly slows down the pace as we narrow in on the intersecting stories of Mia (Stone) and Sebastian (Gosling) from their unique perspectives as a part of the Hollywood culture. The film grounds itself in the L.A. landscape from the get-go, and becomes a rather endearing portrait of its storied past, something that gives us context for the main characters. 

As their stories merge, we find their relationship filled with interesting dynamics and twists and turns, and their less than conventional love story has much to teach us about the nature of relationships and what it means to give ourselves to these relationships whole-heartedly.

These two Hollywood hopefuls share a similar struggle, caught somewhere between their dream and their reality, and eventually find inspiration through the sharing of each-other's stories (with the help of the dazzling romance of the L.A. lights), a moment (or moments) that aspires them to turn their dream into reality. But it quickly becomes clear that with this relationship also comes a new unexpected struggle- the fact that their burgeoning relationship is also beginning to re-orient their dreams towards the needs of each other, something that requires them to consider a certain level of give and take along the journey. imgres-1

At its heart, the film is about the choices that we make and how choices always come with consequence, both for good and for struggle. Much the same as we find in the film Brooklyn, the nature of "choice" is described in La La Land as a process in which we must always be brave enough to celebrate one path while grieving another.

For example, in the case of Sebastian, he makes the choice to take a full time music gig, a choice that sacrifices both his passion for the music he actually wants to play and the relationship he desires to give himself whole-heartedly to (and that is also continuing to invest in him).

While the film is about choice, it is also about the importance of passion. Sebastian's neglect to fuel his passion for old-school jazz directly affects the passion he has for the relationship with Mia. In a wonderfully emotional scene, Mia encourages him not give up on his passion for jazz, which in a very real sense also becomes a plea not to neglect his passion for her as well. As she so poignantly states, by learning to love him she has also learned to love jazz, but it is also by learning to appreciate his passion for jazz that she has been able to grow a passion for him as well.  

What breathes a sense of irony into Sebastion's story is that he remains so desperate to be seen as someone who is successful, so desperate that he is willing to lose a piece of who he is. But in the process, he ends up neglecting the one person who has accepted him for exactly who he is.
imgres-3

In this same sense, Mia makes the choice, under the encouragement of Gosling, to pursue her own dream of becoming an actor, but eventually comes up against her own struggle with self-depreciating thoughts. It is her inability to see see herself as worthwhile and confident enough to act according to her strengths that causes her to lose her sense of passion, and it is this absence of passion that ends up keeping her from being able to fight for the relationship that she values so deeply.

And here we arrive at the rather bittersweet nature of the narrative. Instead of finding their identity in one another, and instead of finding their purpose in encouraging each other towards becoming the best versions of themselves that they can be, they end up searching for their worth outside of themselves. The tragedy of the story is that this causes them to miss opportunities to truly see themselves through each other's eyes as well (some foreshadowing we are given in the early going as Sebastian abruptly brushes past Mia instead of stopping to hear her words of encouragement). And so we gain a picture, a rather magical picture in-fact, of the characters slowly drifting apart as the story moves forward. So slowly in-fact that the surprising and unsettling finish, which we should see coming, ends up hard to predict. And yet, it is this slownesss is what allows the viewer to truly appreciate the conflicting emotions that the ending does create:

It is time which slows down when they are together. It is also the slowness of time which pushes them apart. It is a rather beautifully rendered final scene that reminds the two characters that life could have been different if they had made different choices. Life could have been different had they learned to share in their passions rather than isolate themselves at the each others expense. Life could have different if they had made use out of the slowness and learned to cherish the momentary magic of simply giving time to looking into each others eyes.  But the painful truth of time is that they can't go back and change the past, they can only choose to live differently moving forward. This is what it means for the characters, as they say, to grow up. 

As both characters eventually reemerge from this slow-drifing, they find themselves right back where they started, only this time carrying the consequence of their choices and the baggage of this missed time. And this is ultimately where Mia and Sebastian can teach us something about moving forward together or apart. Relationships push and pull us between the competing forces of understanding who we are as an individual and understanding who we are becoming together. It is when we let go on one side or the other that we stand in danger of losing sight of what the relationship can be. In La La Land's most melancholy moments we are reminded that we cannot live together in isolation. In it's most romantic ideals, we are reminded that we need not feel isolated when we make the effort to learn how to live together.

"Look at the view, " Mia says as they stand overlooking the lights of L.A..

"I've seen better," Sebastian responds. imgres-2

This small exchange manages to capture the heart of La La Lands mix of melancholy and romance better than any other scene in the film. The truth is relationships are messy. Life is messy. It very rarely looks the way we imagine it should when we are blinded by love. But it is when we embrace the messiness and acknowledge the struggle of the shared space these relationships create, that we also give ourselves the freedom to open our eyes and experience what lies beyond the romance of the lights as well. And there is great worth in opening our eyes to see and enter into the bigger picture of what a wholly formed love really is, and often the bigger picture ends up much more beautiful and worthwhile than we could have ever imagined from the momentary sidelines. Mia and Sebastian caught a glimpse of what this could have been for them, and it was enough to change their perspective on what was possible moving forward, offering a bit of joy amidst the grief, a bit of music in the mundane, a bit of hope in the broken, a bit of dancing in the rain.

And having just had the privilege of celebrating 12 years with the one who won me over all those years ago, La La Land was a good reminder to me that love is an investment that is worth more than anything this world has to offer.

My love for Whiplash was the only reason I watched a musical, this musical.

Maintaining the theme of Jazz in his movie Damien Chazelle scrutinizes the genre... in a good way, once again like Whiplash adding romance and relationship to drag on the true agenda, which was disguised as the sub plot of the story. Two lives with different goals and dreams, both individuals ideal and perfect for each other but conflicted by... well, goals and dreams. But does it matter? No.

Such a fantastic movie, a crazy unique style of editing and cinematography and needless to say story, it really gave a sort of Memento feel about the film which was truly mesmerizing. Building an Antagonist for this film is so hard, but it was done so well with the use of John Legend, the musical scenes didn't seem to be useless exposition more so stylistic advancements to the plot using lyrics as a way to develop characters and to divert attention from romance and rather towards the passion of the individuals proving more important.

Damien Chazelle is young and just what the film industry needs; someone to flip cliche narratives around and prove that meaningful film can result from it.

"They don't make movies like they used to". This is a phrase that is often passed around when discussing the films of today. We are living in a world of sequels and reboots of old films that never quite scratch the itch of the genuine feel classic films give us. However, every now and then a film comes along that reminds us of what we are currently missing in Hollywood and we fall in love with it instantly. La La Land is the sheer definition of that rare film and it stands second to none with it's direction, storytelling, and performances that make this film the pedigree of what Hollywood is capable of.

Director and writer Damian Chazelle made waves in 2014 with his small indy hit Whiplash and he does it again with La La Land. Chazelle has created a modern film that feels like a classic musical but makes it so gleeful and heartwarming that you fall in love with it instantly. From the way the camera moves during the song and dance numbers to the small nuanced moments of raw emotion and even the color pallet, La La Land carries enough weight that you feel for our main characters throughout the entire film. Chazelle even has small elements of classic films to really show how this film isn't just a musical but a love letter to how musicals of the 30?s and 40?s. These inclusions give the film more weight and timeliness with the heart of the message and just proves that Chazelle is a director who will surely grow into one of Hollywood's finest.

The story here is very simple but extravagant in it's execution. The story follows an aspiring actress and a jazz pianist who become entangled with one another in the brutal world of Hollywood. This is indeed a modern musical with all of the passion and wonder of classic films. The story progresses in ways that you really don't see anymore with dance numbers that show us their struggles rather than bore us with pointless dialogue. The songs used in the film are catchy but they feel genuine and crucial to the story, giving every scene more weight. It is incredibly hard for a film to find the balance between story and song but La La Land grabs hold to it and uses these incredible lyrics and dances to convey emotion and elevates this story, and the film as a whole, into a true work of art.

A film like this is nothing without its cast and La La Land has two of the best around to bring this film to life. Ryan Gosling plays the jazz pianist Sebastian and delivers another award worthy performance. His timing is impeccable and when he does something as little as staring you can feel everything his character is going through. Playing the actress Mia is Emma Stone and she is nothing short of a triumph. Her performance is so powerful and moving that you empathize with her from the minute you see her. Gosling and Stone are no strangers to each other and their chemistry shines once again. When they are together you feel like this is a powerhouse couple and you care about what happens to them because you believe they would be together. It is very rare for a film to feature performances like this and to have chemistry on top of that is nothing short of perfection.

This is normally the part of the review where I break down where the film went wrong, however I can't do that for this. Everything in this movie is so masterfully done that I can't say that this film struggled in a single area. Sure, if I were nitpicking I would say that the pacing struggled in one scene; but to do that is just petty when the rest of the film works as well as it does.

Overall La La Land is an anomaly in today's cinema. It embraces the past to progress into the future and does it in such a way that you can't help but feel like you have witnessed something special. When discussing musicals films like West Side Story, The Sound of Music, and Singing in the Rain all come to mind. Now, mark my words in 10 or 20 years we will talk about La La Land in the same regard. This is an instant classic if there ever was one and we will still be singing and enjoying this film for years to come. Do yourself a favor and don't miss out on this. Films such as this don't happen but once every decade or so, be sure you witness this and see this as soon as possible.
Beautiful, original and an instant classic.
Awful movie. Terrible ending. Only good thing was the acting. Waste of my time and yours if you actually believe in true love and good endings. WILL NEVER WATCH THIS MOVIE AGAIN.
Loved it. Beautiful movie
Such a Great Film! Very Unique!
Really liked this, much more than I thought I was going to :)
A thoroughly underwhelming film. Blah Blah Bland!

I have seen this twice and will
Probably see it two more times! I love it! An ode to old Hollywood and musicals but with a fresh modern twist. Can't recommend enough!

Another time Damien Chazelle marveled me! This is a Masterpiece! An extraordinary feat that resumes why I love movies so much. I never thought even a second that this movie could be better than Whiplash, well it is.
This movie is very original and wonderfully done. I disliked the ending however I enjoyed this movie

Musicals have never really been high on my movie watching priority list. I typically reserve Disney movies for that. 

That being said, I never thought a tribute to movies of old would completely sweep me away. Congratulations "La La Land"! You completely took me by surprise with all of your singing, dancing, and fun choreography. I will say that I was very interested in seeing it since Damien Chazelle made a film a couple of years ago that will forever be an inspiration to me ("Whiplash"). Thanks for making another great film, Damien. A film that honors the past and makes you look forward to the future of movies.
A stunning concoction of irresistible music, quick dialogue, an exceptional blend of heart and pain, beautiful cinematography and editing, unpredictable plotting, and just pure entertainment.
A real delight, with at least one knockout musical number, clever writing, engaging characters, and a wistful, mature ending that elevates what's gone before.

I am not a huge musical fan, but honestly, the only thing that bothered me in this movie is that in the first act after the main characters meet and before they fall in love they spend some 5 to 10 (unnecessary) minutes trying to explain why they would never fall in love with each other, but that's it. But besides those 5 to 10 minutes that could be better utilized, the movie is a whole lot of fun.

I really enjoyed this movie! It's been five  days since I've seen it, and I'm still replaying the soundtrack on YouTube and thinking about the story in general...I gotta admit though, the ending had me heartbroken and shocked. I think it was lame how (spoiler) they spent the whole movie convincing us Mia and Sebastian were cute together only to suddenly have her be married to some other guy in the last five minutes -_-
Takes a while to get into the real story. Too much fluff in the beginning. Did not realize it was a musical.
Without a doubt in my mind, this is going to be considered one of the best movies of all time when the time comes.
Best film I've seen in a really long time. This is what a movie should be.
Beautiful to look at and amazingly acted (and danced, and sung) by the two leads; a nostalgic nod at film musicals and The Umbrellas of Cherbourg in particular.
My favorite film of 2016.  Go see it if you like good cinema.

I normally don't like musicals but I loved this movie. Gosling and Stone have great chemistry again. The direction was so good with many awesome one take shots. It was just good storytelling and I loved the way it ended, very emotional.
Fantastic time seeing this in the theater
Though some of the initial flair and mystifying charm wears off by the end, the the leads and the terrific material are enough to keep you going.
Really cute and not overly musical if that's what's holding you back from watching it.

From a movie goer who loves musical films, this has no place calling itself a musical. I adore the acting from both Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone in most of their films, but everything in this just fell flat. The singing was dull and passionless, except from the few characters in the beginning which gave me hope this would truly be a musical. The dancing was rudimentary and didn't take a great deal of skill like the musicals of the mid 20th century. I appreciate the fact that people have positive opinions about this film but for the life of me, I cannot figure out why. When viewing a musical, you'd expect to have several songs fluttering around in your head but after this, not a single one stuck in my mind. And that was after two viewings. I was genuinely excited to see this film. It looked like it had everything. Two amazing leads, music that would inspire a new generation to love musicals, and a lot of jazz. Sadly, I was let down. But if anyone can tell me why this is so highly regarded, I'd love to listen because I'm baffled.
Great movie in 2016 !!
Highly disappointing--in no way reminiscent of classic musicals, dull story, only pulled off vi a deus ex machina in the latter part. Don't bother.

It's a move that tries to be unpredictable by leaving you wondering "WTF just happened?". Several plot elements are missing necessary lead-ins, making things 'just happen' and you have to figure out or wonder how they got there.
It reminds us all why we loved going to the movies in the first place. A must see.
Loved, so beautiful!

An extremely beautifully directed, acted and shot. La La Land is immersing, funny, sweet, sour and nostalgic. You leave the theater somewhere between sad and thrilled. An absolute masterpiece, an homage to dreams, dreamers and old Hollywood.
4.5/5.  I appreciate this movie even more since I've moved to LA.

I saw this amazing film for the 2nd time last night. I liked it even better the 2nd time!! The music is brilliant and the story telling is fantastic. You  really feel invested in the story of Mia and Sebastian; their love story and their individual dreams. The chemistry between Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone is out of this world. The cinematography and choreography was spectacular. I cannot overstate how magical this film is. It has the feel of the 1950s style musical. From the opening musical number it hooks you in and you are under it spell. I loved this film!!!
Was Fantastic, Loves every minute of the film. Emma and Ryan were great. Definitely worth seeing.

La La Land  is an interesting film that boast some great performances from its lead actors and actually tells a great story at the core of the film. It was thrilling to see these two characters form a relationship while also pursuing their dreams. The only downside is that I think most of the musical and dance numbers take away from the film. I didn't find any of them catchy to listen to, only passable, especially the opening song and one shortly after. Luckily the film thrives when they aren't focused on the singing and dancing. La La Land has so much style and feels like an old school throwback to what film used to be. See it.

omg so many feelings about this movie. i actually hate suddenly bursting into song musicals and the routines before Mia and Sebastian meet were unnecessary. But then, then Emma and Ryan met and everything fell into place. The romance and their chemistry were amazing and the story was so real that i felt the struggle.The old hollywood feeling was strong and Emma's eyes never looked so big and gorgeous. I dont want to spoil anything but: although the ending was sad it was more realistic. you need rain to see the rainbow and you know thats love, thats life, so bittersweet. I'm gonna go listen to city of stars a couple of thousand times more now.

Old Hollywood returns to the big screen! This film brought back memories of watching Singing in the Rain and The Sound of Music. However, La La Land lacks the memorable tunes and strong vocal performances that these other famous musicals have. I caught myself wondering on several occasions what the film would be like if it featured two amazing vocalists who could act rather than two actors who are willing to sing. The chemistry between Gosling & Stone seems genuine and the two are delightful to watch on screen. Gosling's piano performances were a highlight of the film. This is definitely a musical you should see in theaters -- it will undoubtably be nominated for several Oscars this year.

All one needs to do to witness the collapse of popular taste, cinema history and aesthetic integrity is look at the gushing reviews of this cynical, inept, phony, heartless pastiche of tropes and slickness designed to make the foolish whinny. One well-choreographed dance number does not a musical make. The star-singing-and-dancing travesties made me look back on AT LONG LAST LOVE with unfamiliar respect. As unforgivable as that $200 hamburger they get people to buy because the restaurant owner spent a fortune on fancy lighting. Sure, these producers and the director know their audience and deliver what it wants. Well, so do the people managing a hog farm. Swill.

Not quite Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, this fun, flirty visit to old school Hollywood dreams has a perfect pairing in Ryan Gosling and the always radiant Emma Stone.  The clear love of old fashioned ballroom dancing is delightfully featured in a variety of numbers.  The opening has a very busy freeway overpass filled with parked cars and there is an immediate, infectious outbreak of dancing, dips, slides, skateboards and hood sliding.  The scene is jaw dropping for anyone who lives with horrible traffic knowing that the film crew was able to shut down a major Los Angeles freeway overpass for three days!  Mia and Sebastian are chasing their dreams, she to make is as an actress and he, to open his own jazz club playing free form and jazz standards.  Until that happens he plays for disinterested diners with his tip jar ala The Piano Man and she, works as a barista at the snack shop on the Warner Bros. lot, breaking free for auditions.  Do they fall in love?  Of course they do and they dance a bunch too.  Does it work out?  Go see this wonderful film and find out.  Ryan Gosling apparently studied piano for over a year to play the role and he totally sells the piano playing as his own.
I don't get all the hype and i love musicals. This is mediocre at best. The actors attempt at singing fails and the story could've made more of a connection with the audience.

Fast paced, modern and totally unexpected ending, but appropriate for the times, really like two movies in one the first half a 1950's musical, the second half darker and more serious. Loved it.

From the outside, La La Land could not be more different from writer/director Damien Chazelle's previous movie, Whiplash. Whiplash was a brutal film about jazz, living the dream and harsh reality. La La Land is the opposite: it's a musical, a homage to older, far less cynical times and movies. It's colorful, heartwarming and madly in love with it's lead actors. But make no mistake, underneath the song and dance and brilliance of Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, it's still about the same thing: living the dream, all that jazz and yes, harsh reality.

One of the best, if not the best, movies I have ever seen! Everything from direction, acting, styling, choreography, cinematography, and emotion goes above and beyond for this film. This film is an ode to the golden age of Hollywood and to those who are brave enough to follow their dreams. The emotion and values presented in this film are inspiring and create a cocktail of feelings that I have never felt in a movie before. This movie truly does make me happy and restores my faith in the movie musical. The only flaw I can find is the singing is not necessarily perfect, however the acting provided by stone and gosling make up for it. I expect this film to sweep the oscars with wins for emma stone, Damien chazelle, and the picture as a whole.

Damien Chazelle is no less than a Dr. Frankenstein, taking bits and pieces of an old (and curiously disrespected) genre and re-infusing the thing with fresh life. From the first frame to the last here is a new musical, no doubt, and yet at the same time  it breathes nostalgia for the sense of unlimited possibilities that the old films used to leave one with. "It's alive! It's alive!" The stars, as in days of yore, deliver stardom.
I want to see this again. I want to own this!
Haven't seen a musical like this in 30 years. Except for the end part where the woman dumps the guy to fulfill her career dreams. But that is the way it has been since Frozen.
Good film, worth a watch. Not sure what all the extra excitement is all about though!
" Here's to the fools who dream. "
While the actual plot isn't bad, the songs and dance routines (with the sole exception being Emma Stone's audition song) don't fit the movie and most certainly do NOT propel the storyline.
Great, fun, and brings back the concept of musicals as a message about life's realities.
I don't understand all the high praise over this film.   I was disappointed to the extent that I walked out of it after an hour.
Visually stunning. A breathe of fresh air from someone who doesn't really like musicals that much.
Gosling gives a perfect performance for this likely Best Picture winner (my favorite movie ever)

If you love movies like Singing in the Rain then you'll love LA LA Land. It's sort of modern day Los Angeles meets old Hollywood. As my sister put it: it's like Amelie, meetings Singing in the Rain meets 500 days of Summer.

La La Land is a modern take on a very traditional Hollywood fantasy. Frankly, I wish I hadn't heard the hype before entering the cinema because I was a little disappointed. I expected to be swept off my feet. Instead, I was moderately entertained.
Beautiful cinematography, awesome performances by Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling.
Entertaining and very creative.
Would have to have been the best movie I have seen for a long, long time.loved it !!

Slow start that builds into an entertaining film and a great story

4.5/5 - La La Land is classic love letter to the Hollywood of old. It's an invigorating addition to the musical film genre that brings to mind the greats like 'Singin' in the Rain' and 'My Fair Lady'. But don't let the tag "musical" put you off. This film stands on it's own even without the fantastic musical talents of Justin Hurwitz at the helm. Speaking of the music, director Damien Chazelle handles this film with as much care and attention as he did with his last film 'Whiplash'. Once again Damien Chazelle fines the right balance of story progression and character development along with finding the right times to interject with a musical number. This film is full of colour and the aesthetic of Hollywood has never looked better. Los Angeles is on full display in this film showing us some dazzling vistas. I honestly can't say enough about how pretty this film is. Everything just pops with vibrant visuals. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling stand toe to toe and really play off each other with pleasant results. Both are a joy to listen too but Emma Stone really steals the show with her solo performance. My only complaint is the run time. Theres scenes in this film that puzzle me as to why they stayed in. 15-20 minutes could have easily been taken off without hurting the overall film. This film was a great way to end this years amazing line up movies to come out. See this one in the cinemas!!
Didn't know what to expect, it was a wonderful movie, one of my new favourites!

Best ð¶al ever? Possibly. Not a fan of the twist ending. Otherwise, amazing film. Not very crazy and heavy on the musical aspect. Not a crazy cookie cutter musical. Very fun. Very enjoyable. Seems somewhat long.
Typically love ALL musicals, but this movie totally missed the mark.  Way too much hype, boring storyline, singing wasn't even that good.
Simply flawless. A masterclass in classic Hollywood film.

Spectacular story; both Ryan and Emma acting was superb, I was emotionally caught in the script...adorable singing scenes with a cute touch of tap dancing moves along with smooth jazz band tunes...FaNTasTic !!!

Not a fan...found the movie disappointing and all the band wagon reviews seem to hide the fact the movie is over rated. The film don't breath new life into anything, the performances are mediocre considering neither lead actor can sing or dance. Even comparing this film to musicals from the past does a disservice to all the truly great actors, directors, choreographers and musicians whose work sits in the vaults of the major motion picture studios. If you want to really go GA GA look up one of the really excellent films.  Please see La La Land however so you can compare it to past musicals and see why La La Land doesn't hold a candle to a picture like "Singing in the Rain", "Funny Girl". or "My Fair Lady".not to mention "West Side Story". La La Land viewed in isolation may "appear" like a good musical film but if you are a fan of the genre  you will quickly see why some people are rejecting the glowing band wagon reviews being heaped on La La Land. People are so head over heals about it, it will probably  clean up at the Oscars...if the film makers themselves believe their own PR..

The opening scene had me hooked and I was so excited for the rest but that was the only part of the movie that was any good.  So dull and slow and they really couldn't get better actors and singers for the two lead roles?  I love both of these actors but not for these parts.
sorry don't like musicals

loved the opening and just about all of the song and dance routines. neither Thompson or Gosling is much of a singer. His dancing was probably the best of those skills for either one. An odd pair for a musical and the plot was a  little slow. probably a lot better than many of the flicks out there, though.

I can't believe what I'm about to say. This whimsical and beautiful throwback to the golden age of cinema is the best movie of 2016. And it's a musical. Any true cinephile couldn't help but get giddy watching this movie.
¿Es una buena película? Pues sí! Pero se siente excesivamente "artificial".

Needs motion sickness trigger warning at start. Camera motion had me queasy & head achy within first 20 seconds (and for the next 24 hours). Ugh. ...But the music is good, so you could close your eyes the whole time.

La La Land has everything you would like to see in a movie. Excellent performances, great direction of art and photography, and a music that combines perfectly with the history of the movie and also plays with your feelings during all the movie.

An enjoyable movie that mixes old-fashioned Hollywood musicals with some modern sensibilities about romance, relationships and following your dreams. Some enjoyable numbers and two incredibly charming stars. I'm a little worried about it racking up too many Oscars because Hollywood loves stories about itself, but it's certainly deserving of some, particularly for the music and cinematography.

Saw the buoyant musical LA LA LAND, an outstanding blend of old time musical and modern sensibility. A story of struggling actor Emma Stone and struggling jazz pianist Ryan Gosling in Los Angeles, filled with a top notch original score and cleverly staged dance pieces. The story plays out a little like the great NEW YORK, NEW YORK, but the charming chemistry of the two stars is far better than DeNiro and Liza Minelli. The great direction and writing of Damien Chazelle (WHIPLASH) recalls the loving view of LA that Woody Allen can bring to Manhattan, with the staging of a Vincent Minelli. There's a plot device to separate the lovers that's a little clumsy--although expected, but everything else works from the smashing traffic opener to a lovely coda of what could have been. Maybe the best film of the year!

This has to be the best musical I've ever seen and Damian Chezelle proves himself again as one of the best new directors after Whiplash. The two main performances are powerful and believably and the story perfectly balanced fun entertainment and the dark themes presented. 

Rey's Rate: 9.0/10
Superbly filmed, directed and acted. While not my cup of tea, I could appreciate the quality of this one.

A delight from beginning to end. It's a whirlwind walk through a relationship with all the joy, humor, frustration and a touch  sadness that makes this movie accessible to anyone who has ever experienced love. My complaint would be that too many reviews are focused on the genre and leave you wondering what this movie is about. Even the marketing is focused on the style and offer nothing of plot. I'll leave it to the other reviews to let you know how good the stylistic musical genre is: excellent.

1st half musical, 2nd half more so movie with musical elements. Didn't think either of the mains were particularly good singers, choreography was "eh," but overall I did enjoy the movie for the most part.
Loved it. This is a love story to Los Angeles as much as it is between the characters
a perfect movie in my opinion. go see it!

The beginning of the movie looked like High School Musical.     I was not happy about that.   As the main characters appeared....I felt much better.  Emma Stone was good but Ryan Gossling made the movie for me!  He's good in every movie!   I actually enjoyed his singing,dancing and piano playing.  It was all him!!!! There was no big song so you won't be singing it when you walk out of the movie. There was a pretty melody that you might whistle.     There's a lot of hype about this movie.    You may be disappointed!
Omg I can't even think about this movie without tearing up!

Surprisingly good.  I was prepared for embarrassing schlokiness and horridly inappropriate schmaltziness, but the story was engaging, the acting believable, the dialogue snappy, and the music decent enough to give this one a very good rating.  Hidden among the good qualities of this film was the camera work, which was outstanding.  Gosling and Stone play very well off each other, and the film poses many valid questions about destiny, choices, and time.  Worth a look on the large screen.

After Crazy Stupid Love, I realized that I would watch Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling meetcute in pretty much anything, and so I have. It's a pity neither of them can sing. Stone and the other ladies are ostentatiously breathy unless they're belting (which I prefer). Disappointing, but unsurprising. Only John Legend's voice really shines, but his only big number is essentially a concert piece rather than propelling the narrative at all.

I'm really happy that Hollywood is making original, big-budget musicals again. I will see these fantasias as long as they make them. The orchestration and music was absolutely delightful, even if the songs were cheesy-simple. Many of my favorite bits though were the extended, dialogue-less dance sequences, which worked so much better than I would have expected.

I also enjoyed the ending, which somewhat managed to un-romcom the treacly tale.
Though its final act/scenes make it hard to pinpoint the intentions of the film makers, La La Land is a fun, sweet, and inspiring flick.
This gave me the feels.

Highly stylized throwback musical that is both modern and nostalgic. The chemistry between Stone and Gosling is completely captivating.  The film drags a bit in the middle, but the film is still a subtly enchanting romance about following your dreams.
Fun, feel-good love story with a beautiful color palette.
Magnificent! A real screen gem! ????

Wonderful music, fun dancing and gorgeous visual design.  A real return to art in the service of beauty.  You're not in it for the plot, and the characters, though compelling, are not deep.  But it's surely one of the most beautiful movies ever made.

La La Land is a movie like no other! A throwback to classic Hollywood in a present setting. Wonderful performances by our leads. Plenty of laughs and plenty of touching moments. Overall, this is a film that will just make you mad that you didn't think of it!
