La La Land is a modern musical that pays homage to classic musicals of the 50s and 60s, while adding a new flavor as well. Every film enthusiast finds this movie to be spectacular in every way. People love every single aspect that there is in La La Land. Damien Chazelle has proven himself to be a filmmaker keep an eye on; ever since his 2014 feature Whiplash that has been praised by both critics and audiences alike, and won J.K Simmons a Best Supporting Actor award at the 2015 Academy Awards. After the success of Whiplash, in 2016 Chazelle released a film called La La Land. This movie has the potential to be one of the best films of all time. It pays homage to retro musicals, and it does give off it own flavor too. However almost every bit of potential is wasted. I will give credit to Gosling and Stone who are good, but that's about it. Damien Chazelle's writing and directing is all over the place. The cinematography is probably the best aspect of this entire feature, but there are some scenes that do not mix well with the films cinematography at all. The score and the songs are trying so hard to be more than what it is. The second act feels as if you are watching a totally different movie due the direction this movie takes. The runtime also could've been cut down a little too because there are a few scenes that drag. This movie has been praised by so many around the world, and in SOME ways that make sense, but at the same time it doesn't.

I'm definitely not a huge musical guy but the balance of typical movie moments and the dancing/singing out breaks is well done. At times at felt like it was an odd movie but in the best way. From start to finish I never stopped enjoying the show. And a simple but powerful ending was a real unexpected pleasure to take away from the movie. It was both sad and happy at the same time.

Early in Damien Chazelle's La La Land, Emma Stone's Mia namedrops two famous films: the 1943 drama Casablanca and the 1938 screwball comedy Bringing Up Baby-and, for a moment, it seems as if the film is headed in the screwball direction. Mia and Ryan Gosling's Sebastian flirt, sing and dance a charming number overlooking the L.A. skyline, and start to fall in love. But once Mia ditches her boring beau of one month for Sebastian, things get Casablanca earnest, fast. This is where the film starts to come apart. Chazelle embarks on a very (128 minutes runtime!) extended meditation on the sacrifices required to pursue one's dreams, with detours into jazz and fieldtrips through the city of Los Angeles that will delight lovers of the City of Angels (including, not coincidentally, members of The Academy) but leave everyone else feeling like outsiders on an inside joke. Since neither Gosling nor Stone are dancers or singers (though give them both an A for effort), the musical numbers tend to drag rather than entertain. What we are left with is a highly original, but also highly uneven film that manages to come up short of the Hollywood classics at which its lofty ambitions are aimed. In eschewing tried-and-true Hollywood formulas, La La Land manages to fall into a sort of filmic no-man's land. For Chazelle, like his Sebastian and Mia, there's a tragic cost to pursuing one's dreams.
Relationships are hard but apparently making a decent Hollywood musical with talented lead actors is harder.

With La La Land, I don't even know where to begin. I'm intimidated by the daunting task that is reviewing it, because writing about this incredible film is like holding a delicate crystal bird in my hand. I could drop it at any moment, dooming its future to shattering on the floor. In this case, though, I would probably be unable to even catch the bird, and if I did manage to, I wouldn't be able to hold it for long before it wrenched out of my hands and soared away to Los Angeles.

Critics, Hollywood professionals, and everyday moviegoers alike have spent the last few weeks walking out of the theatre with stars in their eyes and music in their ears. I am one of those people. As a prospective filmmaker, I was excited to see this film for many reasons, but there was a review at the end of one of the trailers which said something like, "they don't make movies like this anymore," that really caught my eye. Well, whoever said that was right. I literally cannot come up with words good enough to describe this film, because La La Land has created a new alphabet. The struggling actress/musician is a classic phenomenon, but Chazelle has veered off the beaten path. Rather than giving his characters everything they want, an unrealistic yet undeniably enjoyable classic Hollywood ending, his characters learn their lessons, so that they truly grow throughout the movie. However, rather than crush his character's dreams by proving how unrealistic they are, he has let them soar, teaching a valuable lesson to even the most cynical audience members. When it was first discovered that Ryan Gosling would be singing, there was an uproar of teenage excitement. However, I can assure you that this film is to be taken very very seriously, it isn't some bubble gum chick flick. Chazelle has wiped the board on musicals, and filled it in with his own definition. Even if you don't like musicals, I dare you not to be tapping your foot and singing these songs for the next week after seeing this. Really. I loved it so much, I saw it again the very next week, and I would see it  a million more times if I could.  Watching La La Land is like drinking six espressos on a technicolor beach, and both times I have seen it have been followed by sleepless nights singing songs off the best original soundtrack in history (thank you thank you thank you Justin Hurwitz, you genius) wondering how I can get my hands on Mia's dresses, wishing I could dance, crying over the amazing ending (but no spoilers here), and picturing both Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling as they collectively drop the mic on an already silent and stunned audience with their aw-worthy performances. This film is the perfect love letter to Los Angeles. This film slaps cynics across the face, and turns them into dreamers. Being a prospective filmmaker, I try to watch as many films as I possibly can, and soak in the ideas. This film cannot compare, though. It simply can't. I cannot compare my own ideas to this, but I walked out of that theater saying, "that is why I want to make movies." This film pours pure genius across the globe and breaths new life into cinema. It may just have slid into the category of best love story of all time. Chazelle (I just love saying his name, don't you?) is surfing a wave of uncharted territory, and I can't wait to see what else comes from his genius. Only thirty one years old (he wrote the screenplay for La La Land when he was only twenty six), Damien Chazelle has already directed two of my favorite movies (this and Whiplash, another stunner of it's own right). Composer Justin Hurwitz has been his companion on both movies, and he is also an absolute genius. Maybe the best part of Chazelle's works is the fact that he has created these wonderful films without the bloated ego that dominates many celebrated Hollywood directors thus far, and it is oh so refreshing.I hesitate to say the words, "perfect movie," for anything, because you never know what could come along and clear the board all over again, but this is absolutely as close to it as I have ever seen. This is the. best. film I have ever seen. La La Land takes the cake as far as I'm concerned, I don't need an oscar to prove it.

This film was an absolute slaughter of artistic integrity. It felt as though aspects of the film were pulled from different realities, but I have so many digressions I find it hard to find a starting point, yet I will attempt. First and foremost, the plot in the first half is hardly passable, no character is remotely empathetic, and for a Hollywood film about Hollywood as a love letter to the earlier musicals of Hollywood there seem to a big set of "of sorts" lying around. Pastiche comes to mind, but in order to be an iconic parody of a film you first must establish what the previous films entailed. Older films we're based in reality, the musical numbers had expositional purpose... Right out of the gate, first scene, opening number, there are necessary camera pans, unenthusiastic lyrics, tedious choreography, and confusing foley mixing. No semblance of narrative structure is brought forth through the opening, no character motive, and barely even any recognizable mise-en-scene is apparent. Speaking of which (aside from the makeup which went unnoticed and therefore did its job well), the setting and costume design made me want to vomit as my stomach churned at the candy-inspired mono-colored wardrobe mixed with similarly bizarre lighting. The entire first half of the film plays out like this, all the while I thought "Why is this not a theatrical production?" Sadly I can't even say that it would make a decent play as the plot seems to have tripped and died on the way to the starting gate. The first fifty minutes our main leads Mia (Emma Stone) and Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) are insufferable guttersnipes with big dreams; mind you, the problem was not their ambition, but their disconnect from reality. And that indeed is the main problem with this film. All films, in some small sense, must have some sense of reality or have empathetic qualities, but this film seems to have been pulled from different dimensions. Everything previously described comes together in this onslaught of strangulation that has you gasping for structure and/or a narrative all the while continuing to press out mediocre songs. I cannot for the life of me think of why Damien Chazelle would turn such incredible potential into a hurricane of abstractions and nonsense. SPOILERS While at Griffith Observatory, after Mia interrupted a film by standing in front of the screen to find Sebastian (for some inadequately explained reason), both characters begin to dance in a Fred Astaire style number but before that happens a handkerchief flies into the air in an observation room and the characters look to camera and go into space. There is no reason for them to do this, none at all, but there it is, assumedly because the director instructed so. As much as it pains me to do this, I am entirely pinning the blame on the director. There was some incredible talent pre-, during, and post-production, yet none of their labor is apparent until the last half hour of the film. Gosling and Stone, whether together or separate, are fantastic talents; putting them in this film was miscasting at its most egregious. However, despite all the nagging, there are some positive elements to the film. The editing, despite Chazelle's possible tantrums of "artistry", was impressive and the last half hour of the film came together nicely in its own. The final songs were empathetic, more grounded, unfortunately not memorable, but were charismatic, and that, in my opinion, was what almost the entirely of this film lacked, charisma. Since this film had so much going on at once, there was no appeal, no allure, so much assailing on the mind left me detached and longing for a decent... everything. The "life that could have been" sequence at the very end was the only piece of film that I would slice away from the rest of the dross and hang on the refrigerator, a masterpiece in story-rich, enticing, compelling film-making that Chazelle so desperately attempted at from start to end. Still, this is only one man's opinion, and I whole-heartedly know that this film is the bee's knees for another, so I still recommend it just in case this is your kind of film. There is so much more to say, but I refuse to beat a dead horse thats already been rotting on the floor since minute one.

When you make a film as good as Whiplash, Hollywood normally lets you have lots of free reign over your next project. It just so happens that Damien Chazelle's next passion project is a love letter to 1940's Hollywood. I can't think of a single film that has captured the glory of 1940's Hollywood, since the glory days of 1940's Hollywood. From the extravagant production design with its luscious colours and wonderful locations to its great use of Jazz in its soundtrack, this film makes Los Angeles look like heaven. I was just there and I can safely say that the real Los Angeles is not as beautiful as it is shown in La La Land. As for the musical numbers, I need to discuss. First off, I generally like musicals. Grease, Hairspray, a countless number of Disney of films, I'm a little fan. However, if it is full of cheesiness, it can turn me off right away (Moulin Rouge has this effect on people). The film opens with a giant musical number without any of the main cast during a traffic jam on a LA Interstate. I have to admit, I was like, "If this is the whole movie, I'm in for a long ride." Another mediocre musical number followed right afterward and I wasn't really feeling it. However, when the movie introduced Ryan Gosling and his storyline, I was onboard. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling have unbelievable chemistry and so likable. I think I just might be in love with Emma Stone. Straight up. She's perfect. The next musical number was the one you see them perform on the poster of the film. That's when I was really along for the musical ride. From that point on, the music was all very good. Whether it made you wanna dance, or cry, the music was all top notch. You can really tell this film was directed by Damien Chazelle because he brings lots of his trademark editing styles and writing techniques to this film and they are all solid. So if you are a fan of classic Hollywood, musicals, jazz, have a crush on either Emma Stone or Ryan Gosling, this is a movie for you. I have a feeling that this film will sweep up lots of Oscars and I believe this will become an instant classic!
Totally pretentious. I love Emma stone and Ryan Gosling but this was a waste of my time.

La La Land was written and directed by Damien Chazelle (Whiplash) and stars Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone as Sebastian, an aspiring jazz pianist, and Mia, an aspiring actress. The two meet in Los Angeles and fall in love.

I went into the movie theater with unreasonably high expectations. As a musician (kind of) and lover of film, it was impossible to watch La La Land without a very critical eye. That being said, LA LA LAND IS AMAZING.

Although the movie takes place in present day, it emulates classic cinema in every way. The absurd optimism, the bright colors, and some of the camerawork work together to take the viewer on a trip through a time machine. Justin Hurwitz, who was a classmate of Chazelle's and wrote the music for Whiplash, whipped up another knockout score full of big band jazz straight out of the 40's and 50's. The musical numbers, random as they were, are brilliantly shot. The opening sequence alone pulled me in with one continuous shot through the 3+ minute scene. From a technical standpoint, this is a nearly flawless movie.

Of course, none of those things matter if the story isn't any good. However, La La Land boasts a well-written story led by two knockout performances. I'll admit that I've never been the biggest fan of either actor, but they both give what I'd say is probably their best performances to date. The chemistry between them has never been stronger (this is Gosling and Stone's third collaboration). This movie asks important questions for all aspiring artists. Is it more important to be loved or to do what you love? Is it worth it to live as a struggling artist and to keep trying?

I have nothing negative to say about La La Land. This is an absolute must-see, especially for fans of old-time cinema, musicals, and cheesy feel-good stories. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a soundtrack to go purchase.

Final grade: A+

-Ben

A noisy, not so hot and sunny traffic jam in Los Angeles major highway welcome group of people, who just decided to start singing and dancing in the middle of the whole thing. It's "Another Day of Sun" a title song written for the opening credits of the film La La Land, a very energetic and big band style of song, just like those musical from the 50's and 60's at the end we introduced our star cross lovers, Mia (Emma Stone) and Sebastian (Ryan Gosling)

La La Land is the film directed by Damien Chazelle (Wihiplash) is the story of Mia a Barista who works at a coffee shop in the Warner Brothers lot, her dream is become and actress, a very typical story in the city of Los Angeles. Sebastian is a talented pianist who works in bar just playing what is required for the job, but his dream is to own a jazz club and play the music he likes. The film presents a gorgeous and colorful life in the city where everyone is a dreamer to become successful, in the industry of movies, music or fashion. Thorough the first half and hour of the film Mia and Sebastian characters bump into each other in a very comedic situations defining their roles and presenting them to the audience as mean to be together. 

Chazelle pays perfect tribute to films like Singing in the Rain, American in Paris and West Side Story. On the other hand the plot in La La Land explore stories about dreams, aspirations and how we put them aside just for the purpose of make money, sacrificing the true essence of us. Mia represents the dreamers; the people are just willing to leave everything behind to fulfill your goals. Sebastian represents the traditional, the classic. He wants to preserve jazz knowing that is dying, like film which metaphorically speaking is portrayed in the movie theater "Rialto" when Mia and Sebastian goes to see Rebel Without a Cause and later is closed, may be out of business.

A film made in Hollywood that is a love letter to an earlier Hollywood, about characters who live in Hollywood, and whose target audience seems to focus in on people in Hollywood. This year in the life romance has some great musical set pieces and superb choreography.  I personally think that the vocal song work does not rise to the level of the dancing. The cinematography outside of the set pieces does not give us a particularly beautiful film. The pacing seems a bit uneven, lackadaisical and sometime even sleepy.  The thematic core of jazz has a song that is actually more of a classical nocturne.  For me this movie works 1000 times better than "Hail Caesar!" from earlier in 2016, but it doesn't bowl me over. At the center of it is the question of whether I care about the relationship between Gosling and Stone's characters. The answer is somewhat, but this is not a relationship that had me completely invested in its success or failure.  Oh, the last 6 minutes are brilliant.
it was great collaboration of old school movie magic with the new school. I smiled through the whole film because the talent   in this film is something to behold. I loved it!

Wow....what a rollercoaster of a film.....where do I begin? Okay, the movie uses classic musicals (Singin' in the Rain, An American in Paris, etc.) as its blueprint; those films are this movie's heart. However, while showing love, admiration, respect, and drawing substantial inspiration from those classics, this movie throws in some modern twists based more in reality as if to say, "Yeah, those classics and what not -- they're great, but real life isn't a fantasy like that," and this film plays on this dichotomy through one of the most basic plot lines ever: a romance, but not a straightforward, simple, fairy-tale romance. This is a romance based in reality (REAL is the key word here, in case I haven't made that clear), but wait! This is a musical! Characters randomly start singing and dancing out of nowhere! That's not reality, right? Ah Ha! This is the film's genius -- it depicts reality through a window of fantasy. It balances the two and bounces back and forth between them which is new territory for a musical as far as I know. It draws from the fantasy, simple, straightforward joy of the classics while adding a modern twist that also keeps the film grounded in the real world. Also, the plot and emotions here are not simple and straightforward at all; it bounces all over the place (as things do in reality). There are happy moments, sad moments, laughing moments, crying moments, silly moments, heartwarming moments, eyebrow-raising moments, quirky idiosyncrasies, all kinds of old movie stuff to point out in backgrounds -- this movie does not stop. It is easily one of the best -- probably the flat-out best -- musicals of this millennium thus far. It is a charming, brilliant blending of the old and the new while firmly embracing both. It is a treat any movie and/or musical lover will savor for years to come, so take your friends, your families, significant others.....hell, go by yourself if necessary. Treat yourself. You deserve it.
A must see for anyone that loves a good love story which also includes dancing and music...great chemistry between Ryan and Emma.....

So... 

Let's just get something out of the way first. I'm not a big fan of the movie musical. Every few years someone in Hollywood tries to resurrect the genre in hopes it cashes in on the nostalgia. This time it's La La Land's turn. 

For reasons unexplained I enjoyed the film. Maybe it's because it wasn't wall to wall musical numbers? Maybe I was in a good mood? Maybe the director knew what he was doing? (The same guy who did Whiplash...which I still highly recommend) Maybe I've gone soft? It's a new year after all.

The movie wasn't perfect either. It's another "Hollywood romanticizing Hollywood" flick. Ryan Gosling is completely miscast....unless they were looking for the trifecta of a bad singer, dancer and actor. Also, the movie loses a bit of traction towards the middle act. 

But here I am...recommending this film.

Dear god this was a great Christmas gift to myself.
Chazelle certainly shows us how movies are meant to be made. The story of these two individuals aspiring to make it big in LA is certainly a common theme yet the film does such a great job in keeping hold of such a theme as "follow your dreams" that the love story, while playing a hefty part of the film, actually serves to project the theme tenfold with a heartbreaking and beautifully shot epilogue.

It should come as no surprise that i absolutely adore Emma Stone, as she has proven to be a terrific actress with such an array of character. Ryan Gosling has also proven time and again that he is much more than a pretty face and even in the midst of a love story he can display a hilarious and heartfelt performance.

Having said this, where the film lacks is quite odd, as the film is pegged as a "musical", audiences will be surprised to find out that the musical elements in this film are fairly slim. With beautiful upbeat numbers within the first 30 min of the film, it soon transitions into that of a love story between these two great actors, with some numbers sprinkled about, until the ending 30 min where Stone's emotional solo as well as a tear jerking epilogue rekindle the musical aspect. Secondly, knowing Stone has a musical background and expecting Gosling to pull out a voice relative to his other many talents, both seemed to have unusual and sometimes offputting voices. Stones being very high pitched and sighy, while Gosling having difficulty hitting clear low notes as well as high.
Despite all this, the film's story and development is so fluid and well written that I could easily look past these faults. It would be very difficult not to enjoy this film, as the characters are quite likable and their chemistry is amazing considering the past films Stone and Gosling have been together. And th CAMERA WORK!!! my god the camera work was so great. It is truly how a film should be shot, not only did the technicolor-esque feel and style make it a visually stunning experience. But when you realize how little the camera cuts and how it seems to be following characters as they move, whether behind a wall or around a corner, its this commitment to rolling that gives way for more authentic and unique performances. Even the musical numbers seem nearly all one take and its such a masterful use of the camera that i cannot sit here without stating how such a subtle commitment is just one of many reasons to love this film!

The film tells the story of two people: Sebastian Wilder and Mia Dolan. Mia is a struggling actress trying to get picked up, while Sebastian is a traditional jazz pianist trying to start up his own club. After a few encounters, the duo hit it off and try to help each other achieve what they want most.

            When I first saw the trailers for this film, I thought it looked good, but I didn't think I was going to impress me that much. But as further trailers popped up, that's when I got the indication that this was a Hollywood musical. Not a film based on a Broadway musical, nor was it a jukebox musical, or an animated film with songs in it. A fresh new Hollywood movie with songs written specifically for the silver screen. I got a friend of mine to join me for New Year's Eve, and I sat down thinking, "Come on, Damien Chazelle. Show me what you're really capable of."

Literally from the first opening number, I was hooked. The songs, composed and orchestrated by Justin Hurwitz and written by Pasek and Paul, were absolutely hypnotic. They had me wrapped in this familiar spell that I was caught it when I first saw films like "An American in Paris," "Holiday Inn," and "Singing in the Rain." Matched up with the choreography, the editing, and the cinematography, and you have easily a film that will go down in history with films. With how nostalgic it felt listening to tunes like "Someone in the Crowd" and "A Lovely Night," it made me happy to a point where I felt myself close to crying. That shows you how damn good a film can be.

I also love watching the story between Mia and Sebastian unfold. Of course, they don't like each other at first, especially when their first few encounters leave Sebastian in a relatively bad mood. But as they get to know each other better, you see these two get used to the things that one loves yet the other hates, and help each other find that spark that they need to really bring themselves to that goal, whether for the better or worse. Originally, the duo was planned to be Miles Teller and Emma Watson, but I feel like Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone were a better fit. With this being the third film that they've collaborated on as a couple, the other two being "Crazy Stupid Love" and "Gangster Squad," they really have left a place in cinema history as the modern day Hollywood couple, in the same vein as Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers.

A true major selling point that I loved about the movie was how it takes risky moves with the clichéd love story musical, especially with its ending. Despite it being a bit down, I came out completely satisfied with it. It gave me this feeling a reassurance that I hadn't felt all year, and I was extremely happy. I think that's something a film should be applauded for, is leaving you with that true moment of satisfaction that sticks even after leaving.

If you have yet to see "La La Land," what are you doing reading this for then? Go out and see this damn movie right now! It's getting major buzz at the Oscars for Best Picture, and they're right to declare that. From its acting, to its story, its choreography, and fantastic music, it's a film that deserves to be applauded for its love letter to the Old Hollywood musicals of yesterday.

This movie is very good, perhaps even excellent, but it's imperfect. It tries very hard, though, and the director's hand can be seen with how obsessed he is with closeups, profiles, dazzling use of colors, and winks and nods intended to convey meaning.

Be warned though, it is not correctly advertised. Commercials will have you believe you're going to watch West Side Story. You're not. The beginning and end are a musical, but the middle is...musical. Big difference.

The story is thoroughly charming, and the leads are as well, and together they have an obvious, explosive chemistry. 

The script portrays a real world, but it also veers close to cornball at times, and also both avoids and embraces several movie cliches.

Overall, it's enjoyable, but I have three quibbles: 1) What is a genius like J.K. Simmons doing in a throwaway role? 2) I'm supposed to believe an actress with luminous, expressive eyes - and overall mien - like that is actually struggling to find work where she's expected to be luminous and expressive? 3) The media is losing it's mind over this, in an ingenuine way in which they lose their mind over any film that has Hollywood revering itself (The Artist, Hail Caesar!, et al).

Still: heartbreaking, bittersweet, and fun, though it leaves you scratching your head a little bit, especially with that Jacob's Ladder-esque ending (spoiler?)

December 16, 2016

The key to a good musical is striking a balance between the ostentatious fantasy and the grounded substance (and hopefully there is grounded substance). Hollywood's "institutional" musicals, like "The Wizard of Oz," "Singin' in the Rain" and "My Fair Lady," are beloved not because of their song and dance numbers (although these certainly play a role in their appeal) but because they're actually about something when you take these elements away. Their longevity and indelibility derive from the films' strong messages and subtext, while the musical sequences provide the bells and whistles-they make the movies more fun and entertaining. 

Perhaps finding such a harmony between depth and spectacle is hard to do and explains why musicals are so rare these days compared to when they dominated Hollywood's Golden Age and remained prolific up through the 1960s. But "La La Land" made me believe there could be a resurgence because its quality and craftsmanship deserves comparison to the titles I mentioned above, which is saying a lot. At its heart is a bittersweet love story that feels real and pure and it's this element that writer-director Damien Chazelle keeps coming back to in order to make "La La Land" work as a thoughtful drama, while the music, lyrics and dance sequences give it an extra kick.

Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling star as Mia and Sebastian, the film's predestined couple who at first deplore each other but soon realize they may be soul mates. Mia is an aspiring actress who works at a studio cafe and lives with three roommates, who are also would-be actresses. Sebastian is a jazz pianist who'd rather promote classic jazz artists by opening up his own club than rehash the same old jingles in a mediocre restaurant where the owner doesn't allow him to be inventive. When Sebastian decides to put a spin on things, his tune catches the ears of Mia, who happens to be walking by. She goes in to compliment him, but he completely blows her off after his boss (J.K. Simmons) fires him. 

This isn't Mia and Sebastian's first encounter-they initially crossed paths during a brief stint of road rage on a busy Los Angeles freeway, which follows the film's opening song and dance number, "Another Day of Sun," during which the motorists mitigate the stresses of gridlock by singing and swinging their bodies. Everyone takes part except Mia and Sebastian, who are too concentrated on the next moves of their careers. They meet for a third time at a mutual friend's party, and soon thereafter the wheels of romance and destiny are set in motion, as is Mia and Sebastian's willingness to breakout into their own song and dance sequences.

The movie is called "La La Land" for obvious reasons. Not only do Mia and Sebastian live in Los Angeles but they literally detach themselves from reality as they look into each other's eyes, fly through the air, and sing to one another and themselves, making the entire cityscape and the Hollywood Hills, particularly Griffith Park and its observatory, their own personal, moonlit stage. 

The film is wonderfully romantic, fun and captivating as it follows Mia and Sebastian's blossoming and eventually tumultuous relationship through the four seasons of a year, but perhaps what's most enduring and surprising about it is how genuine their respective experiences in the film and music industries come across. This must stem from the fact that Chazelle himself is a young artist and it's clear his screenplay draws from his own personal experiences when it comes to the pain, frustration and financial hardships Mia and Sebastian must weather in order to achieve their hopes and dreams in show business. Their hurdles never seem exaggerated, right down to Mia's auditions and her attempting to put on a one-woman show, as well as Sebastian trying to convince himself that touring with a jazz band led by his former cohort (John Legend) is something he actually wants. We sense each character's anguish, both as career people and as one half of a couple struggling to find common ground. That brings up another surprise about "La La Land": the outcome of Mia's, Sebastian's, and then Mia & Sebastian's, stories are never certain. How things wrap up-happy, sad or open-ended-I leave for you to discover.

And discover you should, because "La La Land" is alive and magical, deep and true. It's exceptionally produced and enormously entertaining, with not one scene where the energy isn't busting. If I had to criticize it, I'd mention that Emma Stone is probably better suited for the fantasy and Gosling the drama but that neither actor is one hundred percent right for both. Stone seems confined to the make-believe cloud upon which Mia floats, while Gosling doesn't seem like he's ever able rise to it with the same enthusiasm and conviction. His singing and dancing, in particular, feel unnatural. I suppose one could argue this works in the film's favor and mirrors the characters respective natures, thus balancing things out, but when Stone tried to be dramatic or Gosling tried to perform, I was too aware of what they were doing and I ended up seeing the actors on-screen instead of their characters, which proved somewhat distracting. There's little doubt both leads will get an Oscar nomination, but to say they should win is a bit of a stretch.

Nevertheless, "La La Land" reminded me why musicals used to thrive. When they're done right, as this one is, they can be entertaining on so many levels: from their drama, comedy, and romance, to their music, songs and dancing. Of course, by taking on so much, they also run the risk of becoming overwrought and turning into an unfulfilling mess ("Hello, Dolly!"),  but "La La Land" practices moderation and finds balance. It focus first on its essential human story, which is about our inherent desire to feel special among our peers and to the person we love, and then on its music, dancing and technical presentation. The former makes it great; the latter make it greater.

A film that is inspiring, has beautiful scenery, and has characters that are passionate about their craft.  

This film shows us that all we need is for us to believe in our dreams and for someone to push us towards our dreams.

Now, about that ending. At some point you see that ending coming. Actually, I was on board with both the type of endings: happily ever after or the more realistic one. I liked how they went with the more realistic one.

The message is beautiful. Follow your dreams, no matter what. Leave behind people and money if you have to. It also understands that sacrifices have to be made along the way. Like they had to sacrifice each other.

Watch it. You'll enjoy, find inspiration and hear some good music.

Musicals are a rare breed in cinemaland these days. Once every so often a big budget effort (Chicago, Les Mis, Into the Woods) comes along to remind us they do still exist, but even these films don't do much to entice newcomers to the genre. Now I don't know if La La Land will succeed where others have failed and prove to be the birth of a musical reconnaissance, but if any movie can achieve it, this is definitely the one. Vibrant, funny and superbly shot, this tongue-in-cheek throwback to the upbeat musicals of Gene Kelly and Fred Astaire is a toe-tapping delight from the ambitious highway-set opening number all the way to the closing what-could-have-been sequence. Following up after the phenomenal Whiplash, writer-director Damien Chazelle has definitively announced his arrival into Hollywood; the combination of flair and technical mastery in which he executes each diverse set piece is astounding. The song and dance numbers continually build on the story - a struggling actress and a budding Jazz pianist juggle life, love and their lofty dreams - whilst always bringing something fresh both visually and musically, whether it's an 80s parody dance sequence or a soulful jazz interlude. Director of photography Linus Sandgren must be given his due praise too; the camerawork is both enterprising and stylish, the frequent unbroken tracking shots adding another level of pizzazz to the proceedings. Yet for all of the wonder and awe brought by Chazelle and his crew, the film still requires a headlining duo capable of providing an emotional core that can match the song and dance fireworks. Step up Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling. In their third movie opposite each other (after Crazy, Stupid, Love and Gangster Squad) the ridiculously talented acting pair not only boast a sizzling chemistry on screen, but also get to show off their dancing and singing skills that, much to the normal person's ire, are obviously brilliant. More accessible to the average moviegoer than many previous modern musicals, La La Land is a triumphant convergence of music, dance and awe-inspiring cinema.

Amazing numbers, beautiful cinematography, and incredible performances from Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone make for a movie that you'll want to watch over and over again in La La Land. Set in Los Angeles, this story follows two artists busy perusing their dreams with the romance that has sparked between them following a series of run-ins. Director Damien Chazelle hits gold again and brings forth a musical that holds well for today's standard yet still has nostalgia and retro feelings mixed throughout , making La La Land a must see film by all means.

The story is dead simple but the magnificent direction (use of lights, shade and zoom), along with the costumes, scenery, choreographies and soundtrack, result in a gorgeous movie that immerses the viewer from the get-go. Emma Stone gives one of her best performances ever and the cherry on top: a deliciously authentic realism in the dialogues and character reactions. An exquisite musical and an overall palpable, pulsating, adorable film that relies not so much on contrivance as on personality.

I LOVE jazz, love stores and Hollywood musical movies so why is my reaction to "La La Land", which right now seems to be the one to beat for the Best Movie Oscar and Golden Globe, so blah? Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone have chemistry as the lovers from the boy meets girl, boy loves girl, boy loses girl in the acting department but are sorely lacking in the singing and dancing department though Gosling acquits himself in piano playing.

Everything you read, including comments by the director and screenwriter Damien Chazelle, has remarks about it being a salute to old Hollywood movies and to Gene Kelly, Fred Astaire, Cyd Charisse, Judy Garland but,with no disrespect, unless this was a take-off of all mentioned, and even if Charisse's voice was dubbed, "La La Land" fails miserably. 

I have seen some talk about it saluting Jacques Demy and Michel Legrand's movies "The Umbrellas of Cherbourg" and "The young Girls of Rochefort" which it does in some departments such as the production design by David Wasco and the costume designs by Mary Zophres. 

Regarding the choreography by Mandy Moore the opening is really a winner but in other scenes she is let down by Stone and Gosling who just don't have it when it comes to doing the steps she has for them. There is one scene where they are dancing in the stars, at the Griffith Observatory planetarium after watching the James Dean movie "Rebel Without a Cause", that is more special effects than dancing.

The music by Justin Hurwitz with lyrics by Benj Pasek and Justin Paul sort of get lost except for the jazz music which comes across strong, melodic. The love theme lyrics are still somewhat a mystery to me though it is sung and played a few times.

The climax lasting about twenty minutes, a recap of what has taken place for the first 100 minutes, jell everything together but, for me, it was too late.I think I would have been much happier and appreciated the movie, Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone just seeing that section.

J.K. Simmons, who was in Chazells's "Whiplash" and won an Oscar for his role does a brief cameo here while John Legend does an extended one, neither adding or taking away from the movie.

The bottom line is that "La La Land", for me, was not worth the time though I am sure I am in a very small minority. It might have helped if I hadn't seen the Broadway version of "An American In Paris" in Miami this past Tuesday where the leads were amazing dancers and strong singers.

P.S. When will the fad of young actors wearing that 5 o'clock shadow stubble on their faces end? ARGH!!

I adore this film.  It manages to be both a homage to Technicolor studio musicals of the 1950's (with the occasional touch of Jacques Demy) and a very modern take on the genre.  One of the biggest failings of modern film musicals is that most seem completely cut off from the history and tropes of the genre.  This most certainly does not.  Gosling is fine ... he's well-cast as this character, but he doesn't seem very natural when dancing or singing.  Stone is magnificent.  She's absolutely radiant in this film and the film loves her.  There are small problems with it ... it drags a bit near the middle and fails to resolve a few plot threads ... but it's an absolute joy.

What is worth more? Where does ambition measure when compared to reflection? Or...how does one know when to quit? When that ambition outweighs or cannot be met by the pure skill or natural talent possessed? La La Land is a movie about Hollywood and the Hollywood system and how it all flows in and out of making and breaking stars, but La La Land is also a movie about dreams and the ugly side of those dreams no one likes to talk about when they tell you to chase them-compromise. Compromise is what must be obtained if one is hoping to have their cake and eat it too. There is compromise in life no matter what professional or personal route one may choose to take, but when dreams are big enough to take you around the world and on extended stays in places away from home that require long or odd hours such as, say, when someone is a musician or film actor-compromises are unavoidable and typically made by the half of the relationship not actively participating in such a career. With La La Land director Damien Chazelle (Whiplash) follows up his Academy Award-nominated feature debut with an out and out musical in the vein of those golden age Hollywood musicals from the forties and early fifties that personified stardom, celebrity, and a certain type of lifestyle most could only hope to obtain. This goes well with the plight of the story as we follow two young aspiring artists-the girl an actress and the guy a jazz pianist-as they navigate modern Los Angeles in hopes of achieving their dreams even if the odds seem stacked against them and despite their closest friends and family not exactly holding out hope for success to find them. The standard structure of boy meets girl combined with that of a few song and dance numbers that pay homage to those aforementioned golden days of Hollywood aren't enough for Chazelle though. The writer/director isn't simply looking to recreate images and feelings afforded him during his youth as he watched Gene Kelly dance across the screen, but more he is interested in exploring the consequences of having such aspirations; the dark side of fame that doesn't necessarily have anything to do with addiction or other harmful habit forming activities, but more with the decisions such individuals have to make without knowing the answer as to what they'll regret more twenty years down the road. Can I be the person I want with the person I want? Is it worth more to make a life as I so desire or with the one I desire? La La Land doesn't prescribe to know the answers to these heavy questions, but its musings on the subject are infectious and reaffirming in that they capture the struggle one in a handful experiencing the film will have come face to face with at some point in their past.

It is a very me generation film, which does and does not work for Chazelle's second film. We saw an aspiring drummer give up on love to pursue his dream. Now we saw an aspiring actress give up on love to follow her dream. The difference is that the character being given up on in this film has a more of a fleshed out role. The message is the same in Chazelle films: follow your dreams at all costs because love can wait. La La Land is a stronger piece of film than Whiplash, but I would argue that Whiplash is more original. As a filmmaker, Chazelle has successfully made a revamped version of his first film; however, he is embarking into familiar territory. He needs to examine more important social issues and conclude with a message that's relevant to more than just a college audience.

I am not a big fan of musicals, most of our own Bollywood movies being a quintessential heap of songs with some stories thrown into them. And musicals, as a genre, is on a retreat in Hollywood; as the saying goes, "they don't make movies like this anymore." Frankly, I didn't think I would be watching La La Land when the trailers landed. But the Golden Globes wins inevitably caught my eyes, I decided to give it a go and boy it was an absolute delight! I am a photography enthusiast, and the cinematography here was top notch, to say at least. The story flowed, without many complications or hiccups, banking on the ensemble cast and looking gorgeous as usual. But beyond the charming visuals and a smooth storyline, it was the music that held the whole enterprise together. The original soundtrack feels full of life and grace, sprinkled with peppiness and a hint of melancholy. I seriously can't just leave them be and still listening to them every other day. The epilogue was perhaps the masterstroke, starting with an emotional could-have-been filled with joy that was struck by reality and slowly faded away to silence. Highly recommended, especially for people who claim to hate musicals.

However, on reflection, it's very catchy and actually quite fun, romantic, and pleasing. It is one of those movies that you really didn't want to like and succumb to it's cheesy musical numbers, but you inevitable fall into the trap - singing the songs a week later and reminiscing on Gosling's charm and Stone's cute awkwardness. My rating went from 3 stars to 4

It came (FINALLY!  Have been waiting for it to be released since TIFF in September).
I saw.

Did I love LOVE LOVVVE it like I thought I would?  No.  But it was cute and quirky with psychedelic cinematography, stunning set designs and a couple spectacular en masse musical dance numbers.
A colleague shared with me a review he read which stated you will be hooked within the first 3 minutes (kinda paralleling the 'grab your attention' hook tactic utilized in Gravity with it's first 10 minutes).  And honesty, the first 3 minutes are arguably some of the best minutes - along with the biggest pop-up-book scene in La La Land - exploding into a huge, captivating dance number involving at least a hundred amateur signing dancers on a gridlocked ramp exiting off the Los Angeles' freeway.  (See the attached link to a breakdown of the opening scene http://ew.com/movies/2016/12/21/la-la-land-freeway-musical-number-damien-chazelle/).
Consider me hooked.  I loved LOVED LOVVVVED the 4th wall breaking, stunningly choreographed (by Mandy Moore from So You Think You Can Dance acclaim), energetically composed original song dance number.  So bows and applause to you - 31 year old (WHA??) director Damien Chazelle and your crew for the massive undertaking it was that literally mesmerized my dancing shoes off.
There are a few other sensational, imaginative (with subtle homage winks to classic musical movies) razzle-dazzle numbers:  the jump-into-the- pool party number; Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone's first semi-Singing-In-The-Rain / I-Love-Melvin re-imagined dance  number. 
La La Land integrates throwbacks, tributes and adoration to so many things (such as the jazz music genre; 1920's thru 60's Hollywood movies; classic musicals; great actors and actresses; vintage posters and cinema memorabilia) that I stopped counting as I became too engulfed in the intrigue and intimacy of EVERYTHING that La La Land is.
And there is a lot.  Including  the modernizing-yet-old-school film making influences and approaches  undertaken by Chazelle (who wrote and directed the darkly brilliant Whiplash - his Oscar winning, first-time directed film).  Including the absolutely eye-popping technicolourful set designs, costuming ,and make up (though Ryan Gosling did spend most of the movie looking greasy and grimy and ... dirty).  Including a gripping performance from a fellow ginger I love - Emma Stone - whose oscillating emotional range in the film reminded me of an ECG monitor of a patient on speed.  Including the re-teaming of Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone from Crazy, Stupid Love (which I loved, no punning) who have so much onscreen chemistry that it could spark forest fires in Alaska.
However, La La Land - in my own humble viewing observation - wasn't perfect.  I know I shouldn't expect perfection - obviously.  But with Whiplash being a critical favourite; with Ryan and Emma coming together again to sing and dance and kiss and be cute; with an opening number that would top any Oscar opener EVER; high hopes for La La Land were inevitable.
Even though Ryan Gosling learned how to play the piano in thirty days, his singing chops are ... underwhelming (aka weak) at best.  Emma Stone's notes were a little more fuller, but still not ear popping.  Which I understand may have been on purpose due to: (a) Chazelle wanting a nuanced, "real life people" singing-in-their-showers sounding actors; and (b) hiring true singer actors would have turned the flick into Chicago, Les Miserable or Momma Mia rather than Moulin Rouge.   Casting non-signer actors though works both ways here: both good and bad.  Good because we cinema goers who cannot sing well (or *finger pointing at me* at all)  can relate to Ryan and Emma, and be absorbed into the film for - as much as we want to burst out into Grammy award winning signing - we don't have the vocal chops to do so.  On the negative flip side, since La La Land is technically mostly a musical, when both are signing it lowers the total enchantment level and impact of the scene/movie.
Plus, I don't know if it was the theater we were in, or the quality of the sound production, or the quality of the movie itself, but the sound editing dub-ins of the signing and the piano playing was obvious, and, at times, not in-sync to the mouth and finger movement of what we saw on screen.
La La Land is definitely a standout for Emma Stone's (as was 2014's Birdman).  Ryan Gosling's performance was - even with mastering the piano - more one or two note.  Which is  sad, because I love him and he can be outstanding (in the aforementioned Crazy, Stupid, Love; The Big Short; Drive; Half Nelson; Lars and The Real Girl; and my fave Blue Valentine).
After the blockbuster opening sequence (still can't stop praising it), the energy and exciting electricity wains; tempering and toning down into a clichéd relationshippy love story between Ryan's Sebastian and Emma's Mia.  Which is completely fine and understandable with me.  But ...  as the movie progresses, you can feel La La Land's mood and perkiness deflating; which results in the film feeling drawn out, long-in-the-tooth and lackadaisical in comparison to the prior high(er) octane musical stunners.
Also, I feel that Chazelle's directorial youth and greenness peeks through at times (this is only his 2nd directed and 4th major written film), with jarring, quick-cut direction/editing that harks back his style in Whiplash but feels out of place here.  The celestial fantasy dance number in the observatory is cute and whimsical -  a nod to another movie that I can't place -  but I don't feel it has the successful effect I know both Chazelle and I were hoping for (not too sure if it was the sub par special effects; the real life cable lifting logistics/handling; the range of moodiness it tried to cover; the obvious fact  dancing-doubles were used for Ryan and Emma).
Were the above quibs enough to make the film a disappointing letdown overall?  No, definitely not.  
Was it as mindblowing and memorable as what I was hoping it would be (especially with that AMAZING opening number)? Sadly, no.
Was it entertaining, cute, charming, adorable, flashy, vivid, musically toe-tapping, feel good movie of 2016?  HELLS to the YESes.  Hands down.  Also worth a second viewing.
Brilliant film in every aspect. Go see this!

Cinema's movie musical genre isn't exhausted yet. Boasting outstanding performances, beautiful score, and heartfelt drama, La La Land is cinema at its finest. Damien Chazelle invites you to a dreamy and alluring world of music and dance.
 
Damien Chazelle, breathes new life to a forgotten art making La La Land a modern homage to the musical genre. Though La La Land may be reduced compared to classic Hollywood musicals or Broadway, its style still suits its love story. Accompanied by excellent choreography and infectious music, the result is memorable.

Starring Ryan Gosling, a 'serious' jazz pianist who has to settle to make ends meet, and Emma Stone as Mia, an aspiring actress barista. Gosling and Stone are effortless together, their chemistry, as we've seen from 'Crazy, Stupid, Love,' allows their on-screen relationship to appear exciting and genuine. 

Earnest performances, you witness subtlety and intensity when you see Gosling in the piano, and Stone in her lyrics. Mia and Sebastian's journey to achieve their dreams of becoming acknowledged artists makes you root for them, and you anticipate the musical sequences in transition as they lament with grief or erupt with delight. 

The expressive style suits this love story well. The esthetic of recreating classic Hollywood tropes and projecting dreamy sequences are at the right place, they have a charming impression as they bring you into a territory unshared to anyone in the world but these lovers.

I was told it was 'pure cinema magic,' and after leaving the theatre, I'm inclined to believe that.

"They don't make em like this anymore" is the thing most people will say when they leave the theater as the credits roll on La La Land, and they're right. La La Land is a 1950's movie musical, made in 2016. It's an absolutely romantic experience in ever sense of the word. Romantic in it's visual scope, blazing off of the silver screen in Technicolor. Romantic in it's gushing, devastating appreciation for the art of Jazz. Romantic in the on-screen chemistry between Gosling and Stone, who make a sizzling hot couple for our times. I got a Seldon/Lockwood vibe, for sure. We've all heard the hype this film has been getting, and it's for a pretty good reason... "They don't make em like this anymore". Damn right, they don't. La La Land resurrects an era of filmmaking that many have thought to be long dead. It's reinvigorated a filmgoing spirit that once dominated the entire industry, and by any luck, might just dominate it once again. You can thank Damien Chazelle, who in one decade, cemented his name into film legend, and may almost certainly walk home with a shining Oscar this year.

So with all of this in perspective, did the film blow me away. Sadly, I have to report, that it just didn't give me that perfect experience that I wanted. It's a great film, without question, but the problem is.. I've seen this musical. Singing in the Rain is my favorite musical of all-time. I've had that lighter than air, skip in my step, heart singing feeling before, and it's a once-in-a-lifetime kind of thing. Many people, especially millennials will be feeling this for the first time with La La Land, and that is something that I deeply respect. It's remarkable that films can still do this to people, in our jaded, desensitized, and often cruel world. Perhaps this is what people needed after enduring the unusually dark and divisive year that was 2016. A film like this needed to come along and lift our spirits up, and that's precisely what La La Land does.

It's a feel-good romp, and we get this right as the film opens, with an absolutely swinging musical number on top of a disgustingly busy LA highway. I loved, loved, loved the music. It's absolutely the film's strength above all else. I'd give it two years time before La La Land ends up becoming a hit Broadway musical that gives Hamilton a run for it's money. Oh yes, it's that good.

Once Hollywood's top-earning releases, movie musicals have had a much spottier track record lo' these past few decades, and the few that have connected with audiences of late (think 'Chicago' and 'Les Misérables') were all adapted from popular Broadway productions. As such, a wholly original musical written specifically for the big screen is a rare beast indeed, and damned if writer/director Damien Chazelle (fresh off 2014's triumphant 'Whiplash') doesn't knock his passion project out of the park. Much of the credit belongs to the undeniable chemistry of Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, paired for a third time after 'Crazy, Stupid Love' and 'Gangster Squad'; as aspiring artists (she a budding actress, he an uncompromising jazz pianist) scrambling for their first big breaks in Hollywood, this winning twosome are utterly charming, gamely embracing every element - the singing, the dancing, the quippy repartée - thrown at them. Gosling in particular is a revelation here: far removed from the blank stares that used to pass as performances in past roles, his recent comedic work has clearly helped him evolve into a more nuanced actor, resulting in his dazzling work in 'La La Land'. Refreshingly free of irony, Chazelle's confident script strikes the right balance between music and drama, never allowing the breathlessly-staged musical numbers to overwhelm what is, at its core, an unabashedly romantic tale of young love in the City of Dreams. Believe the hype: 'La La Land' is one of the brightest movie gems of 2016, a glorious throwback to Hollywood's Golden Age that feels remarkably fresh today.
Saw Rogue One yesterday and La La Land today -- ironic tributes to Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds respectively.

I get it - he was trying to play homage to the golden time of Hollywood and grand theaters, but he failed. You want people to value movies and appreciate the theater, then make a good movies.

With 2014's WHIPLASH, writer/director Damien Chazelle announced himself as a gifted filmmaker on the rise.  With LA LA LAND, he firmly establishes himself as one of the strongest young artists working in cinema, one with a authorial voice and a command of technique.  LA LA LAND is a wonderful, gloriously old-fashioned experience, and it fires on all cylinders with nary a false step taken anywhere along the way.

It's a relatively simple tale: Mia (Emma Stone) is a struggling actress looking for her big break in Hollywood.  Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) is a frustrated jazz pianist fighting to keep classic jazz relevant.  Mia and Sebastian's paths cross a few times, and before they know it, they're romantically linked; we follow their separate and shared struggles as they seek out their dreams, accompanied by wonderful musical numbers that jump right off the screen. 

There's no way I could possibly hide this, so I had better get it out right here:  LA LA LAND is a movie that affected me in a deep, emotional way.  Setting aside the craft of the filmmaking (which I'll eventually get to), this wistful story about pursuing dreams is potent and moving, and its longing, almost bittersweet edge should resonate with anybody struggling to figure out what they're doing with their lives, or questioning if they've made the right decisions with respect to going after what their hearts really want.  As one of the lyrics of the movie's most powerful song says, "Here's to the ones who dream," and the entire film itself feels like an ode to perseverance and the classically romantic ideals of being true to oneself in the face of adversity.  It's an enormously optimistic movie (though tinged with some melancholy), and one that feels almost as if writer/director Damien Chazelle is speaking individually to members of the audience and saying, "Keep going after the things you want to achieve.  It's worth trying." 

Though there are a handful of supporting characters, the movie lives and dies on the shoulders of its two protagonists.  Luckily, Gosling and Stone are more than up to that task.  Gosling brings a wonderfully understated (almost dry) sense of humor to his role, coupled with a genuine passion for jazz which motivates him at every tun.  He also appears to do his own piano playing, which - considering the intricate nature of the music - is no small achievement.  It is Stone, though, who is the true revelation of the movie; her performance here is the best of her career thus far, a luminous, vibrant turn powered by equal parts determination to succeed and insecurity over her real worth as an aspiring actress.  Stone's been on the edge of the so-called "A List" for a while, now, but her work here should surely push her over the top.  It's perhaps my favorite performance of the year. 

I've seen some describe the movie as a "love letter" to Los Angeles, but I'm not sure I really agree with that.  The film is quite clear-eyed about the complexities and downsides that the city has to offer those who go there to pursue their creative endeavors.  Though the city itself is photographed in an evocative, sometimes dreamlike way, this actually serves to underline the more honest realities the narrative presents about its locale.  Chazelle's story, fundamentally, is not a fantasy, even as it includes fantastical elements.

What the film very definitely displays is director Chazelle's range as a filmmaker.  The bluster and ferocious intensity of his previous film, WHIPLASH, are replaced here by sensitivity and exuberance, but the energy is pitched at just as high a level as it was in WHIPLASH.  This is a movie riding high on the love of cinema and music, and on the power of those two art forms when fused together.  It's unabashedly, unashamedly old-fashioned in the way it approaches its musical elements; this is a movie that is in-your-face with its big song and dance numbers.  LA LA LAND is no reinvention of the genre, no meta commentary.  It very much takes its cue from classic musicals and transplants that ethos into 2016.  The result is a spectacular entertainment of the sort we don't really get much anymore.  The songs, courtesy of composer Justin Hurwitz and lyricists Benj Pasek & Justin Paul, are often infused with jazz sensibilities that wouldn't feel too out-of-place in one of the brighter musicals of yesteryear, and the dance sequences are totally old-school in choreography, but are captured through Chazelle's dynamic (and impeccable) camerawork.  Some of the numbers appear to unfold in long, unbroken shots, something that often has a dazzling effect when you realize how long shots have played out without cuts.  

Acting as both a glorious homage to classic cinema and an incredibly vital, energetic modern work, LA LA LAND is simply a powerhouse.  It didn't give me exactly what I wanted or expected... it gave me more, and it's one of the very best films of 2016.  I can't wait to see it again.

A nostalgic tribute to old Hollywood musicals, "La La Land" is a breathtaking film that leaves you overcome with joy. Director Damien Chazelle has made a huge step forward as a filmmaker by making a modern-day musical. Each song and dance number is staged with an eye for detail, pulling you into the story. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, who perform these numbers, are absolutely stunning to watch. Not only do they have beautiful singing voices, but they have charming chemistry together which makes you believe they are a couple. Despite it's overlong running time, "La La Land" offers an unforgettable cinematic experience that is unlike anything I've seen this year. Even if you're not a fan of musicals, you will be truly glad that you saw this one.

Any film lover afraid of losing musicals forever need not worry any longer. It's not your typical musical, but for a musical to be successful in the 21st century it has to adapt. Damien Chazelle is already a master of the game after 2014's "Whiplash" and now this. He interweaves your song and dance numbers you'd expect from the genre, with a dramatic story about love and life in Hollywood. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone's chemistry is off the charts, probably due to this being their third film together. The huge amount of hype this movie had, made it likely to disappoint. Luckily it did not.

It begins with a traffic jam, a sticky ribbon of car horns and radios on a Los Angeles freeway. As the cacophony of daily Southern California frustration picks up, edging to a boil, a tanned beauty in a sunshine dress pops out the car door and bursts into song. The score, Justin Hurwitz's "Another Day of Sun," is of love sacrificed for dreams of fame and fortune; it foreshadows the tale to come. Before we know it, a serious song-and-dance number is happening amid commuters leaping atop a sea of standstill cars in one of the best movie-musical performances of the decade. 

Introducing us to the strivers packed into contemporary Los Angeles, each of these seekers drives through the traffic alone, hoping, desperately, that their ten-second performance just might catch the eye of someone who can make them a star. Up for grabs are roles in Damien Chazelle's La La Land, LA's antiquated nickname from a by-gone era of impromptu dance and straightforward romance, and each would-be performer seems to outdo the last. Of course, we never see any of these talented commuters again, but, among them, we do find our leads - a Prius-driving Emma Stone as struggling actress Mia and Ryan Gosling as the frustrated piano-playing traditionalist Sebastian. They flip each other off on the freeway as Sebastian swerves past Mia, and so begins the combative romance that follows.

As fate would have it, Mia is lead to Sebastian's piano again and again as the purist prodigy plays gigs featuring Christmas tunes and 80s covers. The relentless clichés that formulate the exasperated artist's creative hell of making ends meet keep him focused on pursuing his life-long dream of opening up a jazz club. That is, until he meets Mia. The small-town girl who put it all on the line to pursue her dream of playwriting and acting, Mia is trapped as a barista in the Warner Brother's studio lot, running from audition to abysmal audition, just praying for a call-back. Unlike Seb, Mia has lost sight of her childish dreams and would now take any role offered to her, from vampire sitcoms to OC knockoffs.

It isn't until the two find each other that her passion is re-discovered, and the tension between careerist reality and purist dreaming is moved to the forefront. The chase-your-dream dogma is, as the title suggests, fantastical in nature but also antique in the way Chazelle unpacks it. Whether the old school jazz or the 50s pin-ups, nostalgia permeates every corner of La La Land, but, as Seb so eloquently clarifies - "Why do you say 'romantic' like it's a dirty word?" - it's not wilted as much as gutsy, offering insight that sometimes the old ways are the best ways, that we can change with the times without compromising who we are.        

If a musical is composed of singing, acting, and dancing, then Sebastian is the musician and Mia is the actress, while their budding relationship is the dance that unfolds. We see this in the places our protagonists gain strength - Sebastian, from his music and Mia from the mirror, but, most of all, we revel in the rhythm of the dance found in almost every pivotal moment of their relationship. It is not until Mia takes off her bright blue heels to put on a more comfortable pair of tap shoes, which, low-and-behold match with Sebastian's, that the two fall hopelessly in love with each other. From Griffith Observatory, where Mia flies over the moon, to an emotional tumble into the River Seine, the depth of their relationship is explored through dance that is, at first, combative, later, synchronic, and, ultimately, heart-wrenching. Unlike many recent movie-musicals, the song and dance of La La Land, although not necessarily remarkable, adds a layer of richness that places it squarely among the best films of the year. 

Relatable by reminding us of our half-forgotten dreams and repressed passions, Chazelle follows Whiplash with another homerun bound to appeal to a broader audience than the critics and Academy voters who championed Whiplash. And if not, Chazelle certainly doesn't care. A facetious exchange between the leads emphasizes this point - "It feels really nostalgic... Are people going to like it?" Mia asks Seb before her play opens. "Fuck 'em," Seb replies - her play, and Chazelle's movie, doesn't need permission. Ultimately, the only person who matters is the dreamer herself.

I will be honest - when hearing that the top Oscar contender of this year is a Musical and thus I would have to go to the theater to watch a movie with non-stop singing, I was not super psyched. But then there were two elements which made me reconsider and think that it may actually be more enjoyable than I think:

No.(1) Damian Chapelle - after Whiplash I am certain that this director is capable of basically making any movie great. No. (2) Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling - after Crazy Stupid Love, I would watch any movie with these two actors, their chemistry is beyond amazing and it is just a joy to watch them together on-screen.

And in fact, all my expectations were met and actually even exceeded. Quite frankly, the opening of the movie reinvigorated my fear of this film being too "musical" - there is a highway, there are cars and all of a sudden, people start singing and dancing just like in a musical. But then the movie gives the audience also a real story - of course it is somewhat of a clichee hollywood romance but entertaining nonetheless. And from start to finish, I wasn't bored once and that was mostly due to the fabulous performances by Gosling and Stone who carry the film and the audience. Again (as in my favorite rom com Crazy Stupid Love), there screen chemistry is so good that one wonders why they are not a couple in real life (probably then their screen chemistry would be more like Ben Affleck and Jennifer Lopez). In the package of your typical hollywood love story, the film actually packages an interesting story about the price one may have to pay to follow their dream. That in fact also made the movie stand out from almost every other Hollywood romance - it defies the meaning of what a happy ending may actually mean and/or entail.

The other elements of the film which I really enjoyed were the comedic set pieces mostly brought to you so charmfully by Ryan Gosling - as he is this naive dreamer in the early parts of the film who has to perform with bands or gigs he totally does not stand but does it for the money are so wonderfully awkward and can probably only be transported in such a way by Ryan Gosling. And well, there is music - lots of music - but not so much to be annoying. The musical elements were sprinkled into the movie in a really beautiful way; dancing, slow-dance, tap-dance and bad ass concert keyboard performances. My assumption is that all the singing was done by the actors and if so - my hats off to both Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling. In addition to solid acting performances, they delivered some solid musical and dancing performances on top. And believe me, it is catchy - two days have passed and I still catch myself whistling the melody.

So if you are somebody who is dreading the idea of watching a muscial but does like some good old rom com and enjoys Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling on-screen together - I can only recommend to watch this film. It will be worth your time.

Corky and endearing in the best possible way. Somehow Chazelle is able to make this tribute to old time Hollywood incredibly refreshing. While I would have been happy just watching Stone and Gosling dance and flirt for the entire 128 minutes, this movie packs a serious punch as well. The cinematography was insane throughout and really brings the whole movie together. Rarely has a film been so spellbinding, nostalgic and wondrously inspiriting than "La La Land," a melodic masterpiece destined for the stars. Written and directed by Damien Chazelle and composed by Justin Hurwitz, the duo delivers another knockout production of musical achievement. Whether you enjoy musicals or not, it's hard not to appreciate the gravitational pull of each magical number. Set against iconic landmarks of dreamy Los Angeles, the story of Sebastian and Mia unfolds in conducted succession. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are the defining embodiment of old Hollywood, perfectly paired and evocative of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. Where Gosling lacks in vocal strength, he makes up for in charm, while Stone is a bona-fide performer. Together they tackle the pitfalls of love, dreams and everything in between -  a cliched story of sorts if not for the score. Hurwitz's fusion of contemporary and jazz blends seamlessly with topnotch choreography and gorgeous cinematography. Whether it's the captivating melody of "Mia & Sebastian's Theme," the mellow duet of "City of Stars," or even the toe-tapping spectacle of "Someone In The Crowd," the film is not short of memorable tunes. Chazelle directs with effortless precision -  an admirable feat for someone so young. Following the success of "Whiplash" and now this second feature, it's suffice to say he has a promising road ahead. While most great films invoke thought and reflection, not all can quite linger like "La La Land."

Some films get universal praise from fans and critics and then you see it and it doesn't quite do it for you. For me, this was one of those. 
To me, this film has very jarring tonal shifts. The film starts out in a classic musical way with a great little freeway off ramp dance sequence. It then spends its first act as a musical, but it moves away from that in the middle and then seems to remember its a musical again in the latter part of the film. 
The music is quite repetitive and by the end I was getting sick of the similar chord progression and reused themes being played. Some of the singing was so so, although Gosling is great with the piano miming (which he did learn to play properly) and Emma Stone is great in the film. 
But the film feels like it was supposed to be a film that played around with old fashioned musicals and would be quirky and fun, but then got hijacked by a director who wanted to complain that no one listens to jazz anymore and he then beats you over the head with jazz music performances. The message of the film appears to be stick to your true passion and work hard on what you want to do and don't do anything else, but that's lost in a sea of artistic choices that feel a bit forced and the film feels like more of a parody.

One should thank the heavens that Damien Chazelle, the passionate Jazz drummer himself, decided to follow his dream of film-making and did not pursue the career as full time jazz artist. But the best part is, in the process of following his love, he didn't leave his passion behind. And as a result, now we are getting best of both the worlds from him. In 2014, it was Whiplash and now it's La La Land.

Cinema Musical is an endangered art which needs the audience it deserves and this movie is the need of the time. So that you can say it's not 'The Sound of Music' or 'Singin in the Rain' the last extraordinary musical you have seen but it is this masterpiece.

La La Land is a story of two dreamers - Seb, a dedicated jazz pianist and Mia, a passionate actress, struggling their ways to make it big. Lost in the city of stars they are waiting just to start a fire. The chemistry of Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling is just out of the world.

There is one scene where Mia tells Seb that she hates Jazz. the scene that follows is bloody wonderful and a pure gem as it shows the passion of the character towards the craft he single-handadly wants to save.

From the opening dance sequence called 'Another Day of Sun' till the final scene in Jazz club, there's not a single moment in the movie which is dull or lazy. Not a single moment when smile leave your lips. Yes, it may accompany some tears in the final moments of film. Shot in CinemaScope, this movie is full of charm, colour, dance, and music. The innovative use of light is class apart.

Music by Justin Hurwitz is quite obviously the backbone of the movie which complements the euphoric choreography very beautifully. Both the songs and background scores are written in gold.

The final 20 minutes sequence of the movie is one of the best movie sequences I have ever seen. Minimal words yet magical impact. These 20 minutes have the potential to be served as life lesson for future editors.

This movie is poetry in motion, this movie is an experience, this movie is a long beautiful dream, this movie is a modern classic, this movie is a masterpiece, and this movie is here to stay and remembered for lifetime.

Go and experience the magic because movies like this come once in a while. Take my words; money you spend on this movie is your small investment towards the good cinema.

If only it doesn't fall prey of the Oscar genre-bias, this movie is going to sweep the ceremony.
An experience you will never forget . Everything worked. It may possibly win best picture

Highly recommend!

have to say also probably one of the first films where I have really rally felt the performance of an actor speak to me in a very unique way . Emma Stone is grand!
