Fantastic modern musical that balances the fantastical style of the past with the more mature storytelling of today.  Ryan Gosling & Emma Stone are electric as the leads, reproducing their superb chemistry from previous films while showing some talent as song & dance leads.  While they don't give the great musical stars like Gene Kelly or Ginger Rogers a run for their money, they turn in some enchanting song & dance numbers that work perfectly for the film.  Behind the camera, Damien Chazelle crafts one of the best modern musicals today, balancing the glorious set pieces of the films of the past with more modern, mature storytelling.  The opening number that breaks out in an LA traffic jam is a prime example, along with some sly humor about LA itself, from the the fact everyone has a Prius to, as one character puts its, "LA is a place that worships everything up to the point they destroy it".  It's a balance that works perfectly for the story, as the numbers never feel out place while the story doesn't follow cliches (the ending, though uplifting, is not the pat one most other films would have cheated at).  Overall, one of the best musicals in recent memory.

La La Land is a rapturous experience, recapturing an old school Singing in the Rain-like magic that, until now, felt impossible to revive. Damien Chazelle knows how to create films with undeniable dynamism and in doing so, created one of 2016's best.

La La Land is the best movie of 2016. Brilliant storytelling. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling are Oscar worthy. This movie is full of nostalgia in the vein of classic Hollywood, giving a fresh take on the old cinematic magic. They can no longer say "they don't make movies like they used to." This movie, man, this movie was phenomenal. It made me feel. I felt everything. Words can't describe the experience I just had by watching it. It was real. It was beautiful. And it was a poignant reminder of love and life. The entire theater erupted in applause when the movie ended. So, there you go. Do yourself a favor and make plans to watch it.

La La Land will make you smile for days. It's a small miracle of a film that is heart warming, dazzling and uniquely beautiful. Damien Chazelle came to notice with the excellent Whiplash and in this film he has gone up a notch with a film that totally delights all the senses. And what's more it's a musical! Set in modern day Los Angeles we cross paths with Sebastian, a jazz lover, and Mia, a struggling actress. They have dreams but reality keeps knocking them down. They fall in love but can they find true happiness in their careers. This special film is about following your dreams and keeping the passion alive. The two leads Gosling and Stone are just superb. They have amazing chemistry and loads of charisma. And they are pretty talented. They aren't amazing singers but they carry the film and it just ads to the charm. The musical numbers are just magical with great homage being paid to the classic musicals of Hollywood. Leave your cynic's mind at the door and just revel in a beautiful piece of cinema.

Different types of people are going to like and hate this movie. This is most certainly NOT the masterpiece it's being brought up as, but it's also certainly not the worst film, and wouldn't even be in some of the best years of film. I was part of the camp that did not like this movie. Let me tell you what I saw and you decide for yourself if you want to see this. It's a musical rom-com with a super pessimistic overtone. The songs are ultra-generic, but about as good as ultra-generic gets. The dialogue is super tight, the humor is really good half the time and kinda flat the other half the time. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are two super sexy and talented leads, with an okay cast around them. It's attempting to pay tribute to Old Hollywood but only incorporating half a skeleton out of the whole body that is Old Hollywood. There is no over-arching plot, and only one character arch is barely resolved. It's a story about a bunch of spoiled schmucks, but relatable enough that it doesn't come across as the most snotty thing ever. For the genre it is, the visuals are really damn solid. For my purposes, this is not a movie I'll ever see again, but I know there are a lot of people who will enjoy the heck out of it even if they can spot its flaws.

After watching a trailer for this film months before it's release, I had already created high hopes and expectations. La La Land flew right past them and sat right on top as the best movie of 2016. Every aspect of this film is astonishing. The music, cinematography, direction, acting, and choreography all come together to create the best film of the year. With stellar performances from Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, the film is unlike anything you've seen. You can feel the emotion and music radiate through you, and it's painfully apparent that a lot of work went into producing this movie. Equally stunning is the direction from young director, Damien Chazelle, whose most notable work is Whiplash. Keep an eye out, cause he's making pure gold.

Phenomenal movie! Although it is a musical, this movie definitely can be enjoyed buy people who aren't a fan of the genre. When there is a song, it doesn't feel like it follows a musical style format, where the characters randomly break out into song. Everyone in this movie always feels like a real person, even during musical sequences. I had really high expectations going into this movie so I was terrified of disappointment. If "Hell or High Water" is about Texas, "La La Land" is about Los Angeles. The romanticism, the dreams, and the limits to those dreams are put on display without subtlety from writer-director Damien Chazelle. His love for jazz and his cynicism about the life of the starving artist is shown in a sometimes self-deprecating way. Both Gosling and Stone breeze through their songs and dances (sometimes without much passion), but their chemistry is always fun to watch on screen. This love letter to L.A. is sure to garner a lot of recognition from the Academy, furthering reinforcing the bubble that surrounds the city, but at least it's a very good movie.

This movie is pure magic. I wanted to love "La La Land", but overall it was a disjointed dud.  The opening scene was electric, and there were a couple of very catchy songs in the movie.  However the dialogue...that dialogue.  Junior-high loves have deeper conversations than Sebastian and Mia.  The movie needed more songs to drown out their drivel.  The overall plot was also morbid, including a total downer for an ending that should have been the real outcome of their relationship.  

The only movie I've looked forward to and was disappointed more than "La La Land" was "A Beautiful Mind", and it won 4 Oscars, which is probably how many this movie will garner.  But the movie could have been so much more, if only director/writer Chazelle would have spent more time on his script and less time on the L.A. glitz.

The performances in La La Land are spectacular. Not only do Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone sing the hell out of these songs, but they also have to dance and act at the same time. Their chemistry was some of the best I've seen this year, and it really made the movie. There was so much great, playful banter between the two that it made you fall in love with them as characters. Gosling and Stone really knocked it out of the park with this one. But I think the true star of the film is Damien Chazelle. As of right now, he is my personal pick for Best Director this year. Everything about this movie was excellently directed. The elaborate musical moments with tracking shots and complex dance moves were done with ease. The personal moments between Gosling and Stone were filmed to highlight the intimacy. The music montages were filmed to entertain entirely. There isn't a dull frame in this movie... 

You can read our review here: http://www.themovieparadise.com/2016/12/la-la-land-review-ryan-gosling-emma-stone-damien-chazelle.html

La La Land è magia, è Amore, è sofferenza, è la cura alla depressione, è una danza contagiosa, è vitalità, è esuberanza, è la gioia di vivere, è follia, è un quadro di Matisse e un notturno di Chopin. Un film totale, sontuoso, sublime, immenso. Viva Chazelle! Viva La La Land!

While the concept of creating a musical on-screen is nothing new, La La Land's take is refreshing and can easily be compared to fun classics like Singing in the Rain.

2016 was indeed a shit year... But not for the silver screen; if this year was a bloody face, La La Land definitely was the consoling pat on the back to give you hope. You just absolutely lose yourself in the performance of the film; much like it's Jazz backdrop, feels like a beautifully done improvisation.

Damien Chazelle loves too make films about music, even when he's only screenwriting the films, instead of directing them. There's a certain musical influence that's expressed in La La Land that no one has ever done before. Or hasn't been able to accomplish in some time. That's create a movie about the very nature of human's in their relationship to the entertainment industry. The entertainment industry has involved and changed over time. However, it's the efforts of certain people to keep the old still fresh. It's also about those same dreamers accomplishing their goal in today's society. The climate has changed and the movie shows the trend of beauty in the industry dying off. Dreamers can only go so far until their own dreams are crushed, resulting in the dreamers creating their own opportunities.

Mia (Emma Stone) is a down and out actress with a dream to make it to the big stage one day. However, life hits her like a bus when in the form of auditions that don't go her way. However, she is still willing to fight for what she wants in life. Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) comes into her life unexpectedly and both of them discuss their dreams of becoming who they are on the big stage. The problem is the fact that they're both entertainers with the passion but not the right break that they want. This create conflict within their own relationship with each other. They're conflict with the outside world effects their conflict with themselves. Creating a almost parallel between the industry and the people who inhabit it. The difference is that the dreamer inside them can overcome an obstacle in their way.

La La Land has done something that no movie before has down. Made me realize that musicals aren't as bad as they seem. Yes they can be annoying and yes they do have a tendency to over do it with the singing. However, La La Land is a treat to be hold. A movie comes only comes along in a lifetime that can capture certain emotions that transcend an entire moment. Like a lot of parts in the film, it short of freezes us in time when things where just much more similar; where dreams could be brought into real life. That's what's special about La La Land and what some people won't get when coming out of the film. Some people might underestimate and look past the wonders of what truly makes the film one of the best of the year.

The film isn't something to be looked at as a spectacle. Gone is the flashy dialogue, the awesome special effects, or even the realistic tone of the film. However the short of creepy aspect of the film, more along the lines of how it plays itself with the leads, doesn't hurt the film. The film might have two notorious actors in the leading role contributing to a society and industry that short of produces some wrong doings. Though this overlooked by heartbreaking and fantastic showing of human nature. The film is beautifully tragic in the most poetic version it could be. It transcends the very boundaries that are holding it show close together. Sometimes a film comes along that will shock you deeply, and even surprise you with a very emotional movie going experience. This doesn't even come close to disappointing in this aspect.

With that I"m going to give this film a big old standing ovation and two thumbs up.

9.7/10

A+

La La Land works really, really hard to make you fall in love with it, and it's largely successful, especially for its stunning choreography, lighting, and music. Emma Stone gives the best performance of her career, while Ryan Gosling pales in comparison. Pacing and some character development didn't work for me, but the overall feeling of the film was, like LA, magical with a side of bittersweet. I resonated deeply with the underlying conflict of love and self-actualization. It's probably going to be an Oscar contender like 2011's The Artist for its nostalgic value with critics, though I think Moonlight is the more successful film, and even Whiplash was a tighter assembly. But Damien Chazelle and Justin Hurwitz deserve all the praise and attention for this fearless spectacle.

I'm surprised, because this is a good throwback to all those traditional Hollywood musicals, and as a film in general, it's not bad! The two leads work well together, and they try their best with the singing and dancing. Ryan Gosling is a little off in that aspect, but when it comes to Emma Stone, she steals the show! Only wish that it could have had a happy ending, but for the film as a whole, I'd say that there's a good reason why it's gotten plenty of Oscar buzz for this year!

La La Land was a movie I was pretty much dragged into seeing and it's one I highly recommend you drag yourself to as well. It's brilliant, sweet, and fun and I am in awe of how they pulled it off.

It's expertly executed nostalgia for a time none of us actually experienced (I think that's called homage). It will convert anyone into a fan of old Hollywood and classical jazz music.

This movie knows what it is and isn't afraid to show off its style and give it some flair. It lets you know right from the start what it's all about with a big colorful musical number in the middle of LA traffic. Lots of color is on display and everyone's outfits are monochromatic for some reason. As things get more serious the colors and the musical numbers fade. This I liked because singing and dancing always felt out of place for me when characters are sad or frustrated.

La La Land is not a pretender. The references to classic Hollywood and Jazz really come across as authentic homages. A rare feat when you consider how often elements from the past are used for comic relief or satire in modern film.

In a time when block buster films have to be dumbed down for the easy translation and mass appeal, I really appreciate smaller movies that can be different and imaginative. Lala Land is not afraid of showing rather than telling and it's free to be esoteric with its references. Calling it niche night a bit too far as classic Disney films mine the same musical and film sources as La La Land.

Acting, as expected, was superb. Characters were great for the most part, the romance was believe and the chemistry was plain to see. Emma Stone's Mia was not always likeable and as the film ended, you wouldn't be wrong to think of her as selfish.

Finally, there are rumbles of cultural appropriation and using people of color as window dressing. I mention this because I am aware of the criticism but I don't really know how I feel about it. At moments throughout the film I felt this was a little uncomfortable. At the same time it's clear that the director Damien Chazelle absolutely loves jazz and it's so prominent in all his work. 

It's complicated, but Chazelle has created something special in La La Land, and I'm always more willing to overlook possibly gray areas when the content is this good.

"La La Land" is a very good movie. A colorful, vibrant musical that mixes the happy/sad turns of a relationship with the difficulty of making it in Hollywood. It's simultaneously alive with modern flair, yet grounded in the old school traditions of a Gene Kelly musical. Yet... it's not THAT amazing. It's not 14 Oscar nominations good. Impressive, but overhyped.

Sometimes we look to the movies to provide escapism. We want to get away from our everyday life for whatever reason it may be. We can disappear into another world with relatable characters to live out some fantasy for two hours. La La Land will be that movie that sweeps you away from your troubles as you fall in love all over again with Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone. Maybe it's just the music theater side of me that geeked out over the beginning as we see both characters stuck in the typical Los Angeles traffic. Cars are stopped for miles with no one moving anytime soon. It's right then and there where all of the passengers get out of their cars for a little song and dance routine. It's perfectly acceptable in the world of La La Land where everyone busts out at any given moment for a musical number where they can all sing and dance flawlessly. I often have these mental moments where I wish we lived in a musical.

Emma Stone plays Mia, an aspiring actress and professional barista hoping for her big break. She's having the typical bad day where coffee is spilled on her; she's late for an audition, and now stuck in traffic. Been there, done that. She has an encounter with Sebastian (Gosling) on the freeway during the opening musical number but doesn't realize quite yet that she will run into him later on. He is a jazz pianist looking to play in fancier gigs but is stuck playing Christmas carols at a local restaurant. Mia happens to run into him playing there on her awful day. Before she has a chance to introduce herself, he bolts out of there after getting fired. The seasons change and more time passes before Mia runs into him again at a pool party. He's there playing keyboard for an '80s cover band. They finally strike up conversation and begin dating. The rest of La La Land follows a year in the life of these two artists who struggle to find that balance of keeping their relationship healthy while trying to keep their careers afloat.

It's very easy to get swept up in the whimsical nature of watching Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone fall in love. This is their third film together following Crazy. Stupid. Love (2011) and Gangster Squad (2013). The chemistry is infectious and they make their relationship on screen look so effortless. Mia has that spunk that Emma Stone is great at which makes for playful banter between Gosling's Sebastian who has a bigger temper than she does. The whole beginning of the film as we watch their relationship grow looks like it's set in a watercolor painting. The opening musical number "Another Day of Sun" is a rainbow of solid colors. It then progress into sweeping strokes of blues, purples, and oranges that accompany the glow of the moonlight and the picturesque world around them. It's as if you are transported back to the days of the old MGM musicals with Gene Kelly or Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. It's a warm juxtaposition for a story that actually takes place in the modern day where cell phones, iPads, and gluten-free pastries are the new norm.

Writer and director Damien Chazelle turned to his Whiplash composer Justin Hurwitz to write new and original music. Like that film, they turn to the music to help tell this story and fit the mood and atmosphere of Mia and Sebastian's relationship. There is constant underscoring ranging from simple piano and string compositions that float along to edgy jazz riffs. There's a seamless transition between the two where you may not notice the music changing shape as their relationship begins to grow and change. The lyrical and dreamy dance numbers fade away as their relationship continues to settle into reality.

La La Land can be taken at face value as a romantic musical with the "la la land" signifying the silly headspace we get in when we meet someone and fall in love. The rest of our life gets put on the sideline as we sing and dance with happiness. Chazelle takes it to another level beyond that as a metaphor for what it's like to be an artist. If you've ever tried to make it as an actor in a big city whether it's L.A., N.Y., or another place, you remember those beginning days where you felt like you could conquer the world. You were prepped for an audition and you gave it your all. After years of struggle, you realize that it's extremely tough work where there are hundreds, if not thousands, of other actors there just like you. L.A. can be the city of dreams or the city of crushing realities. It can make being in relationships extremely challenging when your big break or even getting a job can distract you from the ones you love as we find with Mia and Sebastian's relationship.

You can't get more romantic than Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling which makes the romance of the film all the more palatable. Both of them play into their strengths as actors making it seem like singing, dancing, and playing the piano come second nature to them. Stone infuses Mia with the natural spunk that I love about her. There's a natural vulnerability to her while always being strong and full of life. Gosling is in pure Gosling mode, and that's not a bad thing by any means. He has a bit of an attitude but oozes that easy sex appeal, charm, and sense of humor. Between this and The Nice Guys, I think there's a comedic side to Gosling that we don't always associate with him. Joining them in smaller roles are John Legend as the lead singer of a band that hires Sebastian, Rosemarie Dewitt as Sebastian's sister, and J.K. Simmons as the jerk manager who fires him.

Damien Chazelle knocks it out of the park again as he blends genres, styles, and rhythms in a way to put a literal and metaphorical spotlight on falling in love whether it's with someone else, your career, or both. It's a beautiful call back to the old musicals of the 1930s and 1940s. It's modern, yet timeless. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are the Tom Hanks/Meg Ryan or Bogie/Bacall of this generation. I loved Damien Chazelle's Whiplash and had those same feelings with La La Land.

Is It Worth Your Trip to the Movies? A pure delight that will make you smile from ear to ear.

"Brilliant" doesn't even come close to describing LA LA LAND. It took my already-high expectations and tap-danced all over them. This is the magic of cinema, period. It shattered my mind and shook me to the core. There were numerous times during the movie I wanted to punch my fist in the air and yell "YES!" at the sheer perfection of the moment. When I walked out of the cinema, there was the surreal feeling that the real life around me wasn't real at all - in fact, it took me close to 2 hours to "recover" from it. If you love moving pictures (with perfect cinematography that really dances), or music (oh what gorgeous music), or dance (phenomenal choreography), you owe it to yourself to watch this. Very easily my favourite movie of the year, if not the last five years.

Right from its stunning opening sequence 'La La Land' is a joyous ode to the musicals of old. They don't make movies like this any more, except writer/director Damien Chazelle just did!
Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone play likable star-crossed lovers, artists struggling in that most LA of enterprises - the elusive Dream of Stardom. Los Angeles is the third central character in the film, portrayed as a city of murals, painted in primary colors, an Edward Hopper print come to life. Not since 'LA Story' has the city come to life so vividly.
'La La Land' engages in dialogue with other movies either explicitly, such as 'Rebel Without a Cause', or implicitly, such as in 'An American in Paris'. This is the light side of Lynch's 'Mullholand Drive' which also features an aspiring actress whose excruciating auditions are shown in close up.
Rhapsodic, nostalgic, giddy, 'La La Land' was a huge risk that paid off through its execution and style. The camera gently lilts and tilts across the California landscape, elevating story through screen language. The LA sun casts a golden haze over the aspirations of its protagonists in a world where pavements are lined with broken dreams and success is just a phone call away. 
It is Gosling and Stone who carry the film, Chazelle who exalts it into the constellation of stellar cinematic turns. Highly recommended.

I left the movie theater feeling very happy after seeing LA LA LAND. Director Damien Chazelle shows his great directorial prowess in this musical that is broadly about the cost of our dreams. Like Chazelle's other efforts, though, LA LA LAND is not just "about" a single thing. The movie is about music. It is about romance. It is about progress. Lots of interesting thematic elements get rolled up into the through-line story of two struggling artists (the ever excellent Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling) in L.A. whose frequent, incidental meetings lead them into promising relationship. 
Chazelle's writing and directing obviously work together to homage early movie musicals. (The cinematography frequently reminded me of SINGIN' IN THE RAIN.) Everything about the technical production of LA LA LAND is smoothly executed and nostalgic to the max, which makes the movie all the more impressive based on the fact that the sequences of the picture are so complicated. LA LA LAND must have been an uncanny directorial challenge, but it looks great anyway. In addition to extended, moving cinematographic shots, editor Tom Cross' cutting work helps to set perfect pacing for the movie and offers the audience smooth transitions from shot to shot. 
The musical content of LA LA LAND runs through quite an emotional range and Stone and Gosling are up for the challenge of soulfully working with the music. In addition to their sing and dance performances, Stone and Gosling have believable chemistry and each bring their own unique character quirks to flesh out their already well-written characters. Each performer executes a passionate - and, sometimes heart-breaking - character arc. Both actors are, in my opinion, very worthy of awards consideration. 
While I am, personally, not as big a fan of mid-twentieth century musicals as some other movie-lovers may be, I could not help but not only appreciate, but enjoy Chazelle's passion for them. Beyond passion, Chazelle effectively leverages the musical form to meta-narrate about process of evolving from innocent, passionate dreamer to professional artist. LA LA LAND grapples with the choices people have to make when the make the artist's journey. The ending is unconventional - a bit unexpected. And it is incredibly satisfying.

With all that said for me there were times in the film where I felt rather... bored.  I can say this is certainly not a film for everyone, the girl next to me fell asleep for instance, many will not like this at all and not just because it is a musical but for the "artsy" storytelling style as well.  For me I was into La La Land for its majority but as I said there were a few tough spots for me.  I simply cannot love this film like others have.

From the spectacular, tongue-in-cheek opening number to every quietly sweet connecting song and dance, La La Land enchants with old school movie musical magic. The score, the lighting, the direction and the cinematography all serve to draw the audience into the story of a man (Ryan Gosling) and a woman (Emma Stone), who cross paths on their way to chasing their respective Hollywood dreams.  It also doesn't hurt that Stone's and Gosling's chemistry is in itself captivating. 

I found myself pulling for these characters as much for their charm as their own rooting for each other. And to top it all off (without giving anything away) we're left with the saddest happy ending I can recall from any romantic comedy I've ever seen, demonstrating the real life costs of getting what you want and [sort of] making your dreams come true.

Was it a song and dance gig? A musical? A drama ? Was it a sad ending or a happy ending? I don't think the film could make up its mind and I still don't know. None of the songs or music stuck. Did not find myself remembering any of them afterwards . I give it three stars, my wife gives it 4. Thus the three and a half. I can't exactly nail it down but this movie just did not do it for me. Emma Stone however, maybe getting a Oscar nod for this performance. If you are a big fan of someone in the cast, spend the money and go see it. Otherwise I would recommend waiting for the DVD.
Spot-on characterization of the pathos of present-day Hollywood and its inhabitants with impressive music, choreography, and cinematography which are fun throwbacks to old Hollywood.

A delight breath of fresh air. I was not expecting a musical from the first trailers that I saw, but I'm happy that I read a few reviews before going to see it. Loved the music, the story, the bright and colorful visuals, but most importantly, their chemistry.

I don't see why this film has such good reviews. It was not good. It was slow, there wasn't much story, the characters weren't very interesting. I dd like the use of a single camera for long scenes, but that was it. Some of the music was OK, but it really wasn't all that reminiscent of the better days of musical Hollywood. Don't believe the ratings, and go see something else.

This movie is one of the best films of the year. It brings back the magic of the timeless Hollywood musical era. It had the charm of a Singing in the Rain and yet felt new and fresh with its creative cinematography and current cultural references. The message was also one that was very meaningful.

This is simply one of the most beautiful pieces of art to come out of this decade so far. With only two popular feature films, Damien Chazelle is already arguably a master of the craft. Needs editing to really keep things moving and, well, the 'musical film' aspects are uneven...sometimes it seems like good old-fashioned musical film fun, other times I'm just not sure that the filmmaker TRUSTS such old-fashioned (but highly entertaining when done by experts like Gene Kelly or Stanley Donen or Vincente Minnelli or Hermes Pan). But worth a watch. IN the end, I found it rather depressing...but maybe that is just because i feel such sympathy for actors and other artists who endure so much rejection and who tend to be in constant doubt about their talents and worth...sigh.

La La Land takes the harsh reality of what it takes to make your dreams come true and wraps it up into a sweeping, wonderful musical full of color, light, and imagination. The incredibly creative musical scenes are like paintings coming to life before your eyes. The performances from Ryan and Emma are astonishingly vulnerable and speaks to anyone who has put themselves out there either in a performance sense or by telling the person you love your dreams have no room for relationships.

I thought the movie after the five year jump went off the rails. It didn't make sense that after 7 or 8 months in Paris she would have just dumped him and taken up with some French guy. I didn't get the impression during the previous part of the film that she was particularly flighty and the fact that she ran out of a restaurant to meet him at movie undermines that section of the film rather heavily. So I didn't find it at all believable.

It's been said "They don't make musicals like this any more," and hopefully they won't in the future, either. Director Damien Chazelle's big budget overlong, cliched production provides a showcase for his potentially stellar filmmaking abilities, but its largely forgettable soundtrack, plodding pacing and lack of viewer emotional engagement doom it to unending mediocrity that will likely have you checking your watch in anticipation of its long-awaited conclusion (as it did with me). Granted, the film is technically brilliant and nice to look at and features fine performances, singing and dancing. But its unoriginal story line, all-too-obvious thematic elements, underwhelming humor and inability to get viewers to feel much of anything for its protagonists undermine whatever goodwill is earned by its few strengths. This one's a reach that tries way too hard and never really satisfies.

It's impressive how Chazelle has managed to make a film virtually filtered through a lens of  cinematic nostalgia, the most vibrant, stand-out and daringly different film of 2016. He's not relied on special effects to make La La Land current and engaging to a modern multiplex audience. He's given us a empathetic premise, a popular but under-used genre, two of the most likeable actors in Hollywood and added a flash of cinematic genius. The result is a simple love story, told through humour, song and dance which delights and surprises as if it's the first romantic screen musical ever made. Gosling and Stone shine, cast for their acting process and credibility rather than overly-projected Broadway pipes. This makes La La Land a relatable tale of aspirations and dashed hopes rather than a hackneyed sing-a-long of cliches. Of course the music is instantly catchy, of course the art direction and cinematography are kaleidoscopic, and quite possibly Chazelle has made the best film of the year.
I mean it's no Birdman, but I can't wait to see it a second time. Fan-freakin-tastic. Loved just about everything about it. Smiles from start to finish.
The dream aesthetic was there, the acting is spot on, the music can be quite catchy, the message is quite encouraging, but I can't get over that jarring ending.

A joyful yet bittersweet deconstruction of the traditional American musical wasn't what I expected. It's a love letter to Los Angeles and jazz and its intelligence radiates from every scene. Gosling and Stone deliver titanic performances but it's the use of music alongside the leads' unexpected musical talents which makes this film so outstanding. Writer-director Damien Chazelle's happy yet unsentimental essay about pursuing your dreams is beautiful, uplifting and has a lot to say.

It took me back to the way musicals use to be...but instead of profesional singer/dancers acting...it had professional actors singing and dancing which worked well...it wasn't about the mechanics of the dance..or the style..it was like real people feeling it...and then moving.
Has quickly become one of my favorite movies of all time. I have watched it to many times to count and I will continue to watch it. An amazing film!!

I loved the alternate ending sort of with a life that could have been beautifully summarising soooo much about how pain made them where they are and love and life took them to their ultimate dreams but it is that pursuit that became the end all and had to draw them apart and so on. I can go on and on on the symbolisms and thoughts in the movie and beauty in the simplicity of its depiction as well as the layers that can be peeled if wanted but that's for another day. Watch this. Do not miss it. This is going to the oscars, my friend.

If the darn songs would ever leave my head . . .

Whenever Hollywood puts out a musical it gets rave reviews. Probably because there are so few. So this is no exception. It starts out with a number that makes you think that the movie will be like Grease. But that's the only high energy singing and dancing number. Many songs are subdued. I thought it was because of the limited vocal ranges of Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone. But Emma really belts one out later. There is one song that made me think I was watching a Chinese martial arts film. All of a sudden the principals were flying around the set. There's a good story behind the music and that really is the bulk of the picture. (A girl is trying to make it in Hollywood and a guy wants to start a Jazz bar). You will learn a little about Jazz too. It's a great date movie.

I hated this movie so much.  It was trying to be The Umbrellas of Cherbourg, but failed miserably.  The movie lost me at the opening scene.  The lighting was so bad that you couldn't make out any of the actors' faces.  Why were the headrests removed from the front seats of Mia's car?  Whenever I see this, I immediately lose my suspension of disbelief because people just don't remove head rests in their cars. After that opening scene, the movie did nothing to gain my interest.

Shameless Oscar bait. The story is one I've seen a million times before. We follow the ups and downs of a relationship involving two people struggling to achieve their dreams in L.A.. The film itself tries to mash together fantastical and all too realistic elements, and the result is the tone is all over the place (as is the pacing). La La Land may say things we've heard many times before, but luckily the musical numbers, choreography and cinematography are all fantastic and memorable. It makes you wish the actual story was better. I'd say the first act is the best part of the film (This is where most of the songs occur). Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone also have great chemistry and are too cute on screen (Gosling himself looks dapper as hell). While La La Land may not quite live up to the hype for myself, I'll still undoubtedly find myself re-visiting it just for the musical numbers found within.
Loved this movie...works on so many different levels.  It is visionary filmmaking in its most purest sense.  Please make more stuff like this.

Too long and as much as I love and adore Emma stone I don't think she was right for this role. Her raspy speaking voice is terrific but doesn't translate well to singing.

When it comes to talented filmmakers, there is no other blatantly obvious example of one than Damien Chazelle. I was blown away in 2014 with Whiplash, and it shares so many similarities with La La Land. Both films are about discovering your true potential, and following your dreams. Here's a musical that's not a full-fledged musical, but a tribute to movies, music, and dreams. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone have the smoothest chemistry I've seen in a long time, and the movie oozes charm in every frame. The steady camerawork, ranging from long tracking shots to intricate close-ups, is a marvel to behold. Not everyone will like this movie, merely because there is singing involved; but you need to put that aside and allow yourself to be swept away by this movie, because it has the potential to sweep away anyone who's had aspirations to be truly great at what they do and to do what they love. 
	The beauty of film is that you learn important life lessons that you carry with you in your personal life. There are only a select few movies that have actually accomplished this, and every few years, one of them finds it's way onto the big screen. La La Land is that truly special movie, and it's the best movie of 2016.

Not quite sure what all the hype is about, I suppose there should be further research? Am I missing something? Chazelle wanted to prove he could make a classic movie musical with a 2016 vibe, and by George, he did it. No, Gosling and Stone are no Astaire and Rogers, but they do a decent job of singing, and especially dancing. Taking a page from the classics MGM musicals, our protagonists are struggling to make it in show biz -- he's a jazz pianist, she's an actress. The message is classic (hokey) as well -- don't give up on your dreams. The movie's energy, its look, the music (yes, it's quite good) and the full-on intensity of  the stars raise this close to the top of the genre, certainly in recent times.
I had no idea what I was signing up for, so I didn't know this was a musical. So it took me a little time to get adjusted. But as time went on, I was won over and just fell in love with this movie!

Trite plot is absurdly cliched.  Done better in "A Star is Born".  Character development is glacial and many scenes induce a strenuous rolling of the eyes.  Ryan Gosling is attractive, as per usual.  Emma Stone, however, is the new Anne Hathaway.  Freakishly large eyes, not actually very pretty, and a voice and manner than just irritate.  And while I really like musicals, is there a reason they don't cast trained singers and dancers in these roles?  Overall:  highly over-rated but worth a bargain matinee or cheap on demand rental.

I'll be honest, musicals have never been my thing.  Nor have romances frankly.  But this film transcends both genres by weaving the two together in flawless, energetic and beautifully surreal fashion to create something singular and unique.  The film has an irresistible dreamy style reminiscent of a bygone era.   It draws reverentially from the past, but don't be fooled; its equally grounded in contemporary themes about love, life, success and fulfillment, with a wonderful cliche-shattering end that I especially appreciated.  It's a modern classic that will only get better with age.

maybe a 2.5 at the most.....in my opinion, this movie had an identity crisis. It continually moved between comedic, almost "frivolous" dance/song numbers, but then desperately wanted to be deep and emotional, and moved to darker, more "serious" moments. There were two different styles that just didn't  create a cohesive movie. The musical moments were reminiscent of movies past, but the more serious scenes had too much the feel of present day dramas. I think the movie should have stayed true to its ode to the past......it missed the mark completely for me. I was disappointed.

A visually appealing, masterfully-crated departure from the mainstream of Hollywood films. A tribute to the American musicality filled with sounds and colors reminiscent of the time. Definitely a must see.

"La La Land" is a wonderful modern reimagining of the golden age of Hollywood musicals. It tells the tale of a pair of dreamers - barista-by-day actress Mia (Emma Stone) and struggling jazz keyboardist, Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) who, after a number of change meetings, fall in love and dance like Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers in a series of show-stopping moments set against iconic LA locations. Paired together for the third time, Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone have a lovely chemistry. Indeed, everything in the movie is in harmony. It is visually gorgeous and its intimate songs add to the romance of its escapism. And although it is sentimental in tone, it is not overly so in narrative, because, as in music, it is all about the timing. Still, as an ode to the dreamers of the world, it is a beautiful celebration.

Watched it in the BFI London Film Festival and it is mostly definitely the best movie I've ever seen since Whiplash. On the top of my list for 2017 and I can't wait until I get to see it again next year and it wins almost every award nomination.

As someone who hates musicals, I was very skeptical of La La Land but, as someone who thinks Whiplash is a modern masterpiece, I thought I'd put that notion aside going in. As soon as the opening number was in full-swing, my detest for musicals was affirmed. Musicals are so incredibly unnatural and cancerously happy that it takes stunning choreography and an extremely talented dancer like Gene Kelly to pull it off. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone aren't that great of dancers (or singers in Stone's case), which obviously shouldn't be the case since these numbers are made for the sole purpose of being whimsical and effortless. The movie also takes very long breaks from the numbers to be a straight-up drama. I'd say that makes it inconsistent but I shouldn't complain because the talking parts are the best scenes. When Ryan Gosling talks passionately about jazz or he and Emma Stone argue with weight, their acting shines and my interest is peaked. But then the musical aspect has to go and ruin any momentum. That's mostly because Gosling and Stone don't have the best of chemistry, despite this being their third pairing. Their characters seem adamantly uninterested in each other and then, all of a sudden, they're in love. There's a decent message here but all of the musical numbers (and I mean the dancing/singing ones)  have nothing to do with the ultimate goals of the characters and seem very useless. If they were cut from the movie, it'd be an appropriate length and I wouldn't be cringing in my seat. That being said, this movie is very well-directed and the cinematography is on-point. The actors are honestly very good. They just don't work that well together and their choreography isn't remotely spectacular like the Gene Kelly days. Damien Chazelle can sure write an ending to his movies. However, he's only directed love letters to music (jazz especially) so I really hope he's not a one-trick director and he can branch out from here. Jazz is great and all but musicals just aren't my thing. (2.5/5).

Superb. First-rate music. Beautifully-set scenes. Exhilerating flights of fancy. Terrific performances from Gosling and Stone. Evocative scenes. At least one scene of compelling, superbly-written drama (when they have dinner together at their home). Some first-rate moments of comedy (love the early scene in Gosling's character's apartment with that character's sister). Effortlessly unfolds with a mish-mash of genres. Eternal Sunshine-esque if Eternal Sunshine were an uplifting musical, as absurd as that sounds, see it. You'll get it.
I save a 10/10 for perfect cinematic experiences. This movie needs to be seen.
Yep, nothing short of a masterpiece

Review - 'Here's to the fools who dream'.

What would happen if one stopped dreaming? Damien Chazzel (Whiplash) would have probably been a jazz musician without piquant, instead he followed his dream and today he delivers a movie that is "The best thing that has happened to cinemas this year". 

Such heart and tenderness is seldom seen or felt in a movie and La La Land opens up the seventh heaven of pure bliss and it inevitably takes you on a journey brimming with emotions. You would be helpless but feel in awe and admire the kind of pure cinematic brilliance with warm storytelling that would stay close to your heart.

The movie is set in contemporary LA, we are made privy to a huge pile up on a freeway but an unassuming girl, goes about her way grooving to 'Another Day of Sun'. Here starts off the magic which doesn't end until you endeavour to blast the reminiscence of the flavour that the movie has left you with. 

It is at this point our love birds come across each other but in a bitter manner with Sebastian getting the finger from Mia. Sebastian is a staunch traditional jazz religionist and plays music for a living but has a dream for a jazz band and then there is our dreamy eyed Mia, a wannabe actress trying her luck at Hollywood but with no triumph. These unassuming and unlikely characters, blend with each other, pushing each other for glory, thrive to conquer their dream. Like every other couple, they have their highs and lows and yet they stick to each other and what conspires of their love at the end is tragic. 
 
Damien has a gusto for storytelling. It is ingenious of the director, narrating love in the form of seasons. It's winter and our love birds are having a hard time coping with their lives to meet ends, come spring, it's the season of love transpiring into a crazy and yet emits the warmth of each others company and come fall, everything is falling apart. When there is shortage of words to express, music flows in a lovely manner, clutching the audience in its sweetness. 

The movie has a nostalgic touch with the movie being presented in CinemaScope, which in the times of technical advancement, is least used and Damien does it with elan. The movie is conjured with long shots that can be termed iconic and shots of dim lights, symbolising ones inner emotions. His love for Jazz and his concern for its dying aura is seen throughout the movie, doing his bit to escalate it's magic. The music in particular by Justin Hurwitz, would lighten up a heart filled with melancholy and it reverberates without a flicker. 

Emma Stone is the highlight of the movie, carrying off Mia with panache. She's just lovely and is ably supported by Ryan Gosling as Sebastian, underplaying but his character will stay in one's heart for the respect he has to his love, though his love is pushed into oblivion. Surpassingly, Emma Stone sings her lines in the movie and no one could have done better. 

In fact, trying to praise this movie in any manner would be a futile effort because, words cannot describe La La Land because it's an experience to be lived, emotions to be gone through and it will leave you with moist eyes and a smile. They don't make such movies nowadays and here's to the fools who deserve great cinema. 

Just go watch this magic weaved by Damien Chazzel. By the way, don't let that 'A' certification hinder you from entering the theatres, a movie for all ages, presented in the most dignified manner. This is what cinema should be.

There are two things that can really win me over in a movie; great music and a great ending.  La La Land has both, and then some.

Coming off of Whiplash, one of the best films of 2014, the pressure was on Damien Chazelle to come up with something to top what he did previously.  Not only did he co-write 13 Cloverfield Lane earlier this year, but he finally got to direct his passion project, La La Land.  In fact, the very plot of the film echoes Chazelle's relentless devotion to getting this film made all these years.  And for the most part, the result is magical.  Surely, there's nothing like it you will see this year.  

Like many classic musicals of the 40's and 50's, La La Land's narrative tends to wander into dreamy and surreal territories, but it's at its best when it is simply telling the story of two ambitious artists in Los Angeles, one a jazz musician and the other an aspiring actress.  I think Chazelle's vision would have been fine with other actors, but there's no question that a ton of credit has to go to Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone.  Their chemistry bolsters this story, and really, is why I cared so much about these characters.  Both of them will be nominated and both of them deserve to be.  Their relationship through triumphs and struggles, may be the best romance of the year.

La La Land is one of those movies that doesn't really hit you until the car ride home, or even a few days after.  Sometimes the wandering plot and the inconsistent presence of musical numbers is frustrating, but it all leads to one satisfying ending.  So much so that I significantly upped my score because of how hard the ending hit me.  It isn't predictable or easy, in fact, because the ending wasn't what I originally hoped, made me enjoy it even more.  The final few shots gave me a whole movie's worth of emotion, and it made it worth it in the end.

This is clearly a tribute to the musicals of the golden age of Hollywood and also a constant reminder at the brilliance of Jazz music, but I found the touching romance and struggle of these two artists to be the most rewarding aspect to La La Land.  The beautiful score and equally subtle and swashbuckling songs contribute to one epic theater experience.  I'm still processing how I feel about the film as a whole, but I'm certainly pleased that I saw it.

+Stone & Gosling chemistry

+Music

+Unpredictable

+Satisfying ending

-Middle act wanders

9.0/10
La La Land has all the makings of a classic. Scenery, music, singing and dancing, romance, heartbreak. Ryan Gosling is good. Emma Stone with her sweet voice is outstanding.

I can't stop thinking about this movie. It was so original, so good, so fantastic in every way. I downloaded the soundtrack first thing this morning. I need to see this movie many more times. It was definitely the best movie of 2016. I loved it.

I witnessed La La Land a few hours ago and already it feels as if it was nothing but a nostalgic, airy dream, and I mean that as a compliment. So in awe of Old-Hollywood musicals and romances La La Land is a film for those that think they don't make them like they used to. It's passionate, real and beautifully melancholic. The soundtrack dazzles with energetic original music including a dazzling opening number on a highway, in which dozens of frustrated drivers exit their vehicles and break out into song and dance while singing about their hopes and fears, and a brilliant ballad sung by Emma Stone and a final Epilogue that is awe and Kleenex inducing. The two leads radiate chemistry and the film feels like a modern classic. If there are any true issues it is mostly in the lack of songs in the middle of the film when it focuses more on the relationship. The film sometimes forgets its showstopping roots and instead is more classic boy meets girl story. In the end though, the Technicolor dreamscape that is La La Land sears itself into your heart and its love for movies and music is evident in the way it conveys the hopes and joys of struggling artists who find hope in their dreams. The film will undoubtedly strike a chord with many striving actors and musicians who feel their passion for what they love is driving them to pursue tough dreams. It's a very real message that left me a bit uneasy being in much of the same shoes Mia is in. It hit almost too close to home but its bracing honesty in the creativity and audition process of artists is an aspect of show business that is necessary to portray. Through the highs and lows of its romantic envisioning of an LA fueled romance, La La Land epitomizes everything right with film today and manages to be breathtakingly bittersweet, modern but classic at the same time. Utterly lovely. Rating: 92

'La La Land' finds writer-director Damien Chazelle in top form. For those who may have thought his first feature "Whiplash" was a masterful fluke, Chazelle proves everyone wrong with a film that is both expansive and full of genuine fizz. The auteur picked two pitch-perfect leads in the form of Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone whose irresistible chemistry and penchant for the song-and-dance material is fully on display here. Both injecting new life into an petrified genre (the musical) and giving us something to think about, 'La La Land' isn't afraid to plumb new depths and ask hard questions about the nature of artistry and how working artists commit to their crafts everyday as if its life or death. Both stars perfectly transmit their existential crises and when their lips lock in breathless romance, the audience simply has no choice but to go along for the ride. Here's looking forward to Chazelle's third feature. If anything, he'll build yet another world where we won't want to leave.

You hate musicals? Me too.  La La Land transitions from music to dialogue effortlessly.  I honestly forgot I was watching a musical.  Emma Stone gives the performance of the year in this movie that manages to make you feel warm and fuzzy, but still tells you EXACTLY how it really is.  It's a love letter to people with passion, to people with dreams,  and it encourages you to never give up.  I'll be listening to the soundtrack every day til I get to see it again.  The music is both catchy and elegant.  And wow, this movie is FUNNY.  I laughed a lot.  The cinematography is beautiful.   They make LA look like a place of vibrant color and beauty, rather than a place covered in trash and smog.  Gosling and Stone have effortless and believable romance and chemistry on screen.  See La La Land,  even if you hate musicals.  It is THE movie of 2016.

Only two years ago, writer/director Damien Chazelle delivered his breakthrough drama Whiplash to universal acclaim. For his third feature, titled La La Land, Chazelle reaches into Hollywood's musical yesteryear to retro-frame a musical romance drama into a contemporary setting. Starring Ryan Gosling (fresh off a similarly humorous turn in the underrated The Nice Guys) and Emma Stone (still building on the success of her Oscar-nominated performance in 2014's Birdman), La La Land tells the story of two young artists with major ambitions who by a mix of chance and fate bump into each other in a series of mishaps that evolves into affection.

Sebastian (Gosling) is a down-on-his-luck, jazz-purist pianist who hopes to rejuvenate the dying relevance of jazz while paying strict homage to its musical purity in a nightclub he hopes to one day own. Socially acerbic yet dryly humorous, Sebastian is caught between his own ascendant talent, and his limiting tendency to burn down bridges with his un-workman-like attitude. Meanwhile, Mia (Stone) is an aspiring actress working on the Hollywood lot as she throws herself into the deluge of acting auditions that yields less than positive result. They yield a smoldering indifference that crushes the spirit Mia needs to achieve success. These two cross paths in rather unpleasant circumstances that would normally prevent any future bond, but as they continue to interact, a bond forms nonetheless. In that bond, a greater understanding of each other's artistic interests and talents brings them together as they pursue careers in their respective fields.
 
Through the film's protagonists, who have the only true sizable roles in the film, themes of ambition and love teeter on a scale throughout. As the film ventures through the rigors of artistic career-building, the sizable disappointments that mount through the journey color the character's journeys and test the boundaries of their romance. Ryan Gosling, while very understated in his performance, conveys his vulnerabilities through the slightest facial expressions and gestures, which were no doubt practiced in his two collaborations with Nicolas Winding Refn (2011's Drive and 2013's Only God Forgives). Underneath his sneer and silence, Gosling emits a loveable quality that is certainly pegged down a few notches from his "lovable doofus" role of Holland March in The Nice Guys but still visible.

Emma Stone's more home-sy, real-world performance inspires great empathy for her character's struggles, and major disappointments all of which feel heartfelt rather than planned for some late act resurgence. Instead, Stone embodies a full-fledged character who she infuses with heart that makes the entire film work. Although there is a supporting cast that include musician John Legend and Finn Wittrock, the supporting cast rarely have much to offer beyond the high-concept musical production that involves them, which may explain the film's notable lack of a Best Cast nomination by the Screen Actors Guild. Nevertheless, the film works well enough on the weight of its two leads. Musically, the film fuses its musical compositions, lyrics and score with the performances, characters and themes of the film perfectly, becoming more exemplary of what original songs are meant to do in cinema opposed to the gimmicky end-credits soundtrack compilations that make good promotional trinkets (do you hear me Suicide Squad: The Album?)

As an overall production, Damien Chazelle comes more into his own as a filmmaker as he weaves together a smaller-budget production that seems like the kind of massive Hollywood musical production that was far more prevalent in the 1950s and1960s. Highly reminiscent of the kind of Oscar-winning films of the past (before the brooding social indies took over), La La Land uniquely harkens to history while planting its feet firmly in the present in a manner The Artist couldn't. Tom Cross' editing truly eclipses his Oscar-winning work for Whiplash given the almost circular transitions, stops, revisited motifs and artistic setups. The bold yet almost simple production design is well utilized by its dancing, and singing cast while Linus Sandgren's cinematography beautifully illuminates color mixed in with celluloid classicism almost in the vein of Paul Thomas Anderson's second phase works (such as Punch Drunk Love, There Will Be Blood, The Master and Inherent Vice).
 
As a late-year release, La La Land is a welcome send-off allowing for positive yet not cheaply-sold optimism in the face of a year of uncertainty, death, depression, division, anger, outrage and confusion. By the roll of its ends credit, there is a feeling that a magnus opus has been delivered and it's one that's not a motion-capture of 2016, but one that will live far beyond its time much like the final cymbal crash in Damien Chazelle's first masterpiece Whiplash.

Damien Chazelle's La La Land tells the story of Sebastian and Mia through their beautiful yet tumultuous relationship. Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) is a not-so-successful jazz musician trying to fulfill his dream of saving jazz by opening his own club. Mia (Emma Stone), on the other hand, is an aspiring actress stuck in the big city of Los Angeles trying to make it big but is on the edge of quitting. Both characters face endless roadblocks on their way to greatness and it is tragic to see these characters struggle to realize their dreams. Mia, in particular, is brought down to such a low level that it is truly heartbreaking in that may never be able to fulfill her dreams. The story, overall, is about persistence and devotion to one's craft and how that can be very rewarding. I could not write a review without mentioning the fact that this film is a musical. To be honest, I am not really a fan of musicals, however, this movie is gorgeous and the music is beautiful. The songs are never forced and add a lot to the film, in fact, I could have done with a few more because they were so amazing. The acting (and singing/dancing) is performed masterfully by the film's leads. It should also be mentioned that this film depicts the city of Los Angeles beautifully, the colors burst from the screen as do the moving sets on the Warner Brother's lot. This film is a masterpiece and is easily the second best movie this year, Overall, I recommend that everyone who has a theater that shows this film near them go and see it twice, it is that good.
