La La Land reminds me a lot of American Beauty. I know that might seem weird but hear me out. Like American Beauty I am almost certain that La La Land will win the Academy Award for Best Picture even in a year where there are several better films. It will win because it is glib and shallow but fakes having depth by tapping into something in the zeitgeist, a fear of change, longing for nostalgia and a return to a simpler time. Trump's election only cements it. People are living in the perfect moment to embrace a movie like La La Land, but that doesn't mean its really all that good. 

Let me blunt. As a musical La La Land just plain sucks. The choreography is high school drama level. The Coen Brothers did better in Hail Caesar and that wasn't even a musical. Not only are none of the songs memorable but Damien Chazelle doesn't even seem to get the simplest concept of what makes musicals work, that songs should at the very least express the feelings of the characters in a way that only songs can, and the best musicals tend to use them to advance the plot as well. The only time the movie's musical numbers really work is when the film is intentionally aping other movies, whether that be Astaire and Rogers or the far superior musicals of the great Vincent Minnelli. 

Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone do what they can, and she is especially great in a lot of it. The movie's first half is basically the couple meeting cute and getting together and I found most of this pleasant. However, then the movie decides to resolve their mutual attraction by eliciting a startling series of clichés that leads to an especially stupid and unearned ripoff of the romantic climax of Billy Wilder's The Apartment (not a musical I should note) and then a shallow montage that is supposed to be a stand in for anything approaching character development. 

In the second half the film did almost win me back. Chazelle starts to explore the themes that he so deftly explored in his previous film, the excellent Whiplash, and the film becomes more than candy- coated romance. He has a dream of being a jazz musician and owning a club, while she wants to be a Hollywood actress. Their attraction to each other is seemingly based on the fact that they both feel a level of passion for something that others don't and therefore can relate to each other. However, the movie also explores if they can have both their dreams and each other. 

The big problem with the movie to me is that Chazelle is positively dew-eyed about his love for jazz. We hear Gosling talk about jazz constantly throughout the movie and it is seen as some noble artistic pursuit that he should never sacrifice by selling out. When he does take a gig in order to make money for their relationship the entire thing seems very contrived and ridiculous because it is this money making gig itself that keeps them apart, and later in the movie his characters is portrayed as practically a martyr. 

Her dream, on the other hand, it is unclear how Chazelle feels. Every actor or writer we see in the movie is more or less portrayed as a fame chasing loser. If being a jazz musician is not selling out then being a Hollywood actor is selling out on a nearly cosmic level based on the world this movie exists in. Yet, Chazelle wants to have it both ways because it is because of Gosling that Stone ends up with the chance to live her dream. He literally tells her what to do and then toward the end of the movie takes all the choices away from her. 

It is tempting to label this movie as sexist because of this, but I think it is more thoughtless. It is ironic that people praise this movie for being about the love of movies because like Whiplash what it is really in love with is jazz. The deeper and darker themes are introduced but never followed through on. Take the film's ending for example. Chazelle sets something up that could have been as devastatingly bittersweet as the ending of The Umbrellas of the Cherbourg, but he just can't help himself. Instead he has to beat us over the head with another fantasy montage. This film is a rather average romantic comedy that merely flirts with depth, but maybe its the distraction the world needs right now. 
 Moonlight has won more critics awards. Its the best film I have seen this year and it would be a revelation if it won the Best Picture Oscar because it is about a kid growing up poor, black and gay. Choosing either Kenneth Lonergan's exquisite tragicomedy , Manchester by the Sea or Jeff Nichols's simple and narratively subversive film Loving would both be better choices but Moonlight and Manchester By The Sea are both achingly sad, while Loving intentionally avoids all the Oscar baiting dramatic moments that any other director would have put in.

One star for Emma Stone, who was superb as always, and a half star for the amazing opening, soon after which everything went downhill. I suppose if you don't mind your films having at least THREE absurd coincidences, then you'll be fine with this. However, I'm smarter than this film, and I don't appreciate having my intelligence insulted, especially by the final stunningly IMPLAUSIBLE coincidence. We are supposed to believe that they pull over for dinner right in front of the jazz club like that? Such stupidity took me right out of the film for last time. I was then. I now hope Manchester By the Sea wins the Oscar, but I know it won't, because this is exactly the kind of nonsensical mediocrity that won Crash an Oscar. 2016 is going down in history as the worst year for films. There simply weren't enough good ones. Hell or High Water was excellent, as was Loving and Arrival. This writer/director can take his lazy coincidences and shove them. 

I really wanted to like this. But after the third coincidence, I lost patience. I remember the same bizarre crap in Whiplash. How this guy is getting his films made is a mystery to me. Go ahead people, love this film and rave about it like it's the best film ever made. Like the character in the film, I hold to my beliefs and refuse to bend to the incorrect mass opinion. 

And how can you have a film about true jazz while singing these awful uninspired songs? It just didn't work because of that. But since most people are not real musicians, they will be fooled, and it won't bother them. Another phony pretentious film about music by this Chazelle guy. It only worked occasionally, but that's not good enough. I thought Moonlight was the most overrated film of the year. Wrong. THIS is now the winner of that accolade.

I'm going to be completely honest I didn't expect La La Land to be as excellent as it was due to the fact that it had a lot to live up to but honestly it lived up to all my expectations. La La Land tells the story of two people struggling to make it big in Hollywood or in the films case "The City of Stars" one is a struggling pianist and the other is a struggling actress. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling are two very talented actors and they do a exceptional job in this film and to see these two actors take on such different characters than the ones we are used to seeing was great. Another great thing about Gosling and Stone is they actually have amazing on screen chemistry together which is always great. Damien Chazelle is on his way to becoming one of Hollywoods finest directors for those of you that don't know Chazelle made Whiplash (2014) which though was different in many ways was another music based film and was phenomenal as well, I am looking forward to seeing what Chazelle makes in the future. La La Land has everything you want in a movie its got terrific performances, excellent music, beautiful scenery, and a great story. For all you jazz and/or musicals fans out their I highly recommend La La Land for you. Now for everyone reading this and watched/heard about what happened at the Oscars with the best picture category I have not seen Moonlight (2016) so I cannot say which one really deserved best picture however I am sure that Moonlight was a good film as well.
Brilliant. Very enjoyable roller coaster ride. Very Hollywood. Can see why they tip it for BP. It serves many accolades though perhaps BP a bit much. Still a lot of fun.
By far best movie Ive seen in 2016 so far!  5/5 its a masterpiece.
My full review at https://checkmarkedfilmreviews.com/2016/12/19/la-la-land-2016/
needs more songs!!! (although the ones it does have are perfect.) I read that Chazelle was very much influenced by Jacques Demy, and it shows. absolutely magical!

A beautiful and entertainingly happy film. Damien Chazelle makes pure cinematic gold. He is a magician with music in movies. La La Land has the songs, the acting, the story, the choreography, and the pure movie magic to make it one of the best of the year. 

P.S. I'd pay good money to just watch Ryan Goslin and Emma Stone in any movie because their on-screen chemistry is lovely and palpable.

Cynical view of achieving your dreams. And i dont subscribe to the idea that passionate actors do what they do just to be recognized at starbucks. Still though, personal views aside, nicely acted, directed, shot and choreographed....and leaves you thinking.
they dont make movies like this anymore and they should. loved the characters and story. highly recommend.
Give this all the Oscars.

La La Land is the best movie that I have seen all year, and probably one of the best cinematic experiences of my life so far. The movie is beautiful, from the plot to the radiant and warm colors shown throughout, and like the "City of Stars," Stone and Gosling really dazzle in their performances as well. The film is spectacular and incredibly thought provoking and moving. I loved every minute.

One of the greatest, most skillful, most artistic, most brilliant, most lovely, unique, pieces of filmmaking we have ever seen. This is a resurgence of the 1930s & 40s film-making. It may not have the special effects of interplanetary wars but this is one incredible film in every way. Don't miss this!

I'm a sucker for musicals, so I can't give any harsh criticism.  I enjoyed it mainly for the score and catchy songs.  This is definitely a front runner for "Best Picture" since a musical has not won the big prize since "Chicago".  Emma Stone may have a chance in holding the real Oscar statuette instead of holding a cheap lego imitation.

The best movie of 2016!  La La Land both in terms of story and execution is perfect.  From the opening scene on the freeway, to a Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers style dance number with Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, to Griffith Observatory which has served in countless of movies, La La Land is a throwback to the Hollywood films of yesterday with a modern sensibility.  Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling give amazing performances that equal the greats like the aforementioned Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, and the skills portrayed, not just in song and dance, but in particular Ryan Gosling's masterful display playing piano, brings this film to such great heights that anything short of 5 stars would be an injustice.  As someone who does not live in Los Angeles, but have visited the city of starts enough times to call it a second home, the references to what the city offers may be lost on audience members who are not as familiar with Los Angeles.  But La La Land is more than an homage to old Hollywood and Los Angeles.  It is a film about falling in love and the feeling you get the first time you fall in love and how much it is like a musical.  I believe we all have felt the kind of love that Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling portray in the film, and to be able to capture that feeling of floating in air and put it on screen is something magical.

I loved loved loved this movie!  Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are absolutely amazing, the chemistry between them is so real.  I would pay to see it in the theater again tonight.  A feel good happy movie with so much talent!
Written with a nod to Academy voters, this charming film did well with their casting choices, as Ryan Gossling could charm the pants off of anybody. CDW

They don't make movies like this anymore. From the gorgeous one-takes, the fantastical dance numbers in space, the tap-dancing at sunset, and the catchy numbers, La La Land is an incredible and tragically rare film. It is a tribute to the golden age of cinema, jazz, musicals, as well as love letter to both the city of Los Angeles and to the core belief that we have to sacrifice for our dreams. 

The cast is strong, namely Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling. Both of them share touching light moments, sweet and funny moments, and tragic and heated moments. Their talent is outstanding, the direction is top-notch, and even the use of lighting and imagery is above anything I've seen. In short, it deserves strong Oscar nominations.

why was this film, which centres heavily around the historicity of jazz and acting, so white centric in spite of the richly diverse history of those two arts? the characters were superficial, and because of this their relationship was contrived. the leads are fine singers/dancers-nothing amazing, but not terrible. the musical compositions were stressful at best. why did the side characters-i.e. sisters, roommates-even exist? why was their flirting so contentious and hostile? basically, the whole thing is confusing. i left the theatre only thinking about how much i wanted to eat pasta.

Muy bonita pero no hay que dejarse engaÃ±ar por la nostalgia de los buenos musicales. Las partes tÃ©cnicas muy bien y actuaciones tambiÃ©n pero cuando se trata de cantar y bailar Emma y Ryan destacan muy poco. En mi opiniÃ³n no saben bailar ni cantar.
Perfection - I'm obsessed

50% of this movie is a story about the need to have  faith in both your dreams and relationships. The other 50% is a desperate plea for you to love jazz goddamnit because it's more than Kenny G and elevator music. Oh, and then there's a musical shoved in there. Personally, I would have cut the musical numbers (or at least made more variation in the type of songs they perform [every song is a BIG musical number] and also hired actors with better voices) and stuck with the story and the jazz soundtrack- it felt more real and more sincere. All in all, not a bad movie by any means but nothing terribly memorable either.

"Here's to the fools that dream..."

I wonder if I had just stumbled upon this movie, being Damien Chazelle's third as director, not knowing anything or knowing little about it, if I would've liked/loved/fallen head over heels for it more than I did. Because of the state of the independent film scene (and this is one of those mid-way movies like Pulp Fiction, where it has its toes in indie and mainstream Hollywood, the latter if nothing else via its stars and setting), movies like La La Land come backed with the kind of hype that usually would be reserved for, say, a Star Wars movie. It also has to do too with the director's previous, Whiplash, being a ride that gives Emotional Rollercoaster its cliched status, since it was the announcement of a director (from my generation/exact age group) swinging for the fences. And La La Land, with its major reviews and festival runs, seemed like another one. And it is, ultimately, a great movie. Could it have been better? Hmm.

Sometimes, furthermore, coming right off from seeing as movie and dumping thoughts and feelings out like a raccoon spilling a garbage can at night and scattering the contents is not always "correct" as one might say. It may take another viewing, or a few days, to get more of what I felt about it. But I can say that this is a movie about musicals and musical about movies, and usually these cross and twist like it's a dance out in outer space. Chazelle is also bringing a story that is so familiar - artists in music and performance, close enough as the same thing, who meet, have a little push-and-pull at first (they first meet by the usual serendipity of LA traffic jam) - that it could be criticized as a rehash. Hell, we just had a movie come out a month ago/around this same time, Nocturnal Animals, that, if you look closely, isn't too far off (though the endings are VERY different, which I'll get to what is so gobsmackingly JOYFUL about this movie).

Gosling and Stone first were paired five years ago in Crazy Stupid Love, and I'm sure Chazelle knew this and bet on it being stronger this time around. Though as a nitpick (and it should be mentioned) Gosling can't sing anything exceptional, Stone can and they know how to dance and bond and kiss and bring the romance out in full force. La La Land would be a beautiful exercise in technicalities, of pulling off all of the care-free MOVIE ideas that Chazelle has (seriously, he's about as geeky in his homage as Tarantino - notice the Ingrid Bergman wall-sized poster in Mia's place and other parts, or the whole use of the WB lot), but what makes it a triumph is that the actors work well together and separately. More than well, they find the truth in the cliches that come with artists-trying-to-make-it and sell it as well as Chazelle's script can get them to.

Which, perhaps, is the one thing that keeps me from saying 'OMG THIS IS THE GREATEST MOVIE IVE EVER SEEN IN MY LIFE' (which, again, hype) - it takes you so immediately into musical terrain with its opening number in LA traffic that it's jarring to then go back into the 'real' world, more or less. Songs of course happen, but it's a balancing act, and all the while Chazelle's story points for these two is so familiar as far as the 'What Happens When You Follow Your Dreams in Artistic/Corporate America' thing that it goes into what could almost be dangerous terrain - not embracing and finding a truth in cliche, but just being conventional (i.e. how Gosling becomes a piano player in a group John Legend's got, and this takes him away from his actual 'dream' of a jazz club, and then Stone's Mia's dream of being an actress, etc etc so forth and so on).

... And then the final 15 minutes or so happens, where we flash ahead five years to what's happened with these two people who, at one point, went to the same planetarium as in Rebel Without a Cause and dance and go into the stratosphere of the galaxy (I'm reminded of the French New Wave, a lot, by the way, in how much Chazelle embraces post-modern self-consciousness; if Breathless was his Whiplash, is this his, uh, A Woman is a Woman?) And the two of them have changed, more or less, and Gosling plays a song that transports into the 'what if' and it's... I don't have words for it. It's what the movies are about. It's a magical, wonderful 15 minutes that reminded me why I can stand being around people whispering (like I don't hear you, old bastards) and munching popcorn and can be transported into a completely made-up, empathetic landscape.

My first instinct is to go for the typical critical bulls*** of saying 'this is "better" than this' (that is Whiplash vs La La Land), but it doesn't matter. That last fifteen minutes, and many other scenes and Stone's performance and the dancing and the whole color palette and the cinematography (oh man, I don't care if you're verging from homage into rip-off of PT Anderson, it's so delicious for my eyes to look at), confirms that Chazelle is the real deal, a filmmaker with something to say about the human experience, about what it means to chase that unfortunate dragon known as the "dream" of artists and musicians and actors and so on, and at the same time can bring it forward with... soul. It takes a little time, but my instinct is to call this a soulful Hollywood movie first, beautiful homage second.

Emma Stone saves this movie. Her smile and her eyes. Everything else is just well done Hollywood nostalgia.She is the one who understands the genre and the style. Ryan Gosling is borderline embarrassing. No talent for dancing or singing, and him playing the piano is not credible at all. But he is a professional and proudly explained on the Jimmy Kimmel Show that he can't play the piano or dance. But as a professional he learned it for the film and then erased it from his memory right after if. Understandable. The other Oscar contenders, Manchester by the Sea or Moonlight are really powerful and original material. This film is too easy, in many ways. It is not fair that Lonergan (Manchester) or Jenkins (Moonlight) are going to compete at the Oscars with this feel-good studio picture. And they can't win, they won't. Those films are too raw, too artsy, too depressing. They may get one or two awards. Maybe. But La-La-Land will be a financial big success although not completely undeserved. Hopefully only Emma Stone's smile, dance and singing will be remembered. Not the whole overblown and partially entertaining movie perfect for a our dark future.

I'm not a huge fan of musicals. I liked Grease when I was a kid, but I've never been one to jump at the prospect of seeing a new one. I probably wouldn't have seen La La Land if it hadn't been getting so much buzz, and I have to say that I am glad I saw it. From the very first scene, it's hard not to get swept up in the music and feel of this movie. The story isn't that special but the dances and cinematography take La La Land to a whole new level.
Can't remember a more magical musical in such a long time.
Jaw-droppingly brilliant!
The best film of the year!
absolutely incredible. a rare masterpiece, modern day classic. GO SEE IT NOW

Musical Theater buffs, children, and all parents and adults can enjoy this masterpiece, directed by Damien Chazelle. It tells the story of an actress named Mia, who is struggling with romance and finding a job. She finds a pianist named Sebastien who plays Piano, and is struggling with a steady gig and money. After Sebastien (Ryan Gosling) ignores her in the restaurant he was playing in, they start to run in to each other a lot more. They start to realize that they could be together, and they get engaged. Sebastien teaches her about jazz, and they both help each other to become successful, until of course, the tragedy, which you have to see the movie for. I really like how this movie spends a lot of time in the "musical theater" phase, such as the opening scene where they used one shot to film a super- spectacular dancing scene. There are also stunning visuals that includes the dancing, such as the part where they fly into space and dance. The singing, music, and PIANO PLAYING is beautiful, especially the original songs such as "City of Stars" written by Justin Hurwitz. I also really admire the story, it is very sweet and age appropriate for everyone. There are some very sad parts in the movie, but most of it leaves you to think, "what would have happened next?" You may be wondering if I love it so much, why isn't it an 100%? Well, as a film critic, I would say that it changes tones very quickly, like from sad to intense, or happy to chaotic. But I do highly recommend this film to EVERYONE! It is one of the best movies of the year, and deserves some Oscars. Rated PG-13. Ages 7 and up.
The songs are still playing in my head.  I can watch this again.  What a delightful 2 hours!
Dubious about seeing a musical however this was brilliant start to finish.
Some parts were good. Emma was good. The film, meh. Unless you are an inspiring actress or jazz lover, then it's just....meh. The cinematography was good. I hated the ending. Watch older musicals.
I loved everything about this movie. The story, the songs, the dancing, the chemistry between the actors, everything. A new classic.
Once again Damien Chazelle delivers a powerful movie with an impeccable soundtrack. My favorite movie so far this year.

I love the idea of a modern twist on old Hollywood musicals, but I don't think this movie lived up to the hype. The plot was cliche and the characters were very one dimensional. That being said it was visually beautiful. It was decent, but not oscar worthy in my opinion.

La La Land opens in the middle of a dead stop traffic jam on an LA freeway.  Soon, drivers poke their heads out the windows, begin to sing, and within minutes are dancing on the hoods of their cars - a magical moment made more pointed by the fact that everyone looks and is dressed like regular people we'd expect to see downtown.  OK, then!  We're in for something special!

Or not.  La La Land is billed as a musical, and does have its leads sing a few songs, but director Damien Chazelle seems to have been given only enough budget to stage that one production number.  The rest of the movie turns out to be a fairly pedestrian romance.  It's a year in the life of two struggling artists.  Ryan Gosling is a jazz musician, repressed, playing Christmas music as restaurant muzak, Emma Stone is an actress, making a living as a barista on the Warners lot.  In time, each has to come to terms with the degree they want to take chances or compromise.

When I read the story description, it sounded curiously like Scorsese's "New York New York", but I knew this was not going to be THAT depressing.  As much as I disliked NY-NY for its abusive relationship, that story had some scope as it covered wild swings in the lives of its characters.  La La Land is microscopic.  It has two key plot points, and tries to stretch that into a full length movie.  Only in the very end, when it enters a brief new magical reality - and a deeper emotional one, did the movie briefly pick up.
Interesanta povestea lor de dragoste. Scenariu bun pa la finla, actori foarte buni. Nu e un muzical per se, e o poveste spusa imaginativ. Finalul l-a suparat pe crisan.
One of the most beautiful movies I have ever ever seen. Don't miss it

La La Land is everything a movie should be and more.  If you've ever been in love, had your heart broken, chased an impossible dream, or if you just need to feel good about life for 128 minutes, then this is the film for you.

I really liked the first three quarters of the movie, but I did not enjoy the last section as much.  The first sections were upbeat and cheery, but the last part became very melancholy and slightly depressing.  I would have liked a bit more consistency in the movie in terms of the mood.
Yeah it looks pretty but there is barely any plot at all, what is there is predictable, and I couldn't have cared less about the characters.
Going to see "La La Land" with my sweetie today! It looks totally charming, romantic and magical! Have you seen it?
Enjoyed it a lot but was disappointed.  It wasn't  as big of a production as expected .  They weren't as talented as I expected. They were dreamy together though.

it's a day later and I'm still on cloud 9 about this movie.. it's magical.. funny.. endearing.. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are enchanting..Hollywood just doesn't make movies like this anymore..the cinematography and sets are beautiful.. it hits you with a few suprises.. it is definitely one of the leading movies for best picture of the year !!! go watch it

La La Land: An aspiring actress and a jazz pianist  navigate their feelings for one another with their dreams of success in this very contemporary love story set in Los Angeles and adorned with the look and feel of the antiquated sparkling musicals of the 1940s and 50s. A couple of out-of-place moments aside, Damien Chazelle's film is pure cinematic gold - a love letter to life's dreamers - with emotional, raw performances by Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, a haunting score that will linger in your mind long after you leave the theater, and a gut wrenching wallop of an ending that will leave a huge lump in your throat. The beautiful story, about the bittersweet emotions of life paths not taken, will be a classic. A+
Wonderful cinematography, choreography, score, acting and script.  Truly enjoyed the throwback to an older style of movie making.
Great start, sort of slow in the middle to end, nice ending

It starts off slow, and for about the first half hour I was truly hating it, but the more screen time Stone and Gosling share the more infectious they become, which lends itself towards making its insanely heartbreaking yet poignant and bold ending that much more impactful and meaningful. Stone warrants Oscar consideration, Gosling is great, and despite being a musical, I haven't and likely won't stop thinking about it for a while.

La La Land oozes charm and craftsmanship. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone shine and the highest praise to everyone involved in the music. I developed a greater appreciation for jazz watching this.

A slice of old school Hollywood pizzazz, I would welcome a modern revival of the musical genre on the back of La La Land. The direction is superb with certain scenes framed in such a manner that one is effortlessly drawn in - at times I was so engrossed I forgot the cinema surrounds.

It is not without flaw. The film sags in the middle when the tunes take a dry spell and consequently it loses its uniqueness for this chunk. At least one well-deployed ditty would have helped alleviate this. That said, a cleverly sculpted and thought-provoking ending easily won me back. Worthy of awards.

4.5 stars. *Buys soundtrack and score immediately.*

One of the better scripts I know of for a musical. Both leads' acting is showcased well. Chazelle works the profession-vs-social-life dynamic again, this time disguised as a love letter to the Golden Era of cinema.
AMAZING, I went away a better person

From the opening of the movie, it captures audiences' mine by showing off the magical long-short. This opening of the movie is not only just beautiful but also able to be read as a summary of the whole movie. Likewise, from the starting of the movie, all most every single scene of the movie is meaningful for the dramatic personae's situation or feeling, and at the same time, they are visually  and acoustically beautiful. 
Last 10 minutes sequence is impressing enough to engrave hurtful scar on everyone's heart.

A nostalgic take on the Hollywood musical, employing cliches of many kinds in alternating tongue-in-cheek, then reverent, tips of the camera to the once immensely popular MGM productions of the 1940s. This may signal a revival -- we'll see. Set in sunny LA, in contrast to the rainy New York City of many of its predecessors, this production follows the recent unfortunate trend of employing big-name actors with not great singing and dancing chops (presumably because big-name actors with those kind of chops are scarce these days), and attempts, somewhat successfully, to compensate for those arguably essential but missing talents with cleverly framed visuals and plot twists. Not to mention the superb acting: Emma Stone shines, to me at least, somewhat reminiscent of a young Judy Garland, though with infinitely more complex facial expression. Forgetting about  the Golden Age comparison, I enjoyed La La Land a lot; I laughed and cried, and it made me both proud and sad to be a Southern Californian.

Will easily become one of THE BEST musicals of all time to grace the silver screen since the days of Gene Kelly & Fred Astaire! Been waiting awhile for a movie that's exquisite & beautifully done! This is close to PERFECT as you can get, Grade AAA+++

After becoming America's indie champ with 2014's Whiplash, filmmaker Damien Chazelle follows up with a movie-magic musical that's often astonishing, even if it isn't clear whether it's well-executed pastiche, or just plain dumb fun. A throw-back film in every sense of the term, La La Land reaches back to forgone movie musicals, and Chazelle makes it as retro as possible. He lets the film be carried by the songs and dance choreography, which are all often satisfying, but he also wisely gives us a universal love story too. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone have strong chemistry together, even if neither of them of them have refined singing abilities. While the storyline can delve a bit into cliched rom-com territory in the mid-section, it bounces back strongly for the third act, giving viewers an epilogue that's both unexpected and bitter-sweet, and ultimately fully satisfying. Not one of the year's most artistic achievements, but a fine throwback film that demonstrates how a modern musical can work in cinema as opposed to theater.

Absolutely beautiful movie! The colors were vibrant and every scene was perfectly captured. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling aren't just great actors, but their singing is also pretty good! I don't know if I would say this was my favorite movie of the year, but I can definitely accept that it might be the best in terms of quality.

Saw this today and was blown away by this movie. I have not seen a movie with this quality of content that is inspiring, creative and delightful in a long long time.  It is a gem of a movie. Two Thumbs up for sure.
Pretentious, cliched with little soul and chemistry. Way overrated!
A super-imposed look at Hollywood dreams and reality with a heart-touching story, coupled with brilliant music - pure Hollywood Magic!

Can my movies not have sad/"I'm so happy for you" bittersweet endings? I have those enough in reality -_- .... But anyway, If you don't like musicals, you will still love this! Gosling can do no wrong! :P It makes you care and invest in the romance of these two individuals without ever dragging it or making it the center focus the whole time. And it does that with the help of the music and songs that carry the story forward at every point. The film beautifully weaves present day with the touch of a bygone era of Hollywood and what the life of someone struggling to make it in this city is like! It's not about love, it's about people who dream and other dreamers we meet along the way..

P.S. - still hate the ending. don't buy it. it's 2016. don't they have facebook to know someone got married and had a kid? :P

Director Damien Chazelle brings out the best from Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, the beautiful story, set design and last but not least the music making La La Land one of the most heartfelt musicals to hit the big screen in decades!

I know what they were hoping to do but...Ryan Gosling has no voice, Emma Stone looks like she needs a good meal, neither of them could be rated OK as dancers, but there are some sweet moments and the music is, on the whole, pleasant.
The cinematography is amazeballs. I love Emma Stone.

The most beautiful movie I have seen. Everything was perfect, the dancing was well executed and singing at times was hauntingly beautiful or just fun as well. Holds a place in my heart and is my movie of the year.

There is a lot more emotional weight to this movie than I expected after all the talk about it being a musical. Beautifully done with engaging performances from the two lead actors. I highly recommend it.
Check this out if you want to know what a cinematographer does
Starts slowly, yanks at you, twists a lil, oh my, oh no, oh yes, ..... oh my goodness!  The End!
Loved it. It is different than anything that I have seen before, in a good way, I took my 13 year old daughter and she loved it too.
Creatively presented in the classic style of musicals, a movie around life decisions. Shoulda, woulda, coulda...story of our lives.
Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone carry this film to its surprising and "authentic" end.

First Hit:  It will touch your heart with joy and sorrow because of its exquisite acting and beautiful stylistic presentation.

From the very beginning, the audience knows they are going for a ride. The partially obscured black and white "CinemaScope" logo morphing to a unobstructed full color logo gave only a hint of the amazing film to follow. The opening scene with the camera panning numerous cars and drivers stuck on a LA Freeway on ramp, with each driver listening to a different radio station, all of a sudden transforming to a big-time dance number with people using both the cars and lane dividers as props was genius and sets the tone that this film will be a musical and will be different in the ways it integrates the musical dance sequences with the acting.

We are then introduced to Mia (Emma Stone) and Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) through sequences of the work they do and the things they are interested in. She is an aspiring actress who supports herself as a barista in a coffee house located on the Warner Brothers movie lot. He's a jazz pianist in small club, wishes to own his own jazz club playing traditional jazz improvisation.

They meet after he honks at her in the opening traffic jam, after she walks into the club he's playing in (just after he gets fired), and again when he walks into her place of work. By the time they walk through the Warner Bros lot, the audience has a strong sense of their path and them as a couple you care about.

During the film, we are treated to a wonderful, hopeful story that segued into well-conceived dance, song, and piano scenes by Mia and Sebastian. There are two things that struck me about these scenes:  1) The dance sequences were shot full bodied and all-encompassing instead of a series of composed edits and cuts showing feet, facial expressions, and a whirl of colors and bodies. This is how musical dance sequences were shot early on by the very best (Ginger Rogers, Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly) of this genre. And 2); They did their own work. They did their own singing, dancing, and for Gosling, piano playing. They were strong, real and imperfectly perfect, just like all of us.

In my book, this just why these talented two are top box office draws and are two of our best. However, a lot of the credit for this amazing film belongs to the clear direction and vision of director Damien Chazelle who showed us his abilities in "Whiplash", another outstanding film. Lastly, I loved the old time ending by using "The End" at the close of the film, it perfectly bookended the opening,

Gosling is absolutely riveting and sublime. His extraordinary talent is so obvious in every scene he's in. He is a excellent pianist, his suave smooth dance movements are a joy to watch and his acting is top notch. He may be nominated for an award for this turn. Stone is wonderful and clearly made for this part. Her hopeful joy, moments of moving sadness and the ability to move from a dramatic scene into a dance scene were exceptional. J. K. Simmons as Bill, in his very brief scenes, was very good. John Legend as Keith, a musical group leader, was strong and a joy to see. Chazelle wrote and directed this film. Because I was emotionally moved throughout the film, I can say he was very successful in delivering his vision. He and his film is worth an award nomination.

Overall:  Although I normally don't like musicals, I laughed, cried and my heart was touched throughout this fantastic film.
An enchanting movie, the classic musical reimagined for the 21st century.  I loved every minute!

It's understandable that this piece of musical has inspired ardent swooning from some quarters (too easy to see why) and passionate hatred from others (even easier to understand; it just takes a bit of attention). Of course, the problems with this film are rather upfront: Ryan Gosling can't sing and Emma Stone is, well, just stoned. Don't know why these two are front-runners for Best Actor and Best Actress at this moment. The script *attempts* to be subtle, but for the sake of Oscar voters, it has to spoon-feed. The choreography is basic. HOWEVER, despite all the issues that the film presents, I would have thought of myself as small-minded if I magnify them over the sincere tribute (albeit a bit misunderstood) that the filmmaker is showing.

Didn't expect I would love a musical movie this much. Emma stone might have given once in a lifetime performance. Right from the beginning the music and the direction, cinematography takes you into a wonderful ride of 2 hours.

fun, enjoyable but nothing new, over-hyped and lacks the great dancing and singing of the great musicals, as there is not an astaire, rogers, gene kelly or anyone close dancing-wise in sight.
It's the worst movie of the year, no chemistry between Gosling and Stone, bad acting, lousy singing, poor script, predictable story line, boring movie overall.

Bright! Bold! Stupendous! Phenomenal! Spectacular! Superb! 
This film reminds me of the musicals of days gone by. It is visually stunning, and full of colors of every hue imaginable. It pulls you in immediately before the title even gets to the screen. I found myself sitting on the edge of my seat (literally) several times. I almost had to remind myself to breathe! This is indeed a musical ride of joy, filled with songs, a love story and L.A. as it's backdrop. Run - don't walk to see this film. I suspect, that like me, if you're a film aficionado you will see this delight more than once.

A year after enthralling audiences with his second feature film "Whiplash", Damien Chazelle is back at it again with his magical and mesmerizing Musical "La La Land" starring Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, a film that doesn't just capture the style and essence of a musical in the vain of "Singing in the Rain" but also perfectly blends it with the style of modern day cinema, thanks in part to being set in modern day but taking place in a traditionally Hollywood part of Los Angeles, and boasting some beautifully colorful cinematography that gives you the feeling you're in a sublime and dreamlike state. The direction and editing on display here is quite flawless, Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling once again show off their undeniable chemistry as two struggling performers trying to make it big in the city of stars. In a year full of such disaster and indifference, "La La Land" is just what the doctor ordered.

Unfortunately director Damien Chazelle fails to follow his excellent film Whiplash with this mediocre Musical that is quite boring and long at times. Though the acting is quite good not even that can save this film from several genre pitfalls.
What an beautiful fun well written and acted movie! Run or dance quickly to see it ð???ð???

Yes. Yes yes yes. A job well done. it was sublets and classy and sexy without it all being thrown in your face. I just left the theaters and I'm mezmarized. The songs, the dance, the plot, the passion, the joy and heartbreak still sounding in my ears. Just give it all the awards now and save everyone else some time.
Not a big fan of romances or musicals but this movie really made me feel actual feelings the whole way through. And I applaud the cast and crew for doing so.
Like what just happened???

Not just a really great, fun musical. The last sequence is a beauty. I'm sure most of us have had an experience like this, if different in the loveliness of the telling. On the he other hand, probably not everyone's cup of tea.

They don't make movies like the 40's anymore...they make them BETTER! This is simply pure entertainment and escapism for a couple of wonderful hours, and you'll want to come back again and again. Whiplash was the best of 2014 and La La Land is one of the three best films of 2016 for production value and pure entertainment (Moonlight and Lion are equally good in their own unique ways). All the rest from 2016 don't come close.

Director/Writer Damien Chazelle truly gave us a spectacle in La La Land. There has not been anything like this for at least a decade. Amazing music, choreography, story, acting, backdrop, camera work, etc. all around. And did I mention terrific acting by two of the most talented young stars? Ryan Gosling was right on the spot, and Emma Stone put on a show. From the very first scene to the last, the chemistry between the two was something to behold. And again the camera work, unreal. La La Land is the epitome of what can happen when you do every small thing right. There was hardly a wasted moment or a note. La La Land is a tale of two aspiring young people's journey in LA told right. Spectacularly brilliant.

This movie was simply fantastic. Great acting, great singing, great directing, great everything. This movie deserves every award possible! If you don't like musicals then please don't go, but if you don't mind them then I'm sure you'll still be able to enjoy it thoroughly.

Simply amazing. Gosling and Stone are near perfection in this Romantic Musical modern twist that reminds you of how films were made decades ago. I highly recommend those who are fans of the films from the 40's and 50's or musical enthusiasts to see this.

The music and the choreography are EXCELLENT. the story keeps you guessing and when you think you have it figured out.... well just go see it.
In all truthfulness, this is the perfect movie.

This movie brings an usual experience and feeling. I feel like I can see again pieces of my foolish youth, all the dreams and love. The linger feeling that last after the movies ends reminds me of how silly and stubborn I was, how selfish I used to be. We have dreams, but we young people can't accept the defect of our own dreams. 
I can see myself in every corner of the streets, and my young self hiding the main character's eyes. Her question: "Where are we now?" is the most obsessing question for the whole movie. Where are we now, the used- to- be fools, who have to say goodbye to the youth and grow up. Where are we now, the ones who'd rather keep our ego than holding our love ones' hands.There are many way to be successful in life, but there is only one way to keep that person's hand. And sadly, we the fool always fail to do so.

Go see this movie! It seems more and more rare to find a movie that leaves you with a good feeling. Even in its somber moments the movie leaves you feeling good & positive. The songs are amazing, I still can't get the "city of stars" melody out of my head. Extremely well done!
The best movie of 2016!

A very enjoyable musical with two dynamic performances by Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling. This was extremely well done, I'm happy that I finally got to see it right before the oscars. A light throwback to old Hollywood with very good production/direction/acting made this film work.

"La La Land" | B- | Literally the most overrated movie in film history.  Based on pre-viewing reviews, I expected the second coming of Citizen Kane.  Unfortunately, it's the "Hairspray Live" of movies.  Technical perfection can't help the paper thin script, ridiculous opening "traffic" dance mess (note to directors & producers: if traffic is stopped on the on ramp, you should edit the free flowing traffic on the freeway out of the scene - duh!). Gosling & Stone are amazing but their chemistry is more brother-sister than smoldering passion. The brilliant final 10 minutes elevate the movie to B- from an average C.

I really liked it the first time and then when I read about the way it was filmed I watched it again with a new set of eyes. Needless to say I absolutely loved it the second time! My husband fell asleep the first time though he said he loved all the songs. I took my Mom with me the second time and she loved it as well. Such a fun watch- beautiful scenes, beautiful actors and a beautiful storyline. I also love all the music and have had the soundtrack one repeat for weeks! I will buy it as soon as I can and watch it several more times I'm sure!

This is the best film of 2016 and a near-masterpiece. Only one small issue prevents it from being so.

It's hard to say what the most impressive part of the movie is. Is it the songs all original written by Writer-Director Damien Chazelle? The great performances by Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone? Or the gorgeous cinematography? Tough to tell, but let's gush over all of them.

The film grabs you by the balls from the opening scene, a song titled "Another Day of Sun" (The film's second best song) as everyone stuck in crappy LA traffic gets out of their cars and starts dancing on the freeway. It's energetic, joyous, and so fun to watch. From there we meet a struggling actress (Emma Stone) and a struggling jazz musician (Ryan Gosling) as the struggle to survive in a city famous for making dreams... or breaking them into a million tiny pieces.

This the Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling show. They both give good performances, both acting and singing wise. However, Stone's singing is a tad better than Gosling's. Still, that's not to say Gosling's bad. It's just Emma Stone gets the film's best song all to herself and she nails it.

This a beautiful film to watch. The colors just explode, especially in the scenes where Gosling and Stone are dancing. The Griffith Observatory is a real highlight for this.

However, the film has one tiny flaw. There's a scene where Gosling and Stone have their big climactic fight and something about it just doesn't quite gel. It feels a bit like conflict for the sake of conflict with nothing in the film really supporting the accusations Stone makes of Gosling. It's not a major problem, but it is the one negative to an otherwise amazing movie.

The songs rock. The singing rocks. It's gorgeous to look at. It's the best film of the year. GO FREAKING SEE IT!
Entertaining and refreshing!

I give La La Land four stars.   I was not sure at first how to rate it.  The opening sequence caught me off guard and I really like it.  But then I was a bit let down immediatey afterwards and it took a while for me get back into the movie.  By the half way point I was captivated.   It's not difficult to guess the ending but the way they created the final moments still make it surprising and interesting.  Bring your tissues.   It'a a wonderful romance and it;s time for one.
everything a movie should be!

High expectations are dashed against the jagged rocks of Griffith Park as LaLa Land plays like a theme-park version of a nostalgic Hollywood musical, updated for the kids, scrubbed of deep narrative, eye popping color over visual appeal and endearing enough only to get you to the next ride.    We can only pray that pishycaca does not enter the English lexicon.  
In consideration that the big Hollywood musicals came of age as an answer to the depression and World War II, 2016 certainly appears primed to usher in a new era of escapist entertainment where we are drawn, en masse to theatres to forget the troubles of our country and our world.  And while writer/director Damien Chazelle most exquisitely proves he has the chops ("Whiplash") to create effective and compelling mood pieces around the struggle for artistic accomplishment AND artistic freedom, sacrificing character and story to that end doesn't always make for great entertainment.  While the musical set pieces offer compelling visuals and a toe-tapping score, they do little to further the story, which is wafer thin at best.  Often clashing between Hollywood homage and modern storytelling, Chazelle seems to offer up his endearing leads as ciphers of struggling artistes, while wasting Oscar-bait actors like JK Simmons (who won an Oscar for "Whiplash"), Rosemary DeWitt and even John Legend as one-note character bots written only to serve the our heros.

And although Ryan Gosling seems both too young (the aforementioned pishycaca) and too young for the part, both he and Emma Stone do the best they can when presented with a good set of ideas without the narrative and emotional glue to hold it together.  As Stone says to Gosling half way through the film "it's too nostalgic" his response is apt  "well fuck em".  Indeed.
Best movie la la land winner Academy Awards by DVD forever I like
little strange, not the best dancing, horrible singing, but entertaining anyhow
I wish I could give this film 10 stars. It's everything I've ever wanted in a film and everything I never knew I wanted. I never wanted it to end and felt high for days after seeing it. Bravo.

Yes. Yes. Yes. Halfway through watching this I literally thought to myself, "This is a movie I'll remember for the rest of my life." I think I was smiling from ear to ear for most of it, even the sad parts just because it was so well done and made me so happy. I'll definitely be seeing this again and again.

12 hours later, I'm still reeling from La La Land. Damien Chazelle has delivered a beautiful, vibrant, and audacious film. It's clear nods to the movies of old are what make the movie work. This film with make you feel so many emotions--most of the positive-- the whole thing feels like being at Disney World as a kid. At one point Sebastian says that LA "loves everything, but values nothing". It's safe to say La La Land loves music, film, and most of all love. Perhaps more importantly, it values every single one of those things.
what a great movie. the bittersweet ending was perfect.

This movie takes an ordinary plot and transforms it into a great movie thanks to the trifecta of song, dance and acting! Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone prove they have deep artistic chops.  Definitely one of my top 10 movies of 2016

Movie of 2016 indeed!

Beautiful in art direction, score, acting and plot line. A perfect film.
Absolutely fantastic, wonderfully heartfelt and so much fun!

Simply put: the best movie of the year! An enchanting score with great original songs, beautiful cinematography, impressive editing and inventive camera work, all charmingly orchestrated by Damien Chazelle, the master behind this irresistible love letter to old hollywood. Ryan Gosling shines as Sebastian, but Emma Stone, as Mia, steals the show in an unforgettable and touching performance; saying she has neveer been better is an understatement. A tap dance back in time.  Good, old fashioned entertainment.  Treat yourself and see it.  Preferably as a matinee.  You'll thank me.

At a point in 'La La Land', one character explains to Ryan Gosling's jazz pianist/dreamer words to the effect of he's the reason why jazz is dying; his love of traditional music and a refusal to accept or try anything for new audiences has trapped jazz in the past, with young people being unable to relate to it. That's a none-too-veiled metaphor for what writer/director Damien Chazelle has tried to do for Hollywood musicals with this film -- make them relatable for new audiences. It mostly works, but -- like people who either do or don't appreciate jazz -- I think folks who generally appreciate dancing and musicals will enjoy it a lot more. The skill and craft involved in putting on this entire production is evident from its opening moments. The film's emotional hook comes later on, centered around Emma Stone's character, and a performance of its best song -- really, the only great song. For all the nostalgia and aesthetically fabulous production, the whole thing rests on the charm, easy chemistry and performances of its two stars -- all solid, for the most part. Bottom line, I enjoyed 'La La Land' more for what it tried to do than what it actually did.
I LOVED THIS FILM.  If you like the old time musicals you will love love love this film.  It's been a long time since I felt good walking out of a theater!
A story of beauty and disappointment.

A PARISIAN IN AMERICA - My Review of LA LA LAND (4 Stars)

Having written and produced a musical feature film myself, I know and appreciate the enormous undertaking they can be and how every moment becomes a question of tone and intention.  Sheldon Larry, the director of LEAVE IT ON THE FLOOR, always paid careful attention to the musicality of the camera work and we both agreed that we love musicals that don't apologize for being musicals.  We wanted our characters to break out in song at every possible point and give the audience access to the magic in their heads.  With rare exceptions, CABARET and CHICAGO being two of them, I'm not a huge fan of performance-based musicals.  I'll take a cast singing and dancing on a sidewalk over a stage any day.  

Writer/director Damien Chazelle (WHIPLASH) clearly gets that, and then some.  The magic in his lovely yet problematic LA LA LAND begins right away with a cropped CINEMASCOPE title card that needs to expand full screen in order to announce to the audience that THIS is a widescreen musical.  From there, we're plunked onto a Los Angeles freeway onramp in a tracking shot of cars highly reminiscent of Jean Luc Godard's WEEKEND. We notice little pops of color and the disparate rhythms coming out of the various stereo systems.  Then the sounds all come together and everyone gets out of their cars to sing "Another Day Of Sun", a jazzy, staccato song and dance number that swoops and glides around in what's meant to look like one long steadicam shot.  It's a standalone piece of art that will easily go down as one of the classics of the genre.  Cinematographer Linus Sandgren (AMERICAN HUSTLE) creates lovely negative space in many scenes, allowing this film to breathe.  He's also helped immeasurably by Production Designer David Wasco (PULP FICTION), who has a knack for the French New Wave look.  

It's on this ramp where our protagonists, Mia (Emma Stone) and Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) meet not-so-cute.  Mia, an aspiring actor who works as a movie studio barista, and Sebastian, a struggling jazz pianist, perfectly embody the dreamers who fill up almost every block of this city.  As Mia and Sebastian keep bumping into each other, their travails instantly mark them as kindred spirits.  Of course, their starving artist storylines eventually intersect, and no big spoiler here, they fall in love.  Anyone who has ever watched a movie romance will likely guess the ensuing story beats.  

Chazelle, who clearly lives and breathes film, wears his movie references on his sleeve.   LA LA LAND clearly owes a debt to the old MGM musicals such as SINGIN' IN THE RAIN and AN AMERICAN IN PARIS, but it especially pays homage to Jacques Demy's 1964 French musical, THE UMBRELLAS OF CHERBOURG.  Go ahead.  Watch it online right now and then continue reading.  I'll wait.  Unlike that great Catherine Deneuve film, however, LA LA LAND isn't a sung-through musical.  In fact, it's a little thin on numbers and many of the songs end up sounding the same.  There's a stretch in the 2nd act where I thought he forgot to insert anywhere from 1-3 numbers.  Instead, we're treated to lots of instrumentals, stage performances (cue pet peeve red flag here) and the usual love story complications.  

None of this is to say it's bad.  LA LA LAND is often great, even masterful.  It has a literal floating-on-air quality, and Stone and Gosling have enormous appeal and chemistry to spare.  While neither of them are belters, they create a wonderful intimacy and in Gosling's case, a knack for a Gene Kelly-like flair for movement.  Choreographer Mandy Moore, a staple from SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE, makes sure he punctuates every turn with just the right hand flip or extension.  He's a natural.  Stone has a very thin voice, but it's all the better to pierce your heart during her eleventh hour number, "Audition (The Fools Who Dream)".  Nothing in the film is staged as simply as this song, yet it remains my favorite for cutting to the heart of the movie's themes.  
Despite a tone of pure joy, reminiscent of that Oscar-winning juggernaut THE ARTIST, this film does have its flaws.  In addition to the aforementioned dearth of numbers in its second act and a somewhat sameness to the music as a whole, I found the John Legend subplot to be fairly ineffective.  Legend plays Keith, a fellow musician and apparent rival of Sebastian's.  His character is set up as an asshole, yet I didn't really see anything in the script or in Legend's blasé performance to suggest that.  It seems like a lot of screen time to show how far afield of his dreams Sebastian has drifted.  I also didn't quite understand why Mia leaves a boyfriend (AMERICAN HORROR STORY's Finn Wittrock) in the lurch after referring to him as "sweet".  It would have been very easy to give Mia a good reason to dump someone so unceremoniously.  I mean, I was dumped earlier this year via Skype, which sucked, but Mia just gets up and leaves without so much as a word to him.  Mia SUCKS!

A bigger point I want to make about the film is that there are times where it feels more like an homage than a truly concentrated love story.  Yes, the old school musicals featured paper thin archetypes as well, and Gosling and Stone DO give gorgeously detailed performances worthy of every accolade.  Still, there seemed to be a bit of a disconnect in some of the sequences, particularly the early and highly kinetic "Somewhere In The Crowd".  Set at a Hollywood cocktail party, Mia and her roommates (barely established) climb the social ladder hoping to get discovered.  The camera bobs, weaves and twirls around to give us the vibe of the affair, but it fails to truly draw us into Mia.  When confronted with the choice of spinning a camera around a swimming pool or moving in close on an actor's face to see how she feels about the environment, I would choose the latter.  Chazelle sometimes chooses the dazzling effect over the character beats.  

Still, all is forgiven by the end where, channeling AN AMERICAN IN PARIS, he produces a dazzling, unforgettable sequence about fate and choices.  Sure, I would have followed this up with a Mia/Sebastian duet, because, well, it's a musical...but Chazelle has delivered a film to celebrate, even if I was just a little bit let down.
The greatest movie of 2016. Maybe even the greatest movie I've ever seen

The story of a couple who had separated dreams and tried to push themselves to achieve them together; it wasn't always easy but they supported each other through everything.
A well deserved nomination at the oscars for Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling highlights the quality of this movie.
Best musical of th century. Instant classic.

A visual and musical marvel, La La Land expertly balances its bright visuals of the fairytale romance with mute tones of the realism of the real world. A love letter to the cheesy but heartwarming romantic films of the Golden Era.

Mr. Gosling has classics ha some looks and ultra professional choreography which comes from his little known Disney training. Emma Stone doesn't possess the same physical appeal, but, casting must have seen chemistry between the leads that  doesn't seem to translate in the trailer. Both this and "Passengers" promises a joyful holiday.

The movie was incredible and well done. My heart is happy and broken, but happy. Wow! Beautifully done and a wonderful cast, wonderful music and lyrics, and a sight to see.  Found myself on a Spotify in the car listening to the soundtrack immediately the movie! The story is a love story and everything real and honest that comes with growing, learning, dreaming, and moving forward. Sigh. Too good to pass up watching in a movie theater!

In just his second feature film, director Damien Chazelle has transcended to the heights of such auteurs as Jacques Demy and Vincente Minnelli; two other filmmakers who cut their teeth in adapting musical narratives that could only be told through the filmic medium. And make no mistake, "La La Land" is one of those narratives as well. Do not read about it. Do not ask your friends for the CliffsNotes version. Don't even preview the soundtrack on your train ride to the theater. Just go and experience this joyous, wickedly funny, impeccably well-realized jaunt through the stars. It's well worth the anticipation.

This movie has some amazing scenes, but is vastly overrated.  Some songs are great, but I cannot remember several.  The performances are great, too, but the characters are wafer thin, basically defined entirely by their art and by each other.  The plot is old and has been done better, and while the set piece is exciting, it doesn't feel earned.  What saves it is spunk, amazing production values and a depth of commitment from Emma Stone that hides the fact that her character is basically a cipher.  People really want the movie musical to be resuscitated; and to me, this zest is the fire behind the overhype and overrating of the film.

Love Love Loved It.  Dreams are made and dreams arent and that is what life is about. This captured that in its essence. The Cinematography captured the amazing beauty of Los Angeles from a distance as opposed to the urban grit.  The story mimics this in portraying Sebastian and Mia in their glory, but having deal with the rut of their everyday life 
Could definitely be a best pic winner. Will certainly be nominated.

A simple but very good romantic musical. A story set in Hollywood with an aspiring actress & a jazz pianist, both with self-doubt but support & confidence in the talent of the other. The story & performances were very good. However, this movie was not up to the quality of Chicago, Les Miserable & Moulin Rouge.
An instant classic. Beware! You may want to see it again and again... DO IT!
A truly genuine masterpiece

Even though I was lucky enough to see an early screening of this film, I kept hearing a voice my head telling me "This is not gonna be good, you hate musicals remember?" If you are anything like me you will probably think the same thing and completely ignore this film. I'm telling you now DON'T.  This film is a surprising achievement that celebrates music, romance, and ambition. If you dislike or even hate musicals, this movie might change your mind. 
  In this film, where the world is inhabited by people who break out in song during traffic jams, we get two souls who fall for each other. Mia Dolan (Emma Stone) and Sebastian Wilder (Ryan Gosling.)  We see them fall for each other and embrace the beginning of their blossoming romance. Not just their love we witness but we see how they struggle with their ambitions and dreams. 
  This is Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone's third film together after "Crazy, Stupid, Love (2011)", and "Gangster Squad (2013)."  They had time to grow together and create great chemistry. This movie is shows how comfortable they are with each other and how exciting they both can be. Gosling's character is a pianist who has an obvious love for jazz,  while Stone's character is a simple barista who dreams of being an actress. They both start at the bottom and we see them grow together. They have many hilarious, fun, and sometimes even sad moments. They are a match made in movie heaven and are amazing in every scene. 
  The director is Damien Chazelle, who brought us the very intense movie "Whiplash (2014)." He clearly has a love for music and wants to express it in every way that he can. The direction is phenomenally executed. He uses lengthy scenes that transition into dreamlike sequences leaving us (and by us I mean me) in awe. The cinematography also changes up from time to time and keeps each scene fresh and exciting. The dance choreography is perfectly executed and brings every sense of the word "fun" to the screen. Then we have Justin Hurwitz 's music which he clearly put a lot of heart and dedication into. The songs are very memorable, in fact, I was humming one of the songs on the way out of the theater. It's not just all singing either, we also get some great instrumental music as well as Jazz that help add on to this movie's brilliance.  
  Another thing that I really enjoyed about this film was its message of dreams and the struggles to get there. We observe two lovers who try hard to make their dreams come true. Even when thing's get difficult and sacrifices need to be made. Never settle and never give up on a life you imagine. It's very good at mixing the art of music with the ambitions it's trying to convey. 
  So as I said before, if you don't like musical's this movie might change your mind. There is powerful performances, great direction, hilarious moments, gorgeous visuals, excellent dancing, and catchy songs all leading to a bittersweet ending. It's got the heart of classy 1960' musical while still being a fresh and original film. I highly recommend this, its great fun and breathes new life into a dying genre.
Excellent movie, amazing acting and cinematography.

One of the best movies I've seen in the last five years. I watched this with my wife at an advanced screening. A masterpiece by the director, beautifully unforced musical, mixed with reality. Exceptional music. Strong chemistry, Emma stone deserves an Oscar. I want to catch it again in the theatre when it comes out. I don't write reviews!

It was pretty good, but I'm not sure that I found it AS GOOD as the hype is making it sound. It felt very old timey, like a movie from the past, which was neat. Especially since it was set in present day. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone were good (as usual). I thought that their dancing was fine but that their singing could have been better.
Way overrated. Mediocre at best

As musicals go it was OK.  The singing and dancing other than the opening sequence with people dancing on the freeway during a traffic jam was just adequate.  Neither of the leads had a voice to write home about and their dancing was just marginal as well.  Fred and Ginger they definitely were not.
I am not surprised that it will be the darling of the award season because it celebrates Hollywood as the place where dreams come true.  Unfortunately the story is pretty marginal: girl flips off boy, boy runs into girl, girl and boy meet at a party and start a romance, boy finds success playing in a band, girl thinks he has sold out, she finds success and they end up apart.
I have seen worse movies.  I have seen better movies.  I wouldn't have paid to see it but I can think of a worse way to spend a couple of hours.

Cinema has been in quite the reflective state in recent times. On a large commercial scale, J.J. Abrams intentionally made 2015s Star Wars: The Force Awakens to channel and homage the films of the late 70s and early 80s, Quentin Tarantino had done a similar venture to create the epic nature and scope of Spaghetti Westerns of the 60s with his masterclass The Hateful Eight of the same year and going a little further back Michel Hazanavicius recreated a silent picture of the 20s with 2011s impressive The Artist. Similar to those landmark treats, Damien Chazelle's excellent 2016 musical opus La La Land is a magical time capsule that transports us to the Golden Age of Hollywood moviemaking while completely modernizing it all at the same time. Written by Chazelle and with music by Justin Hurwitz (who will win an Oscar), the pair have completely interwoven original elements so well that it will become difficult to think of a time when the track "City of Stars" didn't exist. Told visually through excellent cinematography (which Linus Sandgren should win an Oscar for), amazing choreography, great costumes (which is Oscar material) amazing editing (Tim Cross, who won an Oscar with Chazelle's 2014 Whiplash, looks to win another), La La Land is a treat on a superficial level but hidden behind all those bells and whistles is a simple story. The plot is very minimalist-about how a striving actress (played by the bright eyed Emma Stone) and a striving jazz musician (played by the cool Ryan Gosling) find romance in the City of Angels-but there is no fault in the minimalist approach because the focus that Chazelle brings in really fleshing out the entirety of the film is exceptional and he achieves in arguably the most difficult aspect of these types of pictures by truly making us care for the two leads. With homages ranging from Frank Capra's 1934 chemistry-laden It Happened One Night to Vincente Minnelli's extravagant 1951 An American in Paris to Gene Kelly and Stanley Donen's witty 1952 Singin' in the Rain all the way to the colorful and melodramatic Jacques Demy 1964 classic The Umbrellas of Cherbourg (this one shares the most similarity), Chazelle has created a film that is aware of its predecessors and lovingly acknowledges them, while doing the unthinkable and achieves to tap dance toe to toe with them. This film has the Technicolor wattage to shine brightest in 2016 and backs it up with grounded humor, fine performances and dramatic handling of the material that never feels heavy handed. La La Land is an experience that embraces the romance of the past, embraces the love of the movies and embraces the power of achieving your dreams-cementing it as a modern classic.

To start with, let me state my bias. 2014 was a great year for film. In particular, there was one film that stood out to me far above the rest: Whiplash. That year, though, Birdman was chosen by the Academy as the best picture of the year, and understandably so. However, Whiplash should have won every award it was nominated for. I cannot heap any more praise than I already have upon it and it really put Damien Chazelle on the map in a tremendous way. Earlier this year he wrote 10 Cloverfield Lane, which is again, one of my favorites for the year. Now with La La Land, he's three for three.
     La La Land starts out with a beautifully shot and choreographed, over the top musical number clearly reminiscent of the heyday of the Hollywood musical. What put this scene apart from other musicals, though, was his technique and attention to color. They're small things that are used so effectively that the audience might not even pick up on what is happening and the work and attention to detail that is put into the opening. Like Birdman, it's done as a tracking shot, being shot and cut as to appear as one continuous, fluid motion of camera. The use of this camera technique is repeated a few times throughout, so the opening is a fantastic way to introduce the audience to Chazelle's cinematic aptitude. The second aspect of the opening number is the attention to color. Every member of the chorus has their own color, vibrantly differentiating one from another, yet they never seem unrealistic or out of place. It brings to mind Zhang Yimou's 2002 epic "Hero", which is criminally underrated. In "Hero", Yimou uses color not for ascetic, but for character, each scene and situation identifying itself not just by the events and narrative structure, but also their individual beauty. Chazelle does something similar with color in that the costumes chosen for each individual character aren't there just to have pretty clothes illuminating the wearer, but to paint the characters themselves. All of this is done in just the first ten minutes or so, and it doesn't let up.
     In Birdman, Alejandro Gonzales Innaritu brought Emma Stone's best out of her, and she received the honor of being nominated for Best Supporting Actor for her hard work. This year, though, she's going all the way to the top and will take the golden statue for Best Actress, guaranteed. She reaches a peak near the climax that is reminiscent of Anne Hathaway's Fantine in "Les Miserables", where the entire focus is on her, nothing else, and she conveys such crushing emotion that those who are unmoved by her performance are clearly heartless people. In contrast to Les Miserables, though, Chazelle uses this particular scene far more effectively than Tom Hooper. My largest complaint of Les Miserables, whether the film or the stage production, is that while there are some great high points throughout, the emotional peak is fairly early on at Fantine's "I Dreamed a Dream". La La Land, though, doesn't have this problem. It's paced and structured so masterfully that the action and emotion climbs from scene to scene, act to act, so it keeps hitting a new high point over and over again until, in the classic narrative fashion, until the climax comes to a head and everything crashes down in a beautiful conclusion.
     When it comes to what he's written and directed, Damien Chazelle is two for two and well on his way to being one of the top writers and directors of this generation. Moving into awards season, this is what La La Land is going to win for Best: Picture, Director, Actress, Original Screenplay, Original Score, Original Song (either for "City of Stars (Reprise)" or "Audition (The Fools Who Dream)"), Production Design, Cinematography, Costume Design, and Film Editing, with possible nominations also for Best Actor and Makeup and Hairstyling. Basically, it's going to sweep this year's Academy Awards.
4.5/5
P.S.
I want to give this one a 5/5, but that's a rating I never give and hold at a very high regard, so I'm going to watch it at least once more in the theater to see if it still holds up and can push it into that realm.

Damien Chazelle, fresh off his critical hit "Whiplash" (a movie I loved by the way), has gone full blown old school big budget Hollywood musical...and it is highly entertaining. It's got bold colors, great music, Hollywood stars in with that classic charm, great cinematography...it is exactly what you want in a throwback Hollywood musical fused with a little bit of modern sensibilities.  Chazelle is definitely one of the finest young directors in Hollywood today.  This is classic escapism with good songs and romance.

3.5/5
