It is a musical movie and has a lot of songs and singing so if you don't like this kind of movie, dont watch it. The first 1/3 is choppy and clunky but the rest is very good. Frankly, that's the part which had least singing and much more score.

We are currently in an era of reinterpreting and rebooting old content, there hasn't been much freshness in films for a long time. Films has been around long enough to have explored so many stories and techniques, and film audiences have seen more films than ever that it's hard to come up with something that can leave an impression that lingers for days after watching. Having seen and loved Whiplash, I was really looking forward to Damien Chazelle's next film. The fact that it would be a musical with Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone just made me super impatient to watch it. Oh I also love jazz so that just made it pretty much perfect. Expectations were sky high from this team and boy did they meet them. I'm happy to say, I was far from disappointed. Here director Chazelle has made an irresistible musical comedy-drama that serves up a real delight for the eyes and ears. If you haven't heard of this film yet (where have you been?), I'm sure you will do in the coming months. From the films incredibly choreographed opening scene, the film becomes an eye catching, toe-tapping and most importantly of all joyous film going experience and the film transforms a story that at its core is rather generic into something else entirely, that will very likely place this one into the top echelon of cinematic musicals, as well as a classic of our time. Tonally, this film was very different from Whiplash, (one was an intense and dark psychological thriller whereas this was a brilliant, comedic, and emotional romance) but Chazelle's style can still be seen in this film. This film not only leaves a lingering impression, but it also gives you a feeling that you're watching something that will be talked about for a long time. Sure, the film does take notes from the past, however, rather than rehashing another predictable, well-known story, it tells a honest story, which, when combined with the near-obsolete genre of jazz musical, has a lovely effect and is so fresh from what you seem today that it seems strangely, new. This is also attributed to the beautiful use of color and visuals, smooth, old-style camera-work, unexpected plot/editing, and just the right amount of special effects to make it special. The story follows a jazz pianist Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) and a waitress Mia (Emma Stone), who aims to break into the showbiz in the City of Angels, without ever compromising its realistic spin. While, Mia is an aspiring actress who keeps struggling from one audition to the next, her daytime job is working at a coffee shop in a studio lot where she can be near her dream, Sebastian is a dedicated jazz musician struggling to make ends meet, dreaming of someday running his own jazz club. Mia and Sebastian meet and fall for each other, but they live in a city known for crushing hopes and breaking hearts. Together they continue to explore the joy and pain of pursuing their dreams. The most impressive thing about the film, for me, is just how daringly it dances between the old-fashioned "Singing' In The Rain" style of musical, and a bolder, modern style. The song numbers are great  and are an undoubted homage to classic musicals - a thoughtful mixture of old school dance numbers you'd expect from a musical in the 50s, and emotionally-wrenching ballads that hit you where it hurts; there is one particular sequence toward the end of the film which is a real gut-punch. Here, Damien Chazelle has found a way to reignite the general love for Los Angeles the way "Rebel Without a Cause" did decades ago, in fact, much of the film is more or less of an homage to that James Dean classic. The colors, the look, the design, the tone, even though it's set in present day, the characters could've easily been transported from a golden age era. Fully embracing the widescreen splendor, the film's winning opening gambit is a slithering singing- and-dancing sequence on the chockablock freeway choreographed in one dashing long shot. Then the film pans out its narration of an ever-typical girl-meet-boy story (in this case, it is the girl who makes the first move), divided by seasons with a winter-to-winter rotation, initially, the story bifurcates in two different forks until the two finally hit the ground running, interposed with scintillating music numbers which can hypnotically melt your heart and dazzle your mind. Chazelle adroitly centers on two protagonists through and through like in those vintage romantic flicks where you can see haloes around them, anyone, anything else in their world has all duly faded into the dark background whenever their eyes meet, their hands touch, and they kiss. Neither life nor love goes smoothly for this pair of stubborn dreamers, but they sure do try hard at both. Mia continues working as a barista on the Warner Bros. studio lot and going to frustrating audition after frustrating audition. Eventually, she decides that her best way forward is to write, finance and produce a one-woman show which, fittingly, focuses on her experiences of leaving her hometown in Nevada and moving to L.A. to pursue her dreams. After dropping the humorously humiliating job where Mia sees him at their third encounter, Sebastian continues to hold fast to his dream of opening his own jazz club, but doesn't really do much about it. He reluctantly takes a job on keys in a music group run by an old acquaintance (John Legend), but doesn't enjoy it because they don't play his style of pure jazz. Sebastian's unhappiness turns to resentment and ends up being directed toward Mia, just as her show is about to open. The eventual resolution of their love story and their individual pursuit of their dreams feels right for a film which celebrates dreamers, but shows what happens when life doesn't go as we've planned. The lead characters may be struggling in certain fields but it is their dreams they are chasing at the end of the day. Something we all have done or are in the process of doing. This makes you quickly feel like you know these people and what they're going through. Throw in some comedy, love, drama and magical soundtracks as well as sequences and you have yourself a masterpiece. Alongside DOP Linus Sandgren (whose work here may well lead to a hefty individual awards haul this season), and genuinely the whole team behind this production, Chazelle has crafted up that rare film beast, a unique tapestry of brilliance that practically bounces along frame to frame and is matched majestically by its two leads, who in turn give us a duo of characters we are unlikely to forget anytime soon. What also helps is a beautiful score and extremely well written songs. I found myself humming "City of Stars" all night long, already saving the soundtrack on every music platform I could. The music and dance numbers are a perfect blend of Gene Kelly musicals and more contemporary stuff like Chicago. The production design helps with this with bright, vivid colors abound from the walls of a passing building to Emma Stone's dress. However, the film does have one flaw - the absence of conflict. Conflict is necessary in any film and with romantic films, the conflict is usually somewhere out of left field and is usually the low point. This film, despite everything else, is no different. The problem is, why we are made aware of what may have caused the major rift, but there is no exact detail. Did they grow apart, did their careers just consume so much of their time they broke up and decided to become friends? Friends which kept aware of what the other was doing but didn't have much communication, this isn't answered. We are just teased with a possible way the film could end which for some maybe unrealistic. Tasked with not only reigniting the chemistry they shared in the likable 2011 romantic comedy Crazy Stupid Love and the 2013 Gangster Squad but pulling off the unenviable task of singing and dancing their way into the filmgoers hearts, Emma Stone as the big dreaming wannabe actress Mia and Ryan Gosling as jazz loving hard-done-by musician Sebastian make for a lovable on screen duo whose relationship together is all at once alluring, believable and at times heartbreaking. Ryan Gosling and especially Emma Stone were absolutely astounding. Both of the stars were able to authentically portray such a vast range of emotion as well as deliver great musical performances. The chemistry between the two actors was great. Gosling and Stone were able to believably play off of one another and it made for an entertaining and emotionally engaging relationship to watch unfold. In smaller roles, John Legend & J.K. Simmons are likable.  On the whole, 'La La Land' is amazing, alluring, magnificent, and emotional making for an unforgettable cinematic experience.

The essence of cinema that brings a twinkle back to Tinseltown. A fanciful film reduction, if you will. Music and dance empathetic to the new generation of foolish dreamers who will one day become the movers and shakers.
Easily one of the best films of the decade.
Delightful musical, most enjoyable.
It was good, but not as good as I expected. Stone & Gossling have great chemistry though.

Not always an enthusiastic fan of watching musicals on the big-screen, my apprehension only heightened during the opening dance number of this sure-fire hit. It wasn't until Emma Stone's wishful actress persona--the distracted barista Mia Dolan--raised her middle finger to Ryan Gosling's impatient, cocksure alter ego musician Sebastian in L.A. rush hour traffic that "La La Land" really began its powerhouse production sequence.  Thereafter, the year's most romantic and formidable twosome square off using singing jujitsu and snickering one-liners to launch an enthralling love story within the City of Stars.
As two dreamers caught in the painful budding entertainment world of setbacks and rejections, Gosling and Stone each become the other's biggest cheerleader and encouraging voice of reason. Gosling's jazz loving pianist role affords us the delightful opportunity to see the 36-year old actor actually play the piano on film, highlighted through sensational cinematography not seen to this level of excellence since 2014's Academy Award-winning "Birdman".

A twenty-eight-year-old native of Scottsdale, AZ, Emma Stone's incredible acting genius is only getting better with time. Her remarkable job as a recovering drug addict in "Birdman" garnered Stone an Oscar-nom for Best Supporting Actress.  As a testament to how good she's become as an artist, we're transfixed on Stone's passionate auditions in pursuit of an acting gig in "La La Land".  Equal parts endearing, funny and quirky, Stone seals up her Oscar gold in this compelling and career performance.
Working together on their third movie, Gosling and Stone share an on-screen chemistry that only comes around once every ten years!  The pair's contemporary song and dance routines rival the film industry's original musical mold of 1930's stars Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers.  We've seen Tom Hanks' slow-burn romance with Meg Ryan defeat sleeplessness in Seattle. And we've watched Leonardo DiCaprio chase Kate Winslet around deck chairs aboard the sinking "Titanic".  And now we've got Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone in "La La Land", once again showing us how love starts and where it may go.

Between the fabulous acting, eye-popping cinematography, jarring edits, and ear-pleasing music score, "La La Land" is the easy front-runner to win this year's best picture award--amongst a laundry list of other nominations I am sure.  This romantic musical drama immediately rises to Classic status.  It's a charming love story and marvelous film production that can, and will, withstand the test of time a la Astaire & Rogers.  A musical has "never shined so brightly" for "The Fools Who Dream".  A+!!!

Grade: A+

One of the biggest wastes of time ever in a film.  Nicely photographed, likable actors, but a bore.  This 70-year-old loves film as well as musicals, but this is nearly a complete miss.

5 Stars. A surprising sincere ode to old Hollywood, while at the same time having a great central romance that works wonders. There's issues with it but it's such a beautiful, and at times, bold movie that I couldn't give it any less. I'll actually be surprised if this doesn't take it all come Oscar's. I believe and wholeheartedly think Moonlight deserves it and is the better and more important film, but this was everything the academy looks for and it's actually good.

This of course gets a ratings bump due to it being a musical, and the fearlessness it approaches it.  I'm like most Angelenos, I have a begrudging relationship with my city.  However, when it's portrayed this lovingly, I eat it up.

Ryan Gosling is wonderful, and Emma Stone warms up pretty quickly.

What I liked about this movie was that it could have fallen into cliche very easily. What made this movie refreshing was that it had an edge to it. It acknowledged that love can be fleeting and yet something that moves us. Its dreamy, romantic quality is something we all aspire to and something we don't always get in life. That to me is the true allure of this movie -- that it portrays the interplay between dreams and reality so gracefully and yet so poignantly.

LA LA LAND - 5 stars (out of 5 stars)
In an era of emotion-free autotune, humiliating TV talent contests and cynically constructed boy bands there would seem to be no place for a good old-fashioned song and dance extravaganza.
Yet "Whiplash" director Damien Chazelle begs to differ.
Abstaining from any CGI trickery or insincere power ballads, he delivers a euphorically pure shot of undiluted joyousness, an irony-free tonic that doesn't just lift the spirits but sends them soaring heaven-wards.
It's all about a boy and a girl. Both are appealing. Both are eccentric.
Ryan Gosling is Seb, a jazz pianist whose purist leanings and ambition to open his own club are hampered by an indifferent world, particularly the chicken-in-a-basket crowd who patronise the supper club where he's the resident entertainment.
Emma Stone is Mia, a silver screen-obsessed wannabe actress and writer who constantly skips off shifts as a barista on the Warner Bros studio lot to attend auditions which usually end in disappointment.
They first meet in a traffic jam on a sun-kissed, present day Los Angeles freeway...but the focus here is a sensational one-shot dance routine where the traffic-jammed commuters jump out of their vehicles and do the show right there.
A few tentative steps later they re-connect at a Hollywood party (he's playing jazz synthesizer in an appalling covers band) and the sparks begin to fly, particularly after a one-take entrancing set-piece above the glinting lights of downtown LA. It could be 1950 if we didn't know better.
Their sunny romance quickly goes into overdrive...but there are stress points. He joins a successful but punishingly hard-touring band while she struggles to reverse her thwarted ambitions as a playwright and Actress. Their lofty Old Hollywood ambitions threaten to come between them.
Despite the song and dance focus of the film, its heartwarming success is ultimately down to the constantly sparking chemistry between Stone and Gosling. They are also surprisingly gifted dancers and singers and their heart-on-the-sleeve vulnerability lends real authenticity to their faltering romance.
Emma Stone plays a convincingly strong single women whose underlying vulnerabilities come out at times only to be pushed back down by her dream of life. Her Oscar-nominated work in "Birdman" was striking, yet she has never been better and deserves the many awards she is receiving for her performance in this film.
Nominated previously for an Oscar (for "Half Nelson"), Ryan Gosling Seb is a charming, eccentric guy who finds romance with jazz and his musical dreams at odds with his romance with Mia. He's a very well-written character played to perfection by Gosling. Without these performances and the chemistry between Gosling and Stone "La La Land" would have fallen flat. While surrounded by a cast which includes J.K. Simmons and John Legend the film doesn't give its supporting characters back stories nor plots...the film belongs to Gosling and Stone alone.
The authenticity of the "old style musical" is brought to vivid life by beautifully designed costumes and production design filmed in authentic Cinemascope. It's a treat to the eyes and ears.
Both the score and songs are presented in unmitigated, true original glory. And the choreography is immaculate.
The sweet romance peppered by bittersweet honesty is undoubtedly one of the best of 2016, if not the very best.
Sweet-natured in a time of often cynicism, this buoyantly uplifting fable sets the soul soaring and the heart beating.
Dance to its tune.
full of emotions and very stylized story told about LA and dreams.

I can't belive that I actually watched this, and, totally enjoyed it 

Definitely, a very captivating performance from Emma Stone.

Well crafted and beautifully executed classic Hollywood musical. I'm not one for musicals but Chazelle achieves a grandiose sense of joy that's hard to deny while the two leads sparkle with chemistry. The film is basically a more Oscar-friendly version of Whiplash and you can practically imagine the clips that will be used in Oscar montages in years to come. It's light and fluffy and while it's nowhere near the best film of the year, Hollywood loves movies about itself and this will surely win Best Picture, which is fine by me.

Pese a los comentarios pesimistas, el género musical no ha muerto y se resiste a morir.  Como prueba de ello están "Chicago", "Moulin Rouge" y "Les Misérables", cintas tan grandes como arriesgadas.
Aunque "La La Land", la película del prodigioso director Damien Chazelle (autor de la grandilocuente "Whiplash"), da inicio con el logo de Cinemascope, esta pertenece al grupo de musicales pequeños y delicados, tipo "Once" o "God Help The Girl".  Y esto no tiene nada de malo. 
Los que esperen un musical gigantesco y extraordinario como los de la Era Dorada de Hollywood ("Singin' In The Rain", "Swing Time", "An American In Paris", "The Band Wagon"), se encontrarán en cambio con una triste historia de amor, protagonizada por Ryan Gosling y Emma Stone, quienes dan lo mejor de sí interpretando a dos jóvenes en busca de hacer realidad sus respectivos sueños (tener un bar de Jazz y ser una actriz famosa). 
Gosling y Stone no son grandes cantantes ni tampoco grandes bailarines, pero logran capturar la magia del amor en la pantalla. Aquellos que tenemos metidos los grandes musicales de Hollywood en la médula espinal, percibimos a "La La Land" como un musical bello pero menor. Sin embargo, no cabe duda que esta es una gran película que posiblemente estará nominada como Mejor Película a los Premios Oscar y puede que se robe la estatuilla.

Pese a los comentarios pesimistas, el género musical no ha muerto y se resiste a morir.  Como prueba de ello están "Chicago", "Moulin Rouge" y "Les Misérables", cintas tan grandes como arriesgadas.
Aunque "La La Land", la película del prodigioso director Damien Chazelle (autor de la grandilocuente "Whiplash"), da inicio con el logo de Cinemascope, esta pertenece al grupo de musicales pequeños y delicados, tipo "Once" o "God Help The Girl".  Y esto no tiene nada de malo. 
Los que esperen un musical gigantesco y extraordinario como los de la Era Dorada de Hollywood ("Singin' In The Rain", "Swing Time", "An American In Paris", "The Band Wagon"), se encontrarán en cambio con una triste historia de amor, protagonizada por Ryan Gosling y Emma Stone, quienes dan lo mejor de sí interpretando a dos jóvenes en busca de hacer realidad sus respectivos sueños (tener un bar de Jazz y ser una actriz famosa). 
Gosling y Stone no son grandes cantantes ni tampoco grandes bailarines, pero logran capturar la magia del amor en la pantalla. Aquellos que tenemos metidos los grandes musicales de Hollywood en la médula espinal, percibimos a "La La Land" como un musical bello pero menor. Sin embargo, no cabe duda que esta es una gran película que posiblemente estará nominada como Mejor Película a los Premios Oscar y puede que se robe la estatuilla.
Dazzling and moving with the right amount of melancholy - it is a movie you don't want to miss.
Best of the year. very fun. Ryan and Emma are amazing.

First let me say that Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling were delightful and the music was engaging. But even this triple bounty of talent couldn't save La La Land from its own identity crisis. The movie couldn't decide if it were an homage to the great Hollywood musicals of the 50's or a parody of the French New Wave. The production designer didn't know what decade to reference so the film clumsily smithed together a pastiche of styles from the 40's through the present, which didn't make sense. The write/director vacillated between presenting a light hearted romantic musical where "they all live happily ever after" or if the film were a serious drama - so he turned it into neither. Beginning with an overly ambitious opening dance scene on a congested LA freeway, which looked blown out and poorly shot you will be disappointed. My advice is to wait until it comes to cable so when you get bored you can get yourself a snack and not miss much.
Awesome movie and I'm not even a fan of musical movies.

Unless there's a mermaid, lion, beast or bear involved, I loathe musicals.  I hate how people sing and dance out of context when you could just as easily speak. So I went into this movie just expecting to enjoy the setting, filming locations and Ryan Gosling, and rolling my eyes at the song and dance numbers. Instead, I came out loving the filmmaking, cinematography, the charisma of the actors, the plot and, yes, even the songs. It's a tribute to Los Angeles and to film, and this musical-hater loved this musical.
Chazelle's strong direction coupled with powerful performances from Stone and Gosling help to create a wonderful and nostalgic treat at the cinema.

From beginning to end, La La Land delivers a masterful experience with the right mix of humor, drama and visuals. This exceptional movie has artistic performances from Gosling and Stone.

La La Land stands out the most from other romantic films i've seen in this decade with stunning filmmaking and deep writing which made this one of the best experiences this year.

The presentation of La La Land excels and offers a great experience for everyone who goes see it, you can relate to the vivid characters and eccentric dialogue that Damien Chazelle has put down.

With lovable and funny characters, La La Land might just be one of the best films this year and maybe, the best romance film i've seen in years.

La La Land gets a 9 out of 9
A beautiful take on the ordinary - through the lens of a melancholy heart

An instant classic! The filmmakers get the most out of the medium, and it looks spectacular on the big screen. Pure musical enthusiasts may have issues with the leads at times, but it's a movie musical (not a musical).
The score. The colors. The two of them together. The fucking finale? Yes. 100 times yes. Going again for sure.

A big colorful, beautiful optimistic film.  From the big opening until the song "Audition" every dance number exudes joy and will make you want to join in with the people up on the screen.  With "Audition", Emma Stone, as Mia, brings the movie into different territory and breaks your heart.  This movie is so much fun, but also enters deeper territory which left me with a profound sense of sadness and melancholy that I have yet to shake, although I saw it 2 days ago.  I am sure my failure to chase the dream was one reason I was so moved by it.  However, I was also moved by the reality that chasing the dream means compromise and conflict and, although this is a movie, it maintains that sense of reality.  It does not ignore the What Ifs that accompany real life.  Emma Stone, as aspiring actress Mia, gives an incredible performance.  She defines the lyrics from the song "With One Look" from Sunset Boulevard (not including the bits alluding to the aged out actress).  Stone need not even say a word, with just a look she can break your heart, she can make you smile, she owns the screen - as unassuming and sweet as she is, she is magical.  Ryan Gosling, as aspiring jazz musician/club owner, Seb, can be a little harder to love sometimes, not because of Gosling, but b/c the character is more complex.  Difficult at times, very stubborn, yet then so darn charming.  

The dance number featured on the poster between Stone and Gosling is so much fun.  Great style and made me wish I was up there dancing with them.  

The costume design is excellent.  Along with the choreography and music, the costumes have a timelessness to them.  La La Land is set in the present day, but its style is classic. 

The song "Audition" is just stunning.  Everything about that scene is heartbreaking and perfect.  Although Stone is no belter, her voice is perfect for this piece.  Everything in this movie is so natural, Stone's singing voice is lovely and fits her character perfectly.  The singing and dancing seem to flow organically out of the plot.  There are many, many aspects of this film that are just superior, in particular Emma Stone, the direction, the costuming, and the song "Audition".  I hope members of the Academy take note.  "Here's to the ones who dream; Foolish, as they may seem; Here's to the hearts that break; Here's to the mess we make."

La La Land is a terrific movie--one that stuck with me overnight and had me thinking the next morning. Like Damien Chazelle's last movie, the criminally underseen Whiplash, La La Land evokes strong emotions.

In some respects, this is an old-fashioned movie musical set in a vaguely contemporary LA (with some hints at Hollywood's glamorous past), but whereas the relationships in old musicals often served the music, in this case, the relationship feels wholly authentic, and the music serves it. This is a romance, but a real one that struggles between complex people with different lives and goals.

La La Land reminded me in many ways of the movie Once in the way it weaves together music with a truly honest human relationship. It's like a Disney movie that brings two people together through song and dance but then continues to follow them as they figure out what their relationship means and if it can fit into their lives.

The energy between Stone and Gosling, so obvious in Crazy, Stupid, Love, is put to terrific use in La La Land. Stone didn't even need to say a word--you could just feel every emotion, both joyous and sad, through those eyes. And Gosling plays a man at battle with himself over his passion and his poverty with intensity. As a former part-time jazz musician myself, his character's inner struggles felt real. 

Lastly, I just have to comment on how lovely the movie is. Somehow Chazelle manages to make the movie seem utterly realistic on the streets of Los Angeles while at the same time giving it a healthy dollop of theatrical fantasy. Much of the film is shot in spectacularly complex tracking shots in real LA locations (including one song-and-dance number that involved a hundred dancers on a closed section of the 105-110 interchange), giving it a handheld and raw feel but also pulling the viewer into the scene.

I hate to oversell movies, but this was clearly the best film I've seen this year (but I haven't seen all the great films yet, including Nocturnal Animals and Moonlight.) Chazelle has a way of making performing music an intense part of his stories--Whiplash's breathtaking drum solo climax plays out the relationship of two adversaries and La La Land's climax has lovers' hopes, wishes, and regrets played out on the piano (and on Stone's and Gosling's faces). The director is only 31 years old, and I can't wait to see what he does next.

This isn't L.A. this is La La Land

Primary colors and theatrical song spill over each consecutive frame onto this dreamlike story. Similar to great Broadway plays, Old Hollywood classics, and legends of Jazz, La La Land presents a fantastic ideal that simultaneously connects to the audience as they experience it, an ideal that lingers. If you catch yourself whistling Mia & Sebastian's Theme after you see the movie I'm right. 

The movie reminds me of the power of film, unlike narrative, song, dance, or other arts alone, there's a special something that can only be expressed when cinema elements come together, an experience different from the sum of its parts. 

Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone both encapsulate, almost stoically, the roles of the aspiring jazz musician and actress. But the chemistry between them, that we have seen before, breathes refreshing life to a familiar love story. Their chemistry's theatrical dynamic delivers a fantasy you might not believe in, but would want to, like a lie that tells the truth more honestly than reality. Their fantasy leads to the realization of both of their dreams, a bittersweet success that reaffirms time and space, to be the most painful and truest evils to love. 

The denouement scene where the entire story is rewritten with regret explosively concludes where the opening musical number begins, and Damien Chazelle should receive another standing ovation for his direction of a story that revolves around the axis of music, resulting in a profound thematic expression.
Oh. My. Goodness.  Such a breath of fresh air, I'm in love.

Technically, the film is beautifully filmed. There are certain shots that are just excellent. Overall, this film deserves all of the Oscar buzz it is getting. It is original and refreshing. In Damien Chazelle's nostalgic, emotional rollercoaster of sound and color, two curves converge, that of the old and that of the new. La La Land is undoubtedly a love letter to classic Hollywood in its approach and gusto, but not once loses sight of modern sensibilities, aptly morphing the sweet and the sour, the passion and the heartbreak. It's perhaps in its rigorous balance that the film shines, and yet it's never as powerful as when it gives in to chaos, for that's when we are truly immersed in the city of stars. Inspiring and soul crushing in equal measure, this musical showcases two essential truths. One, there is still room in cinema to sell dreams, just like Hollywood used to; two, Chazelle's directorial vision showcases a premature mastery of the craft. The musical numbers are exquisitely executed and blend in the narrative without the often awkward transitions so common in the genre. Not only that but there's a sense of control, a tight grip Chazelle holds over the narrative, jumping from the upbeat celebration of life to the intense reality of broken dreams without missing a beat. In many ways, he brings to the film the passion he sells, which much like jazz is a fierce competition for a grand emotion. And La La Land has it. It has it all.

I had such high hopes for this movie. I tried for weeks to get my tickets for the premiere at AFI Fest. I finally got them and was so excited. I waited in line for over 7 hours to get in. Let me say first and foremost I am a huge musical fan. Gene Kelly and Fred Astaire are among my idols. I have to say I was uncomfortable from the beginning scenes. This is supposed to be an homage to musicals and Los Angeles itself. The longer I watched the more I saw it as not so original as there were ripoffs of many old musicals. There were pieces of An American in Paris, Singing in the Rain, Funny Face and more. I have nothing bad to say about the acting as I think both stars did the best they could with what they had to work with. They are not singers or dancers but with choreography that was so very boring they really didn't have to try very hard. The movie was beautifully shot with many iconic locations. I only wish it was something more original and not falling on so many timeless and much better movies.

This movie was a pretty big disappointment. Though technically very well done- the cinematography and music were very good- the overall story was jumbled, incoherent, and lacking. Characters showed up and left, motivations and desires were left unpacked or just completely lacking, and overall the tone flip-flopped so much that I ended up feeling very little at the end.

A likable enough musical with an updated score, good music, and a decent story line. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone make an attractive couple and of course she can really sing, but Ryan really can't. It makes for some hard to listen to duets even if the melody is good. Their respective stories are also interesting as they fall in love, then fight, but it is only a 3 star movie when all is said and done. Unlike the 2014 Into The Woods where every song was a knockout, and ever actor could REALLY sing, and the Stephen Sondheim's lyrics were magical, La La Land pales in comparison. So, if you want to wait for it to come to DVD, you won't miss a lot. But if you want to see a musical for Christmas, you really can't go wrong.

Like your "mildly" racist uncle rambling drunkenly at Christmas dinner, La La Land - particularly its characters - seem to think that anything which is older is better. For people who would not have had a great existence in times past (read: anyone not beautiful and white) that really rings false. And it feels like this movie almost intentionally stamps on the toes of this idea with a scene where Gosling and Stone are the white saviors of jazz at an all-black jazz club.
Let's talk about the love story, too. In what way is it an interplay, or equal or supportive? Frankly Emma Stone's character is basically evil

The dinner is served, girls and boys! Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are here to dazzle you with this movie musical serving as ode to both 1950's musicals and screenwriter-director Damien Chazelle's love for jazz. 

The story is generic but cosy as your favorite pillow: jazz pianist boy meets waitress / aspiring actress girl and they fall in love. And then a whole bunch of people dance and sing. 

The two lovely stars are both singing and dancing themselves, doing a good job at that. Still, personally I'd have chosen an actress with stronger onscreen presence to pair up with already-legendary Gosling. But you know, whatever.

I am not actually into musicals, so for me, by far the most impressive thing about this feel-good crowdpleaser is the boss man behind the screen: Damien Chazelle. 

The dude is only nearly 32 years old but he has done three movies already, always as a director and a sole screenwriter. You know him better as the author of 2014's majestic surprise hit "Whiplash".

So... go see it. If you like musicals, you will be pleased. If you don't care about them, there's still enough feel-good stuff to enjoy the ride for 128 minutes.

If you are a fan of "Whiplash" dying to get another dose of Chazelle, then be prepared for a nice surprise in the form of certain bald guy who should have a bigger role here for sure.

Emma Stone shines in this virtuous ode to Hollywood. Cast up in droves of colourful settings and classic musical numbers, "La La Land" can sometimes appear to be more head in the clouds than grounded. But as the film smoothly inches forward, the pressing questions of reality seep between the coloured cracks and a deep, moving story is born. 
It's the kind of film that takes the gray palette you've been painting with and effortlessly replaces it with a wide array of new colours. And even if the colours don't last, at least the feeling does.
Having seen it 3 times, I can say with confidence that Damien Chazelle's "La La Land" is a dazzling movie experience.

"La La Land" and The Magic Of Unrequited Love 
Love, as most people would agree, is an emotion spurred by fortuity, driven by desire and strengthened by longing. However, there are only two ways the journey of love can end. Either at a crossroads which leads two people down an unknown path together or propels them on different journeys altogether. Blessed are those that find the former for there's a side to love that tugs at your soul if you go down the latter. It doesn't leave you, follows you like an iota of your shadow and often drives you towards the realization of your better self. This last facet is what many a cinematic journeys have tried to explore over years. "La La Land" tries to do the same. It however succeeds on levels where others have faltered. 
Mia and Sebastian's meetings in the land of dreams, Los Angeles are owed completely to serendipity. They're chasing their dreams; she constantly auditioning for acting roles and he being a pianist, pining to own a jazz club of his own; trapped by both their circumstances or by sheer deficiency of luck, in equal measure. 
However when fate intervenes, they get together and set down the path of discovering themselves through the eyes of the other. 
That the movie is a musical, works tremendously in its favour as the melodious interludes enhance the narrative. The journey that the lead pair undertakes together is buoyed by the music which is the essence of their relationship. The accompanying visuals elevate the proceedings to a surreal level. Damien Chazelle, the director who broke out in a big way with his stupendous feature "Whiplash", dedicated the movie to old-school Hollywood fare and the relationship of Mia and Sebastian is steeped in old-world charm reminiscent of yore. The twist, in the modern setting of the story, works wonderfully when you accept that whatever is happening could only possibly happen in cinema. There is no conscious effort to project believability. This is where the heart of the movie lies. 
Emma Stone won the prize for Best Actress at the Venice Film Festival, where the film premiered, and this is, by far her best work deserving of all the laurels and accolades. Ryan Gosling gives the understated performance of the year as he respectfully surrenders to the powerhouse that is Stone. The pair that first featured in "Crazy, Stupid, Love" has an effortless chemistry that is the driving force of the feature. 
The movie does not have a perfect ending. It recaps the moments of Mia and Sebastian's lives together through a perfect kaleidoscope of images. It is sad but they have contented smiles for the delineation of their dreams and hopes for each other is fulfilled. It might break your heart, but when you think about it once you have left the cinema, you know through your ache that there could not be a better end to the story. 
Rating: 5/5

I understand that the year 2016 has been, charitably put, unkind to many people and why we all could use a little escapism around this time of year. Writer/director Damien Chazelle made a big Oscar splash with 2014's Whiplash to make his passion project, a sincere musical that recreates the style of classic Hollywood. La La Land is a stylistic throwback that has enchanted critics and seems destined to compete for some of the biggest awards this season. Just imagine how much better it would be if it was great.

Chazelle and company certainly knows how to make an impression. The opening number transforms an L.A. traffic jam into a full-blown song-and-dance explosion, with commuters exiting their cars and coalescing into a teaming mass of jubilation on the freeway. It's a moment that is sincere and full of energy and promise. The brightly colored commuters come together in long unbroken with a widescreen camera that dives and dips and leaves plenty of space for the audience to appreciate the dancing. This is a movie that wants you to see all of the rainbow-colored performers while they strut their stuff. It's here that we're introduced to Mia (Emma Stone), a part-time barista and struggling wannabe actress, and Sebastian (Ryan Gosling), a jazz musician who dreams of opening his own club at a historical site. These two dreamers resist each other but of course destiny has another plan. A highlight is a flirty sequence set atop a Hollywood Hillside overlooking the purplish dawn. Mia and Sebastian sing how beautiful this scenic view would be if only they were with someone they loved, playfully antagonizing the other into a dancer's rivalry. The dancing is mischievous and fun and performed in wide angles to soak in the movements. It's easy to get caught up in Chazelle's early swell, a transporting experience that extols the virtues of classical musicals by the likes of Vincent Minnelli, Gene Kelly, and especially Jacques Demy's The Umbrellas of Cherbourg. Chazelle fills out his frame like a painter. There's an infectious love for Old Hollywood that tries to alchemize its influences into something new and old, and for a good while Chazelle is able to maintain this fizzy, effervescent experience and remind you of the soothing joys of a good movie musical told with finesse and brio.

Then after about forty-five minutes the fizz gets a little staler and that's when I felt the gnawing emptiness underneath all the Old Hollywood homage. It reminded me of 2011's Best Picture winner, The Artist, as a movie that is more affectionate imitation than genuine substance. As I wrote in my review for The Artist: "The entire affair has such a slight feel to it; the movie is a confection, a sweet treat that melts away instantly after viewing. If you strip away all the old Hollywood nostalgia, there is very little substance here." It's all mimicry of the highest order but Chazelle hasn't put enough authentic feeling into his imitation. There's a fealty to the sources of his inspiration that Chazelle is replicating, and his screen pops with coded visual reminders (look, it's Gosling leaning off a street lamp), but it fetishizes the inspirations rather than building from them. Quentin Tarantino is transparent about his outré influences but he doesn't forget to tell an engaging story too. It's in the movie's dispiriting second half that it becomes all too clear just how little substance there is to our lovers as well as the industry satire. This is miles away from Singin' in the Rain, folks (my favorite film musical, for the record) and more the same old broadsides about the industry: they're shallow, they're inconsiderate, they swallow up the dreamers, they "celebrate everything and value nothing," as Sebastian put it. It's not like the movie is telling you anything you haven't heard before, and that's fine but it limits any impact. It also seems to exist in a universe where minorities are mere background players to prop up the dazzling lives of the beautiful white leads. Imagine the enjoyment if some of that snappy industry satire was reserved for its less progressive casting practices. Can you imagine this kind of movie starring Tessa Thompson (Creed)?

Affection can only go so far because eventually the gravity of your characters, their relationship, their goals and dreams and relatability will need to kick in, and it doesn't. I think this is because the first forty-five minutes are the typical rom-com story of the boy getting the girl. It's the portion where the movie weaves its old Hollywood spell and courts us too, and it's fun. And like bad relationships, once it has you La La Land feels like it has to do less work. Chazelle has to manufacture a series of pity problems (more below) to push his lovers apart and question whether these two star-crossed kids might make it after all. If the beginning half is the swirling romance that reverently celebrates old Hollywood, the second half is the attempt to "ground" the film in a sense of realism. It feels too late tonally to switch gears and it undercuts the first half. It might sound contradictory but if La La Land was just going to be a trifle then I wish it went all-in rather than half-heartedly trying an "edge" of harsh reality to mix the sour with the sweet. Just because the movie sets up the dreams of its characters, puts them together, and says not so fast doesn't mean that Chazelle has properly set up this nascent melancholy.

Mia and Sebastian are not particularly strong characters. The unified star power of the lead actors is enough to disguise this fact for a majority of the movie and maybe for some the entirety. They don't have anything of import to say beyond their dreams and their jobs that are presently in the way of achieving said dreams. I couldn't tell you anything else about these characters. For Mia and Sebastian, the world is divided into those who are pure and those who are impure, and the dichotomy will rankle anyone who has interacted with more than their share of hipster. Sebastian is a music snob who wants to impress upon the world the importance of jazz even as it shrugs indifferently. Nobody gets it, man. He'll fight the good fight no matter what because Sebastian's fight is Chazelle's: taking outdated material and importing value to a new generation. The characters serve the plot and exist to entwine and then be dutifully pulled apart. It's hard to invest in the characters when they won't show who they are and why they should be together. Maybe that's the point ultimately, a rich meta commentary on how attenuated the central courtships in movies themselves are, or the fleeting relationship between film and audience, or maybe I'm just hoofing as hard as the leads to insert more meaning here.

The second half paddles into what my friend Ben Bailey affectionately termed White People Problems: The Musical. I won't fully concur but the conflicts are too forced and the characters become whiney. Sebastian rejoins a pop band where he doesn't feel 100 percent creatively fulfilled because he isn't performing "true jazz." The band is also popular and this causes friction because he has "sold out" on his dream, as if toiling during for any period of time is giving up. I guess you must be single-minded or it doesn't count. Their combined egos won't allow for different variations of success. La La Land pretends to endorse the dreamers but does it really? The only dreamers who seem to count are Mia and Sebastian. What happened to Mia's lively group of roommates and friends from the beginning party? What about the nebbish screenwriter the movie mocks for an easy laugh? There are no significant supporting characters in this movie; the universe belongs to Mia and Sebastian. They're not as insufferable as the characters from Rent but it's definitely a detriment. Look at the characters in Fame, a group of hungry teenagers who came from all walks of life and circumstances to try and achieve their titular dream of stardom.

The limitations of its doe-eyed leads present some issues. Stone (Birdman) is smashing in the movie but part of that is because, aside from some song-and-dance choreography, the movie asks very little of her other than to be cute, a trait Stone has in natural abundance. There are two standout scenes for the actress. The first is an audition where pretends to be a mistress getting the "sorry, I can't do this" phone call from the man she thought had loved her. The sheer variety of emotions that Stone is so able to quickly convey on her face, in her tremulous eyes, and posture are remarkable. Of course the problem is that she's too objectively good to keep getting blithely rejected by cold-hearted casting agents. The second is a musical showcase where Stone belts out a story about how her aunt inspired her to be a thespian. Stone is effortlessly captivating but she deserves better than to be foil to a grumbly Gosling. I feel that Gosling is one of those actors who can be amazingly talented when plugged into the right role and with the right director (see: Half Nelson, The Believer, The Big Short). He has an easygoing charm that all-too easily morphs into smarm without the right guidance or motivation on his part. Sebastian feels like a scowling grump who wants to bludgeon the world with his point of view. It feels more like he's in it for submission. Gosling's performance left me wanting someone else to play his part. They were so strong on screen in Crazy, Stupid, Love but that sizzling chemistry of old is gone here. They feel inert together, amplified by Gosling's antiseptic performance. They're both rather limited singers, very thin of voice, and that does hurt a musical. The songs by composer Justin Hurwitz and lyricists Benj Pasek and Justin Paul are exceptionally milquetoast. They're all slight renditions on the same blandly pleasant tune. They evaporated from my memory by the time the end credits started rolling. Moana has nothing to fear come Oscar time from these at-best competent compositions.

If imitation is the highest form of flattery, then Chazelle's anodyne musical is brimming with appreciation and adoration for the world of classic Hollywood, and that alone will be effectively transporting for many film critics and select audiences bred on a diet of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. La La Land is an airy confection but one that dissipates all too easily after viewing thanks to the limited characters, the limited singing, the limited dancing, the limited songs, and the lack of overall substance independent from imitation. It has its lovely moments and Stone is an ingénue worth loving, though not as much her slim character, a dreamer who dreams the dreams of a dreamer. The breezy and bubbly first half doesn't really mesh with the second half. I think it's telling that Mia and Sebastian's "love theme" is a sad plaintive piano trinkle. As the characters get more sullen and sour, the fizzy fun fades away and it starts to feel like a New Year's Eve hangover that left you addled and warm but only in a vaguely ephemeral sense. If it leaves you toe tapping and giddy, I'm glad. I'm already mentally prepared for it to practically sweep the Oscars, as they do love celebrating their own importance. La La Land is a movie musical that is stuck looking backward that it loses its own footing.

There's no car chases, bombs or aliens. Maybe one or two F-Bombs. Other than that, it's just an old-fashion love story with a happy ending. How refreshing! I love "LA LA LAND!"

I went to go see an advanced screening with my fiancé and were amazed by the first musical number. It was well paced, creative and the edits were masked fairly well to create a feeling of a one-shot take.


That feeling of wonder and amazement died out around 10 minutes later.


The film focuses on two characters, Mia, an up-and-coming actress, and Sebastian, a pianist whom I only found out his name when the credits rolled. The bulk of this "musical" is dedicated to bland, generic mumblecore-esc small talk between the two characters. After about 30 minutes, you want to scream "WE GET IT, THEY'RE IN LOVE! GIVE US SOMETHING ELSE!" Because the central conflict, rather the only conflict in this drudge of a film, comes what felt like the hour mark.


However good actors Stone and Gosling might be, this movie is all about them. In fact, the movie says "why care about other people" and pushes nearly every other character aside, instead of having them boost up the main characters and make them three-dimensional characters.


"Wow, Male Protagonist's sister seems really interesting and has a great personality that compliments him." Shouldn't be followed by "I sure hope she shows up again..." because after a few scenes, if that, you will never see them again. Mia's roommates? 3 scenes I think. Ryan's sister? Again, one scene. Mia's boss? Three scenes. You might as well not even have them in this film. If this was a short film, it would've made sense, but this movie is 2 hours and 8 minutes.


Ok, there's this one scene where the two protagonists are talking about Jazz, and Ryan talks about how Jazz is about conflict and how it's dying (which is crap, by the way) and the first thing I thought was "Oh good, conflict. I would love to see that right about now." And that's the main thing. Spoilers, the conflict is he works too much so hey break up, but he believes in her so they reconcile. La-de-freakin-da. 


He wants to open a Jazz club, but can't hold a job, she wants to be an actress but no one will hire her. Those are character motivations, but the film does nothing with them.


Then she gets mad at him for getting a stable job in a band, but it's bad because he has to travel all the time and doesn't really enjoy it. It's called a job. It's how you pay rent. It's how you can put money aside for your dream of owning a club, because no one is just going to give it to you.


Heck, she finds this out in the next freaking scene but shrugs it off like nothing. What a hypocrite, and this is who the movie wants us to root for.


Even the big "climax" for Mia falls flat. She finally gets her chance to be taken seriously for an audition and her telling a story turns into a song and all I could think is "Dancer in the Dark did this better" because when they used it, there was no backing music, it was from Selma's heart and gut. It was raw. The same setup for this scene was boring at best and migraine-inducing at worst.


I feel like the saddest thing is that this could've been an interesting story. Mia doesn't like Jazz, but that's the love of Ryan's life. Don't give her a musical number until the end and make the movie about her own perspective that music should be more like, I don't know, pop or something. Use the story as a device to grow the character and the theme of music to mirror the character's growth. When she finally comes around to understanding Ryan and Jazz, that's when she nails the audition, etc, etc.


There are so many plot holes as well. Why does she keep tap shoes in her purse instead of sneakers, which would be more comfortable for walking (for that matter, why does she keep the same kind of tap shoes Ryan Gosling wears). You could shrug it off as "it's a dream/fantasy sequence" but, no. She gets in the car with them. She drives home with them. What part of a fantasy is having a guy hand you the shoes you changed out of as you leave? Also, if this is set in modern day, why wouldn't they have exchanged numbers when they made plans? Things come up and sometimes plans change. A simple "I forgot about this dinner with my bf and his brother" solves the situation. Later on, they do use cellphones, depending on your interpretation of how to use a phone.


I could go on and rant about the weird, inconsistently dilated pupils, some of the effect shots had errors, such as poor rotoscoping, unsynched lip sync, and so on. It's just baffling that this film wasn't straight-to-VHS, because it feels like a rushed film made for a quick cash-grab.


At the end of this film, there is a fantasy sequence of how everything should've gone, and as aesthetically pleasing as it is, it's a slap in the face. That's what you wanted the film to be, and now you're basically just rewatching the entire film again in a better-paced fashion.


And I get it, film should surprise you and try to be non-conventional and experimental, but this film is just way too bland to accomplish it.


The best way I can describe my frustration is he final two shot of the film. In this shot, Emma Stone shoes more emotion then the entirety of the film combined. There is so much said in one look that the previous 2 hours, 7 minutes couldn't say with words. Maybe that was the point? Even if it was, you just wasted 2 hours getting to it. Good job, you're amazing, go pat yourself on the back.


It's really hard to put an entire film on two actor's shoulders to carry for the entire movie. Even some of my favorite actors have fallen under similar weight, but, at the end of the day, even in those films, there is a method to the madness. There is meaning, you grow as a person through the trials you face. You overcome diversity and obstacles to become a better person and that's why we love movies. That's why musicals are great, they almost satirize that by pushing everything to their extremes until those emotions, those feelings are almost a parody, but, because of the suspension of disbelief, we accept them. They aren't documentaries, they're dramatizations and a bad musical doesn't understand any of that.


You look at something like All That Jazz (1978) where the thesis is that musical numbers should come during some logical extreme or fit the situation. That film actively points out that a musical number for the sake of having one is boring (during the Gideon and Jagger dance number, just look at Joe's reaction to it). Whether you believe in that or not, every motion in the choreography had a purpose. The worst thing in a musical number is for your viewer to go "and they're going to spin now. Called it." It's hackney, contrived, and dull.


I wanted to call this film "fun and mindless" I really did, but it's more like torture to get through than a good date movie. Save yourself some time and fast forward after the first three musical numbers until the end.
If you love musicals and love Jazz then you will love this movie, if not you will not like it at all

La La Land is a phenomenal entry in the Musical genre that will no doubt blow you away from the exhilarating opening number right through to the emotional and perfectly climactic finale. In the film you are guided through a modern LA following a struggling pianist Sebastian and an endlessly dedicated actress Mia, and their journey to find success in their respective dream careers. Full of constantly swinging emotions you will experience moments of happiness, sadness, and pure excitement that will take you on a rollercoaster with plenty of surprises. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are electrifying in every scene they feature and have chemistry bleeding off the screen that will have you loving both of their characters. Damien Chazelle directs this film and if you don't know who he his then you most definitely will know. He previously directed Whiplash (2015), one of the best movies of that year and shares many of the same qualities that makes this film so majestic. 

The way you are introduced to these two main characters (Sebastian and Mia) and the way you gradually learn more and more about them is handled in such an amazing manner that you quickly fall in love with them and feel as though you know both of them. Watching them interact throughout the film and go back and forth whether it was through musical numbers or just one on one dialogue scenes was so engaging and entertaining because you really care for both of them and they just have a chemistry together that you cannot look away from. The performances by Gosling and Stone are most definitely two of the best you will see this year, but Emma Stone in particular puts on a show so compelling and so emotionally powerful that if anyone manages to take the Academy Award for Best Actress from her come February i will be more than shocked. The dedication and emotion they convey through their performances adds so much to the film and compliments every other department very well. There is also a good amount of humour injected in small doses constantly throughout the film and that helped to lighten the tone when transitioning from moments that may not be so upbeat. 

As i mentioned previously, Damien Chazelle is the mastermind behind La La Land and his huge passion for music is represented vividly. The way he implements it into the film is executed with near perfection in every scene. It features as a technique used to establish a sense of tone, to evoke certain emotions and emotional transitions, and even extremely cleverly as a storytelling technique where many scenes rely on the music and visuals alone to tell the story. There are even moments where the overall tone of the film manages to shift multiple times through a single song so elegantly it was just beautiful. One cannot talk about this film without highlighting the downright flawless cinematography that only elevates your enjoyment of the film. Every shot is so intricately detailed and planned out that half the time i found myself getting lost in the stunning scenery that continued to wow me right to the very end. And it isn't just the complexity of scenes that draws your gaze, simple shots such as one involving black silhouettes gliding over a starry night sky backdrop were unbelievably beautiful. This movie i would say is worth seeing simply to admire the cinematography work and visual style on show. 

There isn't a single negative i have been able to pick out where i thought the film needed some fixing. The pacing ebbs and flows with the tones and emotions playing out in the film which is just an amazing way to emulate how certain characters are feeling at various points of the film. Genius filmmaking. I will say though that yes there is romance, there is drama, and there is humour here for you to enjoy, but this is first an foremost a Musical at its core. If you don't like musicals you will be painfully and eagerly awaiting the credits, but if you are a fan of the musical genre then holy shit, you cannot miss this film once it comes to theatres. 

9.7/10

Straight up: I'm not a Musical Guy. That said, this movie brings Singing In the Rain into the 21st century, complete with palm trees and potholed streets. Ryan and Emma dance and sing with conviction (if not the next coming of Frank Sinatra and Ella Fitzgerald), and who knew Ryan could represent on the piano? It's a love letter to Hollywood musicals that cheats with jazz on the side, and I loved the way the stars sold out to to the movie 100%. Nice little cameo from John Legend, nothing to stretch him too much here, and J.K. Simmons does J.K. Simmons things wonderfully, a sprinkle of bitters across the surface of this gimlet of a movie. This is a star vehicle if there ever was one, and you'll want to have seen it at least once when the Academy starts naming names in a few months.

So much hype behind this movie has clouded the simple fact that it isn't any good. Ryan Gosling can't hold a tune if his life depended upon it and his dancing is beyond ridiculous. I believe someone from high school choreographed this film. Also, there is absolutely zero chemistry between Gosling and Emma Stone....who at least is able to hold her own.

Save yourself 3 hours of your life and skip this film.

A simply breathtaking venture from start to finish that you'll want to see several times, 'La La Land" is about so much yet is so simple.  It's a love story and oh yes it's a musical.  The first musical in decades that is any good.  It's going to dominate awards' season and while that doesn't mean it's the best movie of the year, if this isn't in your top ten you likely went in with a bias.  This is one I thought I was going to take for the team ( i brought my better half) as I am not a Ryan Gosling fan and was apprehensive about the idea of a 2016 musical love story.  Consider me won over.  This film grabs your attention and doesn't let go until it wants to.  Emma Stone is glorious, and just about every design quality looks perfect.  Time went into this project and not a stone was left unturned.  We all deserve to watch this and enjoy it.  You can't be a fan of music and cast this aside.  While it won't be my favorite movie of the year, it certainly is up there.  Final Score 9.5/10

Just finished a screening and I can't stop thinking about it. Rarely does a film become my favorite and my choice for the Best Film of the Year but La La Land just achieved that, striking a deep, personal chord (The last time that happened was "Inside Llewyn Davis" which coincidentally was a musical of sorts too).

It brings up memories of the beautiful LA I remember interning at Warner Bros driving around with a golf cart. And being a musical theatre song-and-dance man/actor/jazz lover/filmmaker/Prius driver/dreamer this film just resonated with me moreso than I was prepared for.

I love that it highlights the loves we grow and lose as creatives trying to 'make it;' the cynical romances artists have and how dreams get altered by love. I fell in love again, and rarely does a film achieve that.

Its as if the musical genre that was so live in old hollywood never died and stayed alive and "la la land" is its natural evolution in 2016. This could have been just a throwback but its modern enough to not exist on pure nostalgia. I always give bonus points for ambition and the singing, acting, dancing, editing and cinematography are all done well, not something anyone has the guts to try these days. Many musicals have a mediocre plot that lives to serve the amazing music.  I found La La land ot have an above average story and music but neither blew me away.  Whiplash is just better.
Although visually and musically gratifying, with a captivating performance from Emma Stone, 'La La Land' lacks a certain realism in its narrative to truly inspire.

"That's LA, they worship everything and value nothing."

As a millennial in love with the past, there is a certain relatable feel to the way Ryan Gosling's character, Sebastian, describes LA's ever evolving sense of self. The city's need to move forward to newer, brighter, bigger, pictures often folds its own history into a suitcase and kicks it underneath a bed of memories, not to be seen ever again. Once in a while a weary soul, searching for something truly special, unearths these dusty and gray memories; they shine them up like new and rediscover the rich golden history of film, long thought gone. Director Damien Chazelle (Whiplash) brings the genre of the Hollywood musical back to roaring life with the colorful, bittersweet romance of La La Land. 

The story opens on a crowded highway in standstill traffic during a sunny, winter day in LA. As the honking of cars and blaring of radio tunes begins to silence, a song blossoms up as the music begins to kick in; an overture commences with a big musical number (actually filmed on a busy LA highway), setting the tone for the rest of the film. From here, we meet two young aspiring artist, Mia and Sebastian, destined to meet each other in short time. Mia is a struggling actress dreaming of making it big in Hollywood, giving her talents an audience yet constantly getting rejected and interrupted during auditions. Sebastian is a jazz musician living a past forgotten by many and yearns to open up his own jazz bar, bringing back the music he so desperately loves. The two meet during chance encounters and fall in love, pushing each other to achieve their own dreams. Along the way, those same dreams threaten to tear them apart as reality slowly creeps in causing Mia and Sebastian to rethink their dreams and their relationship.

Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling play the roles of Mia and Sebastian, respectively, cementing their unmatched chemistry on film. Their character's love and devotion to each others passion drives them and the story to unprecedented heights; you could even say the film works solely off their magnetic connection and ability to relate to audiences. John Legend makes an appearance as an old colleague of Sebastian named Keith, beckoning Sebastian to move forward with his music and leave the jazz world of decades past behind him. J.K. Simmons also has a small, funny cameo, channeling his best Terence Fletcher from Chazelle's 2014 hit, Whiplash. Chazelle works his magic off camera as director and writer, giving us a beautiful and melancholy story, surrounded by clear LA skies, technicolor hues, and a brimming optimism sorely missing from movies nowadays. The songs and score are composed and orchestrated by Justin Hurwitz, infusing jazz melodies that give weight to the film, an old soul wrapped in covers of the present day. The six original songs excite, uplift, and catch audiences attention with vibrancy and a dash of bittersweet sadness, adding a light touch with emotional depth as the story unfolds.

In capable hands with talented artist, La La Land makes viewers fall in love with musicals and reinvigorates a faded genre of Hollywood with a story about the pursuit of one's dreams and the chances we take to make them come true. Chazelle creates musical movie magic at its purest, most enchanting, and most heartbreaking, making hearts dance and swell with joy all the way through. The film may not be for everyone, admittedly, but it comes with a moving message for the dreamer in all of us, telling us to purse our dreams and take chances in life, which could open the door for something wonderful. Music and film unite to mimic our truest moments in life, which are often accompanied by a tune spinning in our heads. Whether it's dancing on top of cars, diving into pools in three piece suits, or dancing away in a sea of stars, the power of music and machine bring life to a piece Hollywood magic the industry has been missing. Made with love, precision, and brilliant composition, Chazelle's La La Land is easily one of the best, if not the best, film of 2016.

Bravo director Damien Chazelle (Whiplash [2014]) another fantastic film. A musical, drama and comedy La La Land is simply amazing. Borrowing and paying homage to films from the 40's and 50's, but set during the present day we follow two dreamers Mia (Emma Stone) a struggling actress that works as a barista on the WB Lot and Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) a jazz musician that is scared of change, but has big plans for himself one day. The two have a few chance meetings and eventually fall in love. Eventually, Sebastian takes a job in a band which gives him a steady job, but drives him further away from his dream and also Mia. They both have to realize what they really want eventually. The cinematography is fantastic, the songs are fantastic, the chemistry between Gosling and Stone is great (there's a reason this is the third time they've starred in a movie together). Gosling is literally trapped in the past...driving an old car, dressing like a lost actor from the 50's and its Mia that opens his eyes and he vice versa to unlocking her own abilities and believing in herself. I will say this is probably the best film i've seen all year. As a film buff its got some great scenes and especially the last 15 minutes might be some of the most heartbreaking stuff I've seen in awhile. This a great film and I hope you all give it a look...it's technically a musical, but it works so well and I guarantee if you've ever been in a serious relationship this movie will relate to some level to ya. Get out and see it!

I had the opportunity  to see a free screening of it last week here in Vegas. The movie has everything a film should have in it. Damien knows how to hook the audience in with a unpredictable hook. Just when we think the movie is over is is not. The audience is thinking to themselves it really is not over? Many of today's movies do not have the wow factor, or the element of unpredictable. This one does. The whole cast and crew do a great job of capturing the golden years of Hollywood in a very 21st century style of storytelling. More then anything the movie tells political correctness to get lost. Damien shows the audience it is okay for a man to be man and woman to be a woman. Men are suppose to lead and be the provider and protector for the woman. Women want to know how their man can make them feel safe and protected. All of the musical numbers are just amazing. My favorite song from the movie is Dreamers. Emma Stone does a great job of really capturing the essence of this song. Just like Vegas, LA is a city that will eat one up. It is full of promise and at the same time many hardships for those who call it home. The entertainment industry is a very tough and competitive business. Just because one has talent does mean they will automatically make it in Tinseltown. It take sacrifice and work to have our dreams come true. In the end all of us want to find love and live a a successful and wonderful life. We have love, money, and the Lord in our own lives. This movie is a five out five stars. It really is that good.

this is a great example of a movie that did so much more with so much less. long takes, beautiful montage sequences. i wouldnt call it sparse dialogue, but very intentional and concise at times. trimmed a lot of fat, and those small edits all went a long way to create a greta larger picture. they really paid off. 

the performances were outstanding. emma stones best. for sure. 
love ryan gosliing. he does the kind of work on screen i always wished and dreamed of doing. stoic but so expressive. manly but with his own sense of flamboyance. 

the story flowed and stayed true to itself and never got melodramatic. (another example of its "strength in what it wasnt")

this movie totally owned it style. right out of the gate too. it was a big musical that wasnt afraid to be big bold and silly. a true ode to the old style movie musicals. one of the films real unsung heores that wont be celebrated but gave teh film the detail that puts it over the top, the scene transitions. it marked the movie as a film not of its time, and yet it worked so well in its time. the style is decades old. what is old is new again (and fresh too)

The majority of people who saw this movie loved it, myself included. Those who didn't like it are either non-musical fans who are complaining about the fact that people break into song and dance, or musical fans that don't know the difference between homage and perfect recreation. This movie, as indicated by many, is a tribute to classic movie musicals. Key word: TRIBUTE. It's not as perfectly sung and danced as the classics because it's not trying to be the classics, but it still has a lot of heart about it that is reminiscent of them. It has a slightly imperfect edge that makes the characters seem more accessible.  The musical numbers are integrated seamlessly into the story, and the songs themselves are either very joyous or very cerebral. All are great though. Top-notch performances by both Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, and am ending that will make you think for days. I think this is as close to perfect as you can get in a movie, and a perfect homage to classic movie musicals while still feeling fresh and modern. Well done, Damien Chazelle.

If you want something that's simultaneously old school and fresh, this is the way to do it. Incredible music, a timeless story (with a needed dose of reality stirred in), and one of the most endearing romances I've seen on screen in a long time. If you don't like musicals, it shouldn't matter at all; if you do...brace for impact. Shit's gonna light up your world.
Damien Chazelle's quickly becoming one of my favorite modern filmmakers (hopefully this'll be the one that makes me remember his god damn name), and his affection and frustrations for showbiz and LA is spelled out crystal clear with his incredible direction. Emma Stone gives the best performance I've seen from her (haven't seen Easy A. forgive me), illustrating the heartbreaking truths of continued rejection and the spilling of one's guts associated with trying to make it as an artist, and Ryan proves once again why he's my favorite working actor with onscreen instrumental talent and emotional magnetism that hit me where I live. 
Not much else to say but to give it a chance. I wouldn't say it's quite as good as Whiplash, but boy does it come close while also be ten times more accessible than such a dark character study could ever hope to be. Two for two Mr. Chazelle. I'll have to catch Grand Piano on Netflix while I wait for your next big flick.

La La Land cuenta la historia de Mia (Emma Stone) una aspirante a actriz, y Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) un músico de jazz que luchan por encontrar su lugar en Hollywood y cumplir sus sueños. 

Damien Chazelle logra capturar la esencia del viejo Hollywood, y de esos musicales como Singing on the Rain, pero trae la historia al presente y la actualiza. La dirección es milagrosa. Cada escena es una obra de arte, en cuanto a dirección, sincronización y todo el trabajo que hay detrás para lograr capturarlas. No soy fanática de los musicales, porque siento que las transiciones entre las canciones y las actuaciones son abruptas, pero al contrario, en La La Land logra unir ambas de manera natural.

La historia es mágica, y la química entre Stone y Gosling es perfecta, y fue un acierto que estos personajes fueran seres humanos imperfectos. Creo que es un tema con el cual todos podemos sentirnos identificados, porque todos hemos fracasado en algún momento tratando de perseguir nuestros sueños, y esta película enfatiza de que si no resulta, hay que levantarse y seguir tratando de lograrlo.

Para mí, la escena que se destacó fue el final. El montaje es de las mejores escenas que he visto en un par de años, porque logra tomar una situación triste y decepcionante, y la convierte en algo esperanzador. 

De las mejores películas del 2016.

Simmons is in this film for such a brief moment in this film. I liked the diversity in this film as far as mixing styles and showing modern with past styles in music and looks of old with new. The joyful musical genre has been in the Hollywood cemetery for too long now, but even rarer now is a musical with entirely original music in an entirely original story, which director Damien Chazelle (Whiplash) achieves with expert choreography. While he may give Southern California a bit too overly glamorous of a view with no dark edge, he still recaptures the same zest of West Side Story while cranking the spectacle up a notch. It's always a challenge for any serious director to stage a film where everyone breaks out into song without it oozing Disney Channel cheese, but Damien Chazelle has done it!

Within Chazelle's cinematic recreation of Southern California, he fastens our seatbelts through the bumpy relationship between two artists over the course of four long seasons, starting at the heat of Christmas. One is a ruby-red aspiring actress who cannot land an audition, and thus must serve coffee under a careless manager to make ends meet. The other is a Fred Astaire-Dooley Wilson mash-up whose fast fingers command jazz on the piano, no matter what his boss wants him to play. After they first meet over road rage at rush hour, these distracted minds find that destiny has forced them together with coincidental run-ins day after day. Everything after that is as pure and classic as dancing under a full moon.

Once we learn about what these two have in common, boy is it the beginning of a beautiful friendship! He wants to revive Jazz as a modern art form, but she cannot stand listening to it, and this subject alone stems all the other conflicts that these two share over the course of a year. It is a pleasure to see the ups and downs of their romance, even if the other people in their lives are treated by the screenwriter as if they don't even matter.

Yet it's not the supporting cast who helps us to understand their relationship, but the numbers that project their thoughts onto the moment. On their first formal meeting, she hears his piano playing as lit by a single spotlight, as if she's glancing into his own little world. On second formal meeting, they tap dance in front of a skyline at twilight. On the first date, they are swept off their feet-literally, to a dance against the stars in a planetarium. On the tenth date, they sing an Oscar-worthy duet. As time goes by, the dream of making it to the top of the world in Paris quickly diminishes. Her tears swell up along with the audiences'; I'll even admit I choked up as well, and I'm a man.

A new classic for musical and film fans. The characters are compelling with added humor and emotion from their more than talented protrayers.
