There are two types of people in the world, those who love La La Land and those who despise La La Land. You will most likely be able to sort yourself into either camp from the opening scene. The movie opens in L.A traffic on a hot Californian winters day when someone suddenly feels the joy from the good weather and begins to sing, before long every person from every car is singing along to an undoubtedly catchy bright song. If this doesn't sound like your type of movie its probably best to quit now, if your anything like me then youll be completely in for the ride. As the movie progresses the tone does shift to a darker more realistic movie about , the values of dreams and passion but the entire movie does have an dazzling bright, and whimsical feel. This is the type of movie that really shouldn't work but through great direction, performances, music and a tough of Hollywood magic it does. Damien Chazelle does an amazing job directing. its clear he has so much love and passion for not just this movie but the genre in general. It walks the perfect line of call backs to classic Hollywood and a modern musical. Emma Stone shines in this giving a perfect mix of innocence and hopefulness and realism and heartbreak. She is also has an absolutely amazing singing voice. Acting against her is Ryan Gosling. Ryan brings this amazing classic Hollywood charm to role in a both idealized and grounded role. The screenplay is wonderful. It has an amazing mix of humour, heart and story. The most surprising thing about the movie was its humour. Especially in the first half of the movie the tone is surprisingly high and funny. The second half gets noticeably darker and more grounded but the transition feels natural. It follows the characters as they start out optimistic and in love but as tome goes on they're forced to face the facts about the cost of following passion. The love story between Mia and Sebastian (Stone and Gosling) is wonderfully sweet yet convincing. They're natural chemistry mixed with great screenplay lead to one of the greatest movie couples in recent cinematic memory. The musical gives the entire movie a whimsical feeling but each song sets an distinct mood for each scene. Gosling and Stones voices are able to hit a range of different styled and melodies. The cinematography is beautiful. I gives L.A a very timeless yet still current feeling to it. it had great flow and very few jump cuts which is very impressive during elaborate dance sequences. Over all La La Land is a charming beautiful love story 9/10.
I loved it! I thought Star wars was going to win my favorite movie of the year but this movie tops it.

Not sure why or how it swept the golden globes. Kudos to the director for trying to bring a modern day musical to the big screen. The story was cute, would have been a much better movie as a romantic comedy rather than a "musical."

The dancing is lots of fun, the singing good (though not great), the love theme is boring, the chemistry just so-so, the story a bit hackneyed. But the production numbers and just having a full-on movie musical are well worth the trip. This is a joy to watch, because everyone's having so much fun.

And then there's Emma Stone. Ooh-la-la.

Damien Chazelle believes that Hollywood is as much a boulevard of broken dreams as it is a flavorsome Tinsel Town in which everything proves to be affectionately Technicolor if you look hard enough, and those intertwining beliefs get him far in the winning modern-day musical "La La Land." A proponent of both the idealistic Hollywood Golden Age and the darker romanticism of the latter day musical a la "Hair" (1979) and "Romance & Cigarettes" (2005), he finds a wispy balance between old school tribute and game-changing revolution and ends up with something a little "Singin' in the Rain" (1952) and a little "All That Jazz" (1979).
	Which ensures tonal imperfectability, but like all movies that try to connect the fantasy of breaking out into song when words can hardly profess your true emotional state and the reality that life is more shit throwing than rose colored, "La La Land" is a heady dose of epic enterprise matched in charm.  Immediately clear is that it is among 2016's great films.
	The movie, made all the more charismatic as a result of its inspired casting, stars Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone as a pair of struggling Hollywood amateurs brought together by circumstances more cinematically quaint than Gene Kelly and Leslie Caron's first meeting in "An American in Paris" (1951).  He, a traditionalist pianist named Sebastian, fantasizes about bringing jazz back to the masses and opening a club Morris Levy'd be proud of.  She, an aspiring actress named Mia, currently works at a coffeeshop on the fringes of a production studio but yearns to be the Ingrid Bergman of the new millennium.  After two abrupt encounters that find Sebastian in the grips of frustration, the twosome eventually finds common ground at a party characterized by the rubbing of elbows of big wigs and upstarts.	
	For its next two hours does "La La Land" follow their romance with a dedication that rings as hopelessly tender, supplely theatrical, and delicately bittersweet.  Like Judy Garland and James Mason's relationship in "A Star Is Born" (1954) - though octaves less stormy - the film is unmoving in its conclusion that the hard-to-reach finish line that is professional success isn't much a personal life's wingman.  To struggle together isn't always synonymous with staying together, and yet there's a gorgeous stir in that sentiment that gives "La La Land" the weight necessary to corroborate that it's lyrical, not just romantic zing.  Its characters grow together, perfect themselves together - they're so much more than the frequently stock characters of the musical.
	"La La Land" is, of course, likely to appeal to the old souls that find a strange manner of tranquility when in the presence of Louis B. Mayer's star factory and all its prim products.  Quickly clear to us is that Sebastian and Mia are the sort that have to fight for years to become hot commodities, but only later, in the film's climactic scene (which, in addition to being one of the best movie moments of the decade, finds an auditioning Mia singing of the melancholies that come along with being a hopeless dreamer), are we reminded of all the individuals that lusted after seeing their name in lights but didn't ever find out what it was like to get their big break.
	And that fantasist cum fatalist attitude is what gets Chazelle far.  Though he's devout in his homages to the musical's most triumphant eras (with the opening credits preceded by the CinemaScope logo, with the photography reminiscent of the warmth of 1961's "West Side Story," and with the final few moments throwing in glimpses of dreamworlds of 1953's "The Band Wagon's" quality), never does he lose sight of the woes that plague an idealist in a world that doesn't much care if you make it or if you don't.  When not ensnared with the technical mastery of its musical sequences - the flamboyant "Someone's In the Crowd" is the 2016 equivalent of "Singin' in the Rain's" iconic "Good Morning" routine, and the gravity toying, star bound slow dance (set in the all-important planetarium of 1955's "Rebel Without a Cause") is an unforgettable sight - ample time is committed to digging claws into the characters' neuroses.  
	The succession of audition scenes on the part of Stone is enough to argue for the conviction that she's among the best actresses of her generation, but better yet are the sequences that challenge the latter and Gosling's easygoing rapport.  It's reliably endearing to watch them make small talk, but "La La Land" is at its most magnificent when they're at odds with what they want professionally and what they want personally, the world working against them as their respective dreams clash with the dreams of the other.  
	Stone is Oscar worthy as a woman at war with the painful cravings to become America's next sweetheart and the increasing plummets in self-confidence due to her seemingly incessant journey of bad auditions.  Gosling is her perfect match - the Astaire to her Rogers - as the musical zealot that'd rather die with his ambitions deep in his belly than give up on them.  Together do they blend seamlessly, bringing a type of cinematic romance that goes far beyond working off chemistry that works for a screen test.  Here, they develop a relationship of three-dimensional impact, so much so that even when their courtship is faced with potential ruin do we still find ourselves rooting for their success as a pair.
	They're the kind of persona driven stars we need in our disenchanted times, and Chazelle, hot off 2014's fast and furious "Whiplash," is a talent in full command of his artistic breadth.  He's an auteur able to connect his heart to the lens with the clarity of a young Scorsese, turning relative inexperience to youthful acuity that reeks of frenetic energy and a remarkably personal style.  "La La Land's" superlative conjoining of the old and the new, complemented by the joys of fantastical musical tropes, establishes it as a modern classic.  That a modern classic can take on the form of the cinema's most dated genre is the biggest indicator of the way its zeal overtakes you.

I had extremely high expectations for 'La La Land', having loved Whiplash and heard a lot about it. Still, it exceeded all of them. This movie is on another level: the cinematography, the color palette and the direction are brilliant; Chazelle proves to be, at the age of 32, probably the mosto promising young director around. The score and all of the music numbers are astonishing, especially the first, the planetarium, and the final one. The chemistry between the two leads is incredible. and the acting is top-notch; in particular Emma Stone gives a mesmerizing, authentic and raw performance. The perfectly paced story unfolds naturally and without any boring or unnecessary moment, and builds up to the marvelous, jaw-dropping finale. It truly makes you feel happy about life, gives you true emotions, and it takes you in a dreamplace for two hours. Simply put, a masterpiece. 10/10

The dance numbers, inside nods to the city of LA and Ryan Gosling's quirky, charming bravado carry this film through its first half. Plus, it seems Gosling and Emma Stone aren't very good singers, which I get is part of their characters, but is hard to listen over long stretches in a feature film. "What's wrong with being romantic," Gosling's character asks in the beginning of the film. Nothing, and this film is romantic and charming but I do like to see some development between characters past the visually pleasing song and dance numbers that are really just flashes in the pan. A light, enjoyable film but more style than substance.

In real life, most people don't randomly break out in song and dance, but the escapism of the big screen has been bringing Movie Fans musical feature films since the very first days of the sound motion picture. Only the second film to win the Academy Award for Best Picture was a musical (1929's "The Broadway Melody"). Oversaturation in the marketplace and changing audience tastes led to the production of fewer musicals, but they never went away. Some of the best-loved musicals in film history (e.g. "Meet Me in St. Louis" and "Singin' in the Rain") came out in the 10-year span 1944-1953. But the ensuing decades each produced very popular musicals: "West Side Story", "The Sound of Music" and "Oliver!" (all Best Picture Oscar winners from the 1960s), "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory", "Grease" and "All That Jazz" (1970s), "Victor/Victoria", "Little Shop of Horrors" and "The Little Mermaid" (1980s), "Beauty and the Beast", "The Lion King" and "Evita" (1990s) and, in the early 2000s, "Moulin Rouge!", "Frozen", "Dreamgirls" and "Chicago", which became the first musical in 34 years to win Best Picture.

2016's "La La Land" (PG-13, 2:08) is the purest original (non-adapted) live action musical in many years, and has both the pedigree and the quality to duplicate the accomplishment of 2002's "Chicago". "La La Land" was written and directed by Damien Chazelle, who was the writer-director of 2014's "Whiplash", which earned him Oscar nods for his script and his film. This one is filled with original songs which are composed and orchestrated by Chazelle's previous collaborator, Justin Hurwitz, with lyrics by the award-winning musical theater team known as Pasek and Paul. Musician John Legend has a major role in the film and its stars, Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, are both past Oscar nominees who earlier appeared together in two other movies - 2011's "Crazy, Stupid, Love" and 2013's "Gangster Squad". And, yes, they both sing and dance while telling this particular musical's story of romance, dreams and hope. It takes place in the present but feels like a throwback - like the most entertaining musicals of yesteryear. 

The film's title has a dual meaning: (1) referring to people who live their lives in a seemingly unrealistic dream world and (2) the city of Los Angeles itself, where most of the action takes place. In fact, the film opens with a song-and-dance number with commuters stuck on a typically grid-locked L.A. highway. At the very end of that scene, aspiring actress Mia Dolan (Stone) has a random, brief and unpleasant encounter with struggling jazz keyboardist, Sebastian Wilder (Gosling), who acts like a real... pianist. The two run into each other again in Sebastian's jazz club, immediately after he's fired by the club owner (J.K. Simmons) for insisting on playing his own music. Sebastian is no more polite this time. The two finally "meet cute" and before long, Mia has left her roommates behind and moved in with Sebastian.

Neither life nor love go smoothly for this pair of stubborn dreamers, but they sure do try hard at both. Mia continues working as a barista on the Warner Bros. studio lot and going to frustrating audition after frustrating audition. Eventually, she decides that her best way forward is to write, finance and produce a one-woman show which, fittingly, focuses on her experiences of leaving her hometown in Nevada and moving to La La Land to pursue her dreams. After dropping the humorously humiliating job where Mia sees him at their third encounter, Sebastian continues to hold fast to his dream of opening his own jazz club, but doesn't really do much about it. He reluctantly takes a job on keys in a music group run by an old acquaintance (Legend), but doesn't enjoy it because they don't play his style of pure jazz. Sebastian's unhappiness turns to resentment and ends up being directed toward Mia, just as her show is about to open. The eventual resolution of their love story and their individual pursuit of their dreams feels right for a movie which celebrates dreamers, but shows what happens when life doesn't go as we've planned.

"La La Land" is a wonderful movie, but not, as some reviewers would lead you to believe, flawless. After three contentious encounters, the two main characters just suddenly fall in love, a development that isn't very well earned by the script or the acting. Otherwise, the performances are excellent (especially Stone's) and the script is funny, poignant and grounded... except for that whole thing about characters suddenly breaking into song. But when they do, those songs are both fun and touching. The dancing, however, seems to lack some of the energy and joy that you find in the older Hollywood musicals that inspired this film. Having said all that, I have to put these relatively minor criticisms into perspective: This is a very entertaining and affecting movie. You'll likely be emotionally invested in these characters, smile a lot - and leave the theater wanting the soundtrack. For someone who wants more variety and positivity in today's films, this one is a gift. "A-"

Writer-director Damien Chazelle returns, after the incredible Whiplash on which I gushed over 2 years ago, with a romantic musical starring Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone. Glowing reviews since the film's debut at the festival circuit only elevated expectations even more and so it is with some trepitation that I venture into this film. However from the moment the film opens with a tone-setting retro chic musical number set on a traffic jammed LA highway that will melt the hardest of hearts and bring a smile to the grumpiest of faces, I know that I have been worrying needlessly. La La Land is a faithful, uncynical, assured and effective take on the musical genre. Keeping the story simple  - boy (a Jazz pianist with big dreams) meets girl (an aspiring actress), fall in love, obstacles arise - set to some of the catchiest tunes you'll hear this or any year, the only word that comes to mind is: Magical. Chazelle's direction is slick and effortless; the pacing is perfect. Shooting it as if we still live in the Golden age of Hollywood in the 50s, the only thing that betrays this timelessness is the existence of mobile phones, the musical numbers are staged with meticulous precision and beautifully composed takes (no MTV style cuts here) that allow the actors to shine and shine they do. I could criticize Stone & Gosling's first duet sounds a little shaky but by the time City of Lights and Audition, two songs for which we might as well give them the Oscars for Best Song now; they are just heartbreakingly good. With two solid gold performances from the leads and impressive visuals that's a feast for the eyes, had the film followed it with a traditionally crowd pleasing ending, this would easily be a 4 star movie. But just when I settle in for this inevitability, he pulls out one final inspired move, with a melancholic and bittersweet ending that provides suprising depth and insight, gaining at least an extra 1/2 star and leaving me breathless and grinning like a lovesick fool as I skip out of the cinema. Following in the steps of An American in Paris, Singing in the Rain and The Umbrellas of Cherbourg, this has 'Classic' written all over it and proves that you can still make movies like they used to. All you need is talent, conviction and whole lot of passion.

Damn.

I went into this movie with literally the highest expectations. Just last year, we saw the long-awaited return of Star Wars, and no matter what you thought of that movie (I loved it), it was a notable event in history. I didn't think expectations could exceed that, but after Damien Chazelle's incredible breakout Whiplash (my pick for movie of the decade so far), and a ton of critical acclaim for this follow-up, my expectations reached an all-time high.
I had no doubt this movie would be great, and I suspected it would be the year's best, or at least my favorite. My suspicions were proven true.

Despite a near-perfect opening, I personally wasn't completely into it until maybe 10 minutes in. I feel like this is a normal adjusting period for musicals. After that, as I said earlier, damn.

I'm worried I'll overuse positive adjectives to describe the music, performances, cinematography, etc. I'll just say they were all so exemplary it seems a disservice not to discuss each aspect on end, but I will resist that urge.

To be fair, the plot to this movie is simple, largely old-fashioned, and if one were to try to describe it negatively, unoriginal. But it's executed so flawlessly (or near it) that I have no complaints. Plus it's an homage to classic musicals, so there's that. There are themes and even some small scenes that reminded me of Whiplash, but again, it worked. And John Legend's parts were just fine, but not as exemplary as the rest of the movie. That's only if I have to find a problem. I honestly love this movie so much, I have to stop writing this now or I may just ramble on forever. It's legitimately one of the greatest theater experiences of my life. Please don't miss out on this.

I was impressed by WHIPLASH last year, LA LA LAND is above and beyond that, it's an absolutely magical film and Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling are truly superb. Some would say it's an hommage to the classical Hollywood musical but if you have ever seen LES PARAPUIES DE CHERBOURG, you know where Damien Chazelle inspiration is coming from, from the musicals of Jacques Demy. it's also a magnificent love letter to the city of Los Angeles and to the disruptive art form known as Jazz.

The songs are lacking in truly hummable tunes but perfectly staged, and the colourful, exuberant opening and closing numbers in particular made me grin. Emma Stone is generally great and Ryan Gosling does handsome-but-smug very nicely.

Such an amazing film that I'm very glad I was fortunate to see before it comes to my local area. This one checks off all the boxes of what makes an Oscar Award Winning film. I would be stunned if this doesn't win for Best Picture among many other categories. Gosling and Stone are two of the best talents in Hollywood and they really shine here.
Unique and very original.

The new picture by the creator of "Whiplash" consists of few different films. You can find a bodacious musical in a spirit of Hollywood's Golden Age as well as an intimate story about love of two dreamers. An anthem in honour of the titular city and an ironic portrayal of the show business. A fairy tale about pursuing one's dreams and a bitter-sweet story about accepting what is irreversible. Suspended between tradition and modernity, pageantry of classic spectacles and independent cinema's intimacy, "La La Land" seems to be Oscar gold.

Damien Chazelle opens the film with a cannon fire. It is a perfect describtion of the virtuoso traffic sequence on a highway, directed in one shot, featuring hundreds of extras. A young woman unexpectedly intones a song about "another day of sun" and in that moment the crowd, absorbed in drivers' malaise, sings and dances like the cast of "Singin' in  the Rain". Only main characters, Mia and Sebastian, are not in the mood for fun. She works in a coffe shop and ineffectively auditions for roles. He is an unemployed pianist, dreaming of his own jazz club. Although their first meeting does not herald the love till death do them part, the romance sems inevitable. Leading actors are Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, who have had chances to fall head over heels in love with each other in "Crazy, Stupid, Love" and "Gangster Squad". However, in those two films love theme is a subplot. In "La La Land" it' is its heart. 

Sebastian walks in Mia's life in the right moment. The girl begins to accept the thought of being one of many, trying to impress bored casting directors. Jazzman inspires her and so she takes heart from his words. At the same time, he starts to be in two minds, whether his musical doctrine and arbitrary judgements are signs of immaturity. Their happy end at the horizon may only be a mirage. Chazelle wonders, if a couple of 
success-seeking artists has a chance to build a harmonous relationship. Can the feeling triumph over ambition and ego? Is everything a guise, play or a fantasy in the city called Dream Factory? Many filmmakers have searched for the answers, i.a. Bob Fosse in "All That Jazz" and Martin Scorsese in "New York, New York". Though, "La La Land" is not as drastic - mockery is softened by melancholy and pesymistic conclusions hidden under subtle humour. Ultimately, Chazelle's film is a love letter rather than a reproach on Hollywood.

As for visual wonders, "La La Land" is a masterpiece. All camera pirouettes, rich colours, polished choreography and elegant costumes amaze. Musicals connoisseurs can easily notice inspiration by american canon ("A Star is Born", "Funny Face") and also european ("The Umbrellas of Cherbourg"). However, Chazelle is not the epigone, idly focused on the past. He changes the genre conventions in inteligent way: regurally combines classic musical's traits with modern film trends. A great overview of director's artistic strategy is the scene shot in the style of the 50s, where the romantic tête-à-tête between characters is broken by the cellphone ring.

At one occasion, Sebastian's friend expresses that jazz is losing the listeners, because of traditionalists who are reluctant to adjusting their music to realities of the 21st century. Those words refer to musicals which, apart from occasional reanimations, seem to be gone. The 
31-year-old director has ambition to reform the genre as well as become its legend. It is hard not to root for him. Chazelle has directed only three films, the second is considered a classic and the third is about to be one. If his talent continues to develop at such pace, it's horrific to imagine what his next picture will be, when he stands behind the camera.

I loved most of the movie. It had fantastic clothing and set design and the cast is a perfect fit. It would have gotten a higher score if the ending were slightly different. The music and homage to classic films is done perfectly and only enhances the film. Emma Stone is honestly the stand out. Perfect balance of fantasy and realism.

Harken back to the days when Hollywood was about spectacle and passion, a dream factory. Mix all that with the realities facing struggling artists in the new millennium, and you've got La La Land. 

Damien Chazelle has carved his name into movie making lore with his "reboot" of old Hollywood musicals in the vein of Singin' In the Rain, An American In Paris, and the works of Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire. Watch the first 5 minutes of this movie, that first number is masterfully shot, with impeccable and precise timing that is just simply magnificent.

Gosling and Stone play off each other perfectly, and their chemistry resonates brightly onscreen. The music is highly creative, at once refreshing and nostalgic.

While still not my favorite of the year by any stretch, I was at least satisfied with the film.  You'll love it if you're a musical junkie.  You'll enjoy it (or at least tolerate it) if you're not.

In today's day and age, musicals have surely become a thing of the past. From Rock of Ages to Mamma Mia, this genre has been on the decline for years. Back in the days of Sound of Music or even Grease, people were flocking to the cinemas to see the latest foot-tappers. With the exception of a few recent films like Les Miserables (which wasn't globally loved) or the Oscar-winning Chicago, musicals just haven't had the flare like they used to, until La La Land was unleashed for the world to see this year. I will not be surprised if this film sweeps every awards show it is nominated at, because it truly is a must-see. La La Land is without a doubt, one of the best films you will see this year and here are a few reasons why that is.

I am not a massive fan of this genre, but I won't ignore the greats. Singin' in the Rain is one of my favourite films of all time and this is right up there in terms of quality musicals. Look, this is a story you have seen a million times, but not exactly told quite this way. As a barista/struggling actress (Emma Stone) works to accomplish her dream, she continuously bumps into a struggling pianist (Ryan Gosling) from time to time, making it seem like fate. Exploring their feelings for each other and learning to love each others passions, this is a beautifully crafted picture that is both a love letter to Hollywood and an exploitation of it. Time progresses rapidly throughout this film and the time in between each transition seems flawless, as do the musical numbers that explain each scene in depth. This film is a true marvel and what filmmakers should always strive to achieve.  

Whiplash was one of the greatest films of 2014, due to its passion and simplicity into the life of a passionate drummer. Director Damien Chazelle knows exactly how to put music on screen. He clearly has found a niche in the type of films he will be exploring in the future and I am completely on board. Whether a drummer is being showcased on screen, a pianist playing their heart out, or a big musical number is being performed, there is something special about the way that Chazelle directs his films. The music in his films may be displayed perfectly, but nothing about this film is more perfectly executed than the style (cinematography to be exact. 

From the opening sequence to the subtle transitions, there is not a single moment that felt off to me during my viewing of La La Land. When this film began with a seemingly continuous take, I was already hooked. From then on, this film was finding new ways to impress me in more ways than one. Whether it was subtle callbacks to moments from Singin' in the Rain or making a film fan like me drool at the site of an imitated shot from Rebel Without a Cause, this was classic Hollywood filmmaking at its finest. The visual effects in certain sequences only added to the film and the fact that almost every high-end extravagant-looking sequences was done practically, just goes to show that this film needs even more recognition than it's already receiving. 

The 2000s have given us musicals in Moulin Rouge!, Chicago, Dreamgirls, Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street, Hairspray, and Les Miserables. There are many I left out there, but you get the point. I have seen most of the aforementioned pictures and I can say with the utmost confidence that La La Land is the best musical since 2000. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone share impeccable chemistry, but audiences should not be surprised by this. They both give award-level performances, the music is stellar and memorable, it makes you feel amazing, the direction is off the charts, and the imagery is something that you would find in a classic Hollywood picture from the 50s. There are a few instances where I felt the film would go into cliches, but there is a reason that everything is shown on screen. I loved every minute of La La Land and it's one of the best films of 2016.
Talented, charming and original. La La Land gets every note right, and often in one take. The best movie of the year.
A loving love letter to the Hollywood of Old. Epic in scale at times yet intimate. Superb performances, top notch visuals and production design, fantastic music; this movie has it all!

"Damien Chazelle's "La La Land" is a mind-blowing spectacular. It totally revives the movie musical in the most magical way possible"
Movie Review: La La Land
Date Viewed: January 2 2017
Written and Directed By Damien Chazelle (Whiplash)
Starring: Ryan Gosling, Emma Stone, John Legend, Rosemarie DeWitt, Finn Wittrock, Sonoya Mizuno, Callie Hernandez, Jessica Rothe, Tom Everett Scott, Meagan Fay and J.K. Simmons.

Damien Chazelle's "La La Land" is a mind-blowing spectacular. It totally revives the movie musical in the most magical way possible. The writing is pitch-perfect and the performances are top-notch. Even though "La La Land" takes place in the modern present, it still has the charm, passion and feel from those classic MGM musicals from the 1950s and early 60s like "Guys and Dolls" and "West Side Story".

"La La Land" tells the story of an aspiring actress and struggling jazz musician who meet up and try to find their place in the world. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone have amazing chemistry together, the songs are terrific and this picture has a heart that's tough to crack. It's one of the best movies of 2016.

The movie greatly begins with an opening musical number on a crowded highway in Los Angeles where all the drivers get out of their cars and sing "Another Day of Sun". After that delightful scene, we jump to an aspiring actress named Mia (Stone) as tries out auditions for possible roles. She later hangs out with her roommates at a lavish party in the Hollywood Hills but she decides to go to a gig at a restaurant where she meets a struggling jazz musician named Sebastian (Gosling) who Mia earlier encountered during a moment of road rage. Sebastian later gets fired by the restaurant's owner (J.K. Simmons) for not playing the songs on the setlist and for his disobedience. Mia attempts to compliment him for his beautiful song but Sebastian furiously brushes her off.

Several months later, Mia and Sebastian meet up again at a party where he plays for a pop cover band. After the gig and teasing Sebastian a little, the two of them walk together to find their cars and they talk about their passions for their two different arts. Sebastian dreams about becoming a famous jazz musician and opening up a jazz club for himself and Mia dreams about becoming an actress and hitting it big in Hollywood.

Mia's passion for acting is in there but apparently that's not enough as she fails more auditions but she decides to take Sebastian's suggestion and that is writing a personal single-actress play. As Sebastian begins to perform jazz more regularly, his relationship with Mia grows more romantic and they move in together.

Soon, Sebastian meets up with an old high school classmate, Keith (John Legend) and he wants him to be the keyboardist in his jazz band. Sebastian is dismayed by the group's pop-oriented style but he still joins the band anyway as their keyboardist and this news disturbs Mia as she and Sebastian argue over their careers and their relationships. The ending maybe hard for some viewers to swallow and is much different from most musical movies but "La La Land" is an old-fashioned musical that works on it's own merits and it earns it's five stars.

Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone previously worked together and had a romantic relationship in the 2011 comedy "Crazy, Stupid, Love" but it was a different kind of movie, their relationship in this movie fires on all cylinders and their performances shine as brightly as the bright lights of Los Angeles. Writer and director Damien Chazelle (who previously helmed the hardcore musical drama "Whiplash") could've turned "La La Land" into another musical extravaganza with sheer lunacy and annoying supporting characters but not this time, he turns "La La Land" into an enchanting musical with hard-headed bite, delightful songs, great performances and a real sense of place.

Some people have said that the movie musical is dead. They should talk to movie critics and the Academy voters and explain why because "La La Land" is one of the best musicals I have seen.

Oh, La La Land, how the hype has been real. We all know how incredible Whiplash, writer/director Damien Chazelle's last effort, was so it makes sense that so many people, including myself, were excited about this, and... it's good. It's not amazing; it's not great; it's not really good. It has pacing and script issues and the story and themes are very derivative. The nostalgia goes overboard at times, but it still works more often than not. Emma Stone is fantastic, though, and the music is great. It's fun, cute, and with terrific cinematography. It isn't worthy of the hype, but succeeds in its own right. Mia (Emma Stone) is an aspiring actor that works as a barista while Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) is a pianist who wants to open up his own jazz club. The two cross paths a few times and form a relationship, which eventually is tested by their attempting to follow their respective dreams. Oh, and there's a good amount of singing because this is a musical. The music is great and--speaking as a person that doesn't like musicals and usually finds them to be hard to get behind--mixed with the choreography makes for something easier to swallow. It does seem as if Chazelle's reach exceeds his grasp one or two times, namely with musical numbers made to look like single takes but with pretty obvious filmmaking and editing tricks. Nonetheless, the beautiful look to the movie and Stone's range make it possible to forgive this to an extent. The softness to the aesthetic in the nighttime scenes mixed with the bold color palettes on display at time demonstrate Chazelle's eye to create a mood with a shot. However, it's largely Chazelle's ability to capture the joy and humor that fits with this material and the Old Hollywood glamor that it pays tribute to. Still, in my opinion, La La Land isn't close to the perfection that others have painted it to be. As mentioned earlier, Chazelle's script relies too heavy on nostalgia in leu of creating its own uniqueness and there are pacing issues and unsatisfying character portrayals due to his script. The movie seems to peak before the halfway point, leading the following 20 minutes or so to feel like a slog. I checked the time and thought to myself, "Wait, there's over another hour of this?" The energy takes a hit afterwards. Similarly, John Legend's character is ditched and has not much of a resolution once he isn't in the forefront. And although I've praised the music and most of the musical numbers, the opening sequence has some pretty questionable lip syncing and I instead sat there thinking, "Oh, that's fake." My criticisms with La La Land may sound like I didn't like it, but I did. It's a good movie; it isn't great and it has obvious flaws. The successes that the filmmakers display here are generally wide and therefore don't give a lot to comment on, while the errors are smaller, but there are more to speak of. Some scenes feel like magic and a lot are cute, and the movie as a whole has a fair amount going for it. I'm glad that I saw it, but I won't see it again. 7.7/10, good, B, above average, etc.
7/10 lovely at times but feels like its missing the structure needed to be truly solid film.

Chazelle, much like his previous film Whiplash, creates a mesmerizing canvas and provides engrossing direction. Stone's performance is shiningly-endearing and spectacular, and her chemistry with Gosling is the heart of the film. La La Land is a breath of fresh air in the musical genre, the most enjoyable (and likely best) film of the year, and above all reminds you why you go to the cinemas. 10/10

La La Land revives a bygone genre that is forever cemented in classical Hollywood cinema and will surely be remembered amongst its greatest musicals. Gosling and Stone showcase their chemistry yet again in this spectacularly shot, beautifully composed, and brilliantly choreographed feature worthy of every Academy Award it won. Damien Chazelle writes a candid, heartwarming story perfectly fitting for a retro musical rooted in the past despite its contemporary setting. Everything from the costumes to the performances takes you back to a time when life was much simpler and joyful and that is a unique quality that no longer transcends through modern movies. Of all the things to love about La La Land it's the ending that leaves you in tears and sniffing as "The End" appears before the credits roll, but the fond memory of how incredibly enjoyable the experience was will surely put a smile on your face.

This film was a lovely and delightful riff on classic Hollywood musical romances. Was it the best picture of the year? Of course not. But nobody walking into this movie cold - no reviews, no context - could not smile. My only complaint was that I wanted more of Gosling and Stone just talking. Not dancing. Not singing. Sometimes a rare film gem comes along that makes you re-think what's possible in cinema. Almost every year, most good if not great Oscar-worthy films have been, for the most part, dramas overrun with moodiness and gravitas. So when you hear about a completely original musical set in present-day based on elements of classics from decades prior, it's easy to be skeptical. But what makes this film stand out isn't just its musicality, but the honesty in its intentions. No, it doesn't have a stereotypical Hollywood ending where everything turns out as you think it will, but in a way, that almost makes it that much more grounded and thought-provoking. This film's artistic backdrops, long takes, buttery-smooth editing, and jazzy tone all work seamlessly with the story - making this, by far, the most upbeat prospective Best Picture nominee of the year. Yet what this movie also does well is call into question how meaningful our success is, and whether or not it's worth the sacrifices made along the way to achieve our dreams.
Good movie, but too hyped up

When it comes to my anticipated movies, this one, believe it or not, is actually my most anticipated movie of 2016! YEAH, I actually anticipated this film even more than Rogue One! Another interesting thing to note is that this is the first that a musical is my most anticipated film of the year! Seriously, ever since I saw the teaser for this film and read about what it was about, I was hooked. I knew I couldn't miss out. But another thing that made me anticipated for this is the fact that this film came from director Damien Chazelle, who previously directed one of my favorite films of the 2014, "Whiplash". That alone, sealed the deal and made me say, "Yep! I am soooo seeing this!" So now that my most anticipated film has hit the big screen, will it make me want to follow my own dreams and live in LA, or will this just make me wish I were deaf from the start? Let's find out by taking a look at "La La Land".

THE STORY
So the movie follows these two people who are trying to pursue their dreams despite the fact that they live in Los Angeles, where dreams are known for getting crushed. They cross paths for the first time, they end up falling in love, and we get to see their story as a team, while also incorporating musical numbers along the way. On one hand, you make think this story has been done numerous times, but believe it or not, the story is actually, ORIGINAL! For the first time in so long, we have an actual story that is original in a movie! And also, it's execution is PERFECT! You can really tell that Chazelle really went deep into making the story original and very engaging from beginning to end. Rather it be Mia and Sebastian's story, Sebastian himself trying to pursue his jazz career in an era where Jazz is dying, or Mia trying to be an actress but her auditions always get screwed. Another thing that helps the stories execution is definitely the musical numbers, from the moment that this film opens with it's big fun song to the ending with a more serious song, the musical numbers even out the time we get to have a story told and the fun we have while hearing these songs. (I'll get more into the songs a little bit later.) For the first time in over a few decades, we've got a movie with an original story that is beautiful and very well executed!

THE VISUALS
With an original story that is perfectly executed, you can also expect the visuals to look perfect. And the visuals in this movie definitely exceed my expectations. They really mix the idea of an older Los Angeles and modern day Los Angeles perfectly to the point where you think you're in a whole new world. And it really does look beautiful. Another amazing aspect of the visuals is easily the use of the camera. The camera operators don't constantly cut away from one shot to another giving the audience members like me a headache and a hard time trying to focus on what's going on. Instead, the camera movements are smooth, the follow the action and the amount of pans and 360's used in the film really make it easier for the film to watch, especially when there's a musical number going on. Also, another little thing I like is how certain parts of the film pay homage to the classic movies of the early to mid 1900s, like the copyright label at the bottom of the screen when the title card appears. But the true highlights in the visuals are the lighting and especially some of the other special effects. The lighting in the film really suits the style of the film well and also helps make the musical numbers really engaging, especially during the musical numbers as well. Like how the lights would go out and focus on whoever was singing or if there was a performance going on, or the sunset during Sebastian singing on the dock, the list goes on. But there was one part of the film where the visuals really looked top notch, and that was the scene with the observatory. I won't say much about it since I don't want to spoil anything, but I'll just say once you see the movie, then you'll know what I mean. Not only is the story perfectly executed, but the visuals are perfectly done as well!

THE CHARACTERS
There aren't very many characters to talk about in this movie, so I'm only going to talk about the ones we focus on in the film. But just because there aren't many characters, doesn't take away any perfection that this movie has. For the few characters we have in this movie, they really are perfect. First up, we have Sebastian, he is a dedicated jazz musician who's plan is to open up his own jazz club where no one can tell him what to play and when to play it. But joins a band with an old friend for a while which interferes with his relationship with Mia. At first glance, you may think he's a total douchebag just by looking at him at the start, but when you see what he has to go through, you really feel for him and it shows that he's doing everything he can to try and succeed, even if he's getting screwed over by those around him. Which really makes you want him to succeed. Then we have our other main character Mia, she's an aspiring actress who starts off as a coffee shop barista but wants to live big in LA and star in a big Hollywood movie, which is really difficult for her considering that every audition she goes to, something always goes wrong and the people just blow her off like a bug on a piece of clothing. You can really feel the struggles that Mia is going through and it shows that despite giving up at times, she wants to succeed in life. As for the other characters like Mia's roommates, Sebastian's bandmates, and the others, they don't really have that much screentime, but you can really tell that they have a purpose in this film and it really helps push the story of our two main characters forward. Just when you thought that there would be flaws with the characters, here they as perfect as can be.

THE SONGS
And now it's time for what I have been dying to talk about throughout this review, the musical numbers. There are a total of 5 original songs in this movie, and each of them are very well executed and as I said before, they really push the story forward with its execution and help the visuals look better than ever. From the very beginning with "Another Day Of Sun" to the introduction of Mia's life with "Someone in the Crowd" sung by her roommates, to the moment when Sebastian and Mia first meet with "A lovely Night", and when Mia has a big audition of her life, with "The Fools Who Dream" which actually has a very interesting backstory to it. But the one song that stands out in the film is easily what I would consider the theme of this movie, "City Of Stars". "City Of Stars" perfectly sums up the movie's theme of trying to pursue your dreams with a melodic and very well executed beat and tone that helps fit the scene that happening in the movie. The songs in this movie are not only well executed, but they're very well written as well. Seriously, you can really tell that the songwriters have lots of talent and were at their full potential with these songs! Which really helps make these songs very infectiously catchy and make you want to get up and dance along with the people on screen. When it comes to musicals, it usually takes a lot for the songs to be perfect, with Damien Chazelle and his crew, that was not a problem under any circumstances.

I'll be honest with you guys, when I went into this film, I had very high expectations. But, when I got out, not only did they meet my expectations, But they beyond exceeded them! La La Land is not only one of the best films of 2016, but it is also, without a doubt, one of the best movies of all time! The story is very well executed and engaging, the visuals are beyond perfection, the characters are very loveable and have great chemistry, and the songs are infectiously catchy and make the movie fun to watch! I definitely recommend that you check this film out immediately, if you haven't seen it yet, then what the hell is wrong with you? Go see this movie any chance you get! It's very rare that a musical would be this high up in the ranks of my favorite films of the year, and all it took was Damien Chazelle and his crew, Ryan Gosling, and Emma Stone to make that all possible. This is a film that will be remembered for many generations and I know for a fact this will immediately be in my Blu-Ray collection when it comes out! No doubt about it that it gets the RoboSparta Seal Of Approval, but it took me a lot of thinking about it's rating. I almost would never do this for any movie at all, like ever. But for a movie of this calibur, I think it's time to make a milestone here.

STORY: 10/10
VISUALS: 10/10
CHARACTERS: 10/10
SONGS: 10/10

FINAL SCORE: 10/10 - "PERFECT!!!!!!"

Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone bring electricity to each and every scene, whether it be the songs they sing and dance to, or the acting side of their overall performance. The camera work does wonders, bringing a classic view to modern day L.A., and also bringing out the colours and visuals that are around us. We live in a world where there is sadly, usually, bad news than good. Damien Chazelle revitalizes the modern musical with the nostalgic and poignant "La La Land." 

An aspiring actress and jazz pianist, wonderfully played by Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, fall in love and chase their dreams in the enchanting "City of Stars." 

Technically marvellous, all aspects of the film - from cinematography and lighting to choreography, music and performances - are beautifully conceived and executed. As dreamy and magical as the musical sequences look, they are grounded by complex emotions and the harshness of reality. 

"La La Land" is undeniably an ode to dreamers. But while the film celebrates the joy and fulfillment that comes from pursuing one's passions, it also laments the sacrifices, the missed opportunities, and the dreams that never do come true. 

Simple, yet elegant and emotionally rich, "La La Land" is a truly rewarding cinematic experience.

This movie will win you over with its irresistible charm and infectious take on old Hollywood. I went in cynically wanting to dislike it as a cheesy musical/blatant Oscar bait, but it gradually wore me into submission. It is such a wonderful love letter to old movies and jazz and old school romantic love stories. Everything I found smug and irritating about Hail, Caesar! earlier this year, comes off so much more authentic and earnest and ridiculously charming in this movie. Gosling and Stone are pitch fucking perfect together onscreen, like a classic pairing of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers or some shit like that. It really is that good. I loved the director's previous effort Whiplash, but this is so much more fun and beautifully realized. The long shots and surreal backgrounds make it feel like it was adapted from a famous Broadway musical, and it probably will be turned into one after this sweeps the award season. It will make you fall in love with movies and movie-making all over again and inspire people to go after their dreams. The ending is bittersweet and a little too neat in regards to how everything turns out, but I love this movie and it will probably be in my top 10 for the year and is definitely the deserved frontrunner for Best Picture of the year. It is the antidote to 2016.

Entertainment at its best, La La Land sends us back to an era when a film can be intelligent and still fun to watch.

Packed with the emotional energy and gravitas of a musical from the era that inspired it, with a boisterously contemporary voice courtesy of Damien Chazelle, La La Land is guaranteed to put your heart through the proverbial wringer!

Somehow manages to be a feel-good triumph as well as a darkly honest exploration of the quest for fame and romance in Los Angeles.  In other words, we have a full-fledged cinematic miracle: A Hollywood musical with dramatic integrity .

Really enjoyed this one. It's an imperfect film, but that's part of its charm. Nothing felt over-the-top or manufactured, but rather authentic and real. Some great messages that are open to interpretation depending on the viewer. And  the MUSIC! A rare gem of a film.
A colorful burst of musical fun, smarts, laughs, and surprising depth; all wrapped in a gloriously written, directed, and acted love letter to the performing arts.

Since its first seconds, Damien Chazelle transports us into his colourful and unashamedly nostalgic Los Angeles. Seducing us with his intricate portrayal of the balance between the mundane and the magic that compose this city, we are engaged through the lenses of his two passions: classic cinema and jazz.

The references, visual queues and homages to the likes of Jacques Demy, Gene Kelly, Chaplin, Fred and Ginger, etc. are constant and abound, but they never overstay their welcome thanks to the film wearing its heart on its sleeve and being so sincere and open about where it draws inspiration from (an argument could be make about it being basically an adaptation of Les Parapluies de Cherbourg).

The execution is, for the most part, showy and ostentatious, but it is in line with the homage to the big studio excesses of Hollywood's golden era and the concept of Los Angeles as this cultural behemoth. The frenetic array of joy feels totally earned, but Chazelle still finds moments to ground the film and contain it for his narrative purposes. This works perfectly for the eventual disenchantment of Mia and Sebastian's relationship, but not as much when the subplot with John Legend and a jazz rock band kicks in and deviates the film from its essence: the highs and lows of this romance between two people striving for their dreams.

Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling work well as this characters, bringing nuances and making their romantic foray feel palpable, from its quirky comedic beginnings to its inherently melancholic progression. Stone does clearly overshadows her partner by seeming more engaged and real than Gosling`s jazz snob caricature, tho.

In the musical aspect, it is really outstanding. The main melodies and motifs draw again from the sentimental sensibilities of Michel Legrand, and even if lacking in comparison, composer Justin Hurwitz does manage to stand on his own here.

Yes, it is cliched, over the top, and for moments self-indulgent (that revisiting at the end is beautiful to look at, but its impact pails in comparison to the subtlety of the Demy epilogue Chazelle clearly tries to emulate), but all the same, La La Land embraces this and goes for it, managing to be an effectively endearing experience that is bolstered by its pure charm.

From the very first scene, La La Land captures your interest in a vice and never lets go. It was so magical, visually stunning, and the songs will stay with you long after you leave the theatre. And, despite La La Land being a musical, when people weren't singing and dancing it still had the feeling of a regular movie, which made the story itself captivating. 
I don't think Emma Stone has ever given a better performance than this. She was good in Birdman, sure, but she soared in La La Land. One scene in particular that sticks out to me is "The Audition", during which she was able to sing a beautiful solo while the camera circled around her; all in one take. On the contrary, my only criticism is that Ryan Gosling wasn't doing much acting while he was singing and dancing. He is a very gifted singer, and a lovely dancer, but his face remained a little deadpan during musical numbers. 
But the whole movie is damn near perfect. It was interesting story-wise, the music was fantastic, it made me happy, sad, and made me dance in my seat. 
But what really makes this movie, to me, is the ending sequence. That was what made La La Land "perfect". It tied everything together so beautifully, but also left some room for the viewer to do their own thinking, and it even made me, who has cried during only one other movie ever, shed a tear. 
La La Land is surely going to make cinematic history. It's new and exciting, and it's an experience you surely won't want to miss it.

One of the best musicals and movies ever made.

There is no way I wasn't going to like this movie. I will go out of my way to watch anything Ryan Gosling, Emma Stone, and Damien Chazelle do. So if you think the Goose is a dud or Emma looks like Pepe the frog meme or "Whiplash" is pretentious, we are going to disagree. Well, she does kind of look like Pepe, but that's not the point. As a person who has had to cringe their way through many a musical, I did not cringe once during "La La Land". Maybe that's because it is only partly a musical. There are quite a few musical sequences, and they are immaculately choreographed. The color design and cinematography in general are just gorgeous. There have been a few "ode to old Hollywood" films out this year like "Hail, Caesar!", and "Allied", but this film seems to be more nonchalant when going about it. It is also about jazz but to a much lesser degree than "Whiplash". As Goose and Stone's chemistry go, there are few actors that are as charismatic as these two, and there is never a crack in their characters. They play their roles as if they were Sebastian and Mia, probably because they lived a very similar life to them at one time. The movie might be old Hollywood more because it is a simple love story that never gets too gory with the details, but its modern sensibilities help to shed the melodrama. Instead we are presented with a realistic relationship in a fantastic setting, where sometimes things don't quite work out like we imagined, and it's not anyone's fault in particular. Finally, there is a lot of buzz about this going into awards season. I won't say it isn't justified because there aren't that many modern filmmakers that are as audacious as Chazelle in the scope of what he has accomplished. But for a musical, the music doesn't seem to be the top priority, for better or worse.

Peter Rainer wrote in his review that the movie ends with a what-might-have-been fantasia that is one of the most emotionally moving passages I've ever seen in a musical. And I'd have to agree. Feel good movie? Well, somewhat. But I haven't stopped crying.

The first musical number really sums up La La Land well- a flashy song that has potential to be tremendous, but falters in execution. Visually stunning, the film connects you to two passionate and hard-working dreamers, and begins with great promise. However, it really gets muddled up in the Hollywood numbers and bits, and fails to deliver any clear message by the time the credits roll.

Mia: It's pretty strange that we keep running into each other.

Sebastian: Maybe it means something.

Mia: I doubt it.

Sebastian: Yeah, I didn't think so.

An observatory, a boulevard, a bridge, a downtown trolley, all make up the various filming locations of the new filmÂ La La Land. These locations are iconic, yet remain unnamed throughout the film. The sum of these locations create the city of Los Angeles. Any meaningful production is a sum of its cast members and in the case ofÂ La La LandÂ there is no difference. Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) and Mia (Emma Stone) come together to create a wonderful production, but a lesser known yet ever present cast member is the city itself. Throughout the epic musical sequences, the city in its whole is either visible or represented by its historic street lights. Some might argue that the city is a backdrop to the songs and dancing of Sebastian and Mia, but the city itself takes center stage with the vibrancy of a leading man. It lends its beauty to be danced upon by Sebastian and Mia without relinquishing its hold as being the center of attention.

"La La Land" is a film full of dreams and aspirations filled with a lovable romance, amazing performances, and a heartfelt story. 

Written and directed by Academy Award (R) nominee Damien Chazelle, LA LA LAND tells the story of Mia [Emma Stone], an aspiring actress, and Sebastian [Ryan Gosling], a dedicated jazz musician, who are struggling to make ends meet in a city known for crushing hopes and breaking hearts. Set in modern day Los Angeles, this original musical about everyday life explores the joy and pain of pursuing your dreams.

Man it's official. Damien Chazelle has potentially created the two top films of their respective years in "Whiplash" (2014) and now, "La La Land" (2016). With "Whiplash" being my favorite movie of all time, I was more than excited to see what Chazelle had for us next. Turns out, he produced one of my favorite films of 2016, and easily my favorite musical of all time.

Ryan Gosling plays a jazz pianist who's looking to salvage what's left of jazz and make a career for himself. He plays the character of Sebastian, who's kind of a bitter guy all around. In fact in the first few times we meet him, he's kind of an asshole. But despite what he's gone through and the troubles he's faced, he's a passionate human for jazz and he truly believes in what he's doing. I think the most inspiring thing in life is to see passion and feel passionate about something. Seeing just how passionate someone is about something is one of the most uplifting and inspiring things to experience, and you can absolutely see the joy and dedication his character has to jazz. It's the truth, jazz is a dying art and as a drummer/pianist myself, it really is hard to see. But Gosling puts on an amazing performance and Chazelle continues to show us people who are truly passionate about what they do.

Emma Stone is an aspiring, yet struggling actress who's trying to make a name for herself. As she trudges through countless auditions with the same result each time, it feels like she's in an dream with no happy ending. Emma Stone plays the character of Mia, who faces the difficult challenges and brutal life of Hollywood. Her character goes through so many rough patches and the fact that it's so real makes it sad to see. But Emma Stone was wonderful in this film and the energy and personality she brought to her character was irreplaceable. 

The chemistry between these two was electric. I loved seeing this power couple on screen with the way they talk to each other, interact, dance, sing, and their conflict with one another. They mesh so well and this movie is a romance movie under the cover, and they truly make it feel genuine. In fact, the romance aspect of the film was my favorite part! Together, they make their love seem so real and natural, while it's simultaneously heartbreaking at the same time. This is the romance movie of the year.

Normally, musicals put numbers in the most awkward stages or it's executed really cheesy, but the score of this movie was fantastic. I loved the score and the soundtrack and I was tapping and dancing to the rhythms throughout. The music was beautiful and so appropriate for the moments. The choreography for the dance was more than impressive, with many one takes and fun segments to watch. The singing felt very real which is a major positive. Gosling and Stone aren't the PERFECT singers in the world, but they are really good. Whenever their characters sing, they don't sound all auto-tuned and what not, but it sounds like their genuine voices. I liked that they weren't always perfectly on pitch, even if they were damn close. The music in this film was amazing and I can't wait to get the full album. 

Chazelle has now created this reputation for these musically based films involving passion and dreams. Although completely different from "Whiplash", both films involve characters trying to follow their dreams and their dedication to their craft. I loved the story and the screenplay of this film, with dreams being the main message of the film. This story is so complex yet relatable and it's one of my favorites of the year. The dialogue was so interesting and attention grabbing, as Chazelle really knows how to craft conflict and dialogue.

This film is also just so fun, yet so heartbreaking. I truly came out of this with the biggest smile on my face. In a time that's been rough and confusing, this is one of those relatable, funny, and inspiring films that I needed to see. I guarantee you'll feel a little something in your heart by the time this film concludes. 
 
In the end, I absolutely loved "La La Land". It's one of my favorite films of 2016, and easily my favorite musical of all time. I can't wait to see what else Chazelle puts out for us in the future, and I hope I see another Gosling/Stone duo in the near future.

La La Land is a cinematic masterpiece. It's a throwback to the days where musicals reigned supreme. Except, unlike those films, La La Land has gorgeous cinematography, unmatched character development, outstanding choreography, funny and emotional dialogue, and tunes that will have you singing for days. If you do one thing this year it should be seeing La La Land on the big screen; for the film is quite simply a masterpiece, I cannot put it any other way.
This was the stupidest movie I've ever seen. It sucked. Do not go see this. It was bad.

Very great movie with great music, great dialogue and awesome plot and twists. Ryan and Emma deserve an Oscar including this phenomenal movie. Go see this. It's fantastic.

La La Land is a musical masterpiece! It's a stunning film with incredible cinematography, acting, and music. A must see for 2016!

After watching this film at the Chicago International Film Festival, my original plan was to wait until closer to the film's actual release date to give my thoughts on it. However, after sitting with it for two days, with the images and sounds still sweeping through my mind, I cannot help myself. I will be as vague as possible, because I do not want to ruin the experience of seeing it for the first time, but I have to talk about it.

La La Land, as it has been advertised, pays homage to classic movie musicals. Not only does it visually allude to films such as Singin' in the Rain and The Band Wagon, but it also preserves the upbeat, wondrous tone of those classics. There is something wonderful about seeing this  tone and style recreated for a modern film. Cynicism and pretentiousness are completely absent from this film, and nostalgia and joy take their place. 

But calling La La Land a terrific recreation of the classic movie musical is selling it short. Like director Damien Chazelle's previous work, La La Land has much more going on narratively than the movie may lead people to believe. On the surface, this is a love story about two artists trying to make their ways in Los Angeles. However, this framework is deceptively simple. 

La La Land forces us to think about the realities of personal relationships and artistic endeavors. It explores the excitement of our dreams, the hardships of pursuing these dreams, and forces the audience to question the importance of both. Fortunately, Chazelle never looks down on the audience with these ideas. They are not presented in a heavy handed manner, and he never forces you to think a certain way.

On top of its thematic richness, La La Land has one of the best understandings of film as a storytelling medium that I have seen in recent years. On the surface, it is the most technically astounding. The cinematography is stunning, and the soundtrack is beautiful. Even better is that both the visuals and soundtrack are never used in a way that is shallow or uninteresting. La La Land has an understanding of how to tell a story visually. It understands the power of sequencing, the power images can have on the emotional impact of a story, and the way in which these images simultaneously indulge our fantasies and remind us of our humanity. 

In other words, for me, it embodies everything that I love about movies.

There are instances that everyone can recall in a cinema where we have felt what I like to call "movie magic." These are evoked by the films that completely absorb us into its world, and movies that have a lasting, personal impact on us far beyond the theater. They are the films that we hold as the pinnacle of what makes watching movies so great.

La La Land is one of those movies. 

During its 128 minute running time, the only times I wanted to look away from the screen was to turn to the people around me and check and see the faces of those around me to see if they were experiencing the same kind of magic that I was. I can affirm that everyone I saw in my theater was. 

La La Land is a masterpiece. It is not only the best movie of 2016 so far, but also possibly one of the best of the decade. It's spectacular, stunning, moving, and absolutely magical.

Why did I love this movie so much? Maybe it was its love letter to LA, the same love I feel for LA? Maybe it's because it was so beautiful to look at, to listen to and to admire? There was a passion to this movie that I feel all the time! Truly loved every moment of it

La La Land is a joyously well made musical that brimming with optimism, never feels trickery and feature fantastic performances from lead Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling. A love letter to golden age Hollywood lost in a contemporary LA. Director/Writer Damien Chazelle, creates a world that we dream about, but it also understands the cruelty that can come out of those dreams. Shot in CinemaScope, and yet it's still an intimate masterpiece with vibrant Colour pallet inspired by Jacques Demy's musical films. Although it's set in a bygone era of Hollywood musical film, La La Land never feels dated thanks to Composer Justin Hurwitz talented song writing, making his characters never come-off as Westend stars, instead the smooth musical transition feels grounded as they are real people.

I loved this film.  The plot was sweet and charming, but also realistic and mature.  I loved the distinctive style and almost impressionist-like tone of the film.  The colors were beautiful, setting the different moods perfectly.  Great performances from Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling whose chemistry really pulled the audience into the movie.  The ending felt right for the movie.  This film was wonderfully romantic in every sense of the word.
I don't understand the hype :/
Irresistible and beautifully shot.
Outstanding!!!!! And I HATE musicals lol

It has been written that 'LA LA LAND' is writer/director Damien Chazelle's homage to the great Hollywood musicals of the past... and it is!!  Ryan Gosling (Sebastian) and Emma Stone (Mia) are both impressively talented stepping in to the shoes of a modern day Fred and Ginger or Gene and Leslie, even Liza and Robert.  The story is a little lacking in spots.  But those infrequent dull spots are quickly dismissed by the look and feel of the movie as it conjures up visions of so many great movies of the past (both musical and not).  I am sure I have not thought of all cinematic references in the film.  This is a movie I have to see again to discover what I have missed and to re-enjoy the performances that make this film so dazzling... and there spots that are dazzling.  I am not going to list the film comparisons for fear of spoiling the joy of finding them yourself.  They do not make movies like this very often.  It is an art form that is needed now more than ever.  Go and see it.  Then let's talk about those movie memories.

"I guess I'll see you in the movies".

"La La Land" follows Mia (Emma Stone), an aspiring actress, and Sebastian (Ryan Gosling), a dedicated jazz musician, struggling to make ends meet while pursuing their dreams in a city known for destroying hopes and breaking hearts. With modern day Los Angeles as the backdrop, this musical about everyday life explores what is more important: a once-in-a-lifetime love or the spotlight.

Back in 2014, there was a film called "Whiplash" that blew everyone away, including me. It was my 2nd favorite movie of that year and I had my eye out for the director next project. Wasn't very long until Damien Chazelle next film in was in post-production and was already a serious Oscar contender. I think "La La Land" and "Silence" was my most anticipated movies of 2016/17. And let me tell you, it did not disappoint.

"La La Land" is one of the best musicals I've seen since "Sweeney Todd" and "Singing in the Rain". It's a movie that lifts your spirit up and leaves you smiling though out. Even with today's generation of loud politics, four years of Trump, celebrities dying, and endless amount of pointless controversy. But then comes a musical about two people who are dreamers, that deal with inn conflict and show how dreams can lead to success. By making the impossible possible while living in a place where dreams come to die.

Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone were both dynamite in this movie. The relationship was sweet and relatable that I actually cared for what was going on. Even with the singing and dancing use as a tool that the characters express their happiness, sadness or disappointment was terrific. This is the best I've seen from Stone and Gosling. Both of them sparkle in this musical.

Damien Chazelle, what can I say about this guy. Chazelle as a film making is both amazing and inspirational. He's on a roll recently and if he's next two movies are brilliant, then he is the best living director today. In "La La Land", he follows a similar theme in his previous movie "Whiplash" about fighting for a dream and jazz, but this movie goes for more a light tone than a dark one. For the dramatic elements of the movie, I really like how he lets it go on for awhile as an emotional effect. He also got an eye for spectacle, because LA never looked so beautiful and fairy tale-like. What else is there to say, but Chazelle nailed it.

Without spoiling anything, but the last shot of this movie was so beautiful and yet sad at the same time. Chazelle sure knows how to end his movies and that's with a powerful punch.

My only complaint I have with the movie is that a few scenes could've been trimmed a bit, as it dragged for me. And while the homages to old musicals were fitting, but some was a bit down your throat. I wouldn't say repetitive (because it's not), but more of a "alright, I get it" kind of complaint. That's really it for flaws.

Overall rating: "La La Land" is simply wonderful. It's a firework of joy and excitement that it's really hard not to fall in love with it. I'm already looking forward to "First Man".
Beautiful, Nostalgic And Infectiously Charming!

La La Land

An ambitious but struggling actress and a passionate but unemployed jazz pianist fall in love in Los Angeles. 

I am by no means a fanatic for musicals but this film, written and directed by Damien Chazelle (Whiplash), is a sight to behold. A modern day musical with an old school feel where everything including the cinematography, music and choreography is magical. Even the chemistry between Stone and Gosling is enchanting. La La Land is an epic love letter to dreamers and a cinematic masterpiece. 

One of my favorite films of the year...and of all time.

Quando si parla di film belli preferisco dividerli in tre categorie. Ci sono film ben fatti e belli da vedere che mi incuriosiscono ed emozionano; ci sono film bellissimi che diventeranno senza dubbio tra i migliori dell'anno e saranno ricordati a lungo grazie a premi e riconoscimenti; ed infine ci sono i film semplicemente di un altro livello, quelli che abbatteranno la barriera del tempo e diventeranno dei veri e propri esempi a cui guardare in un futuro prossimo. Ecco, La La Land fa parte di quest'ultima categoria: perfetto sotto ogni punto di vista, porta innovazione in ogni scena. La storia è deliziosa e, anche se già vista, viene rielaborata sempre con espedienti nuovi, con coreografie mozzafiato e una regia semplicemente di un altro pianeta. La voglia di emergere di un regista così giovane è veramente esemplare e lo riesce a comunicare con un film dedicato proprio alle persone che rinchiudono i propri sogni nel cassetto. Più che un film, La La Land merita di essere ricordato come un vero e proprio sogno.

La La Land is one of the most beautiful films and musicals of the past years! honoring the classic films like Casablanca or an Affair to remember! This should not win best picture!

La La Land isn't just an immensely entertaining, uplifting, yet also poignant film, it ignited a flame inside me. Chazelle is a master behind the camera. Using many long single takes, smooth camera moves and birsk editing, he has created a stunningly beautiful film, that is both nostalgic and modern. The music is truly wonderful, catchy and emotional. The movie's many musical numbers are amazingly choreographed and performed and they enhance the story instead of detracting from it. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling act with finesse and palpable, real emotion, as Chazelle slowly brings us into their world and lets us in on their dreams. Their chemistry is infectious and there is lot of attention put in the dialog between them, in order to create a believable relationship. This is a musical of uncommon depth, that delves into to deep emotional territory. La La Land is a pure delight for anyone that loves music, movies, romance or dancing. Even more so, it's for everyone that was ever passionate about something and wanted to share and pursue that passion. It speaks to anyone that's ever looked up at the stars and dreamed.

Cinematic perfection in every frame. Gosling and Stone are career best, the story is delightful, funny, heartbreaking and life-affirming, the choreography is dazzling and the film is shit with loving nostalgia and modernity side by side.

Stunning all around: the music, the story, the acting, the colorful photography and landscape.
Damien Chazelle is a true young genius filmmaker. Truly! No doubt on the top 3 movies of 2016.

The happiness of this film is beyond measure and while by no means a thinking man's film, the beautiful color palette, electric music, and dazzling chemistry from the two leads make La La Land joy on celluloid.

I don't like musicals. But I saw the reviews so I couldn't ignore this one. I loved the tenseness of Whiplash but this is a completely different ball game. Chazelle pulls it off and more. For starters, there isn't too much siinging that you end up like "really, again?" and the songs that they do have are enthralling. You could fill the Oscar catagory for best original song from this film alone. The dance scenes were also infectious, the choreography was brilliant. As for performances, Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are superbly endearing and their chemistry is dynamite. Despite all the romance and music though, this was not at all cliche, which is huge praise. Damien Chazelle's passion for this film is seeping through every shot. The cinematography is gorgeous. I can't believe what I saw tonight. I spent the whole film looking for a flaw but I just couldn't find one. I saw one critic say "I haven't seen anyone leave this movie in a bad mood" and I must agree, the sense of euphoria when you leave this film is riveting. This is one of the best films of the year for sure. La La Land will become a feel-good classic and will probably be thought of as the best musical of all time.
